I. INTRODUCTION

In October, 1958, Mayor D’Alesandro requested the Planning Com-
mission to review its plans for the East-West Expressway to determine
if a less controversial route could be developed. In making this request
he indicated that particular attention should be given to the effect of the
Expressway upon existing residential neighborhoods.

While work on this request was still under way, Mayor D’Alesandro
was succeeded by Mayor Grady. The Planning Commission felt, however,
that the study should be completed and published, and Mayor Grady
concurred in this conclusion. This report, therefore, presents the results
of the studies which have been made by the Department of Planning and
which are endorsed by the Planning Commission.

This report not only analyzes possible routes for an East-West Ex-
pressway, but also presents the reasons why the Planning Commission
believes it should be built. Chapter IV presents the need in terms of
future traffic demands and Chapter V states the general reasons for han-
dling this demand, at least in large part, by an expressway rather than
through other types of streets or highways. In the final analysis, however,
judgment must be based upon a weighing of the advantages to be derived
from a specific route as against the cost of the same route in terms of
money, property demolition, effect on taxes, and possible detrimental
effect on adjacent areas. The final justification for an East-West Express-
way is therefore not presented until Chapter X following discussion of
possible routes.

The plans accompanying this report have been worked out in con-
siderable detail to demonstrate feasibility and to explore possibilities, but





it should be kept in mind that these are not working drawings. If the
recommendations in this report are adopted the final plans may deviate
in many details from those shown herein.

One point needs to be made concerning nomenclature. By agreement
among highway experts the term expressway is used to denote a highway
with some degree of control (not necessarily complete) over access from
abutting properties and some degree of separation (not necessarily com-
plete) at traffic crossings. The term freeway is used for expressways
having complete control over access and complete separation from other
streets and highways. The Jones Falls Expressway and the proposed
East-West Expressway are technically freeways and to be correct we
should refer to them as the “Jones Falls Freeway” and the “East-West
Freeway.” However, the term expressway (meaning freeway) is deeply
embedded in Baltimore usage (as well as in certain pieces of State and
City legislation) and, while an effort probably should be made at some
point to bring about a correction in terms, it did not seem appropriate
to do so in this report. Therefore, the material which follows continues
to refer to expressways as meaning highways having complete access con-
trol and complete separation from other streets and highways.

An effort has been made to prepare this report without extensive use
of technical terms. Nevertheless, definitions of a few terms used herein
may be helpful:

Desire Line: The path which would be followed by a vehicle if it

could proceed in a straight line from origin to destination. (Indi-
vidual desire lines between sub-areas of a larger area are often

Introduction



grouped and presented visually as bands connecting sub-areas. The
width of the band will be proportional to the number of desire lines
thus grouped. While this type of presentation distorts slightly indi-
vidual desire lines, it is helpful in comprehending desire line patterns
within a large area.)

Through Traffic: Traffic having neither origin nor destination within
a given area. As used in this report the term may relate to the
Baltimore metropolitan area, to the central business district, or to
residential neighborhoods. It is believed that the type of area re-
ferred to will, in each case, be clear from the context.

Traffic Generators: Areas within which there is a relatively high
concentration of points of traffic origin or destination.

While the Department of Planning and the Planning Commission
assume responsibility for the conclusions reached in this report, grateful
acknowledgment should be made to a number of individuals, firms, and
agencies for the invaluable assistance and advice which they have ren-
dered. A partial listing follows:

Department of Public Works
Urban Renewal and Housing Agency

Baltimore Regional Planning Council

Planning Council of the Greater Baltimore Committee
Mr. Alan M. Voorhees, Automotive Safety Foundation
Baltimore Gas & Electric Co.

Special acknowledgment should be made to Mr. Henry A. Barnes,
Commissioner of Transit and Traffic, and to Mr. James W. Booth, Jr.,
of his staff, and to Mr. Charles M. Upham, Jr., formerly of his staff. They
participated actively in much of the work and without their assistance this
report would not have been possible.

Within the Department of Planning the plans for the Harbor Route
were developed under the general supervision of Mr. John J. Lang,
Deputy Director for Planning Administration, and under the immediate
direction of Mr. Andrew J. Clarke, Jr., Principal City Planner, and Mr.
William Patschke, Senior City Planner.

SUMMARY

Anticipated traffic increases constitute one of the principal justifi-
cations for construction of an East-West Expressway through the
City. Present estimates indicate that east-west traffic will increase
by approximately 509 by 1980. Since existing east-west streets are
now operating at about capacity all of the anticipated increase should
be handled by new routes or by widenings of existing streets.

An East-West Expressway eight lanes wide would take care of 40%
to 509% of expected traffic increases over the next twenty years.
Together with other needed improvements the East-West Expressway
should absorb the increase in east-west traffic anticipated by 1980
and in addition provide some measure of relief to present traffic con-
gestion. This relief would be most pronounced during non-rush hours.

The need for an East-West Expressway is based upon local traffic and
not through traffic. East-West Expressway traffic having neither
origin nor destination within the metropolitan area is estimated to be
no more than 69 of total traffic on the expressway.

While an improved public transportation system is urgently needed,
the best feasible system would not noticeably affect the need for an
East-West Expressway.

The need for a major cross-town expressway has long been recog-
nized. Eight major proposals for such an expressway have been made
between 1942 and 1957. All of these proposals are based upon an
alignment crossing the center of the City just north of the central
business district. The last of these eight proposals was included as
part of the Planning Commission’s 1957 expressway plan. It is
referred to in this report as the Northern Route to distinguish it
from other proposed East-West Expressway alignments.

Since the first expressway proposal in 1942, all plans and studies for



handling anticipated traffic increases have placed major reliance upon
a highway system involving one or more expressways having complete
access control and complete grade separation from conflicting traffic.
Expressways have distinct advantages over other types of highways.
They are safer and they save travel time. They are inherently free
from encroachment from abutting properties and their capacity thus

endures. Expressways can serve to reduce blight and to facilitate
urban renewal through removing traffic (including truck traffic) from -

residential streets. (Other advantages and characteristics of express-
ways are di{scqssed in the body of the report.)

. While expressways have distinct advantages over other types of high-

ways they also have drawbacks and if improperly located or designed
they can act as a blighting influence on adjacent properties.

The additional traffic capacity which would result from construction
of an East-West Expressway could theoretically also be provided
through widening of existing streets. To do so, however, would
require the removal of approximately two and one-half times as many
buildings as would be razed by the East-West Expressway. The
number of families to be relocated, the loss in taxes, and the cost of
site acquisition would be in proportion. Total cost to the City would
be substantially greater.

. The health of the central business district is based primarily upon its

relative accessibility to all parts of the metropolitan area. This
relative accessibility is enhanced by an expressway system focused on
the central business district; it is diminished by the construction of
expressways not located so as to serve the central business district.
In these terms it will take at least four radial expressways leading
outwards from the center of the City to restore to the central busi-
ness district the loss in relative accessibility which will result from

10.

11.

12.

completion of the County beltway. A decision not to continue with
an expressway program clearly focused on the downtown area would
jeopardize the many efforts now being made to save the central
business district.

Failure to prepare and carry out adequate plans for the handling of
future traffic increases would have pronounced effects upon the struc-
ture and character of the City. It seems probable that such a failure
would result in increased congestion, reduced mobility, less freedom
to select jobs or home sites, a speed-up in decentralization, a greater
dispersion of many functions throughout the metropolitan area, a
lower level of cultural activities and of specialized services and busi-
nesses, and a reduced rate of economic growth.

Any route for an East-West Expressway should satisfy the following

minimum requirements:

a. It should be planned in such a way that it will be approvable for
inclusion in the National Interstate Highway System and thus be
eligible for 909 Federal grant.

b. A feasible interchange with the Jones Falls Expressway must be
possible.

c. It should provide good service to the central business district.

In judging between routes meeting the above requirements the fol-
lowing criteria are important: benefits to traffic, to the central
business district, and to the City’s economy; stimulus to new building
or to urban renewal; possible blighting effects; number and quality
of dwellings to be demolished; effect on assessed valuations; total
cost; and significant or important properties to be taken.

No small-scale improvements can be made in the present alignment
of the Northern Route.





14.

15.

16.

1.

Only one largely new route for the East-West Expressway was dis-
covered which met all of the requirements set forth in Item 11 above.
This route is referred to as the Harbor Route. It is shown in its
entirety on Sheet 7 and in detail on Sheets 8 through 12 and 23
through 28. From the western City line to Myrtle Avenue the Harbor
Route is identical to the Northern Route. After crossing Myrtle
Avenue the Harbor Route turns due south to Pratt Street, then turns
east between Pratt and Camden Streets, crosses the Municipal Piers
just south of Pratt Street, crosses under the Jones Falls Expressway
at about Pier 6, then follows approximately along the north side of
the Harbor to Boston Street. It continues on Boston Street until it
joins the Harbor Tunnel entrance road. It is proposed that the
Harbor Tunnel entrance road be widened to the point where it merges
with the proposed new Northeastern Expressway.

A desirable feature of many past expressway plans has been an inner
ring around the central business district. This inner ring could also
be provided using the Harbor Route by means of an expressway
connection running from the Harbor Route at about Myrtle Avenue
northeasterly to the Jones Falls Expressway.

Transfer of the East-West Expressway from the Northern Route to
the Harbor Route would permit a partial expressway connection
between the Jones Falls Expressway at about Eager Street and the
northeastern section of the City.

A comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route in
terms of the criteria set forth in Item 12 above indicates that the
Harbor Route is superior with respect to the following items:

a. Conformity to desire lines

b. Relief for present congestion

c. Opportunities for related traffic improvements

.

St th

To effect these recommendations the Planning Commission proposes

that:

a. An engineering study be undertaken of the Harbor Route and
the completion of the inner ring to verify structural feasibility,
to estimate costs, and to determine accurate taking lines,

b. A design team be created having staff representation from the
various public agencies and departments involved, and

c. If the report on engincering feasibility is favorable, City Council
endorsement of the East-West Expressway along the Harbor
Route be requested as soon thereafter as possible.

field_edited_text_processed:
lll. HISTORICAL BACKGROUND

Interest in improving cross-town highway facilities goes back more
than forty years. In 1917 the Chief Engineer of the Paving Commission
first proposed construction of the Orleans Street Viaduct (although the
Viaduct was not actually completed until 1935). During the 1920’s sev-
eral reports by consulting engineers emphasized the desirability of im-
proving Franklin Street as a main cross-town route.

By the early 1940’s it was evident to those who studied the problem
that the volume of cross-town traffic was becoming too large to enable
it to be handled indefinitely by improvements to existing streets and that
more drastic measures would ultimately be required. It was realized that
this traffic problem was aggravated by a heavy stream of through traffic
and that by-pass routes around Baltimore would provide some relief. It
was also recognized, however, that through traffic formed only a small
portion of total cross-town traffic and that a complete diversion of through
traffic would not eliminate the need for major in-city improvements.

The first proposal for a controlled access highway through the heart
of the City to handle cross-town traffic was made in 1942. Since then
there have been a large number of similar proposals and variations thereof.
To understand our present situation and to appraise the balance of this
report it will be helpful to know something about eight of these plans.
These eight are:

Advisory Engineers Plan
Route A

Route B

Moses Plan

Smith Plan
Transportation Study Plan
1949 Plan

1957 Plan

The first four and the sixth of these plans propose an expressway
starting in the southwest part of the City, crossing the center of the City
at Franklin Street, or a short distance north of Franklin Street, and
extending easterly to meet the City line at, or close to, Pulaski Highway.
The fifth and seventh plans are each based upon an expressway following
this same general path, but envision this expressway as part of a compre-
hensive expressway pattern for the City. The final plan also proposes an
expressway pattern, but the main crosstown route starts in the western
part of the City near Edmondson Avenue rather than in the southwest.
While the main cross-town expressway in each of the eight plans was
intended to serve similar objectives, only the last proposal has been re-
ferred to as the “East-West Expressway.”

Advisory Engineers Plan

Shortly after its creation in 1939 the Planning Commission employed
a group of outstanding local engineers to prepare a recommended program
of public improvements for the City.® This group, known as the Advisory
Engineers, consisted of Nathan L. Smith, Gustave J. Requardt, and Abel
C. Wolman, with Dr. Wolman as chairman. Its report, published in
January, 1942, included a thorough analysis and a comprehensive series of
recommendations covering all aspects of public works and improvements.

The Advisory Engineers reviewed then existing proposals for bypass
routes by means of a Fairfield-Canton harbor crossing and a new major
highway around the north of the City. They concluded that both were
necessary. (The Fairfield-Canton Harbor Tunnel has since been com-



1 From 1939 to 1947 the Planning Commission was known as the Commission
on City Plan. To avoid confusion the present title of Planning Commission is used
throughout this report.

The first four and the sixth of these plans propose an expressway
starting in the southwest part of the City, crossing the center of the City
at Franklin Street, or a short distance north of Franklin Street, and
extending easterly to meet the City line at, or close to, Pulaski Highway.
The fifth and seventh plans are each based upon an expressway following
this same general path, but envision this expressway as part of a compre-
hensive expressway pattern for the City. The final plan also proposes an
expressway pattern, but the main crosstown route starts in the western
part of the City near Edmondson Avenue rather than in the southwest.
While the main cross-town expressway in each of the eight plans was
intended to serve similar objectives, only the last proposal has been re-
ferred to as the “East-West Expressway.”

Advisory Engineers Plan

Shortly after its creation in 1939 the Planning Commission employed
a group of outstanding local engineers to prepare a recommended program
of public improvements for the City.® This group, known as the Advisory
Engineers, consisted of Nathan L. Smith, Gustave J. Requardt, and Abel
C. Wolman, with Dr. Wolman as chairman. Its report, published in
January, 1942, included a thorough analysis and a comprehensive series of
recommendations covering all aspects of public works and improvements.

The Advisory Engineers reviewed then existing proposals for bypass
routes by means of a Fairfield-Canton harbor crossing and a new major
highway around the north of the City. They concluded that both were
necessary. (The Fairfield-Canton Harbor Tunnel has since been com-



1 From 1939 to 1947 the Planning Commission was known as the Commission
on City Plan. To avoid confusion the present title of Planning Commission is used
throughout this report.

field_edited_text_processed:
Historical Background



pleted, and, in a somewhat different form, the northern bypass is now
under construction as the County Beltway.) But the Advisory Engineers
also agreed that these bypasses would not eliminate the need for a major
new cross-town facility close to the center of the City.

Two main routes, each with variations, were studied. (These are
shown on Sheet 1.) One ran along Pratt Street, the other in a tunnel
under Franklin Street. After carefully reviewing the advantages and
disadvantages of each route the Advisory Engineers decided that the
Franklin Street route was preferable, primarily because it came closer to
certain important downtown functions, such as the retail trade center,
and also because the tunnel would eliminate the time-consuming step of
property acquisition near the center of the City and thus allow the project
to be completed earlier. i

The entire route finally recommended by the Advisory Engineers
comes into the City from the east at Pulaski Highway, follows along
Orleans Street, uses the present Orleans Street Viaduct, tunnels under
Franklin Street as far as Paca Street, continues as a depressed expressway
between Mulberry and Franklin Street to the Pennsylvania Railroad a
few blocks west of Monroe Street, follows generally the line of the Rail-
road to the southwest, and terminates at Wilkens Avenue. It generally
approximates Route A as shown on Sheet 2.

Route A

In early 1943 the Master Plan Committee of the Planning Commis-
sion prepared two alternative proposals for controlled access highways
across the City. These were known as Route A and Route B. Route A
was virtually identical to the Advisory Engineers’ proposal except for
these differences:

a) It was felt that a tunnel under Franklin Street could not accom-



modate an adequate number of lanes, and a depressed route along
Centre Street one block to the north was substituted.

b) In lieu of using the Orleans Street Viaduct a new viaduct a short
distance to the north was proposed.

¢) The route ran to the southwestern city line instead of terminating
at Wilkens Avenue.

Route A is shown on Sheet 2.

Route B

This proposal was developed by the Master Plan Committee con-
currently with Route A. It is also shown on Sheet 2.

Routes A and B cross in the block bounded by Mulberry Street,
Franklin Street, Pine Street and Myrtle Avenue. (The main cross-town
routes in all eight plans pass through this block.) To the east of this
block Route B is somewhat to the north of Route A; to the west Route B
is considerably to the south.

From the east, Route B enters the City above Pulaski Highway,
crosses the north side of Armistead Gardens, runs along Federal Street
and then along Hoffman Street, crosses the Fallsway just north of Biddle
Street, generally follows Biddle Street through the center of town to the
Mulberry-Franklin-Pine-Myrtle block, drops almost due south along the
line of Fremont Avenue and Scott Street as far as the B&O Railroad, and
then follows the B&O Railroad to the southwestern City line.

On March 30, 1944, the Planning Commission, after considering both
Route A and Route B, officially approved Route A and recommended to
the Mayor that the City take the necessary steps to construct this
expressway.

Historical Background



Moses Plan

In response to the Planning Commission’s recommendation of Route
A, the Mayor appointed a special traffic committee, headed by Mr. E.
Asbury Davis, to study the matter. This in turn led to the employment
by the City of Mr. Robert Moses and a group of special consultants
associated with Mr. Moses in his various New York activities. The Moses
group prepared a report, dated October, 1944, recommending the con-
struction of an expressway through the center of the City. The Moses
Plan is simple to describe. It was virtually identical to Route A.

Smith Plan

The background of the Smith Plan is somewhat involved. In January
of 1943 Mayor Jackson, anticipating the need for large expenditures for
highways in the post-war period, initiated action to secure approval of a
bond issue for this purpose. As a result the General Assembly, early in
1944, authorized the issuance of a $20,000,000 bond issue for major
highway purposes. The specific projects to be covered were not spelled
out but it was generally held that a cross-town expressway would be the
most important project involved. Ten Million Dollars of this authoriza-
tion was placed on the ballot in the fall of 1944 and approved by the
voters. More or less concurrently the Federal Highway Act of 1944 was
adopted. This Act made Federal funds available on a matching basis
which could have been used for the cross-town expressway. A request by
the City to the State to appropriate the necessary matching funds was
rejected by the General Assembly early in 1945. It would appear that the
publicity attending the issuance of the Moses Report in October of 1944
crystallized objections to this route on the part of affected property
owners and that this opposition was reflected in the General Assembly’s
disapproval. It was also believed, however, that the absence of an
accepted comprehensive plan for major highways within the City was a
factor in .the General Assembly’s disapproval and accordingly Mayor

McKeldin requested Mr. Nathan L. Smith, then the City’s Chief Engi-
neer, to prepare a complete report on this subject.

Mr. Smith’s report, released in May, 1945, has historic interest pri-
marily because it represents the first effort to develop an expressway
pattern for the City. (See Sheet 3). It is also the first plan based upon
an inner ring around the central business district. The east side of this
inner ring consists of an elevated expressway along the Fallsway which,
north of the Pennsylvania Railroad, runs along Barclay Street and then
turns towards the northeast along Loch Raven Road. This proposal was
adapted from a recommendation of the Advisory Engineers.

The main cross-town route in the Smith Plan substantially follows
Route B from the eastern City line to the Fallsway, jogs south on the
elevated structure, runs west along Route A to the Mulberry-Franklin-
Pine-Myrtle block (thus forming the northern segment of the inner
ring), continues due south to Pratt Street (forming the western side of
the inner ring), and continues generally southerly along Russell Street.
The route was designed to tie in with the new Washington-Baltimore
Expressway, then in a planning stage.

The south side of the inner ring consists of an elevated expressway
along Pratt Street.

A year after the Smith report the City Council authorized the ex-
penditure of $350,000 for preliminary plans for an expressway through
the City following the Smith route. Despite this approval, several subse-
quent attempts to obtain authorization for the preparation of final plans
for the first sections of this route in the southwest part of the City (so as
to receive the new Washington-Baltimore Expressway) were rejected by
the Council. It was not until the City administration in 1949 gave assur-
ances that it would make no further attempt to push the entire Smith
route that the Council relented and granted the approval that led to the

s

construction of the Russell Street viaduct and its connection to the

Transportation Study Plan

A comprehensive analysis of existing traffic conditions in the Balti-
more metropolitan area was initiated in 1945 by the State Roads Com-
mission in cooperation with the City of Baltimore and the U. S. Public
Roads Administration. This study, officially identified as the Transpor-
tation Study—Baltimore Metropolitan Area, included the most extensive
origin and destination analysis thus far undertaken in the Baltimore area.
William F. Childs, Jr., then Director of the Traffic Division, State Roads
Commission, served as Director of the Study, and the report issued in
October, 1946, is sometimes referred to as the Childs Report.

The Transportation Study Report presented three possible routes for
a cross-town freeway and then analyzed each of these routes from the
standpoint of their ability to serve traffic needs. All three routes coincide
from the southwest City boundary to St. Paul Street and for this stretch
roughly approximate the main cross-town route included in the Smith
Plan. From St. Paul Street to the eastern City boundary the northerly
route also approximates the Smith Plan; the middle route approximates
Route A as previously described; and the southern route, referred to in
the Transportation Study Report as Route C, is a wholly new alignment
running between Bank and Gough Streets. All three routes are shown
on Sheet 4.

The report concludes that “Route C on the basis of the data obtained
and presented serves the needs of the study area as expressed by the
desires of the motorists better than [the other two routes].” Despite this
conclusion it appears that no further consideration was ever given to
Route C.

1949 Plan

In 1949 the Planning Commission published A Tentative Master
Transportation Plan, outlining proposals for a complete system of express-
ways within the City including a cross-town expressway. (See Sheet 5).
The western and central legs of the cross-town expressway are identical
to the Smith proposals. The east leg crosses the Fallsway at the same
point as Route A but then follows a wholly new route approximating
Eager Street. This leg joins the Pulaski Highway at about Erdman Ave-
nue. It will be seen that this eastern leg lies midway between Route A
and Route B.

The 1949 Plan is based upon an inner ring similar to that proposed
by Smith. The eastern side of this inner ring is again an elevated struc-
ture over the Fallsway, but instead of continuing north along Barclay
Street to serve the northeast it swings around to the northwest and runs
up the Jones Falls Valley. This route has, of course, become the Jones
Falls Expressway.

While the 1949 Plan assumes that the main cross-town traffic flow
would come in from the southwest via the Russell Street route, it adds a
depressed expressway running from the inner ring due west between Mul-
berry and Franklin Streets to the Pennsylvania Railroad at which point
it merges with Edmondson Avenue. This proposal is referred to in the
Plan as the West Radial. It will be seen that it is identical to a portion
of the main cross-town route proposed by the Advisory Engineers and also
included as part of Route A and of the Moses Plan.

1957 Plan

After 1949 a number of developments occurred affecting expressway
plans, and corresponding revisions were worked out by the Planning Com-
mission and embodied at various times in the Master Plan. The last such
change was made on December 18, 1957, and the expressway pattern as

change was made on December 18, 1957, and the expressway pattern as

e



it then stood is shown on Sheet 6 and is referred to herein as the 1957
Plan. This plan is the end product of an extended evolutionary process
rather than the result of a single effort to overhaul the 1949 pattern.

The principal developments since 1949 and the resulting changes are
briefly these:

1. The Jones Falls Expressway, proposed in the 1949 Plan, found
immediate favor and a $10,000,000 bond issue to start this ex-
pressway was approved by the voters in 1951. As detailed plans
were developed it became evident that the only feasible location
for an interchange between the Jones Falls Expressway and the
cross-town expressway was at Chase Street several blocks north
of the interchange proposed in the 1949 Plan. As a result a
revised route for the cross-town expressway had to be worked out
all the way from the Mulberry-Franklin-Pine-Myrtle block to
the eastern City line. The new route, approved by the Commis-
sion in 1953, bears a very rough resemblance to the original Route
B. It is referred to in subsequent chapters of this report as the
Northern Route and is shown in detail on Sheets 13 through 19.
(The interchange with the Jones Falls Expressway shown on
Sheet 14 was worked out in the summer of 1957. While never
officially approved by the Commission it was generally regarded
as superior to the 1953 version.)

2. The Federal Interstate Highway Act providing for 909 Federal
financing for a national network of some 40,000 miles of express-
ways was approved by Congress in 1954. In September of 1955
the U. S. Bureau of Public Roads approved on a schematic basis
those portions of the network falling within metropolitan areas.
The approved schematic pattern for Baltimore is shown in Fig. 1.
It includes a beltway around the City, a north-south route

through the City, and an east-west route through the City. The
two City routes meet near the center of the City.

. Prior to passage of the Interstate Highway Act the proposed

expressway system could have been carried out only over a very
long period of years. With the 909 Federal financing provided
by the Act it suddenly became possible to visualize the construc-
tion of the main elements of a system within the foreseeable
future. This required, however, that the system be revamped to
conform to the approved Federal pattern. Two principal changes
were made in the 1949 Plan to bring about this conformity.

a) The West Radial in the 1949 Plan was extended to the western
City line via Leakin Park at which point it joins a proposed
expressway which would lead to Frederick. This extended
West Radial, plus the northern segment of the inner ring and
the East Radial, was now considered to represent the main
stream of cross-town traffic. Thus was born the present East-
West Expressway. It has little justification from the stand-
point of through traffic (there obviously being only a small
amount of Philadelphia-Frederick traffic) but makes a lot of
sense in terms of local traffic.

b) To provide the north-south route in the Federal plan the
Jones Falls Expressway was extended over the Inner Harbor
and then continued in a southwesterly direction to tie in at
the City line with a wholly new expressway to Washington.
This extension of the Jones Falls Expressway is referred to
as the Southwest Expressway. (The Master plan presently con-
tains two alternate routes for the Southwest Expressway. Sheet
6 only shows Alternate 2. Alternate 1 is not shown since it is
regarded as an unlikely possibility. As a matter of fact, neither

11

alternate is as helpful in handling local traffic as would be a
radial running more directly south in the direction of Glen
Burnie. The Planning Commission hopes that it can reopen
this question with the State Roads Commission at a later date.
If a relocation can be worked out it would not affect the recom-
mendations contained in this report.)

4. Creation of the East-West Expressway transferred the main
traffic flow to the west rather than to the southwest, but it was
still deemed advisable to retain the connection between the
Mulberry-Franklin-Pine-Myrtle block and the Russell Street via-
duct, both to provide the western segment of the inner ring and
as a means of tying the present Washington-Baltimore Express-
way in with the City’s expressway system. This connection was
not, however, part of the Interstate System.

5. The connection referred to in Item 4 above comes within a few
blocks of the Southwest Expressway. An expressway link across
these blocks was therefore added to the Plan thus providing a
southern closure of the inner ring some six to eight blocks south
of Pratt Street. The Pratt Street Expressway was then removed
from the Plan.

Events Since 1957

By the fall of 1957 design of the Jones Falls Expressway had pro-
ceeded to the point where it became desirable to have some agreement
with the State and the Federal Government on details of the interchange
between the Jones Falls Expressway and the East-West Expressway. It
was felt at the time that a complete interchange was essential permitting
all eight movements without resort to surface streets. The Department

If a relocation can be worked out it would not affect the recom-
mendations contained in this report.)

4. Creation of the East-West Expressway transferred the main
traffic flow to the west rather than to the southwest, but it was
still deemed advisable to retain the connection between the
Mulberry-Franklin-Pine-Myrtle block and the Russell Street via-
duct, both to provide the western segment of the inner ring and
as a means of tying the present Washington-Baltimore Express-
way in with the City’s expressway system. This connection was
not, however, part of the Interstate System.

5. The connection referred to in Item 4 above comes within a few
blocks of the Southwest Expressway. An expressway link across
these blocks was therefore added to the Plan thus providing a
southern closure of the inner ring some six to eight blocks south
of Pratt Street. The Pratt Street Expressway was then removed
from the Plan.

Events Since 1957

By the fall of 1957 design of the Jones Falls Expressway had pro-
ceeded to the point where it became desirable to have some agreement
with the State and the Federal Government on details of the interchange
between the Jones Falls Expressway and the East-West Expressway. It
was felt at the time that a complete interchange was essential permitting
all eight movements without resort to surface streets. The Department

field_edited_text_processed:
Historical Background



of Planning had worked out several such interchange designs based upon
the East-West Expressway being depressed through the Mt. Vernon area.
The design generally regarded as the best was developed in the summer
of 1957 and is shown on Sheet 14. Federal officials viewed this design
unfavorably, however, holding that it was excessively costly and cumber-
some. A series of informal conferences was held with Federal officials in
the course of which many trial designs were developed and discarded.
Finally, a suggestion was made that a successful design might be possible
if the East-West Expressway approached the intersection from the west
as a double-decked elevated structure. The suggestion was fruitful in that
it did permit a complete intersection to be worked out which overcame
previous Federal objections, but it had the unfortunate corollary of
requiring the East-West Expressway to be elevated and double-decked
from Myrtle Avenue to the Jones Falls Expressway. The Planning Com-
mission was unhappy over this situation, but it appeared that no other
solution was feasible. Upon advice from the Department of Public Works
that a decision was necessary to avoid delay in the design of the Jones
Falls Expressway, the Planning Commission reluctantly approved the pro-
posed interchange design, informally in January of 1958, and formally
in May.

Four months later, on September 17, 1958, the Planning Commission
decided to reconsider this decision and instructed its staff to restudy the
interchange problem in the hope that a feasible scheme could be developed
that would allow the East-West Expressway to be depressed through the
Mt. Vernon area. The Commission’s reconsideration was a result of
several developments. In the first place, it became apparent that the need
for a decision on the interchange was not as urgent as it had previously
appeared. Next, further studies by the Department of Transit and Traffic
indicated that some of the interchange movements were less important



12

than had been assumed. And, finally, the original decision had precipi-
tated strong adverse public reaction.

Shortly after the Commission’s decision to reconsider, Mr. Robert O.
Bonnell, then chairman of the State Roads Commission, acting on a
suggestion from the U. S. Bureau of Public Roads, organized a committee
made up of various City, State and Federal officials. This committee,
generally referred to as the Bonnell Committee, was intended to serve as
a means for thrashing out differences of opinion on the expressway pro-
gram and for reaching agreements among all of the officials concerned.
While it was in existence the committee did resolve some unsettled points
in the design of the Jones Falls Expressway, but it was less successful on
reaching agreements on the East-West Expressway.

With respect to the interchange between the two expressways the
committee reviewed the latest traffic analysis figures prepared by Mr.
Henry A. Barnes, Commissioner of Transit and Traffic, and concluded
that four of the movements were of fundamental importance and must be
covered by the design. The four movements were from the north to the
east and reverse, and from the east to the south and reverse. It was also
agreed that two movements, from the west to the south and reverse, were
of such negligible importance that they could be forgotten. The remaining
two movements, from the north to the west and reverse, were of inter-
mediate importance and occasioned considerable discussion. Mr. Bonnell
suggested that the City explore the possibility of handling these move-
ments through surface streets, improving or widening them if necessary.
In accordance with this suggestion Mr. Barnes developed a proposal which
is shown on Sheet 20. Under this scheme, southbound traffic desiring to
go west on the East-West Expressway would leave the Jones Falls Ex-
pressway at the North Avenue interchange and proceed along Mt. Royal
Terrace and Cathedral Street to a connection with the East-West Ex-

pressway. Eastbound traffic on the East-West Expressway desiring to go
north on the Jones Falls Expressway would follow the reverse path. No
new construction would be necessary north of Cathedral Street (except
that additional traffic on Mt. Royal Terrace between Cathedral Street and
North Avenue might require a widening of the paved area through a
reduction of the median strip) but Cathedral Street would be widened
to the west by taking the property now occupied by the Deutsches House
as well as some land now being cleared as part of the Mt. Royal Plaza.
In addition, a few other properties would be acquired in order to effect the
necessary connection between Cathedral Street and the East-West Ex-
pressway. Cathedral Street would terminate at this connection. Surface
traffic desiring to go further south would be handled by Maryland Avenue.

This proposal does not meet Federal Interstate Highway Standards
and would not therefore be eligible for 90% Federal subsidy. (It would
probably be eligible for 509 Federal subsidy under the so-called Urban
Program.) With respect to the interchange between the Jones Falls
Expressway and the East-West Expressway there would be no reduction
in property takings in the Mt. Vernon area. The proposal does permit a
simplified interchange to be designed as shown on Sheet 20.

Officials of the State Roads Commission indicated that it would be
acceptable to them for the City to use this simplified intersection plan as a
basis for proceeding with the Jones Falls Expressway and Mr. George
Carter, then Director of Public Works, instructed the design engineers to
go ahead accordingly. He informed them, however, to incorporate in their
plans only those provisions for the interchange which were absolutely
essential so that if the East-West Expressway were never built, or if it
were built in some other location, no unsightly stubs for ramps would be
left dangling into space.

13

All the events described above from the beginning of 1958 took place
as a result of efforts to get on with the design of the Jones Falls Express-
way. Nevertheless this required that considerable attention be devoted
to the East-West Expressway and the resulting public controversy led
Mayor D’Alesandro in September of 1958 to request the Department of
Planning and the Planning Commission to make a further study of the
Expressway route. The Mayor concluded his request by asking “. . ..
that due consideration be given to the preservation of neighborhoods and
the development of needed facilities for moving people, particularly the
people of the Baltimore metropolitan area.” This report is the result of
this request.

IR EER!
IV. TRAFFIC NEEDS

Traffic Growth

The customary basis for highway planning is an origin and desti-
nation survey. In the past such surveys have usually been carried out
through a combination of home interviews and interviews with the drivers
of cars stopped at selected points. For a metropolitan area as large as
Baltimore’s such a survey is expensive and time consuming. One was con-
ducted jointly by the City and the State in 1945-46 (Transportation
Study, Baltimore Metropolitan Area, see Chapter 1II), but there has been
no comprehensive interview-type origin and destination survey since.

Within the last few years a new, simpler, and less expensive technique
for developing origin and destination information has been worked out.
It is based on the discovery that while the behavior of any one motorist
is unpredictable the actions of large groups can be predicted with reason-
able accuracy, provided there is available certain information on land use
and on the distribution of population and of employment. With this
information one can estimate present traffic volumes, and if the basic data
is projected into the future one can predict future traffic volumes. This
new approach is generally referred to as the gravity model technique since
it postulates that certain areas attract traffic from other areas in a manner
somewhat similar to the laws governing gravity.

This new technique served as the basis for a new set of metropolitan
area traffic predictions made by the Baltimore Regional Planning Council.
Most of the actual work was done by the Department of Transit and
Traffic with the assistance of Mr. Alan M. Voorhees of the Automotive
Safety Foundation. Mr. Voorhees is a noted planning and traffic authority
who has played a leading role in the development and application of the
gravity model technique. The results of these studies and a more detailed
description of the techniques employed is set forth in a recent publication
of the Regional Planning Council entitled Freeway Plan.

With respect to east-west travel across the City, the Regional Plan-

14

ning Council drew what was referred to as a screen line along the path
of the Jones Falls Valley extending northward from the inner harbor to
the outer edge of the developed area. Based upon information on existing
land use, population distribution, and employment distribution, it was -
estimated, using the gravity model approach, that the present peak-hour
traffic crossing this screen line was 40,300 vehicles. To check the accuracy
of this estimate the Department of Transit and Traffic then made an
actual count which totaled 40,100.

The same techniques were then applied to the future and it was esti-
mated that by 1980, 60,000 vehicles would cross the Jones Falls screen
line during a peak hour. The increase in peak-hour traffic moving in an
east-west direction across the developed sections of the City and the
County from Pratt Street north is thus anticipated by 1980 to be 20,000
vehicles.

Since the present east-west streets and highways are operating at
about capacity (in many cases they are overloaded) all of this estimated
increase would have to be handled by new routes or by widenings of exist-
ing streets. If it is assumed (a) that future traffic increases would be™
equally divided between east movements and west movements, (b) that
all of the traffic increases would be handled by expressways, and (c¢) that
one expressway lane can handle about 1,500 vehicles per hour, then ap-
proximately 14 new expressway lanes would be required to carry future .
east-west traffic.

In practice, however, 14 lanes would not be enough. East-west move-
ments will not be evenly balanced and it would be highly desirable to
provide some additional capacity to alleviate present congestion on exist-
ing east-west streets. In the judgment of the Regional Planning Council |
20 east-west expressway lanes, or their equivalent, should be provided.
by 1980.

by 1980.

g o o

Traffic Needs

g U d d d e

O M M M M M M M A MY o g W W



Completion of the County Beltway will take care of four lanes. Con-
struction of the East-West Expressway, either as presently planned or
in an alternative location, would provide another eight. New or improved
surface streets (such as Northern Parkway) can be counted as the
equivalent of two expressway lanes, and it is believed by the Regional
Planning Council that improvements in public transportation may perhaps
account for the equivalent of two more. All of these measures add up to
16 lanes (or equivalent) leaving a deficit of four. Theoretically this deficit
should be covered by the construction of a further east-west expressway
at about Cold Spring Lane. The Regional Planning Council’s report
leaves the subject at this point, but it was Mr. Voorhees’ personal con-
clusion, concurred in by the Department of Planning, that the present
figures and estimates are not sufficiently conclusive to warrant preparing
definite plans for such an expressway at this time and that judgment as
to its need should be reserved for the time being.

From the above figures it is clear that the presently planned East-
West Expressway will be needed to take care of 409% to 50% of the
expected increase in traffic over the next twenty years. Or looked at in
another way, the anticipated increase in east-west traffic across the metro-
politan area north of the inner harbor will be more than twice the capacity
of the proposed East-West Expressway.

These conclusions hinge on the accuracy of the prediction that east-
west traffic will increase by approximately 50% by 1980. This prediction
in turn is the end-product of a series of mathematical computations
which can be appraised only by experts in this field. We do know that
the technique, when applied to existing traffic, checked out with good
accuracy. Can we be equally confident of future predictions?

Let us first of all look at the predictions from the standpoint of
general reasonability. The Regional Planning Council estimates that

15

population of the area will increase by 509% by 1980. This is approxi-
mately the same rate of growth which has prevailed since 1940. The
Council then estimates that vehicular registration will increase by 90%
by 1980. In view of the fact that registrations increased by 50% in the
eight-year period between 1950 and 1958, a 909% increase within 22 years
would seem, if anything, to be conservative. Next the Council predicts
that total mileage traveled within the area will increase by 70% by 1980.
Since this is less than the increase in vehicles it can only mean that the
average mileage per vehicle will be less than it is at present. Again this
forecast seems conservative.

Against this background the prediction of a 509 increase in east-
west travel by 1980 certainly does not seem unreasonably high. Further-
more, even if this figure were in error by a considerable margin, there
would still be ample justification for an East-West Expressway based
upon traffic growth.

Through Traffic vs. Local Traffic

Questions have been raised as to the need or desirability of building
an East-West Expressway through the center of the City based upon the
belief that the traffic it will carry will be largely through traffic having
neither origin nor destination in the Baltimore Metropolitan Area. It has
been felt that handling this type of traffic hardly justified the demolition,
the cost, and all of the other problems involved in creating an expressway
through the heart of the City. Through traffic, it is held, is not funda-
mentally the City’s problem and should be diverted either to the Harbor
Tunnel or the Beltway, or, if these are insufficient, to another bypass
route located at a considerable distance from the center of Baltimore.

It is not difficult to see how these questions have arisen. For many
years prior to the construction of the Harbor Tunnel there has been a

years prior to the construction of the Harbor Tunnel there has been a

field_edited_text_processed:
Traffic Needs

O o o dd e dedgddaddd



heavy flow of through traffic across Baltimore, mainly along Route 1 in
the southwest and Route 40 through the center of the City and to the
east. It was easy to assume that through traffic constituted the bulk of
all traffic along these routes and that this would also be the case for any
expressway generally following this path.

This assumption was never correct. Every analysis has consistently
shown that through traffic was only a small fraction of total traffic. While
most past proposals for cross-town expressways have followed the Route 1-
Route 40 path, the reports accompanying these proposals have stated
that the great bulk of anticipated traffic would be local, and it has been
the volume of this local traffic which has been pointed to as the justifi-
cation for the proposals.

The most thorough analysis of through traffic on the City’s proposed
expressway system was prepared by the State Roads Commission in 1957.
This study showed that through traffic on the East-West Expressway
would range from 4% on the western leg to 6% on the eastern leg. No
estimate was prepared of the total number of through vehicles which
would travel the entire length of the East-West Expressway, but it is
possible to deduce from the study that this number would be substantially
less than 1,900 per day.

These results are in no way surprising. Studies and analyses in cities
all over the country have uniformly demonstrated that of the traffic com-
ing into a large urban area on any one major highway only a small
percentage is through traffic. The American Association of State Highway
Officials states that for cities of 500,000 to 1,000,000 this percentage is
usually about 8%. (The percentage tends to increase for smaller cities.
For cities in the 50,000 to 100,000 class it would be about 19%.)

The most certain fact about the East-West Expressway is that, if
built, it will be mainly utilized by traffic having origin and/or destination

16

in the Baltimore metropolitan area.

Effect of Transit Improvements i
Can improvement of our present public transportation system, or

development of some new form of rapid transit, minimize or eliminate the

need for additional freeways? Everyone would like to think so, but the

facts do not appear to be favorable.

Mass transportation is obviously a more efficient means of moving
people than private automobiles. A loaded bus occupies much less street
space than the number of cars which would transport the same number
of people. Rapid transit operating on rail lines takes no street space at
all. Furthermore, mass transportation eliminates the need for parking
spaces at destination points.

The fact remains that mass transit is not realizing these potentialities™

in Baltimore or in most other large cities. Since World War II there has
been a consistent pattern of declining patronage, deteriorating service,



Y
Y

i
A

!

and higher fares. The growing gap between possibility and performance |

plus increasing dependence upon the private automobile with all the
ensuing problems of congestion, need for expensive new traffic facilities,
etc., have focused attention upon the mass transportation problem.
Within the past few years a number of studies have been made of mass
transportation in the Baltimore area, notably the 1955 report of the
Commission on Mass Transportation (the Committee was appointed by
the Mayor and was headed by Dr. Abel Wolman), a report in three parts
issued by Mr. Henry A. Barnes, Commissioner of Transit and Traffic, in
1958, and an unpublished study prepared under the auspices of the
Regional Planning Council. All three of these reports emphasize the need
for improving mass transit and all are basically sympathetic to an en-
hanced position for mass transit in our overall transportation picture.

heavy flow of through traffic across Baltimore, mainly along Route 1 in
the southwest and Route 40 through the center of the City and to the
east. It was easy to assume that through traffic constituted the bulk of
all traffic along these routes and that this would also be the case for any
expressway generally following this path.

This assumption was never correct. Every analysis has consistently
shown that through traffic was only a small fraction of total traffic. While
most past proposals for cross-town expressways have followed the Route 1-
Route 40 path, the reports accompanying these proposals have stated
that the great bulk of anticipated traffic would be local, and it has been
the volume of this local traffic which has been pointed to as the justifi-
cation for the proposals.

The most thorough analysis of through traffic on the City’s proposed
expressway system was prepared by the State Roads Commission in 1957.
This study showed that through traffic on the East-West Expressway
would range from 4% on the western leg to 6% on the eastern leg. No
estimate was prepared of the total number of through vehicles which
would travel the entire length of the East-West Expressway, but it is
possible to deduce from the study that this number would be substantially
less than 1,900 per day.

These results are in no way surprising. Studies and analyses in cities
all over the country have uniformly demonstrated that of the traffic com-
ing into a large urban area on any one major highway only a small
percentage is through traffic. The American Association of State Highway
Officials states that for cities of 500,000 to 1,000,000 this percentage is
usually about 8%. (The percentage tends to increase for smaller cities.
For cities in the 50,000 to 100,000 class it would be about 19%.)

The most certain fact about the East-West Expressway is that, if
built, it will be mainly utilized by traffic having origin and/or destination

16

in the Baltimore metropolitan area.

Effect of Transit Improvements i
Can improvement of our present public transportation system, or

development of some new form of rapid transit, minimize or eliminate the

need for additional freeways? Everyone would like to think so, but the

facts do not appear to be favorable.

Mass transportation is obviously a more efficient means of moving
people than private automobiles. A loaded bus occupies much less street
space than the number of cars which would transport the same number
of people. Rapid transit operating on rail lines takes no street space at
all. Furthermore, mass transportation eliminates the need for parking
spaces at destination points.

The fact remains that mass transit is not realizing these potentialities™

in Baltimore or in most other large cities. Since World War II there has
been a consistent pattern of declining patronage, deteriorating service,



Y
Y

i
A

!

and higher fares. The growing gap between possibility and performance |

plus increasing dependence upon the private automobile with all the
ensuing problems of congestion, need for expensive new traffic facilities,
etc., have focused attention upon the mass transportation problem.
Within the past few years a number of studies have been made of mass
transportation in the Baltimore area, notably the 1955 report of the
Commission on Mass Transportation (the Committee was appointed by
the Mayor and was headed by Dr. Abel Wolman), a report in three parts
issued by Mr. Henry A. Barnes, Commissioner of Transit and Traffic, in
1958, and an unpublished study prepared under the auspices of the
Regional Planning Council. All three of these reports emphasize the need
for improving mass transit and all are basically sympathetic to an en-
hanced position for mass transit in our overall transportation picture.

field_edited_text_processed:
!\

Traffic Needs



The following points are made by one or more of these reports:
1. All reports agree that a subway system is not feasible for Balti-

more. The report of the Committee on Mass Transportation
summarizes this common viewpoint as follows: ‘“Baltimore is far
from an ideal city for the building of subways in which trains of
cars are operated on fixed ballasted rails. The streets are quite
narrow; there are a number of hills, which would call for deep
subway tunnels and long steps, escalators or elevators for reaching
the ground surface; much rock would be encountered in the north-
ern and northwestern areas of the City, and the spokes-of-a-wheel
passenger movement pattern make it difficult to contemplate that
subways costing $250,000,000 or more are economically, politically
or physically justified when comparison is made with other types
of rapid transit which may be available.”

. All reports agree that with respect to monorails many engineering

problems remain to be solved and that no present reliance can be
placed upon this system. The Committee on Mass Transportation
adds this comment: ‘“The prospect of such overhead construction
in our Baltimore streets, approaching as it will an elevated rail
system in the amount of light and air intercepted and the amount
of noise emitted is not a happy one.”

. The Committee on Mass Transportation suggests that existing

railroad lines might be converted to rapid transit use. Mr. Barnes
feels that this proposal is not feasible, in part because of sparse
development along these rights-of-way and in part because com-
muters would have to be brought to the railroad lines by bus or
by auto. Such “divided trips” would, he feels, discourage patron-
age. The Regional Planning Council study endeavors to explore
in some detail the possibility of utilizing existing rail lines for

17

rapid transit purposes. It suggests that three rail rapid transit
lines could extend out from the center of the City to the north-
east, the north, and the northwest. A southern terminal is pro-
posed at Charles Center by means of a tunnel from the Calvert
Street Station. An analysis was made of the population in the
districts served, the extent to which this population might be
employed in the central business district, and the extent to which
the proposed lines might be utilized. It is estimated that trip-to-
work patronage in 1980 might total 15,000, of which, however,
only 10,000 would represent a shift from private automobiles.
The remaining 5,000 would, in the absence of the proposed rapid
transit, be using buses.

All discussion of rail rapid transit is based upon a system designed
to service downtown and which would be only of incidental benefit
to other employment areas. While the reports do not so state,
this emphasis on downtown clearly stems from the fact that there
are no other traffic generators in the metropolitan area, now or
foreseeable, of sufficient size, compactness, or ability to develop
non-rush hour traffic to support any type of rail rapid transit
system without exorbitant subsidy.

With respect to buses the Committee on Mass Transportation
states that: ‘“Mass transportation free-wheel buses (not trackless
trolleys or rail facilities under any circumstances) must have free
access on, along and off such [expressways]. Once on the [ex-
pressway] such buses shall maintain the speed of other vehicles
until they reach their point of exit. Good entry and egress, of
course, must be provided for the buses and other free-wheeled
vehicles.” Mr. Barnes in his reports carries this viewpoint one
step further by stating that express buses qtilizing expressways

Traffic Needs



wherever feasible should form the backbone of Baltimore’s rapid
transit system. The method visualized by Mr. Barnes would
involve the collection of a load on special busways connecting to
the expressways. Some intermediate stops might be made by
using access ramps for a brief return to surface streets. Bus stops
on a high speed expressway are not generally feasible since they
require long acceleration and deceleration lanes. After making
provision for necessary access ramps there are usually few
stretches of urban expressways long enough for these lanes and
even fewer will be located at the right places.

The facts and judgments noted above would appear to produce the
following conclusions:

1. Insofar as we may be hoping to improve our mass transit system
through reliance on express buses, an expressway system is as
desirable or essential to the public transportation system as it is
to private vehicular transportation.

2. If we are thinking in terms of a rail system it can only be in
relationship to serving the central business district.

Let us now explore the second of these conclusions in greater detail.
The purpose of a rail system oriented to serve the central business district
would be, of course, to induce car riders to transfer to rapid transit and
thus reduce the number of cars coming into the central business district.
Since traffic congestion is most acute during rush hours, the problem can
be further narrowed to a consideration of the potential reduction in the
number of cars bringing workers to employment in the central business
district.

Some indication of the range of this potential reduction can be ob-
tained through three separate approaches:

1. A survey conducted by the Planning Council in 1958 indicates

18

that 539 of central business district employees travel to work by
public transportation. How high might this percentage be, given
sufficient improvement of our public transportation system? The
Planning Council, in its Plan for the Central Business District of
Baltimore, has expressed its judgment, based on a survey of other
cities, that at very most this percentage could only be increased
to 689%. The difference of 15% applied against total central
business district employment of 96,000 represents 14,500 persons.
Assuming 115 persons per car the conversion of 14,500 persons
from car to rapid transit would reduce the total number of cars

coming into the central business district during rush hours by

about 10,000.

. The Planning Council survey mentioned above also provides a

different approach to the question. This survey indicated that of
the 96,000 persons employed in the central business district, about
one-quarter, or approximately 24,000, drive cars to work. Of this
number about one-half indicate that they need their cars during
the day for business reasons, or use them for various auxiliary
purposes during the trip to or from work. It is unlikely that this
group could be converted to public transportation regardless of
improvements made. This leaves approximately 12,000 drivers
who theoretically might be converted. If all were converted the
reduction in cars coming into the central business district for
employment purposes would be 12,000.

. The unpublished report prepared for the Regional Planning Coun-

cil referred to earlier contains an estimate of potential passengers
on its suggested rail system based upon a detailed analysis of the
area served by this system. This analysis indicates that by 1980
the system would be carrying 10,000 persons to work who, in the

absence of the rail system, would be traveling by automobile.
This many persons would be traveling in about 7,000 cars.

We thus have varying estimates of a potential reduction of cars
coming into the central business district for employment purposes of
12,000, 10,000 and 7,000.

The first two figures are in the nature of theoretical maximums and
as a practical matter are obviously too high. The third is undoubtedly
more realistic, but even this estimate may be optimistic. Since it is based
upon 1980 population figures it certainly overstates present possibilities.
Nevertheless, let us accept this figure for the purpose of discussion. As-
suming an average round trip of 20 miles per day 7,000 cars would
generate 140,000 vehicle miles per day. This compares with 12,000,000
vehicle miles per day now being traveled in the Baltimore metropolitan
area and 20,000,000 vehicle miles per day predicted by 1980. Evidently

v ,+the elimination of 7,000 cars will not seriously alter the traffic problem.

Furthermore, the greatest concentration of homes of downtown employees
is to the north, and since the 7,000 car estimate is based upon a possible
rail system extending only in a northerly direction from the central busi-
ness district, the car travel which such a rail system might eliminate
would be north-south traffic. The east-west traffic which serves as one of
the main justifications for the Kast-West Expressway would hardly be
affected.

None of these points should be taken as meaning that there is no
need to establish a much improved and more comprehensive system of
public transportation. For one thing, the basic strength of the central
business district is in its accessibility to all parts of the metropolitan area.
This means accessibility in terms of all types of transportation—not just
automobile transportation. An improvement in public transportation to
the central business district will certainly enhance its competitive position.

i9

Of great importance, too, is the fact that increased use of public trans-
portation will ease the downtown parking problem.

Furthermore, it will be recalled from the figures quoted earlier in this
chapter that of the 20 expressway lanes (or equivalent) needed to meet
anticipated east-west traffic increases by 1980 (and to provide a minimum
reduction in present congestion), it was assumed, somewhat arbitrarily,
that the equivalent of two lanes would be provided by unspecified transit
improvements. In addition, four other lanes were unaccounted for on the
basis that further experience might indicate that they would not be
needed. Past experience has shown, however, that future traffic predic-
tions are often apt to turn out to be on the low side. Our ability to
improve public transportation may thus determine whether or not six
expressway lanes (or equivalent) will have to be provided over and above
the East-West Expressway.

Some further aspects of the relationship between rapid transit and
the proposed expressway system are discussed in Chapter V.

town area passes through without stopping. This is, of course, the result

traffic is local in a metropolitan area sense, but it is through traffic from
the standpoint of the central business district.

system, insofar as the central business district is concerned, should be to
provide a means for removing from surface streets within the central
business district the traffic that is simply passing through. It is held that
this purpose is of greater importance than the provision of access to the
central business district, particularly since depositipg large volumes of

Traffic Needs



expressway traffic onto surface streets within the central business district
can cause acute congestion in the vicinity of access ramps. By keeping
expressways some distance away from the central business district it is
alleged that property damage can be minimized and that through traffic
can be diverted around the central business district.

Prohibitive land acquisition costs would bar an expressway from the
central business district itself. The question at issue then is an expressway
along the boundaries of the central business district as against an express-
way some distance further eut. For the reasons presented below it is
believed that the best location for an expressway is as close to the central
business district as is feasible.

1. The argument that distance from the central business district
minimizes property damage is often fallacious. In many cases the
easiest place to locate an expressway is in the belt of slums that
surrounds the central business district. As one moves away from
the boundary of the central business district building quality is
apt to improve.

2. The further one moves away from the central business district
the more elaborate and extensive must be the expressway network
necessary to intercept and divert the traffic now passing through
the central business district.

3. Some traffic entering Baltimore’s central business district comes
in on -one radial artery for the purpose of leaving on another
radial artery going off at an angle. Most traffic passing through,
however, does so because the central business district lies on the
most direct line from origin to destination. Experience has shown
that an expressway will cause much traffic to divert from the most
direct path, but the percentage of traffic doing so will be in pro-
portion to the degree of diversion. An expressway some distance



from the central business district will not, therefore, remove so
much traffic from surface streets within the central business dis-
trict as will an expressway close to the central business district.

. There is no reason why an expressway should not serve a variety

of purposes—in fact there is probably no such thing as a single-
purpose urban expressway. An expressway can well provide both
access to the central business district and a means for bypassing
the central business district. The problem of congestion surround-
ing access ramps leading to the central business district is simply
a question of proper design. The fact that this problem has been
poorly handled in some cities does not mean that it must be
poorly handled here.

. The construction of expressways which do not lead to the central

business district increases the accessibility of other areas relative
to the central business district and by so doing damages the
central business district. This point is discussed at greater length
in Chapter V.

V. THE PROS AND CONS OF EXPRESSWAYS

Introduction

Chapter III outlined past efforts to devise an expressway pattern for
Baltimore. Chapter IV described the increase in east-west traffic antici-
pated over the next twenty years and indicated how this increase might
be handled, in large part, through the construction of expressways. This
chapter deals with expressways in general, while subsequent chapters will
cover the specific subject of the East-West Expressway.

Despite the fact that in 1951 the voters of Baltimore approved the
first section of the 1949 expressway plan—the Jones Falls Expressway—
by a margin of more than four to one, the expressway program is still a
highly controversial subject. The reason is, of course, clear. The Jones
Falls Expressway is not typical in that its route required the demolition
of only a handful of buildings. Every other expressway proposal, including
the East-West Expressway, will have a much more drastic effect upon
existing improvements. This has undoubtedly led many Baltimoreans to
feel that a second look should be given to our local program.

What, then, are expressways? What are their advantages and dis-
advantages? What effects will expressways have on adjacent areas, on the
central business district, or on the overall structure of the City? What
are the alternatives to expressways? This chapter endeavors to answer
these questions.

What Are Expressways?

The basic street pattern of a modern city consists of a rectangular
grid of surface streets dividing the city into blocks or squares. Occasion-
ally a radial street will be superimposed on this pattern. The streets serve
two principal purposes: They provide access to abutting properties and
they permit the movement of traffic around and through the City. Traffic
moving on any one street conflicts with other traffic at every street inter-
section point.



21

Our modern city streets may be better in many details than streets
in ancient or medieval cities, and in recent years we have evolved many
new techniques for handling and controlling traffic, but the basic physical
pattern of our urban streets is no different today from the pattern 1000
or 2000 years ago. It has been said that expressways “represent the first
major innovation in highway design since the wagon road replaced the
footpath.”

Expressways differ from ordinary city streets in these important

respects:

(a) There is no direct access between expressways and adjacent
property. (Indirect access occurs, of course, through ramps
leading to surface streets.)

(b) There are no intersections with other streets or railroads. Ex-
pressways pass either over or under.

(c) Left turns into opposing traffic are eliminated.

(d) Pedestrians are barred.

(e) Parking is banned.

To effect a separation between expressway traffic and other traffic,
expressways in developed urban areas are nearly always depressed or
elevated. Exceptions occur when an expressway can be routed to take
advantage of topographical or physical barriers to the continuation of the
normal surface street pattern. Such barriers might be stream valleys,

Street is a good example.
