field_edited_text_value:
V. THE PROS AND CONS OF EXPRESSWAYS

Introduction

Chapter III outlined past efforts to devise an expressway pattern for
Baltimore. Chapter IV described the increase in east-west traffic antici-
pated over the next twenty years and indicated how this increase might
be handled, in large part, through the construction of expressways. This
chapter deals with expressways in general, while subsequent chapters will
cover the specific subject of the East-West Expressway.

Despite the fact that in 1951 the voters of Baltimore approved the
first section of the 1949 expressway plan—the Jones Falls Expressway—
by a margin of more than four to one, the expressway program is still a
highly controversial subject. The reason is, of course, clear. The Jones
Falls Expressway is not typical in that its route required the demolition
of only a handful of buildings. Every other expressway proposal, including
the East-West Expressway, will have a much more drastic effect upon
existing improvements. This has undoubtedly led many Baltimoreans to
feel that a second look should be given to our local program.

What, then, are expressways? What are their advantages and dis-
advantages? What effects will expressways have on adjacent areas, on the
central business district, or on the overall structure of the City? What
are the alternatives to expressways? This chapter endeavors to answer
these questions.

What Are Expressways?

The basic street pattern of a modern city consists of a rectangular
grid of surface streets dividing the city into blocks or squares. Occasion-
ally a radial street will be superimposed on this pattern. The streets serve
two principal purposes: They provide access to abutting properties and
they permit the movement of traffic around and through the City. Traffic
moving on any one street conflicts with other traffic at every street inter-
section point.



21

Our modern city streets may be better in many details than streets
in ancient or medieval cities, and in recent years we have evolved many
new techniques for handling and controlling traffic, but the basic physical
pattern of our urban streets is no different today from the pattern 1000
or 2000 years ago. It has been said that expressways “represent the first
major innovation in highway design since the wagon road replaced the
footpath.”

Expressways differ from ordinary city streets in these important

respects:

(a) There is no direct access between expressways and adjacent
property. (Indirect access occurs, of course, through ramps
leading to surface streets.)

(b) There are no intersections with other streets or railroads. Ex-
pressways pass either over or under.

(c) Left turns into opposing traffic are eliminated.

(d) Pedestrians are barred.

(e) Parking is banned.

To effect a separation between expressway traffic and other traffic,
expressways in developed urban areas are nearly always depressed or
elevated. Exceptions occur when an expressway can be routed to take
advantage of topographical or physical barriers to the continuation of the
normal surface street pattern. Such barriers might be stream valleys,
water fronts, large parks, etc. The Jones Falls Expressway north of Chase
Street is a good example.

Expressways represent a relatively new concept. The Bronx River
Parkway north of New York City was perhaps the first of any conse-
quence, and, while its design now seems obsolete, it dates back only about
35 years. Since then many thousands of miles of rural expressways have

field_edited_text_processed:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways





been constructed and this type is relatively common.

A few early examples of urban expressways also exist. The Pulaski
Skyway from the Newark Airport to the Holland Tunnel is one such.
No motorist who endeavored to negotiate the northern New Jersey indus-
trial flats prior to its construction will forget the fantastic congestion
which then existed on the surface streets. Hours were required to cover a
few miles. The West Side Highway in New York City running south
from 72nd Street is another early example. We don’t often think of the
Orleans Street Viaduct here in Baltimore as an expressway, but this is
essentially what it is. It has performed satisfactorily for some twenty-
five years.

Despite these early examples it is only within the last few years that
a large-scale program of urban expressways has gotten under way in cities
all over the country. Even now only a few hundred miles of urban ex-
pressways have been completed and are in use.

Expressways Are Safer

There appears to be no doubt whatsoever that expressways are much
safer than normal city streets. Statistics assembled on this subject over
a number of years by the U. S. Bureau of Public Roads show that urban
expressways are approximately twice as safe as city streets in terms of
fatal accidents and approximately five times as safe in terms of total
accidents. The record to date shows a cumulative fatality rate of 2.3 per
hundred million vehicle miles on urban expressways compared to 4.2 for
other city streets. The corresponding figures for all accidents are 154
and 751.

The Morning Sun for August 4, 1959, commented editorially on this
subject as follows:

“The statistics building up both in Maryland and elsewhere

22

show how much safer controlled access highways are. Nationwide,
the turnpikes like the New Jersey and Pennsylvania turnpikes and
the New York Thruway are the most striking examples of roadside
control. And despite the higher speeds allowed, they are definitely
safer. It was recently announced that the death rate for turnpikes
in 1958 was only 1.3 for every 100,000,000 vehicle miles. It was 2.3—
almost double—for other highways and roads.

“Right here in Maryland a small but significant sample tells a
similar story. Both US Route 13 from Salisbury to the Virginia
line and US Route 40 from Baltimore to Frederick have portions of
highway with controlled access and portions with unlimited access.
The controlled portions were markedly safer. The State Roads
Commission reports that on Route 13 there were no fatal accidents
at all last year on the controlled stretch compared to a rate of 12.4
deaths per 100,000,000 vehicle miles on the unlimited portion of the
dual highway. On Route 40, the rate was 3.4 on the controlled
stretch against a 9.8 figure for the unlimited access part of it just
outside Baltimore City.

“True, these figures are based on happily few deaths in each
case. One bad two-car accident anywhere could wrench the statistics
into a quite different relationship. But the experience on other high-
ways with tight roadside control suggests rather that the first com-
parable figures here in Maryland are following the normal pattern.
If the argument for beauty alone has failed to move Maryland’s
legislators as much as it should, perhaps the growing argument for
safety will help turn them into proponents of truly tight roadside
control of new super-highways.”

While the examples and statistics cited in this editorial refer to rural
rather than urban expressways, the Sun correctly points to control of

field_edited_text_processed:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways



this purpose would be more than could reasonably be expected to be con-
structed within the foreseeable future. But a feasible program of express-
ways could be expected to reduce rush hour traffic somewhat on major
streets and to cause a substantial drop in rush hour traffic on secondary
streets.

Because traffic congestion is at its worst during the two peak hours
in the early morning and in the late afternoon we tend to concentrate our
attention on this rush-hour traffic. Equally important in its blighting
effect on residential neighborhoods is, however, the fact that heavy
through traffic continues on many streets all during the day and evening
and in some cases (e.g. Franklin and Mulberry Streets) virtually all
around the clock. An expressway system which lacks the capacity to
handle all through traffic during rush hours may well have the capacity to
handle all, or virtually all, through traffic during non-rush hours. The
really dramatic effect of expressways in relieving existing streets will thus
probably occur during non-peak hours.

Heavy truck traffic through the City represents a special aspect of
the blighting effect of traffic. This situation was recently highlighted in
Baltimore by a series of regulations issued by Mr. Henry A. Barnes, Com-
missioner of Transit and Traffic, controlling truck traffic in the Northeast
Baltimore. Under the heading of Blight Prevention the Sun for August 5,
1959, commented editorially as follows:

“While urban renewal is not his field, Mr. Henry Barnes is
working for that branch of government in curbing truck traffic on
thoroughfares in new residential areas. Truckers may not see it that
way, but to outsiders it is painfully clear that if Mr. Barnes failed
to give homeowners in Northeast Baltimore some relief from the
thundering herd of night crawlers, the area in a few years’ time
would become the subject of costly blight-eradication programs.

“Unlike the railroads, the trucks have no right-of-way of their
own. If they snarl traffic at busy hours, no local government forces
them to build an overpass or underpass, as is the case with their
rival form of heavy freight carriers. The trucks depend on the
public streets. The public has the right to impose restrictions on
their use of these streets out of consideration for the general welfare.
Mr. Barnes has been acting in accordance with the larger consid-
eration, and in preserving the peace and quiet of residential areas he
is saving the city the grief that comes when it must take action after
a neighborhood has gone downhill.”

Without in any way minimizing the importance or desirability of
Mr. Barnes’ action, it is appropriate to note that while the City has the

- power to regulate truck traffic it cannot wholly bar trucks from City

24

streets. Eliminating trucks from some surface streets may simply push
them over on to other surface streets. The tendency is for truck routes
to end up passing through those areas having the least articulate occu-
pants. These again tend to be the older blighted areas of the City. Truck
regulations may protect the newer better neighborhoods of the City, but
often at the expense of efforts to renew the older sections. Actions which
further the Urban Renewal Program in one area may serve to impede
it in others.

Again, expressways can help to solve the problem. To the extent that
heavy truck movements can be confined to expressways they can be totally
barred from residential streets. No system of expressways can ever be
complete enough to handle all truck movements within the City, but a
feasible system can handle a substantial proportion. The important point
is that a truck movement shifted from one surface street to another is apt
to solve one problem at the expense of creating another; a truck move-
ment shifted from a surface street to an expressway is likely to be a

complete solution.

Expressways Can Create Blight

While expressways can reduce materially the blighting effect of
through traffic on surface streets, expressways themselves can be blighting
agents if they are not properly located and designed. This can happen
in several ways:

1. Physical Barriers: An expressway can act as a physical barrier
making more difficult communication and circulation between land
on one side and land on the other. The extent to which this bar-
rier exists depends to a considerable degree upon the type of
construction. A depressed expressway will not be an important
barrier if all intersecting streets are bridged over the expressway;
to the extent that some previously existing streets are not bridged
the degree of separation will be increased. Expressways elevated
on a structure generally allow free access beneath the structure
and thus represent no physical barrier, although the structure
itself may act as a psychological barrier. Expressways elevated
on an embankment or running along the surface generally permit
the fewest crossings and thus act as the greatest barriers.

The importance of the separating effect of an expressway depends
upon the land use on either side. It is generally of little or no
importance if the expressway runs along some natural feature
which itself acts as a barrier—down a ravine, along a waterfront,
etc. It is normally not of great importance (and sometimes help-
ful) if the land use on one side differs from the land use on the
other—e.g., along the dividing line between residential and indus-
trial development. The same conclusion generally applies if the
expressway serves to divide well-established residential neighbor-

25

hoods. On the other hand, the barrier formed by an expressway
can be definitely harmful when the expressway passes through
the middle of an established neighborhood, and the higher the
quality of the neighborhood the more harmful the effect is apt
to be. An expressway can also be detrimental when it serves to
separate areas which should be in close proximity for economic or
business reasons. An expressway embankment with few crossings
passing through the middle of a single industrial holding would
be an extreme example.

. Noise: The noise created by an expressway can have an adverse

effect on surrounding properties, although it is usually less bother-
some than one would think considering the volume and speed of
the traffic involved. The noise tends to be steady and this type of
noise is usually less objectionable than the alternate roars and
silences of passing rush hour slugs of traffic along important one-
way streets. The worst noise associated with an expressway is
created by heavy trucks negotiating up-grades on access ramps.
Ordinarily the noise factor is a problem only with respect to
residential structures facing elevated or on-grade expressways.
For other types of structures the noise will be no more harmful
(and in most cases less troublesome) than the general level of
traffic noise now prevailing on major surface streets. The nature
of construction for a depressed expressway generally results in
the expressway lanes being some distance from the nearest build-
ings and this plus the difference in grades usually minimizes the
noise problem. For this and other reasons depressed expressways
are greatly to be preferred through residential areas.

A difficult noise problem can be created by the lower deck of a
double-decked elevated structure in close proximity to residential

field_edited_text_processed:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways

| I I \ | | B I
R EEEREEEEERERER



buildings at approximately the same level as bedroom windows.
Traffic on the lower level is noisier than that on the top level
since the noise can reverberate between the two decks. The prob-
lem is minimized by using a single level structure, by raising the
structure some distance above bedroom windows, or by increasing
the distance between the structure and the residential buildings.
An expressway designed in this manner with 75-foot to 100-foot
separation from nearby residential buildings and without nearby
access ramps will probably create less noise than a normally busy
adjacent city street.

. Light and Air: An elevated expressway can serve to cut off light

and air from the lower stories of adjacent buildings. This problem
is important for residences, retail trade buildings, and probably
offices. It is of less importance for industrial buildings and of no
importance for warehouses. It is generally of little consequence
if only a corner of a building is in close proximity.

A separation of 30 feet to 40 feet between the expressway and
adjacent buildings will usually be sufficient to minimize this prob-
lem. A somewhat greater distance, say 50 feet to 60 feet, would
probably be desirable if the expressway is double-decked.

. Partial Takings: Properties remaining after clearance for an ex-

pressway can produce a most untidy and unpleasant appearance
which may have a blighting effect on the neighborhood. This
result will not occur when clearance comes up to an existing
street so that the nearest buildings are those facing the opposite
side of the street. The blighting effect is usually most acute when
the expressway runs diagonally across the existing street pattern.
When this happens a great many small triangular pieces of land
are left over, back yards are exposed, and building rows are cut

in the middle.

In some circumstances it is possible that over a period of time
adjacent properties will be rebuilt so as to reflect the existence
of the expressway. In this manner the scars left by the express-
way may ultimately be removed. Such a process often requires,
however, the consolidation and rearrangement of the lots in
question and is not easily accomplished without public action. It
is perhaps not wholly coincidental that several public housing
projects and Renewal Area 4 lie adjacent to Fayette Street which
was widened in 1937, that the Mt. Royal Plaza Renewal Area lies
on both sides of the extension of Howard Street constructed in
1938, and that Renewal Area 7 lies on both sides of Russell Street
widened in 1953.

To minimize the blighting effect of partial takings in heavily
developed areas it is desirable to run expressways between two
parallel streets and to clear all of the land between these streets.
Such an arrangement is also desirable from a traffic point of view
since it facilitates the construction of access ramps at appropriate
points and permits the border streets to be used for the collection
and dispersal of traffic between access points.

Evidence that expressways do not have as great an adverse effect
upon adjacent residential areas as is generally assumed can be obtained
from a study recently conducted by the California Division of Highways /
and reported in California Highways and Public Works for March-April, ’Y
1957. While it might be said that the California Division of Highways
would not be wholly unbiased in conducting such a study, nevertheless
the published report seems to indicate that the investigation was thorough,
conscientious, and objective. The study involved a comparison of sales
prices for houses immediately adjacent to expressways with similar houses
field_edited_text_value:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways

| I I \ | | B I
R EEEREEEEERERER



buildings at approximately the same level as bedroom windows.
Traffic on the lower level is noisier than that on the top level
since the noise can reverberate between the two decks. The prob-
lem is minimized by using a single level structure, by raising the
structure some distance above bedroom windows, or by increasing
the distance between the structure and the residential buildings.
An expressway designed in this manner with 75-foot to 100-foot
separation from nearby residential buildings and without nearby
access ramps will probably create less noise than a normally busy
adjacent city street.

. Light and Air: An elevated expressway can serve to cut off light

and air from the lower stories of adjacent buildings. This problem
is important for residences, retail trade buildings, and probably
offices. It is of less importance for industrial buildings and of no
importance for warehouses. It is generally of little consequence
if only a corner of a building is in close proximity.

A separation of 30 feet to 40 feet between the expressway and
adjacent buildings will usually be sufficient to minimize this prob-
lem. A somewhat greater distance, say 50 feet to 60 feet, would
probably be desirable if the expressway is double-decked.

. Partial Takings: Properties remaining after clearance for an ex-

pressway can produce a most untidy and unpleasant appearance
which may have a blighting effect on the neighborhood. This
result will not occur when clearance comes up to an existing
street so that the nearest buildings are those facing the opposite
side of the street. The blighting effect is usually most acute when
the expressway runs diagonally across the existing street pattern.
When this happens a great many small triangular pieces of land
are left over, back yards are exposed, and building rows are cut

in the middle.

adjacent properties will be rebuilt so as to reflect the existence
of the expressway. In this manner the scars left by the express-
way may ultimately be removed. Such a process often requires,
however, the consolidation and rearrangement of the lots in
question and is not easily accomplished without public action. It

projects and Renewal Area 4 lie adjacent to Fayette Street which
was widened in 1937, that the Mt. Royal Plaza Renewal Area lies
on both sides of the extension of Howard Street constructed in
1938, and that Renewal Area 7 lies on both sides of Russell Street
widened in 1953.

To minimize the blighting effect of partial takings in heavily
developed areas it is desirable to run expressways between two
parallel streets and to clear all of the land between these streets.
Such an arrangement is also desirable from a traffic point of view
since it facilitates the construction of access ramps at appropriate
points and permits the border streets to be used for the collection
and dispersal of traffic between access points.

upon adjacent residential areas as is generally assumed can be obtained
from a study recently conducted by the California Division of Highways /
and reported in California Highways and Public Works for March-April, ’Y
1957. While it might be said that the California Division of Highways
would not be wholly unbiased in conducting such a study, nevertheless
the published report seems to indicate that the investigation was thorough,
conscientious, and objective. The study involved a comparison of sales
prices for houses immediately adjacent to expressways with similar houses

field_edited_text_processed:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways



located at greater distances from expressways. Approximately 500 sales
were investigated and in each case an interview was conducted with both
the seller and the buyer. The houses adjoining the expressway were
located from 75 to 200 feet from the expressway traffic with the majority
of the houses being within 150 feet. Most of the houses were at the same
level as the expressway or at a lower level.

The results of the study showed that the sales prices for houses
adjoining the expressway were approximately 1% to 29% lower than the
houses away from the expressway. This difference is hardly large enough
to be significant. In the course of the interviews 429, of the residents
living adjacent to expressways indicated that the noise did not bother
them, 339 were recorded as having “slight objection,” and 109 stated
that they were bothered only by trucks. The remaining 159% found the
noise objectionable. In response to a question on their general reaction
to the location, 48% of the residents living adjacent to expressways stated
that they felt the location was “no better or worse than other areas.”
239, preferred an expressway location while 20% did not like the express-
way location. The remaining 9% had a mixed reaction.

Additional evidence along the same line is available in current resi-
dential development along the County Beltway. In the general vicinity of
Towson a substantial number of houses have been built and sold on land
adjoining the Beltway. Apparently the purchasers did not regard the
proximity of the Beltway as being objectionable.

As a generality it can be said that an expressway will have an adverse
effect upon adjacent properties in any case where the expressway is less
attractive or less desirable than the use which it replaces and that, con-
versely, an expressway may have a beneficial effect when the opposite is
the case. Thus, almost any kind of expressway adjacent to a high-grade
residential area will act, at least to some extent, to depress abutting

27

properties. The one possible exception would be an expressway with a
very wide right of way which was extensively landscaped—similar, for
example, to the Westchester County Parkways. On the other hand, a
depressed expressway running between parallel streets through a blighted
residential area might have a beneficial effect on adjacent properties. Or
again, an elevated expressway between parallel streets in a blighted com-
mercial area with ample space between the structure and nearby buildings
might very well have a helpful effect. Determining whether an expressway
will be a desirable or undesirable neighbor is thus a relative matter. It
depends upon the character of the expressway, the quality of the adjacent
properties, and the nature of the buildings or uses removed to make way
for the expressway.

And finally, it should be noted that with respect to elevated express-
ways a great deal depends upon the quality of design. At their worst
elevated expressways can be heavy, oppressive, and downright ugly. By
comparison a well designed expressway structure can appear relatively
light and graceful.

Expressways Provide Incidental Advantages

Expressways frequently provide the opportunity to take advantage
of certain incidental benefits or by-products. The more important of
these include:

1. An elevated expressway not running along an existing street often
provides an opportunity to make use of the cleared land adjacent
to or underneath the structure. Landscaping and off-street park-
ing are two obvious possibilities.

2. An expressway, whether depressed or elevated, running in land
which has been cleared between two parallel streets creates an
opportunity to widen the two parallel streets with minimum cost

and effort.

3. Automobile driving along regular city streets is usually a rather
dreary and dismal experience. Driving on urban expressways is
often stimulating and even exciting. Not only is there the

“ pleasure of being able to proceed continuously and at good speeds
through highly congested areas, but also expressways sometimes
can provide the opportunity for interesting and even spectacular
views of the city. The expressway running along the west side of
Manhattan Island in- New York City is a good example. At the
upper end are magnificent vistas of the Hudson River and the
Palisades on the opposite shore. Further down are intimate
close-ups of the great trans-Atlantic liners as well as views of the
skyscraper concentrations at midtown and on lower Manhattan
Island. Here in Baltimore the approaches to the Harbor Tunnel
afford new and unusual vantage points from which to see the

harbor and the center of the City. Expressway driving in many

"\cases can be an exhilarating experience.

Costs

There are wide variations in expressway costs. One of the most
expensive was the Central Artery in Boston which cost about $36,000,000
per mile. About one-quarter of this cost was for right of way. At the
other end of the scale is the Cabrillo Freeway in San Diego which was
completed in 1949 at an average cost of $768,000 per mile. In this case
right of way costs were negligible.

A short elevated expressway close to the central business district of
San Francisco ran $16,000,000 per mile, while in Chicago the eight-mile
depressed Congress Street expressway was built for about $12,500,000
per mile.

In view of the great variations in expressway costs it is not possible
to generalize beyond noting that any expressway through developed urban
areas will be expensive.

A certain amount of research has been done to demonstrate that
expressways produce sufficient savings to justify their initial costs. For
example, according to studies conducted in Los Angeles, the average saving
from expressway use came to 2.0 cents per vehicle mile, computed as
follows:

BT VT P R SIS L A 0.33 cents
Vehicle maintenance cost savings due to

elimination of stop-and-go travel............... 0.24 cents
ROCICOBL WRVINEE el o v s e kW s o b e e 0.56 cents
Commercial vehicle time savings

Cotoratnd to ol BB i o ini o i s pnnig 0.87 cents

In 1954, 46 miles of Los Angeles expressway, completed at a cost of
$198,000,000, carried 1.2 billion miles of vehicle travel. The apparent
saving at 2.0 cents per mile totaled $24,000,000 or enough to equal con-
struction cost in eight years. Studies in other cities show similar results.

It may be held that these figures should not be taken too literally
if only on the basis that no self-respecting government agency is ever
without a similar justification for the program which it is administering.
Be that as it may, it is probable that this type of statistical analysis
should be qualified to some extent.

It should be noted first of all that these savings accumulate in little
bits and pieces for a large number of individuals and for this reason are
largely unnoticed. Any individual making a ten-mile expressway trip
will be highly conscious of the time saved and the pleasure added, but he
certainly will not tell himself that he has just saved 215 cents in mainte-
nance costs. The owner of a fleet of trucks will undoubtedly be able to

field_edited_text_processed:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways



spot savings from his records, but not the average car owner.

Furthermore, insofar as savings exist they may be taken by many
persons in some form other than cash. People may take advantage of an
expressway to move further out of town so as to secure more space. For
such individuals total travel costs may not diminish even though cost per
mile has been reduced. To the extent that expressways result in thinning
out the metropolitan area, the owner of a truck fleet serving the area
may also find that at least some of his potential savings have been eaten
up by the need to cover greater distances.

The savings quoted above do provide ammunition for those who
believe that expressways should be financed by taxes assessed specifically
against automobile users—gas taxes, tire taxes, etc. They also justify the
construction of expressways in terms of the net effect on the total resources
of our economy. They can be used to demonstrate that the necessary
expenditure of manpower, capital, and materials is warranted.

All of this, however, presupposes a rational approach to public and
private automobile expenditures which does not, in fact, exist. We spend
money on automobiles and on facilities to serve automobiles to achieve a
wide variety of satisfactions, some of which are measurable in dollars and
cents, but some of which could not be supported on any economic basis.

Potential operating savings are an important factor in the overall
picture, but they should be kept in perspective. We should ask ourselves
first, what is the minimum level of highway service which we wish to
achieve and, second, what is the best method of achieving this goal taking
all factors into account—initial cost, operating cost, number of properties
to be razed, number of families to be displaced, effect on taxes, effect
on the economic base of the City, effect on the central business district,

29

etc. Operating savings represent simply one element in a complex
evaluation process.

Expressway Systems in Large Cities

This Chapter so far has dealt with the characteristics of a single
expressway. No large city can, however, rely on one expressway to handle
its traffic problem, and the relationship of an expressway to other possible
expressways and to the entire pattern of arterial highways within the
city is a matter of importance.

The most authoritative document on the design of expressways is the
publication of the American Association of State Highway Officials en-
titled A Policy on Arterial Highways in Urban Areas. (The recommended
design standards set forth therein serve as the basis for minimum Federal
requirements for the Interstate Highway System.) This document dis-
cusses the type of highway system needed for a large city in these terms:
“ ... the basic pattern of arterial highways is in the form of a wheel.
Radial routes are the spokes; the outer circumferential or belt highway
is the rim, and the inner belt around the central business district is the
hub; large cities also may have an intermediate belt. Local conditions
may distort the symmetry of the wheel pattern and even eliminate parts
of it, but in general the overall pattern is much the same for all cities . . . .
The type of highway-freeway, at-grade expressway, or major street—to
be used in the arterial highway pattern is determined by joint consider-
ation of the type of facility needed to carry the traffic load and that
physically and economically is feasible in that part of the city. The larger
the urban area, the greater is the necessity for high-type facilities. In a
typical large city (500,000 - 1,000,000) the framework of the arterial
system consists of several expressway or freeway radial routes and two
or more belts. Major streets complete the system.”

field_edited_text_processed:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways



Expressways in Relation to the Central Business District'

A residential suburb in Baltimore is not, by itself, very different from
a residential area in a smaller community. What distinguishes the Balti-
more suburb is the proximity of the downtown area and the corresponding
availability of all of the functions and services that customarily are located
there. It is in the center of our City that we find the large central
department stores, the small speciality shops, the theaters and amusement
centers, the hotels and restaurants, and the headquarters for much of our
cultural life. Here also is the center of the area’s economic activity, the
large offices, the important financial institutions, and the major concen-
tration of professional activities.

It is, of course, well known that our central business district has been
declining in importance as the rest of the metropolitan area grows. The
evidences of this decline have been too well established to warrant repeti-
tion here. It is pertinent to point out, however, that a continued decline
will represent something more than just a transfer of downtown functions
to more outlying areas. If the process continues some activities which
can only be supported on an area-wide basis will be wholly lost. A large
department store can establish suburban branches and perhaps end by
closing entirely its central store, as did Wanamakers in New York. Inade-
quate support for our one legitimate theater, however, cannot be remedied
by setting up a branch Ford’s in Towson and another in Glen Burnie.

Do we want a dispersed metropolitan area with some of our present
downtown functions abandoned and others distributed over a large area
so that we end up with a kind of homogenized city? Or do we want a
metropolitan area with a strong focal point and a vigorous, active center?
The business leadership of the community and the City Administration
have already decided in favor of a strong city center and the one-sided
vote in favor of Charles Center is ample evidence that this decision has
the support of the citizens.

30

The link between a strong central business district and the express-

way program is the question of accessibility. For Baltimore, as for any
other large city, the dominant characteristic of the central business dis-
trict is that it occupies the location having maximum accessibility from all
parts of the metropolitan area. Accessibility is, however, a relative matter.
If, as the metropolitan area grows, congestion increases so that it is more
difficult to reach the central business district, but if, at the same time,
congestion slows down other movements within the area to an equivalent
degree, the central business district will retain its relative accessibility
and its essential strength. On the other hand, if there are major highway
improvements in the outer sections of the area not matched by improve-
ments leading to the center of the city, the relative accessibility of the
central business district will be reduced and the central business district
will decline.

This point can be illustrated by some schematic examples. Assume
that the circle in Figure 2(a) represents a metropolitan area 10 miles in
radius with a normal pattern of surface streets. Assume also that
vehicular travel within one mile of the center averages 10 miles per hour
but that elsewhere it can proceed at 20 miles per hour. Let us also assume
that the point marked A is 8 miles due north of the center of the area
and that the point marked B is 8 miles due south. Based on these assump-
tions it can be demonstrated that all of the area shaded in the upper part
of the circle is more accessible to A than to the center. In other words,
a trip to any point in the shaded area can be done in shorter time starting
from A than starting from the center. The shaded portion represents 30%
of the metropolitan area. The balance, 70%, is more accessible to the



1The commonly accepted definition of the Central Business District has the
following approximate boundaries: Pratt Street on the south, Greene Street on the
west, Centre Street on the north, and the Fallsway on the east. The Central Business
District as thus defined is shown on Sheets 2 through 7.

Do we want a dispersed metropolitan area with some of our present
downtown functions abandoned and others distributed over a large area
so that we end up with a kind of homogenized city? Or do we want a
metropolitan area with a strong focal point and a vigorous, active center?
The business leadership of the community and the City Administration
have already decided in favor of a strong city center and the one-sided
vote in favor of Charles Center is ample evidence that this decision has
the support of the citizens.

30

The link between a strong central business district and the express-

way program is the question of accessibility. For Baltimore, as for any
other large city, the dominant characteristic of the central business dis-
trict is that it occupies the location having maximum accessibility from all
parts of the metropolitan area. Accessibility is, however, a relative matter.
If, as the metropolitan area grows, congestion increases so that it is more
difficult to reach the central business district, but if, at the same time,
congestion slows down other movements within the area to an equivalent
degree, the central business district will retain its relative accessibility
and its essential strength. On the other hand, if there are major highway
improvements in the outer sections of the area not matched by improve-
ments leading to the center of the city, the relative accessibility of the
central business district will be reduced and the central business district
will decline.

This point can be illustrated by some schematic examples. Assume
that the circle in Figure 2(a) represents a metropolitan area 10 miles in
radius with a normal pattern of surface streets. Assume also that
vehicular travel within one mile of the center averages 10 miles per hour
but that elsewhere it can proceed at 20 miles per hour. Let us also assume
that the point marked A is 8 miles due north of the center of the area
and that the point marked B is 8 miles due south. Based on these assump-
tions it can be demonstrated that all of the area shaded in the upper part
of the circle is more accessible to A than to the center. In other words,
a trip to any point in the shaded area can be done in shorter time starting
from A than starting from the center. The shaded portion represents 30%
of the metropolitan area. The balance, 70%, is more accessible to the



1The commonly accepted definition of the Central Business District has the
following approximate boundaries: Pratt Street on the south, Greene Street on the
west, Centre Street on the north, and the Fallsway on the east. The Central Business
District as thus defined is shown on Sheets 2 through 7.

field_edited_text_processed:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways

i



center. The center thus enjoys a degree of superiority over A (or any
other similar outlying point) of better than 2 to 1. It is obvious that the
center’s margin of superiority over A is increased the farther one gets
from A. It would take 27 minutes to drive from the center to Point B;
54 minutes to drive from A to B.

Now let us change the circumstances somewhat. Let us assume that
an expressway in the form of a beltway is built around the city 8 miles
from the center. Let us also assume that one can travel on this beltway
at an average speed of 40 miles per hour. The area now more accessible
to A than to the center will increase, as shown in Fig. 2(b), to the point
where it equals 50% of the metropolitan area. A, instead of being less
than half as accessible as the center, is now just as accessible. Further-
more, even within the area in which it still is dominant the center’s
margin of superiority over A is markedly less. It still takes 27 minutes to
travel from the center to B, but the travel time from A to B has dropped
from 54 minutes to 37 minutes. The previous 27 minutes differential has
thus been reduced to 10, a drop of almost 2/3.

Next, let us assume that in addition to the beltway a radial express-
way (allowing an average speed of 40 miles per hour) is built from the
center of the City due north to the limits of the metropolitan area. This
example is illustrated in Fig. 2(c). While the center has improved its
position somewhat in relationship to points on the east and west sides of
the beltway, fundamentally the situation is still the same as shown in
Fig. 2(b).

Finally, let us assume that three additional radial expressways are
constructed running from the center to the edge of the metropolitan area:
one to the east, one to the south, and one to the west. This condition is
illustrated in Fig. 2(d). Under these circumstances the center again has a
better than two to one superiority over point A or any similarly situated

field_edited_text_processed:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways



outlying point. Its accessibility is better than in any of the previous cases
although the margin of superiority over Fig. 2(a) is slight.

The application of these theoretical examples to the Baltimore area
is, of course, obvious if one regards the beltway as being the Beltway now
partially completed in the County, the single expressway to the north as
the Jones Falls Expressway, and the three additional radials as the
Southwest Expressway and the East-West Expressway.

These examples would seem to suggest that from the standpoint of
saving the central business district the real villain of the piece is the
Beltway. If this conclusion seems farfetched one has only to consider the
array of major shopping centers which are springing up at strategic points
along the Beltway or in close proximity to the Beltway. Included in this
list are Towson Plaza, Eastpoint, Harundale Mall, and Westview. Or
again, consider the new headquarters of the Department of Motor Vehicles
on Ritchie Highway. The State’s principal justification for picking this
site rather than one close to the center of Baltimore was its proximity to
the planned route of the Beltway.

The above schematic examples may also cast some additional light
on the question of substituting improved mass transit for expressways.
The health of the central business district is dependent upon superior
accessibility for all types of transportation. It has been indicated that it
requires four expressways extending outwards from the center at roughly
right angles, one to the other, to remedy the loss of vehicular accessibility

/resultmg from the construction of a beltway. Without this minimum
framework of expressways no amount of public transit improvement can
restore the central business district’s position of maximum accessibility
from all part of the metropolitan area. It may be the most accessible spot
from the standpoint of public transportation, but with the beltway and
without the radials it will no longer be the most accessible for automo-

bile travel.

The central business district’s position within the metropolitan area
is, of course, dependent upon many factors besides highways. Construc-
tion of the expressway pattern outlined in this report will not by itself
insure the future security of the central business district. It can safely
be said, however, that failure to continue with an expressway program
clearly focused on the downtown area will gravely jeopardize the many
efforts now being made to save the central business district. If we call a
halt after completion of the Jones Falls Expressway we face the prospect
of living in a city much more dispersed and scattered than our present
city. It will be more a large urban area than a city—one that will lack
much of the character and identity of Baltimore as we now know it.

Alternatives to Expressways

It is not hard to develop a case against urban expressways. We can
tell ourselves that the construction of expressways produces too great an
upheaval, that the hardships and other problems resulting from the relo-
cation of a good many thousands of people are excessive, that too much
property must be destroyed, and that the loss in tax base will be burden-
some. We can say that we should not be seduced by the availability of
large Federal grants and that we should be able to resist what might be
called the expressway hysteria allegedly affecting many other cities. We
can point to the fact that other metropolitan areas have already reached
the size which we expect to attain in the next twenty to thirty years and
that they did so without reliance on urban expressways. We can tell
ourselves that there are more things in life than the automobile and that
an ambitious expressway program would simply represent a final succumb-
ing of man to machine.

An objective appraisal must certainly concede that most urban ex-

An objective appraisal must certainly concede that most urban ex-

field_edited_text_processed:
!

The Pros and Cons of Expressways



pressways have drawbacks as well as virtues. This being the case, one
possibility which should be examined would be a complete abandonment
_ of future expressway plans. What might the future hold if we did not
construct any more expressways after the Jones Falls Expressway? Or,
more specifically, what would happen if Baltimore decided not to go
ahead with the East-West Expressway?

We could, first of all, endeavor to increase the present capacity of
east-west streets by new streets or by widening existing streets. Previous
sections of this report have. indicated that all of the capacity of the
East-West Expressway would be needed to handle anticipated traffic
growth and to provide some small relief to existing streets. Since one
expressway lane is roughly the equivalent of two and one-half surface
street lanes it would require twenty new lanes of surface streets to equal
the eight lanes planned for the East-West Expressway. These 20 lanes
would have to pass from one side of the City to the other and all, or
nearly all, should cross the center of the City between the Inner Harbor
on the south and about Cold Spring Lane on the north.

It would not be possible to widen existing streets or to create new
ones without tearing down buildings. Removing all of the buildings on
one side of a street would probably permit an average of four additional
lanes to be constructed. Twenty lanes would require the razing of all
buildings on one side of each of five streets. Regardless of where located,
the East-West Expressway will require the razing of buildings on one side
of each of two streets (e.g., the south side of Franklin and the north side
of Mulberry).

Twenty additional lanes of surface streets would thus require the
removal of approximately two and one-half times as many buildings as
would the East-West Expressway. The number of families to be relocated,
the loss in taxes, and the cost of site acquisition would be in proportion.

33

Construction cost would be considerably less and, as a result, total cost
might perhaps be less. A program of creating 20 new surface street lanes
would not, however, generate any new Federal grants and the total cost
to the City would thus be very much greater than the cost to the City
for the East-West Expressway after making allowance for the very sub-
stantial Federal grants available for this purpose.

Furthermore, while 20 new surface street lanes would duplicate the
capacity of the East-West Expressway they would not provide the safety
or the savings in travel time of the East-West Expressway.

It seems evident that if the City is not willing to go ahead with an
East-West Expressway it would be even less likely to proceed with a pro-
gram which would provide the same capacity by additional surface streets.

What happens, then, if we neither build additional expressways nor
add substantially to our present surface street capacity? Here one has
to do some guessing, but the following results seem probable.

In the first place, while Mr. Barnes has accomplished remarkable
results in squeezing additional capacity out of our existing street system,
there are obviously limits to what can be achieved in this way and Mr.
Barnes would probably be the first to admit that we are approaching
these limits. From here on in, if we do not add substantially to our high-
way system, congestion will steadily increase. It would seem possible to
project present trends into the future to the point where congestion had
become so great that traffic movement was theoretically impossible. This,
however, is an unlikely result. At some point this side of complete stag-
nation certain counter forces and trends would probably come into play.

People trapped by congestion are also citizens and voters. The need
for relief would almost certainly become a major political issue which
would have to be recognized by future City administrations. Since we are
assuming that the City is unwilling to embark upon any such major

i
r



The Pros and Cons of Expressways



program as the construction of expressways, the likely result would be a
series of remedial measures on a piecemeal basis to relieve points of ex-
treme congestion—a street widening here, a grade separation there, etc.

In addition to these relatively small-scale improvements there would
probably also develop over a period of years a gradual series of changes in
the metropolitan area representing a multitude of individual adjustments
to the level of congestion. There would almost certainly be a speed-up in
the decentralization of downtown firms and activities and a continued
or accelerated, decline in the.central business district. Outlying shopping
centers would tend not only to serve the shopping needs of surrounding
areas but would more and more take on many of the functions which
previously were best handled by the central business district.

Workers would tend to adjust either their jobs or their homes so that
the two would be in closer proximity. It might be said, from a planning
point of view, that this is a desirable result and so it would be if it came
about through free choice. When, however, it is forced by congestion it
normally means that the worker, restricted in his choice of job or home
site, will end up with a less desirable job or home, or both. At the same
time employers will find that they are able to draw from a smaller and
smaller labor market.

With the Baltimore region tending to become a series of urbanized
sections rather than a unified city, many functions which can only be
supported on a metropolitan area basis will find survival difficult if not
impossible. The smaller specialized shops and services, the theater, con-
certs, museums and similar activities will occupy a smaller and smaller
place in the life of the community. People, finding it difficult to con-
gregate in a central place, will fairly quickly lose the habit of making an
effort to do so.

These gradual adjustments in land uses, in the relationship between

home and jobs, and in habits will tend, along with spot improvements in
street facilities, to place an upper level on congestion and to keep it from
getting completely out of hand. Another factor operating to the same end
will be that economic growth will proceed at a slower rate than antici-
pated. With a high level of congestion in the Baltimore metropolitan
area some firms that otherwise might move here from elsewhere will not
do so. Others now here may move entirely outside of the Baltimore area.
The anticipated increases in traffic described in Chapter IV of this report
are predicated on a reasonable rate of economic growth and assume that
congestion within the area will not be a serious deterrent to this growth.
If congestion is a deterrent then traffic will not increase to the extent
predicted.

If then we feel that the price which must be paid for a planned

expansion of our street and highway facilities (through expressways or .

otherwise) in order to meet anticipated traffic increases is too high we
probably face a future characterized by increased congestion, reduced
mobility, less freedom to select jobs or home sites, a speed-up in decen-
tralization, a greater dispersion of many functions throughout the metro-
politan area, a lower level of cultural activities and of specialized services
and businesses, and a reduced rate of economic growth.

Vi. REQUIREMENTS AND CRITERIA FOR AN
EAST-WEST EXPRESSWAY

Any route for an East-West Expressway should satisfy the following

requirements:

1. It should be planned in such a way that it will be approvable for
inclusion in the National Interstate Highway System and thus be
eligible for 90% Federal grant. Specifically this means that:
(a) At its eastern termination it must connect with the proposed

North-East Expressway leading to Philadelphia.

(b) At its western termination it must cross the city line at about
Cooks Lane so as to connect with the proposed freeway
going toward Frederick.

(c) It must be possible to meet Federal design standards.
2. A feasible interchange with the Jones Falls Expressway must be
possible.
3. It should provide good service to the central business district.
If more than one route can be developed meeting the above require-
ments, then judgment as to the relative desirability of the different routes
should be based upon the following factors:
1. Benefits to traffic.
(a) Extent to which route conforms to traffic desire lines.
(b) Extent of relief to presently congested streets.

(c) Extent to which incidental benefits (street widenings, etc.)
are made possible.

35

2. Stimulus to new building or to redevelopment in adjacent areas.
3. Benefit to the central business district including the retail trade
center, Charles Center, and the Civic Center.
4. Benefits to the economic life of the City—commerce, industry,
port, etc.
5. Blighting effect as measured by:
(a) Extent to which route splits established residential neighbor-
hoods.
(b) Extent to which route separates areas which for economic
reasons should be in close proximity.
(¢) Proximity to high grade residential areas.
(d) Proximity of elevated structures to any residential areas.
(e) Close proximity of elevated structures to retail or office use.
Quantity and quality of dwellings to be demolished.

Effect on assessed valuations.

Total cost.

Significant or important properties to be taken:

(a) Churches

(b) Moderately large or large structures not in poor condition.

(c) Takings which would utilize significant amounts of vacant
land otherwise desirable and available for industrial ex-
pansion.

The above factors are not necessarily listed in order of importance.

o o n

Vii. IMPROVEMENTS TO NORTHERN ROUTE

The most recent alignment approved by the Planning Commission for
the East-West Expressway is that contained in the 1957 Plan. The com-
plete route is shown on Sheet 6 and the details are presented on Sheets 8
through 19. In the balance of this report this alignment will be referred to
as the Northern Route.

When this alignment was first approved it was intended that the
Expressway would be depressed as it passed through the Mt. Vernon area.
For a period during 1958 it appeared that it would be necessary for this
section to be elevated in order to provide a feasible interchange with the
Jones Falls Expressway. While approval of this elevated structure repre-
sents the last official action of the Planning Commission, the Commission
has subsequently informally agreed that if this alignment is to be used
the Expressway should be depressed through the Mt. Vernon area regard-
less of the interchange complications which might ensue. Subsequent
referrals to the Northern Route will therefore be based upon the depressed
version as approved by the Commission in the 1957 Plan.

In responding to the Mayor’s request for a restudy of the route of
the East-West Expressway, our first efforts were directed at ascertaining
if small-scale improvements could be made in the Northern Route. This
phase of our study was not productive. Only two variations seemed suffi-
ciently worthwhile to warrant serious consideration and only one of these
was studied in detail. These two variations are discussed below:

1. The Hoffman Street Alternate

After crossing the Jones Falls Expressway in an easterly
direction the Northern Route turns to the northeast until it
reaches the blocks between Preston and Hoffman Streets. At
this point it becomes depressed and proceeds between these two
streets to Bond Street. All of the existing improvements between
Hoffman and Preston Streets would be taken. The pattern for

36

this stretch of the Expressway is thus much like that between
Mulberry and Franklin Streets west of Fremont Avenue.

The Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel passes under Hoffman
Street and also under the land just to the south of Hoffman
Street. As a result the land to the south of Hoffman Street is
already cleared of improvements for an average width of about
65 feet. If the bed of Hoffman Street is included there is a
cleared strip of approximately 120 feet.

Certain neighborhood interests which have been opposed to
the East-West Expressway, primarily on the basis of the number
of buildings to be taken, indicated that their opposition would
diminish or disappear if the Expressway could be moved over into
this cleared strip. Since the Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel passes
underneath, the Expressway in this location would have to be
elevated. The results of this small northerly shift in the align-
ment are shown on Sheet 21.

From the standpoint of alignment, grades, ease of access, and
traffic handling ability this possible revision is at least as good as
the original route. It is an improvement over the original route
in the number of houses to be taken. Approximately 380 resi-
dential buildings and 40 other buildings which would have to be
demolished under the original scheme would not have to be taken
if this Hoffman Street alternate were adopted. The Hoffman
Street alternate would also reduce the assessed valuation of prop-
erties to be taken by about $1,500,000.

On the other hand, there are distinct disadvantages to the
Hoffman Street alternate. The original plan called for a depressed
highway between two parallel streets. This is the best possible
arrangement from the standpoint of reducing to a minimum any

36

this stretch of the Expressway is thus much like that between

65 feet. If the bed of Hoffman Street is included there is a
cleared strip of approximately 120 feet.

traffic handling ability this possible revision is at least as good as
the original route. It is an improvement over the original route
in the number of houses to be taken. Approximately 380 resi-
dential buildings and 40 other buildings which would have to be

Street alternate would also reduce the assessed valuation of prop-
erties to be taken by about $1,500,000.

highway between two parallel streets. This is the best possible
arrangement from the standpoint of reducing to a minimum any

field_edited_text_processed:
Improvements to Northern Route







possible adverse effect upon abutting properties. In lieu of this
arrangement the Hoffman Street alternate would provide an
elevated structure which for six blocks would be in close proximity
to existing residential structures. The net effect of the Hoffman
Street alternate on the adjacent neighborhood would certainly be
more detrimental than the original plan.

Taking all these factors into consideration it seems clear that
the Hoffman Street alternate is less desirable than the original
plan and should not be adopted. Our conclusions on this score
are not altered by the fact that there is some indication that
adoption of the Hoffman Street alternate might reduce opposition
to the Northern Route.

. Northern Mt. Vernon Alternate

One of the principal objections to the Northern Route has
been based on the quality of the buildings in or adjacent to the
right of way through the Mt. Vernon area. A further objection
has been based on the extent to which the proposed route splits
the Mt. Vernon area in two. It has been suggested that some of
these objections might be overcome if this portion of the Express-
way could be shifted a few blocks to the north where it would be
closer to the northern limits of the Mt. Vernon area and where
existing improvements are somewhat less desirable. Under this
proposal the intersection of the Northern Route and the Jones
Falls Expressway would be moved approximately three blocks
northward so that the crossing would occur at about the point
where Guilford Avenue will cross the Jones Falls Expressway.
From this intersection the Expressway would go directly east on
an elevated structure so as to meet the original route on the other
side of Greenmount Avenue between Preston Street and Hoffman
Street. Proceeding westerly from the Jones Falls Expressway
the proposal would call for the East-West Route to pass over

Mt. Royal Avenue to Calvert Street. It would then turn south-
westerly passing diagonally through the present street pattern to
Cathedral Street. Continuing in the same direction it would join
the original route at about Howard Street. The alignment of this
alternate is indicated by the heavy line on Sheet 22.

While this proposal could be made to work, it has certain

undesirable features:

(a) It would be impossible to depress the Expressway at any
point between Greenmount Avenue and Fremont Ave-
nue. It would thus pass through the center of town as
an elevated structure.

(b) The only type of interchange which could be devised
with the Jones Falls Expressway would be awkward and
cumbersome.

(c) While it is true that the structures in the northern part
of the Mt. Royal area through which this proposed
revision would pass are somewhat lower in quality than
those between Chase and Eager Streets, nevertheless, the
fact that the revised route would pass diagonally through
this section would result in some highly undesirable
taking lines. The scars left by this routing would be
more damaging than those for the 1957 Plan.

For all of these reasons no more detailed consideration was

given to this proposal.

This phase of our study led to the conclusion that no small-scale
improvements of the Northern Route could be made. If the East-West
Expressway is to be located along this route the present alignment seems
to be the best possible. This conclusion is not surprising when it is con-
sidered that the present path is the result of several years of study on the
part of the Planning Commission.

BE'R'R'E'R'EER'E'E'EER
vill. HARBOR ROUTE AND RELATED

PROPOSALS

After studying the Northern Route to determine if improvements
could be made in its alignment, attention was next directed to the location
of substantially different routes.

It will be recalled that Chapter VI of this report sets forth three
basic requirements which should be met by any route for an East-West
Expressway. These requirements were: First, it should be approvable for
inclusion in the National Interstate Highway System; second, interchange
with the Jones Falls Expressway must be feasible; and third, good service
must be provided to the central business district.

Only one new route was discovered which met all of these require-
ments satisfactorily. This route is referred to in this report as the Harbor
Route. The complete route is shown on Sheet 7. The detailed alignment
is set forth on Sheets 8 through 12 and 23 through 28.

From the western City line to Myrtle Avenue the Harbor Route is
identical to the Northern Route. For the following reasons it was decided
to make no change in this section:

1. The crossing of the western City boundary is in effect fixed if the
East-West Expressway is to be eligible for inclusion as part of the
Interstate Highway System.

2. From the western City boundary to Hilton Street the route passes
through Leakin Park and Gwynns Falls Park. While it would
normally be undesirable to use park land for highway purposes,
the City owns a very large amount of park land in this general
area and those portions needed for the Expressway would, for the
most part, be located in the high isolated rugged areas south of
Dead Run. In effect, the Expressway path jumps from hill to
hill and approximately one-third of the total length within the
park would be elevated. There would be no interference between
the Expressway and any developed sections of the park, nor would

38

there be any conflict with present foot or vehicle circulation
within the park. Most present entrance roads into the City are
unsightly; this one would have great beauty. Total park land
required would be about 85 acres, of which about 35 would be
needed for the Hilton Street interchange. This reduction in park
acreage can be replaced in whole or in part by the purchase of
additional vacant land adjacent to the park. Already two parcels
at the western end of Leakin Park have been acquired to prevent
development in the path of the Expressway. When the Express-
way requirements have been met there will remain about 25 acres
in these two parcels which can easily be added to the Park. The
only alternative to the use of park land at this point would be
to run the Expressway through the high-grade residential areas
to the north or to the south.

. The stretch running between Mulberry and Franklin Streets from

the Pennsylvania Railroad on the west to Myrtle Avenue on the
east (a little less than a mile and one-half) has long been ear-
marked for clearance for highway purposes and much planning
during the past ten years has been based on the understanding
that an expressway would be located here. Two public housing
projects located just to the east of Fremont Avenue have been
developed with this Expressway in mind, and the plan for the
Harlem Park Urban Renewal Area has been predicated on this
assumption. The heavy streams of traffic which now flow on
Mulberry and Franklin Streets have made the area between these
two streets highly undesirable for residential purposes and many,
if not most, of the structures between these two streets are so
dilapidated that they should be torn down. With or without the
Expressway, Franklin and Mulberry Streets will continue to be

field_edited_text_processed:
UL

Harbor Route and Related Proposals

'B'E'R'E'R'E'E'R'E'ER'



major traffic arteries and widening would be highly desirable.
Widening without the Expressway would be expensive and would,
in any event, necessitate the demolition of most of the buildings
between the two streets. With the Expressway, widening be-
comes a relatively simple and relatively inexpensive by-product.

4, The Northern Route from the western City boundary to Myrtle
Avenue combined with the Harbor Route from Myrtle Avenue to
the east provides the closest possible access to many portions of
the central business district, including particularly the retail trade
center surrounding the intersection of Howard and Lexington
Streets.

At Myrtle Avenue the Harbor Route deviates from the Northern
Route. It turns south and continues in this direction as a depressed route
to Pratt Street, running first between Myrtle Avenue and Pine Street and
then skirting the western boundary of the University of Maryland Re-
newal Area.

At the lower end of this southerly stretch the proposed route is occu-
pied by St. Paul’s Cemetery which lies between Redwood and Lombard
Streets just east of Fremont Avenue. This cemetery dates back to 1800
and contains the graves of a number of noted men. It would be desirable
to avoid this cemetery, but it does not appear possible to do so. Moving
the Expressway to the east would conflict with the University of Maryland
and University Hospital. A relocation to the west would increase sub-
stantially the number and quality of houses to be razed, would eliminate
the possibility of creating an inner ring around the downtown area, and
would destroy any useful relationship between the expressway system and
the retail trade center.

Several solutions to this situation are possible. If St. Paul’s Church
agreed, the Expressway, depressed at this point, could be tunneled far

39

enough below the Cemetery so as not to disturb the graves. Or possibly
the Church and the City might find it mutually advantageous to consider
the removal of the cemetery to a wholly new site. The problem, which
has evident emotional overtones, will have to be worked out in conjunction
with the Church Vestry.

After passing under the Cemetery the Harbor Route swings around
to the east and continues between Pratt and Camden Streets as far as
Light Street. As it makes this turn from south to east it is also rising to
an elevated structure so as to clear a very large sewer in Penn Street and
the Baltimore and Ohio tunnel under Howard Street. (It continues as
an elevated structure for the balance of the route primarily because it
skirts the northern side of the Inner Harbor and in this location a de-
pressed roadway would be below the water line.) Also, as the Harbor
Route turns to the east connections are provided to Russell Street to the
south so that there is easy access between the Harbor Route and the
Washington-Baltimore Expressway.

As the Harbor Route proceeds between Pratt and Camden Streets it
first passes along the southern boundary of the University of Maryland
Renewal Area, thus serving as a buffer between the proposed University
campus and the industrial area to the south. It then passes within one
block of the Civic Center and Charles Center and access ramps are pro-
vided which would serve both of these new developments. Renewal Area 7
and the Camden B&O Station lie immediately to the south of this stretch
of the Expressway.

The clearance of the blocks between Pratt and Camden Streets pro-
vides the opportunity, if desired, to widen both streets and to utilize the
balance of the land for off-street parking, for landscaping, or for similar
purposes. The cleared land on either side of the Expressway would furnish
an excellent opportunity to plant street trees in accordance with the

field_edited_text_processed:
Toguir

Harbor Route and Related Proposals

v 00000y ganl



Planning Council’s proposed landscaping plan for the central business
district.

After crossing over Light Street the Harbor Route then continues as
an elevated structure south of Pratt Street across the municipal piers.
The piers could be continued in use for small boats or barges but it would
probably be desirable to discontinue all such uses and to construct a new
sea wall a short distance to the south of the Expressway. The ends of the
piers could then be cut off and the space behind the sea wall filled in.
Under this scheme the present buildings on the south side of Pratt Street
housing the Port Authority and the Department of Transit and Traffic
could be left. The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company’s heating plant
on Pier No. 4 also could be left if necessary, although some special arrange-
ment might have to be worked out if this plant continues to use barge-
delivered coal.

If the areas between the piers and beneath the Expressway are filled
in, Camden Street could, if desired, be extended to the east so as to con-
nect up with Eastern Avenue thus providing an entirely new cross-town
street. The balance of the land between the sea wall and Pratt Street
could be used for a variety of purposes, such as off-street parking or a
landscaped park.

Interchange with the Jones Falls Expressway would occur approxi-
mately at Pier 6. The Jones Falls Expressway at this point must neces-
sarily be a considerable distance in the air since it is about to bridge the
Inner Harbor. There is thus room for the East-West Expressway to pass
underneath and still be one level above grade. The plans show connections
between the two Expressways which would permit all important movements.

An illustration of the section of the Harbor Route between Light
Street and the Jones Falls Expressway treated as described above is
presented as Sheet 29. This drawing also shows the relationship of the

40

Harbor Route to Charles Center and the Civic Center, as well as the
interchange between the Harbor Route and the Jones Falls Expressway.

After passing under the Jones Falls Expressway the Harbor Route
continues in a southeasterly direction passing over the President Street
Station until it reaches Lancaster Street. At this point it turns due east
and continues just south of Lancaster Street crossing by bridge the small
portion of the Inner Harbor lying north of Anchorage No. 2.

While the bridge necessary to effect this water-crossing will be ex-
pensive, it does not appear feasible to locate the route further north so
that the water-crossing can be avoided. Immediately to the north of the
proposed route is the large National Can Company plant. To the north
of this plant lies a closely knit residential neighborhood which would be
seriously harmed if the Expressway were to pass through it. The proposed
bridge therefore appears to be essential.

After crossing the Harbor inlet the Harbor Route curves around to
meet Boston Street and follows over Boston Street all the way to the
entrance road to the Harbor Tunnel.

As the Harbor Route first swings into Boston Street it would be
necessary to acquire all of the properties on the Harbor side of Boston
Street between approximately Wagner Street and O’Donnell Street.
There is only one good building in this stretch, however. Property acqui-
sition between O’Donnell Street and the Esso Refinery would, for the
most part, be minor in character and all would be on the northeastern
side of Boston Street.

Because there are several tight places along the Boston Street route
the Expressway would become a double-decked elevated structure at
about the point it meets Boston Street and would continue in this
fashion to the tunnel entrance road. A more detailed study needs to be
made of the relation between the Harbor Route and the Esso Refinery.

could be used for a variety of purposes, such as off-street parking or a
landscaped park.

Interchange with the Jones Falls Expressway would occur approxi-
mately at Pier 6. The Jones Falls Expressway at this point must neces-
sarily be a considerable distance in the air since it is about to bridge the
Inner Harbor. There is thus room for the East-West Expressway to pass
underneath and still be one level above grade. The plans show connections
between the two Expressways which would permit all important movements.

An illustration of the section of the Harbor Route between Light
Street and the Jones Falls Expressway treated as described above is
presented as Sheet 29. This drawing also shows the relationship of the

40

Harbor Route to Charles Center and the Civic Center, as well as the
interchange between the Harbor Route and the Jones Falls Expressway.

After passing under the Jones Falls Expressway the Harbor Route
continues in a southeasterly direction passing over the President Street
Station until it reaches Lancaster Street. At this point it turns due east
and continues just south of Lancaster Street crossing by bridge the small
portion of the Inner Harbor lying north of Anchorage No. 2.

While the bridge necessary to effect this water-crossing will be ex-
pensive, it does not appear feasible to locate the route further north so
that the water-crossing can be avoided. Immediately to the north of the
proposed route is the large National Can Company plant. To the north
of this plant lies a closely knit residential neighborhood which would be
seriously harmed if the Expressway were to pass through it. The proposed
bridge therefore appears to be essential.

After crossing the Harbor inlet the Harbor Route curves around to
meet Boston Street and follows over Boston Street all the way to the
entrance road to the Harbor Tunnel.

As the Harbor Route first swings into Boston Street it would be
necessary to acquire all of the properties on the Harbor side of Boston
Street between approximately Wagner Street and O’Donnell Street.
There is only one good building in this stretch, however. Property acqui-
sition between O’Donnell Street and the Esso Refinery would, for the
most part, be minor in character and all would be on the northeastern
side of Boston Street.

Because there are several tight places along the Boston Street route
the Expressway would become a double-decked elevated structure at
about the point it meets Boston Street and would continue in this
fashion to the tunnel entrance road. A more detailed study needs to be
made of the relation between the Harbor Route and the Esso Refinery.
