B R e b b G b S B & G W G G & & G B B R B B B W B B B ) B B B B B



Since, however, the Refinery is no longer in operation it is not anticipated
that this will be a major problem.

An interchange is provided between the Harbor Route and the Tunnel
Entrance Road so as to permit the main flow of traffic to pass between
these two highways. A connection to Boston Street beyond the Tunnel
Entrance Road is also provided as are various other interchange move-
ments.

The Tunnel Entrance Road is now two lanes wide in each direction
from the tunnel itself to Moravia Avenue just north of Pulaski Highway.
At Moravia Avenue the tunnel entrance widens and merges into the
Northeast Expressway which will continue on in the direction of Wilming-
ton and Philadelphia. Connecting the Harbor Route to the Tunnel
Entrance Road at Boston Street would mean that this road would have
to be widened from two lanes to four lanes in each direction between
Boston Street and Moravia Avenue. No undue difficulties are anticipated
in this widening. Very little additional land would be needed. Most of
the existing bridges would have to be widened or rebuilt. The Harbor
Tunnel and approach roads were financed with revenue bonds and the
approach roads are subject to a provision in the trust indenture which,
in effect, would prohibit their use by non-tunnel traffic. Under present
conditions the proposed use of a portion of the Harbor Tunnel entrance
road as a part of the East-West Expressway would not be legally possible.
This matter has been reviewed by the City Solicitor, Mr. Harrison L.
Winter, who has advised us that it is probable that this legal barrier can
be removed provided all parties concerned wish to do so. This matter
will, however, need further detailed study if the City decides to adopt the
Harbor Route.

An alternative eastern termination to the Harbor Route is possible.
Instead of merging at Boston Street with the tunnel approach, the Harbor

41

Route might be continued more or less easterly across the City line so as
to join an extension to the County Beltway. The Beltway would then
serve as a connection between the Harbor Route and the Northeast
Expressway. This alternative routing would require the taking of addi-
tional residences in the O’Donnell Heights area, but would probably im-
prove the circulation pattern in the eastern part of the City and adjacent
portions of the County. The possibilities of this alternative should be
explored in conjunction with the State Roads Commission and the County.

The Harbor Route as Part of a Freeway System

It will be recalled from the discussion in Chapter IV that the ideal
arterial highway system for a large city consists of a ring around the
central business district with a series of radials extending to one or more
outlying beltways. Since Nathan L. Smith’s 1945 report all cross-town
expressway proposals have been presented as part of a plan for an express-
way system based upon this schematic arrangement.

The inner ring in the Planning Commission’s 1957 plan is shown on
Sheet 6. It will be seen that the Jones Falls Expressway forms the
eastern segment; the Southwest Radial the southern; and the East-West
Expressway the northwestern and northern. The ring would be completed
by a depressed expressway starting with the East-West Expressway at
Myrtle Avenue and Mulberry Street, running south between Pine Street
and Myrtle Avenue, then swinging gradually around to the east so as to
join the Southwest Expressway south of the Inner Harbor at about Sharp
and Hamburg Streets. (Between Mulberry and Pratt Streets this route
is virtually identical with the Harbor Route.) This link is not part of
the Interstate System, but might be constructed under the so-called
Urban Program which provides for 509 Federal subsidy. For this reason
it has been assumed that it would be the last segment of the inner ring to

Wl

Expressway the northwestern and northern. The ring would be completed

Wl

field_edited_text_processed:
Harbor Route and Related Proposals



be constructed and that its completion would be 15 to 20 years off.

On paper the inner ring gives the illusion of being a gigantic traffic
circle, but it would not actually function as such. A traffic circle is a
device for handling intersecting flows of traffic by a weaving process on
a common or merged stretch of roadway. In the case of two intersecting
expressways, such as the Jones Falls Expressway and the East-West
Expressway, the volume and speed of traffic is too great to make such a
device feasible and the intersection must be handled by a grade separation
and a series of connecting ramps.

Although the inner ring would not operate as a traffic circle it does
have a number of important advantages:

1. The geometric requirements of expressway design (including such
items as acceleration and deceleration lanes, minimum weaving
distances, etc.) severely limit the number of on and off ramps
which can be installed within any given distance. Further limi-
tations are often imposed by various surface-level features. The
inner ring, by increasing the length of expressway contiguous to
the downtown area, allows a greater number of access ramps to
be provided which will be of service to the central business dis-
trict. It also permits a more strategic placing of these access
points in a rough circle around the edges of the central business
district. The expressway system can thus provide good access to
all portions of the central business district. Furthermore there is
increased opportunity for surface-street traffic intending to pass
through the central business district to get on to the expressway
system before entering the central business district, thus helping
to free central business district streets of through traffic.

2. The pattern of traffic movements near the center of the City,
whether on surface streets or on expressways, is at best a compli-

42

cated one. An inner ring will provide some degree of choice of
route for many vehicles. This will greatly facilitate a balancing
and adjustment of traffic so as to minimize the possibility of
bottlenecks developing at any one point. Two expressways simply
crossing near the center of the City represent a somewhat rigid
pattern; the inner ring introduces a degree of flexibility.

The inner ring concept can be preserved using the Harbor Route.
Where, under the 1957 Plan, the ring was completed by a southwest
segment, adoption of the Harbor Route would require the substitution of
a northwest segment. Three variations are possible.

1. The first scheme leaves the Harbor Route at Myrtle Avenue and

Franklin Street and proceeds northeasterly, as shown on Sheet 30,
to Cathedral Street, at which point it turns north, passing east
of the Mt. Royal Station and a comfortable distance west of the
Lyric. This route, depressed throughout, would connect with the
Jones Falls Expressway to the west of Maryland Avenue. Surface
connections to Mt. Royal Terrace are also provided. This pro-
posal would change Cathedral Street between Mt. Royal Terrace
and Chase Street from a through street to a service street; through
traffic could easily be diverted to Maryland Avenue. The plan
would require the utilization of most of Lots 4 and 6 in Mt. Royal
Plaza. (Both are now being cleared except for the Deutsches Haus.)

. The plan outlined above is relatively simple and straightforward

except that the northbound connection to the Jones Falls Ex-
pressway would require the relocation of a sizable Pennsylvania
Railroad transformer station. The second proposal, not illustrated,
is a variation of the first designed to overcome this difficulty.
From Franklin Street to Oliver Street the plan is identical. North
of Oliver Street the expressway would be carried over the tracks

field_edited_text_processed:
Harbor Route and Related Proposals



on a bridge parallel to, and just west of, the Maryland Avenue
bridge. It would then merge with Falls Road. Just north of the
B&O Bridge a ramp for northbound traffic would leave Falls
Road, go over the tracks to the left, and merge with the Jones Falls
Expressway just below the 29th Street interchange. Construction
costs for this plan would be greater than for the first, but overall
costs might well be less. This plan also has the incidental advan-
tage of providing a direct connection between the inner ring and
the Maryland and Pennsylvania Railroad right of way should this
right of way ever be developed for some kind of vehicular traffic.

3. The third variation starts out from the Harbor Route identically
to the first two, but at about Chase Street it comes to the surface
and becomes a widened Cathedral Street. It would then proceed
north on Mt. Royal Terrace, joining the Jones Falls Expressway
by means of the presently planned North Avenue and 29th
Street interchange points. It will be recognized that the surface
aspects of this proposal are identical to those developed by Mr.
Barnes for a different purpose. (See Chapter III and Sheet 20.)

Aside from the transformer station there is no great difference in
land cost among the three schemes. The third plan would be the simplest
and cheapest to construct, but it would provide the smallest additional
traffic capacity. A decision among the three need not be made immedi-
ately and should await further analysis and study. Until a decision is
reached, however, it would be highly desirable to prevent development of
the land now vacant north of Oliver Street and west of Maryland Avenue.
This might require purchase of this land by the City.

Additional Possibilities
Adoption of the Harbor Route would provide the opportunity for

43

developing a number of other proposals which would be helpful to the
overall traffic picture:

1. Connection to the Northeast

One of the City’s major traffic problems is the present inade-
quacy of highway facilities between the northeast and the center
of the City. A number of good roads exist in the northeast itself,
but they tend to disappear as one approaches the older sections
of the City and from about 29th Street south there is acute need
for additional facilities. While the problem has long been recog-
nized there has not heretofore been any generally accepted
solution.

It will be recalled that the Advisory Engineers suggested an
elevated structure running north along Barclay Street. At 25th
Street this expressway would swing to the northeast and continue
along Loch Raven Road. While this proposal would work it would
be expensive and, unless a wide path were cleared along Barclay
Street, it would have a detrimental effect on adjacent residential
properties.

From a quick look at a map it might appear that the North-
ern Route runs along the southern edge of the northeast district
and that it would thus be of considerable help. A closer examina-
tion will reveal, however, that there is a gap of about a mile
between the Northern Route and the good highways above 29th
Street. Furthermore, as presently laid out there are relatively few
access ramps to the Northern Route which would be of assistance
to the northeast even if this gap did not exist.

To remedy these deficiencies the Planning Commission some
years ago gave consideration to a proposal involving a depressed

on a bridge parallel to, and just west of, the Maryland Avenue
bridge. It would then merge with Falls Road. Just north of the
B&O Bridge a ramp for northbound traffic would leave Falls
Road, go over the tracks to the left, and merge with the Jones Falls
Expressway just below the 29th Street interchange. Construction
costs for this plan would be greater than for the first, but overall
costs might well be less. This plan also has the incidental advan-
tage of providing a direct connection between the inner ring and
the Maryland and Pennsylvania Railroad right of way should this
right of way ever be developed for some kind of vehicular traffic.

Harbor Route and Related Proposals



expressway which would branch off to the north onto Broadway
from the Northern Route of the East-West Expressway. This
branch, known as the Broadway Radial, would continue north
along Broadway, crossing under North Avenue, and would then
swing around to merge with a widened Harford Road just above
the present intersection of Harford Road and Broadway.

While this proposal would seem to offer a good connection to
the northeast it also poses certain problems. As planned it would
be expensive to construct and the problem has been complicated
in the last few years by the installation of a new major sewer line
in Broadway. Furthermore, it is probable that during rush hours
the Northern Route would be operating close to capacity so that
there might be inadequate spare capacity to absorb any large
amount of traffic coming in on the Broadway Radial from the
northeast. The Broadway Radial does not now appear feasible.

In exploring the possibilities of additional proposals to serve
the northeast, these factors stand out:

a. No new facilities are possible without some demolition of

residential properties.

b. The only section of the Jones Falls Expressway from
which a branch expressway could take off to serve the
northeast is that portion near Chase Street currently
reserved for the interchange with the East-West Express-
way. If the East-West Expressway were transferred to
the Harbor Route this stretch would become available for
a branch to the northeast.

c. It would appear that some advantage ought to be taken
of the possibility of widening Hoffman Street between
Greenmount Avenue and Bond Street by utilizing the

44

strip of cleared land to the south over the Pennsylvania
Railroad tunnel.

d. Harford Road opposite Clifton Park occupies a strategic
location since a number of main roads to the northeast
converge here—Loch Raven Boulevard, The Alameda,
Hillen Road, and Harford Road itself. The City is
already proceeding with plans to widen this stretch of
Harford Road.

Putting these factors together suggests a possible new solu-
tion which is illustrated on Sheets 31 through 34. Under this
proposal Harford Road would be made one way south from North
Avenue to Hoffman Street and, if necessary, from North Avenue
to 25th Street. Southbound traffic would continue down Harford
Road, swing west on a widened Hoffman Street, proceed over
Greenmount Avenue and the railroad tracks on an elevated struc-
ture, and join the Jones Falls Expressway at about Eager Street.

Northbound traffic would follow a similar route in reverse up
to the intersection of Harford Road and Hoffman Street. At this
point northbound traffic would continue straight ahead on Hoff-
man Street to Bond Street. There are several possibilities for
connecting this point with Harford Road north of North Avenue.
Two of these are illustrated. One would provide an elevated
structure to carry the northbound traffic over the railroad tracks
onto Broadway. It would then proceed on the surface across
North Avenue, cut across the western end of Holy Cross Cemetery
and proceed to Harford Road. Another possibility would carry
northbound traffic over Broadway and the railroad tracks to join
Rutland Avenue. Rutland Avenue would then be extended across
North Avenue and the eastern end of Holy Cross Cemetery, swing

Harbor Route and Related Proposals



around to join St. Lo Drive through Clifton Park. Both Rutland
Avenue and St. Lo Drive would be made one way north.

Additional study is necessary to ascertain the best way to
terminate this connection at the north, but either of the two
proposals shown would be less expensive to install than the Broad-
way Radial. Use of Rutland Avenue would be less direct than use
of Broadway but would keep residential demolition to a minimum
(less than 20 houses) and would simplify use of the cemetery
since there are no graves in the eastern end. The Broadway
variation would require the relocation of graves in the western
end of the cemetery and would thus involve many of the same
considerations that were discussed earlier in this report in relation
to St. Paul’s Cemetery.

It was pointed out above that under the 1957 Plan there
might be difficulty accommodating the Broadway Radial traffic on
the East-West Expressway. The same point might be raised with
respect to this new proposal. Would there be sufficient spare
capacity on the Jones Falls Expressway to absorb the traffic com-
ing in on this new northeast connection? It is believed that there
would be as a result of the traffic which would leave the Jones
Falls Expressway to come down the west side of the central
business district if the inner ring were completed as previously
suggested. It can be seen, however, that the key to successful
operation of this northeast connection would be the completion of
the inner ring. In addition it will be noted from the plans that a
surface connection is provided between the northeast connection
and the Fallsway which should serve as a safety valve in case the
Jones Falls Expressway were overloaded at this point.

45

2. Connection to the Retail Trade Center

The Planning Council’s Plan for the central business district
recommended a number of propesals designed to revitalize the
retail trade center in the vicinity of Howard and Lexington
Streets. Notable among these is the proposal for a Retail Mall
together with a connection to the Lexington Market Parking
Garage. The Plan also recommended that if demand warranted
the garage should be enlarged.

While these proposals are certainly headed in the right
direction, to be successful they must be accompanied by measures
to enhance the accessibility of the retail trade center in relation
to the rest of the City and the metropolitan area. This enhanced
accessibility can be provided by the Harbor Route by means of a
few relatively simple additional proposals. These are illustrated
on Sheet 36 which shows the relationship of the Harbor Route to
the retail trade center, the Civic Center and Charles Center. It
will be seen that in effect three expressway legs come together at
about the intersection of Franklin and Mulberry Streets with Pine
Street and Myrtle Avenue. By adding a few additional access
ramps in this vicinity it is possible to secure a complete system of
on and off ramps to each of these three legs at a point only a few
blocks from the Lexington Market Garage. This traffic can be
brought into the garage via Lexington Street and from the garage
back to the expressways via Saratoga Street. Both streets would
be one way. To avoid conflicts with the heavy traffic flow on
Greene and Paca Streets it is suggested that the incoming traffic
be diverted up Pearl Street and that an underground connection
be provided between Pearl Street and the Lexington Market
Garage. This connection would also be used for outgoing traffic.

Harbor Route and Related Proposals



around to join St. Lo Drive through Clifton Park. Both Rutland
Avenue and St. Lo Drive would be made one way north.

Additional study is necessary to ascertain the best way to
terminate this connection at the north, but either of the two
proposals shown would be less expensive to install than the Broad-
way Radial. Use of Rutland Avenue would be less direct than use
of Broadway but would keep residential demolition to a minimum
(less than 20 houses) and would simplify use of the cemetery
since there are no graves in the eastern end. The Broadway
variation would require the relocation of graves in the western
end of the cemetery and would thus involve many of the same
considerations that were discussed earlier in this report in relation
to St. Paul’s Cemetery.

It was pointed out above that under the 1957 Plan there
might be difficulty accommodating the Broadway Radial traffic on
the East-West Expressway. The same point might be raised with
respect to this new proposal. Would there be sufficient spare
capacity on the Jones Falls Expressway to absorb the traffic com-
ing in on this new northeast connection? It is believed that there
would be as a result of the traffic which would leave the Jones
Falls Expressway to come down the west side of the central
business district if the inner ring were completed as previously
suggested. It can be seen, however, that the key to successful
operation of this northeast connection would be the completion of
the inner ring. In addition it will be noted from the plans that a
surface connection is provided between the northeast connection
and the Fallsway which should serve as a safety valve in case the
Jones Falls Expressway were overloaded at this point.

45

2. Connection to the Retail Trade Center

The Planning Council’s Plan for the central business district
recommended a number of propesals designed to revitalize the
retail trade center in the vicinity of Howard and Lexington
Streets. Notable among these is the proposal for a Retail Mall
together with a connection to the Lexington Market Parking
Garage. The Plan also recommended that if demand warranted
the garage should be enlarged.

While these proposals are certainly headed in the right
direction, to be successful they must be accompanied by measures
to enhance the accessibility of the retail trade center in relation
to the rest of the City and the metropolitan area. This enhanced
accessibility can be provided by the Harbor Route by means of a
few relatively simple additional proposals. These are illustrated
on Sheet 36 which shows the relationship of the Harbor Route to
the retail trade center, the Civic Center and Charles Center. It
will be seen that in effect three expressway legs come together at
about the intersection of Franklin and Mulberry Streets with Pine
Street and Myrtle Avenue. By adding a few additional access
ramps in this vicinity it is possible to secure a complete system of
on and off ramps to each of these three legs at a point only a few
blocks from the Lexington Market Garage. This traffic can be
brought into the garage via Lexington Street and from the garage
back to the expressways via Saratoga Street. Both streets would
be one way. To avoid conflicts with the heavy traffic flow on
Greene and Paca Streets it is suggested that the incoming traffic
be diverted up Pearl Street and that an underground connection
be provided between Pearl Street and the Lexington Market
Garage. This connection would also be used for outgoing traffic.

field_edited_text_processed:
Harbor Route and Related Proposals



By this means there would be rapid expressway access to
the retail trade center from all parts of the City. While the last
few blocks of this connection would be by surface streets there
would be no conflict with any major traffic flow.

3. Redevelopment Opportunities

At various points along the Harbor Route east of the Jones
Falls Expressway it will probably be necessary to acquire some-
what more land than will actually be necessary for the construc-
tion of the Expressway. If the Harbor Route is built consideration
should be given to the desirability of establishing small redevelop-
ment areas in conjunction with this excess land. In all such cases
the indicated reuse would probably be industrial. Construction
of the Harbor Route might thus facilitate the rebuilding and
modernization of certain portions of the City’s industrial plant
which are now old and either obsolete or approaching obsolescence.

Other Possible Routes

At the start of this chapter it was stated that our studies had re-
vealed only one feasible alternative to the Northern Route. Some further
discussion of this point is perhaps in order.

The key to locating additional routes proved to be the question of a
feasible interchange with the Jones Falls Expressway together with the
relationship of the route to the central business district.

No reasonable means of interchange with the Jones Falls Expressway
appeared possible between the Northern Route and the Harbor Route.
For virtually all of this stretch the Jones Falls Expressway is double
decked and in the vicinity of the Orleans Street Viaduct the upper deck,
which must cross over the viaduct, is too high to permit a feasible con-

46

nection with interchange ramps. Furthermore, both here and elsewhere
between the Northern Route and the Harbor Route it would be impossible
to provide a pathway through the center of the City and an interchange
with the Jones Falls Expressway without destroying more valuable property
than would be taken by either the Northern Route or the Harbor Route.

In considering the possibility of routes north of the Northern Route
it was clear that no interchange with the Jones Falls Expressway could be
worked out south of North Avenue. The possibility of an interchange at
about North Avenue was not really explored, however, since other objec-
tions to a route in this area seemed decisive. Proposals have been made
for an elevated structure running along North Avenue. It would be im-
possible to do this, however, without producing a serious blighting effect
on the properties now facing North Avenue unless virtually all of the
properties along one side of North Avenue were taken. This would involve
a degree of demolition greater than for either the Northern Route or the
Harbor Route. Furthermore, there would be a serious question as to
whether an expressway along the Northern Route would be of any benefit
whatsoever to the central business district. Access from such an express-
way to the central business district would have to be by means of the
north-south streets from Howard Street to Guilford Avenue. These streets
are heavily congested at the present time and running an expressway
along North Avenue might simply add to this congestion. The heavy
volume now carried by these north-south streets represents one of the
major traffic problems in the City and is a serious barrier to renewal
efforts in the Mt. Vernon neighborhood. For all of these reasons a route
along North Avenue or approximating North Avenue seems less desirable
than the Harbor Route or the Northern Route and no serious study was
given to this possibility.

field_edited_text_processed:
Harbor Route and Related Proposals



The remaining possibility would involve a route south of the proposed
Harbor Route. For the following reasons this possibility appeared less
desirable than the Harbor Route:

a.

C.

To effect an interchange with the Southwest Expressway (which
is the continuation of Jones Falls Expressway) it would be neces-
sary to drop down at least six to eight blocks below Pratt Street,
thus losing the desirable proximity between the central business
district and the Expressway which is one of the main features of
the Harbor Route. Jurthermore, substantial property takings
would be necessary for this interchange.

Some type of harbor crossing would be necessary over the North-
west Branch which would add considerably to the cost. In
addition, there might be legal conflicts with the present Harbor
Tunnel which, in effect, would mean that this crossing could not
be constructed for a number of years. (The bonds for the Harbor
Tunnel were sold with the proviso that there would be no com-
peting harbor crossing until a certain proportion of the bonds
were retired.)

While the point was not explored, it seems probable that more
damage would be done to industrial areas by such a route than
would be the case either for the Harbor Route or the Northern
Route.

For all of these reasons a route south of the Harbor Route did not
appear desirable.

47

field_edited_text_processed:
iIX. COMPARISON OF THE HARBOR ROUTE
WITH THE NORTHERN ROUTE

Chapter VI of this Report enumerates the factors on which a com-
parison of alternative routes for the East-West Expressway should be
based. This chapter compares the Northern Route with the Harbor
Route with respect to these factors.

Benefits to Traffic

1. Conformity to Desire Lines: Studies made by the Department of
Transit and Traffic demonstrate that both the Northern Route
and the Harbor Route conform closely to desire lines and that
either would develop sufficient traffic to justify its construction.
Anticipated traffic on the Harbor Route would, however, be some-
what greater than on the Northern Route. The reason for this
is not hard to find. The two biggest traffic generators in the
metropolitan area are the central business district and the indus-
trial complex in the southeastern part of the City and in the
adjacent section of the County. The Harbor Route serves both
of these generators better than does the Northern Route. It comes
closer to the center of the central business district and has more
access ramps which serve the central business district. After
leaving the central business district the Harbor Route heads
directly for the heart of the southeast industrial area and while
it turns to the northeast upon reaching the Harbor Tunnel
entrance road there is ready access from this point to more out-
lying industrial sections via Boston Street, Dundalk Avenue, etc.
It seems clear that the Harbor Route conforms more closely to
major traffic desire lines than does the Northern Route.

2. Relief for Present Congestion: Either route would provide sub-
stantial relief to presently congested streets. Because of its closer
proximity, the Northern Route would provide somewhat greater

48

1 1

o
g

- -
-
|
=]
ey
ae N
S
Y



relief to Route 40 (Mulberry, Franklin, and Orleans Streets) than
the Harbor Route, although the Harbor Route would be of some
help. On the other hand the Harbor Route would be of great
benefit to Lombard and Pratt Streets while the Northern Route
would probably relieve these streets only to a small degree. A
reduction of Pratt Street traffic would allow Light and Calvert
Street traffic to cross more easily. The Harbor Route plus the
South-West Expressway when completed would provide a substi-
tute expressway path for a good part of the traffic now making a
left turn from Pratt Street into Light Street.

It is not expected that the Northern Route would provide much
relief for the streets running north from the central business
district (Howard Street to Guilford Avenue, inclusive) and, in
fact, it might be argued that traffic endeavoring to get from the
Northern Route to the central business district would increase
present traffic on these streets. The Harbor Route would not
relieve these streets directly but completion of the inner ring
based upon the Harbor Route would be of great benefit by pro-
viding an expressway route along the western side of the central
business district to match up with the Jones Falls Expressway
along the eastern side. The relief thus provided to the north-
south streets should greatly facilitate renewal efforts in the Mt.
Vernon neighborhood. In addition, the North-East Connection,
which would become feasible with the selection of the Harbor
Route, would ease present congestion on the streets leading from
the downtown area to the northeast.

In summary it can be said that either the Northern Route or the
Harbor Route would provide relief to presently congested streets
but that the Harbor Route scores higher on this count.

Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route





3. Incidental Traffic Benefits: With respect to incidental traffic
benefits, selection of the Harbor Route would permit the widening
of Pratt and Camden Streets west of Light Street, and the
extension of Camden Street to connect up with Eastern Avenue.
Also the land between Pratt and Camden Streets beneath the
expressway could be used for off-street parking. Other incidental
benefits for either route are relatively minor and would tend to
balance out.

Stimulus to New Building or to Redevelopment
in Adjacent Areas

It seems unlikely that the Northern Route would provide any great
stimulus to new building or to redevelopment except perhaps to a certain

degree in the industrial area to the west of Erdman Avenue. Whatever

help it might be in this section would probably be at least balanced out
by the stimulus provided by the Harbor Route in the eastern and south-
eastern parts of the City. In addition, the Harbor Route would have the
following effects:
(a) The Harbor Route would enhance materially the chances for
successful completion of Charles Center. Its closeness to Charles
Center and the proximity of off-and-on ramps will increase the
overall accessibility of Charles Center and render its land more
marketable. In addition, the Harbor Route would clear out a
portion of the undesirable area to the south of Charles Center
and tend to separate the Charles Center area from the blighted
district to the south of Camden street.
(b) Construction of Charles Center, the Civic Center, and the East-
West Expressway along the Harbor Route would greatly increase
the chances for a marked improvement in the character of the

49

old and obsolete buildings now located between Lombard and
Pratt Streets west of Light Street.

Would the Harbor Route adversely affect the possibility of an ulti-
mate large-scale redevelopment of the area around the Inner Harbor
such as that visualized by Mr. Arthur D. McVoy, the previous Director
of the Department of Planning? It is not believed so. Under Mr. McVoy’s
plan new buildings would be kept to the west of Light Street and to the
north of Pratt Street, and the area now occupied by the piers would be
filled in for park purposes. All of this would be possible with the Harbor
Route and, in fact, might be facilitated if the Harbor Route served to
reduce somewhat the present heavy surface traffic around the Inner
Harbor. Furthermore, construction of the expressway might bring the
park into being at a much earlier date than would otherwise be possible.
As a single deck structure and with proper design the Harbor Route would
not significantly block the view of the Inner Harbor from the central
business district. (This view would, of course, be opened up to all of those
traveling on the expressway.)

Benefits to the Central Business District

There can be no doubt whatsoever that the Harbor Route would
provide greater benefit to the central business district than the Northern
Route. The Northern Route passes four to five blocks north of the north-
ern boundary of the central business district and eight to ten blocks north
of the center of the central business district. While traffic coming in from
the east on the Northern Route could turn south on the Jones Falls
Expressway to get somewhat closer to the heart of the central business
district, traffic coming in from the west under the present design would be
barred from a south turn onto the Jones Falls Expressway and to reach
the central business district would have to leave the East-West Express-

Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route

I' :! Il ! || 1%! !l :!I :l ’



way at ramps onto Mulberry Street just west of Myrtle Avenue or onto
Eager Street between Cathedral Street and Charles Street. The north-
south streets from these ramps to the central business district are all
heavily congested.

The Harbor Route, on the other hand, passes close to the western
boundary of the central business district and then along its southern
boundary. Numerous ramps along this route would provide ready access
between the Harbor Route and the central business district at a number
of strategic points, notably close to the retail trade center, Charles Center,
the Civic Center, and the financial center.

Studies have shown that the bulk of central business district employ-
ment comes from the northeast, the north, and the northwest. The Har-
bor Route expressway system would provide improved access from the
northeast, while the completion of the inner ring would allow traffic com-
ing in from the north or northwest to choose expressways running along
the east boundary of the central business district or the west. Either
choice would merge with an expressway along the south of the central
business district.

It might be said that completion of the inner ring as part of the
Northern Route system would follow the same line along the western
side of the central business district between Mulberry and Pratt Streets
as is proposed for the Harbor Route and thus would permit equally good
access, at least to the retail trade center. A question of timing is involved,
however. If the Northern Route is used for the East-West Expressway
the Mulberry-Pratt connection to complete the inner ring would not be
built until some time thereafter. If the Harbor Route is selected the
Mulberry-Pratt Street connection would be built at a much earlier date
as part of the East-West Expressway. At a rough guess, the tie-in between
the retail trade center and the expressway system would come at least

S0

10 years earlier with the Harbor Route than with the Northern Route.

Even if no question of timing were involved, the Harbor Route would
still provide better access to the retail trade center than would the com-
pletion of the inner ring under the Northern Route system. Access from
the east and west would be no different, but traffic coming from the north
on the Jones Falls Expressway could not, as design is now proceeding,
turn right on the Northern Route. Jones Falls Expressway traffic headed
for the retail trade center would be forced to do one of three things:

(a) Leave the Jones Falls Expressway at 29th Street and proceed by
surface streets to a tie-in with the Northern Route at Cathedral
Street. (Sheet 20.)

(b) Follow all the way round the inner ring in a clock-wise direction
to about Lexington Street west of the retail trade center. This
would allow the trip to be made all on expressways but would
add two to three miles to the trip.

(c) Leave the Jones Falls Expressway at some intermediate point
(such as Lexington Street near the City Hall) and cross the
central business district on surface streets.

It is obvious that even after the inner ring is completed access from

the north to the retail trade center would be poorer under the Northern
Route system than under the Harbor Route system.

Benefits to the City’s Economy

Any improvement which increases accessibility between the various
sections of a metropolitan area is of benefit to the economy of the area,
and in this general sense either the Northern Route or the Harbor Route
would be helpful. More specifically, however, it is possible to isolate
certain key aspects of Baltimore’s economy and to discover significant
differences between the impact on these aspects of the two routes.

It might be said that completion of the inner ring as part of the
Northern Route system would follow the same line along the western
side of the central business district between Mulberry and Pratt Streets
as is proposed for the Harbor Route and thus would permit equally good
access, at least to the retail trade center. A question of timing is involved,
however. If the Northern Route is used for the East-West Expressway
the Mulberry-Pratt connection to complete the inner ring would not be
built until some time thereafter. If the Harbor Route is selected the
Mulberry-Pratt Street connection would be built at a much earlier date
as part of the East-West Expressway. At a rough guess, the tie-in between
the retail trade center and the expressway system would come at least

S0

10 years earlier with the Harbor Route than with the Northern Route.

Even if no question of timing were involved, the Harbor Route would
still provide better access to the retail trade center than would the com-
pletion of the inner ring under the Northern Route system. Access from
the east and west would be no different, but traffic coming from the north
on the Jones Falls Expressway could not, as design is now proceeding,
turn right on the Northern Route. Jones Falls Expressway traffic headed
for the retail trade center would be forced to do one of three things:

(a) Leave the Jones Falls Expressway at 29th Street and proceed by
surface streets to a tie-in with the Northern Route at Cathedral
Street. (Sheet 20.)

(b) Follow all the way round the inner ring in a clock-wise direction
to about Lexington Street west of the retail trade center. This
would allow the trip to be made all on expressways but would
add two to three miles to the trip.

(c) Leave the Jones Falls Expressway at some intermediate point
(such as Lexington Street near the City Hall) and cross the
central business district on surface streets.

It is obvious that even after the inner ring is completed access from

the north to the retail trade center would be poorer under the Northern
Route system than under the Harbor Route system.

Benefits to the City’s Economy

Any improvement which increases accessibility between the various
sections of a metropolitan area is of benefit to the economy of the area,
and in this general sense either the Northern Route or the Harbor Route
would be helpful. More specifically, however, it is possible to isolate
certain key aspects of Baltimore’s economy and to discover significant
differences between the impact on these aspects of the two routes.

field_edited_text_processed:
Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route





One of the most important—perhaps the most important—factor in
our economy is the port. The Northern Route has no particular relation-
ship to the port. The Harbor Route has a very definite connection. It
runs along the northern side of the harbor and, together with the proposed
Southwest Expressway, ties together many important port-oriented facili-
ties. The Port Authority is in the best position to appraise the value of
the Harbor Route to the port. After reviewing the plans it stated: “It was
unanimously agreed by the Commissioners that the route suggested would
enhance truck traffic serving the Port of Baltimore, and that the effect
of the expressway, at the proposed location, on the development of the
Port from the standpoint of the structure occupying and/or crossing cer-
tain waterfront properties would be minimal and would be far outweighed
by the port advantage accruing by the provision of the expressway along
this particular route.”

The greatest burden on our transportation system is imposed by the
trip from home to work in the early morning and from work to home in
the late afternoon. The relationship between expressways and sources of
employment is thus of considerable importance. Within the City there
are 330 manufacturing firms employing more than 40 employees. To-
gether these firms employ a total of about 75,000 persons. Eighty-six of
these firms employing 16,600 persons lie within 14 mile of the Northern
Route; 193 firms employing 34,200 persons lie within 15 mile of the
Harbor Route.

The central business district with approximately 95,000 employees
represents the largest single concentration of employment in the metro-
politan area. After making allowance for the effect of Charles Center on
employment distribution, the center of central business district employ-
ment will be virtually at Baltimore and Charles Streets. This point is
3 blocks from the Harbor Route; 10 blocks from the Northern Route.

51

While nearly all commercial and industrial firms are dependent upon
the movement of goods, the degree of dependency is greater for some
firms than for others. A study was made of certain types of firms which
by their nature are highly dependent upon their ability to distribute goods
within the metropolitan area or between Baltimore and other cities.

Of the 115 firms within the City engaged in intercity trucking 21
are located within 14 mile of the Northern Route; 70 within 14 mile of
the Harbor Route.?

A selection was made of a number of the more important firms en-
gaged in distribution within the metropolitan area. The location of each
of these firms was then checked in relationship to the two routes. The
results are shown in Table 1. It will be noticed that 114 of the firms are
within 14 mile of the Harbor Route while only 65 of the firms are within
15 mile of the Northern Route. Furthermore, the Harbor Route scores
higher for each category within the Table except that of movers and storers.

Also important to the economic life of the city and as generators of
truck traffic are the major points of transfer between trucks and railroads
and between trucks and ships. Thirteen such points were identified. Six
are within 15 mile of the Harbor Route; one within 14 mile of the North-
ern Route.

In the comparison presented above an effort has been made to select
factors which were both significant and also susceptible to quantitative
analysis. The results are not unexpected, however, since they are fully in
accord with the impression gained by noting on a land use map the close
proximity between the Harbor Route and the areas of major economic
importance to the City. There can be no doubt that the Harbor Route is
of greater value to the City’s economy than the Northern Route.



1 These and similar statistics quoted in this section cover firms from the western
City line to the eastern City line. Since certain sections of the two routes are
identical, certain firms may show up for each route.

Blighting Effect

Chapter IV discussed at some length the ways in which an express-
way could have a blighting effect upon adjacent areas and these ways are
grouped into five categories in Chapter V. Since in this Chapter we are
engaged in a comparison of two routes the discussion which follows does
not relate to the sections which are identical.

1. Extent to Which Each Route Splits Established Residential Areas:
The Northern Route clearly splits the Mt. Vernon area in two.
While the large residential area in East Baltimore between Green-
mount Avenue and Linwood Avenue does not have quite the same
sense of well established neighborhood identity as does the Mt.
Vernon area, the Northern Routes goes plowing through this sec-
tion with minimum adherence to any kind of neighborhood
boundary. At no point does the Harbor Route split an established
residential area.

2. Extent to Which Each Route Separates Areas Which for Eco-
nomic Reasons Should Be in Close Proximity: It appears that
neither route is guilty on this score. In each case there are ample
crossings in any section where crossings would be necessary or
desirable.

3. Proximity to High Grade Residential Areas: The nearest ap-
proach to this condition for either route would be the passage of
the Northern Route through the Mt. Vernon area. While the
extent to which this proximity would be blighting is debatable
there is no similar situation along the Harbor Route.

4. Proximity of Elevated Structures to Any Residential Areas: This
factor does not apply to either route from the point of divergence
to the Jones Falls Expressway, but does occur on each route east
of the Jones Falls Expressway. Along the Harbor Route resi-

-

field_edited_text_processed:
Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route

ooy yygdL





dential buildings on the north of Lancaster Street for a block and
a half west of Broadway will be about 75 feet from the express-
way which at this point is a single deck elevated structure. About
20 houses are involved. A few houses at two or three other points
in this general area would be about the same distance away.

Along the Northern Route the expressway is elevated for approxi-
mately a mile through a predominantly residential area running
from Bond Street to Kenwood Avenue. The distance between
the structure and nearby houses varies somewhat but would
seldom be over 60 feet and would be less in some places. No
count has been made of the number of adjacent houses, but it
would appear to be several hundred. In addition, there would be
some 20 to 30 houses in Armistead Gardens which might be un-
comfortably close to the expressway which again is elevated at
this point.

It is evident that proximity of elevated structures to residences
occurs to a much lesser extent along the Harbor Route than along
the Northern Route.

5. Close Proximity of Elevated Structures to Retail or Office Areas:
This situation does not exist on either route. While it might be
thought to occur on the Harbor Route where it runs between
Pratt and Camden Streets the clearance of all buildings between
these two streets will leave ample room for the elevated structure.
There will be approximately 150 feet between the buildings left
standing facing Pratt and Camden Streets and the main structure
of the expressway. The effect will be to open up the area and
the construction of the expressway should be an asset rather than
a liability to adjacent properties.





Number and Quality of Dwellings to be Demeolished

Total properties which would have to be acquired for the Northern
Route, the Harbor Route, and the sections in common are shown on
Table 2, divided between residential properties and commercial and in-
dustrial properties. Also shown are properties which would have to be
taken for the alternative methods of completing the inner ring. (Resi-
dential properties are defined as those wholly devoted to residential
purposes. A building with commercial use on the first floor and apart-
ments above would be classified as a commercial property.)

Omitting the sections in common, it will be seen that the Harbor
Route would require the acquisition of only 1,293 properties as against
2,729 for the Northern Route. Completing the inner ring with the
Harbor Route plan would also take fewer properties than completing
the inner ring using the Northern Route—510 properties against 1,089
properties.

L



The above figures give no indication of housing quality. The demo-
lition of one good building is obviously a wholly different matter from
the demolition of a slum building. Furthermore a count of residential
properties fails to indicate the number of dwellings to be torn down. Some
residential properties may contain more than one dwelling (one on the
Northern Route contains approximately 150) and some dwellings are
located in buildings not classified as residential structures. To cover both
points Table 3 presents a tabulation of dwellings along each route broken
down by sections and by estimated quality. The results are shown
graphically in Sheet 35. Good dwellings are those built since 1950 or
which appear obviously good from exterior inspection. Poor dwellings are
those listed as dilapidated or lacking private baths in the 1950 U. S. Hous-
ing Census. Fair dwellings are all others. These criteria for quality are
admittedly rough, but since the same criteria were applied against both
routes the comparisons are believed to be reasonably valid.

An inspection of Table 3 indicates that the Harbor Route scores
better on all counts. Omitting the sections which are common, total
dwellings are only 1,198 for the Harbor Route as against 3,593 for the
Northern Route. On the Northern Route 21.99% of the dwellings rate as
good; the corresponding figure for the Harbor Route is zero. 70.8% of the
dwellings on the Harbor Route are poor; only 24.99% are so classified on
the Northern Route.

Any public improvement involving the acquisition of property ad-
versely effects the tax rolls. The amount of assessed valuations of the
property to be taken for the two alternative expressway routes is therefore
a matter of concern.

Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route

U0 0L



Table 4 shows the assessed valuations by land and improvements for
the Harbor Route, the Northern Route, the sections in common, and for
the two alternative methods of completing the Inner Ring. It will be seen
that the advantage clearly lies with the Harbor Route. Assessments for
the Harbor Route are about 5% million dollars less than for the Northern
Route. Also, assessments for completing the Inner Ring with the Harbor
Route are 1% million dollars less than for completing the Inner Ring with
the Northern Route.

TABLE 4
ASSESSED VALUATION OF PROPERTIES TO BE ACQUIRED

PLanhar BRSO W e i $ 9,648,000
INOEERRER TS Ll e i s e S R $15,173,000
Bations 0 Comon . .. o 0. o v e i s b e $ 6,446,000
Completion of Inner Ring with Harbor Route............ $ 2,895,984
Completion of Inner Ring with Northern Route........... $ 4,468,490
Total Cost

The Northern Route from the western city line to its merger with the
Northeast Expressway close to the eastern city line has previously been
estimated to cost a total of $194,000,000, including right-of-way acqui-
sition. Total length is 10.2 miles.

No cost estimate has been prepared for the Harbor Route. It does
not appear, however, that its cost would be sufficiently different from the
Northern Route so that this factor should be important in arriving at a
decision between the two routes. Total length for the Harbor Route is
12.5 miles or 2.3 miles longer than the Northern Route. On the other

S5

hand, 3.0 miles of the Harbor Route represents a widening of the present
Harbor Tunnel entrance and the cost for this should be much less per
mile than for new expressway construction. New construction on the
Harbor Route is 0.7 mile less than for the Northern Route.

More of the Harbor Route is elevated than is the Northern Route
and as a general rule through highly developed areas elevated express-
ways tend to be less costly than depressed expressways. On the other
hand the Harbor Route includes one fairly extensive water crossing which
will be relatively expensive, and foundations along the edge of the harbor
may be costly.

A brief review of the Harbor Route by the Department of Public
Works indicates that there would be a number of intricate engineering
problems, the most costly being that of foundations along the Inner Har-
bor. The Department concludes that there are no engineering problems
involved that would be insurmountable. Nevertheless it would be advis-
able to have the engineering and cost aspects of the Harbor Route studied
by a qualified engineering firm. Such a study would probably be required
by the State Roads Commission before it gave approval.

If assessed valuations are a fair measure of comparative right-of-way
costs, land acquisition for the Harbor Route should be less than for the
Northern Route. On the other hand, the Harbor Route would probably
involve the payment of certain damages to the Baltimore Gas and Electric
Company, the Pennsylvania Railroad, and perhaps to the Esso Refinery.
These payments are not reflected in the assessment figures.

It could hardly be expected that either route could be built except as .
part of the National Interstate System with a 909 Federal subsidy. On
this basis either route should involve a local cost in the general range of
about $20,000,000.

estimated to cost a total of $194,000,000, including right-of-way acqui-
sition. Total length is 10.2 miles.

No cost estimate has been prepared for the Harbor Route. It does
not appear, however, that its cost would be sufficiently different from the
Northern Route so that this factor should be important in arriving at a
decision between the two routes. Total length for the Harbor Route is
12.5 miles or 2.3 miles longer than the Northern Route. On the other

S5

hand, 3.0 miles of the Harbor Route represents a widening of the present
Harbor Tunnel entrance and the cost for this should be much less per
mile than for new expressway construction. New construction on the
Harbor Route is 0.7 mile less than for the Northern Route.

More of the Harbor Route is elevated than is the Northern Route
and as a general rule through highly developed areas elevated express-
ways tend to be less costly than depressed expressways. On the other
hand the Harbor Route includes one fairly extensive water crossing which
will be relatively expensive, and foundations along the edge of the harbor
may be costly.

A brief review of the Harbor Route by the Department of Public
Works indicates that there would be a number of intricate engineering
problems, the most costly being that of foundations along the Inner Har-
bor. The Department concludes that there are no engineering problems
involved that would be insurmountable. Nevertheless it would be advis-
able to have the engineering and cost aspects of the Harbor Route studied
by a qualified engineering firm. Such a study would probably be required
by the State Roads Commission before it gave approval.

If assessed valuations are a fair measure of comparative right-of-way
costs, land acquisition for the Harbor Route should be less than for the
Northern Route. On the other hand, the Harbor Route would probably
involve the payment of certain damages to the Baltimore Gas and Electric
Company, the Pennsylvania Railroad, and perhaps to the Esso Refinery.
These payments are not reflected in the assessment figures.

It could hardly be expected that either route could be built except as .
part of the National Interstate System with a 909 Federal subsidy. On
this basis either route should involve a local cost in the general range of
about $20,000,000.

field_edited_text_processed:
Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route



Significant or Important Properties

The Northern Route would involve the acquisition of 6 churches as
follows:

Orchard Street Methodist Episcopal Church—>510 Orchard Street

New Jerusalem Church—Calvert & Chase Streets

Mt. Sinai Baptist Church—922 East Preston Street

Memorial Baptist Church—1301 North Caroline Street

Southern Baptist Church—Bond & Preston Streets

Israel Baptist Church—1230 North Chester Street

While there are some churches of the store front variety along the
Harbor Route there are no regular church buildings.

The Northern Route would take the Richmond Market building as
well as the small group of remodeled dwellings along Tyson Street.

To ascertain which other buildings on both routes might be of some
consequence, buildings having an improvement assessment of $50,000 or
more were sorted out. Table 5 lists those buildings in this category on
the Northern Route; Table 6 shows similar buildings on the Harbor Route.

Of the six buildings on the Northern Route assessed at $50,000 or
over, all give the impression of being relatively new and in good shape.
Even the apartment house at 1001 St. Paul Street, which goes back to
1927, appears relatively modern. The highest assessment, $840,000, be-
longs to 1010 St. Paul Street, an apartment house less than 10 years old.
This assessment is more than three times the next largest assessment on
either route.

On the Harbor Route there are twelve buildings assessed at $50,000
or over, or twice as many as on the Northern Route. For the most part,
however, these buildings give the impression of being old and obsolete.
Two are wholly vacant warehouses. It is understood that the Joseph M.
Zamoiski Company is building a new warehouse and it is therefore as-

56

sumed that the very large but ancient building which this firm now
occupies will also be vacant fairly soon.
From an exterior inspection there are only four buildings on the
Harbor Route which appear to be of real significance:
a. The Hutzler warehouse at 719-725 West Lombard Street. A
fairly old building but large and apparently in good condition.
b. The old Sharp and Dohme plant in the 300 block of West Pratt
Street which is now in dual ownership. One portion, 309-317
West Pratt Street, is presently occupied by Stewart’s warehouse
and has an improvement assessment of $50,000. The other por-
tion, 319-321 West Pratt Street, is occupied by John C. Stalfort
& Sons, Inc., manufacturing chemists. The Stalfort portion has
an improvement assessment of $40,000. The combined building
is a fairly substantial six-story structure. Its exact age is un-
known, but it would appear to be about forty years old.

Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route



Summary

From the above discussion it appears clear that the Harbor Route is
superior to the Northern Route on these counts:
Benefits to traffic
Stimulus to new building or redevelopment in adjacent areas
Benefits to central business district
Benefits to the City’s economy
Blighting effect
Number and quality.of dwellings to be demolished
Assessed Valuations
For the following factors there appears to be no decisive difference
between the two routes:
Total Cost
Significant or important properties to be taken.
There is no factor for which the Harbor Route is significantly in-
ferior to the Northern Route.
The obvious conclusion is that from a planning point of view the
Harbor Route is a better location for the East-West Expressway than the
Northern Route.

S8

field_edited_text_processed:
X. THE BALANCE SHEET

Earlier in this report it was stated that the decision to proceed with
an expressway must depend not only upon the general advantages of
expressways, but also upon the pros and cons of a specific route. Having
reached the conclusion that the Harbor Route is the best location for the
East-West Expressway it remains to balance the price of an expressway
along this route against the advantages to determine whether the East-
West Expressway should be built at all.

Price of an East-West Expressway along the Harbor Route

While no cost estimate has been made of an East-West Expressway
along the Harbor Route the bulk of the cost will be absorbed by the
Federal Government. The cost to the City will probably be in the range
of $20,000,000.

Taxable private property which would have to be acquired for right-
of-way purposes has a present assessed valuation of approximately $16,-
000,000. Assuming a tax rate of $3.50 the construction of the expressway
would produce an apparent loss of real estate taxes of $560,000 per year.
This would be reduced, however, by the extent to which property owners
invested the proceeds of sales in new construction within the City. Such
investment would certainly occur to some extent but it would be impos-
sible to predict the degree to which it might happen. In addition, studies
in other cities have indicated that expressways which are well located
usually increase substantially the value and the assessed valuation of
adjacent properties. Should this happen in Baltimore, and there is every
reason to expect that it would within the nonresidential areas adjacent to
the Harbor Route, the loss in assessed valuation might be largely or wholly
cancelled out.

The East-West Expressway along the Harbor Route would require
the demolition of a large number of buildings. The total number would

59

ooy oygd

be 2705, of which 2020 are wholly residential and 685 are commercial,
industrial or mixed. However, most of the buildings are old and obsolete,
and many are dilapidated or slums. As noted in detail in the previous
chapter only a handful are of any significance.

As a matter of fact, not only would the clearance of many of the
buildings along the proposed route not harm the City, one can go further
and say that their removal would be advantageous. The blocks between
Mulberry and Franklin Streets running from Monroe Street to Fremont
Avenue are a good example. These blocks are a part of the Harlem Park
Urban Renewal Area and are earmarked in the Harlem Park Urban Re-
newal Plan for clearance for the East-West Expressway. If the City
should decide to abandon the expressway it is highly probable that the
Harlem Park Plan would continue to propose clearance for most of the
buildings in these blocks based upon their poor condition. The same
conclusion can be reached for most of the buildings along the Harbor
Route from Fremont Avenue to Light Street. All of these are within the
Downtown Renewal Area and if the East-West Expressway were given up
the applicable urban renewal plans would almost certainly involve the
clearance of most of these structures. In other words, wholly apart from
the expressway, the buildings along the proposed route all the way from
Monroe Street to Light Street are in such shape that a large measure of
clearance would be indicated in any event. This stretch includes two-
thirds of all of the buildings which would have to be cleared if the East-
West Expressway were built along the Harbor Route.

One other price would have to be paid—namely, a very large amount
of relocation both by families and by commercial firms. There is no point
in ignoring this problem, but it is fair to note that by proper planning it
can be spread over a number of years and that the Urban Renewal and
Housing Agency’s Relocation Service would be availgble to assist. In no

field_edited_text_processed:
The Balance Sheet





ring be completed using one of the methods proposed in this Report
(or a variation thereof) and that further study be made of the possibility
of an expressway connection designed to serve the northeast.

To carry out these recommendations the Planning Commission pro-
poses that the following specific steps be undertaken:

1. The recommendations contained in this Report are based pri-
marily upon planning considerations. While engineering feasibility
has been explored to the extent possible within our limited
resources a more exhaustive study of this aspect is needed. Such
a study will probably be required in any event by the State Roads
Commission and by the Federal Government. It is therefore pro-
posed that the City immediately employ a qualified engineering
firm to report on the engineering feasibility of the Harbor Route
and of the completion of the inner ring. Such a report should
include cost estimates and should carry preliminary design work
to the point of permitting definite taking lines to be determined
to serve as the basis of a condemnation ordinance.

2. Design work to date on the Jones Falls Expressway has indicated
the need for improved administrative machinery to secure a better
degree of coordination between the various City departments in-
volved. It is therefore recommended that a team be organized
made up of staff representatives of the Department of Public
Works, the Department of Transit and Traffic, the Department of
Planning, and perhaps the State Roads Commission. It would
be the function of this team to work closely with the engineering
firm employed to make the feasibility study mentioned above and
also to guide the work of the engineers making the final design.
While such a team cannot assume the responsibility for final
decisions which must remain with the heads of the departments

62

involved, nevertheless, experience in other cities has indicated
that it can be effective in promoting cocrdination, reducing delays
and improving the quality of the final plans.

. The availability of funds is such that large-scale work on the

East-West Expressway cannot start until the Jones Falls Express-
way is completed. Nevertheless, if the engineering feasibility
report is favorable it is strongly recommended that City Council
endorsement of the Harbor Route be sought at the earliest
possible moment. The uncertainty that has surrounded the East-
West Expressway for more than a decade has worked a hardship
on many property owners and has been harmful to the City. A
firm agreement on future expressway plans would be of great
help to the entire City.

to the point of permitting definite taking lines to be determined
to serve as the basis of a condemnation ordinance.

2. Design work to date on the Jones Falls Expressway has indicated
the need for improved administrative machinery to secure a better
degree of coordination between the various City departments in-
volved. It is therefore recommended that a team be organized
made up of staff representatives of the Department of Public
Works, the Department of Transit and Traffic, the Department of
Planning, and perhaps the State Roads Commission. It would
be the function of this team to work closely with the engineering
firm employed to make the feasibility study mentioned above and
also to guide the work of the engineers making the final design.
While such a team cannot assume the responsibility for final
decisions which must remain with the heads of the departments

62

involved, nevertheless, experience in other cities has indicated
that it can be effective in promoting cocrdination, reducing delays
and improving the quality of the final plans.

. The availability of funds is such that large-scale work on the

East-West Expressway cannot start until the Jones Falls Express-
way is completed. Nevertheless, if the engineering feasibility
report is favorable it is strongly recommended that City Council
endorsement of the Harbor Route be sought at the earliest
possible moment. The uncertainty that has surrounded the East-
West Expressway for more than a decade has worked a hardship
on many property owners and has been harmful to the City. A
firm agreement on future expressway plans would be of great
help to the entire City.

INTRODUCTION

Development Area 12 is an office building site in Charles Center. In offer -
ing this area now, the Baltimore Urban Renewal and Housing Agency makes
available another of the most attractive investment opportunities in dOWIl'-’:
town Baltimore, at a time when Charles Center's development is assured.
Three buildings have been completed, five are under construction, and four
more are about to start construction. The Civic Center, containing a
13,000-seat coliseum and 100,000 square feet of exhibition space, and
facing Area 12 across Hopkins Place, was opened in October, 1962.

Within Charles Center, Area 12 is located to take full advantage of the
long-term investment safeguards that have been designed into the basic
Charles Center plan--high density of development, open space, and care-
fully controlled flows of pedestrian and auto traffic. Moreover, the de-
velopment of area 12 will be tightly linked to other portions of Charles
Center and to the major existing elements of Downtown Baltimore. Thus,
Area 12 has been designed to share fully in the potential generated by
Charles Center, the Civic Center, and the several other revitalization pro-
grams underway for all of Baltimore's central business district.

Charles Center is the keystone of Baltimore's plans for its central core,
where private and public interests are making a concerted effort of re-
vitalization and improvement. This program includes the Civic Center,
the Mount Vernon Urban Renewal Project, a downtown campus for the Uni-
versity of Maryland professional schools, Monument Square and Court
House Plaza, an expressway network, and the proposed redevelopment of
the Inner Harbor. Among the other renewal projects close to Charles
Center are two industrial parks for expansion of close-in areas for whole-
saling trades and light industries. In 1965, the Metropolitan Transit
Authority will present a comprehensive plan for publictransportation con-
taining major implications for downtown as an elementof the unifiedmetro-
politan area.

Throughout the entire Downtown revitalization program, public and private
efforts have been focused and coordinated at all levels. Today, the City of
Baltimore, acting through its Urban Renewal and Housing Agency, invites
your interest regarding Charles Center Development Area 12. The agencies
of City government, together with business and civic groups, are ready to
help you measure your opportunity and express your interest in the unique
investment advantages afforded by Charles Center.

A, LOCATION AND ADJACENT DEVELOPMENTS



Development Area 12 is located to the southeast of the intersection
of Baltimore Street and Hopkins Place, at the corner of a new Charles
Center superblock. i

A major asset of Area 12 is the public square to the south and east
of the site (see plan and photo on pages 25 and frontispiece). The plaza will
be builtover an 800-car self-service undergroundparking garage currently
under construction. Also under construction are the other buildings bor-
dering the public square: a 1500-1800 seat legitimate theatre with 39, 000
to 65,000 square feet of retail area and at least 150 public parking spaces;
a high-rise home office building for the Sun Life Insurance Company of
America; and a Federal Office Building containing approximately 460, 000
square feet of office space and an underground parking garage for 185 gov-
ernment vehicles.

Across Baltimore Street to the north will be a new Hilton Hotel and
to the northeast is the existing Lord Baltimore Hotel. Directly west, across
Hopkins Place, lies the Civic Center, which contains a 13, 000 seat colis-
eum, 100,000 square feet of exhibition space, meeting rooms and banquet
facilities. Both of these developments will be connected with Area 12 by
the Charles Center upper level walkway system.

B. A PLANNED DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT



Charles Center is planned with design and building controls in ac-
cordance with the most modern development practice. Each investor is
assured that subsequent developers will provide a suitable and harmonious
environment, consistent with the long range goals of Charles Center: the
best possible development of interrelated land uses, buildings and spaces,
working together to create the greatest possible return both to private de-
velopers and to the City, in terms of revenue, prestige, and design.

C. SITE DEFINITION



The property is '"L'" shaped, as shown on page 10. It contains
59,486.13 square feet, or 1.37 acres, more or less, with more than 500
feet of park frontage, the same amount of street frontage and more than 300
feet of second level walkway frontage. For the precise metes and bounds
description, see page I-2 of the Proposed Form of Disposition Agreement.

field_edited_text_processed:
D. PRIGE

The price of Area 12 is One Million Two Hundred Fifty Thousand
Dollars ($1,250,000.00), subject to the provisions of the Proposed Form
of Disposition Agreement. (For a summary of the major provisions, see
pages 9-15 herein.)

E. DEMOLITION AND SITE PREPARATION



The City has prepared the Site for delivery. Demolition has in-
cluded removing all parts of buildings and structures to approximate grade
of adjacent existing streets and alleys. Basement floors have been broken
to provide drainage and basements have been backfilled and utility lines
abandoned or relocated.

F. SITE DELIVERY AND DEVELOPMENT



Development Area 12 will be available for delivery on or after
January 1, 1966, and the Site will be turned over to the Developer in the
condition described in paragraph Eabove. Prior to that time, the selected
developer may make arrangements for entry on the site for engineering
surveys, test borings and other investigations desired by his representa-
tives.

| Upon delivery, the site will be ready for development in accordance
with the Charles Center Urban Renewal Plan and the terms of the dispo-
sition agreement between the City and the Developer.

G. ZONING

The Site, like all of Charles Center, is zoned First Commerical
Use District.

H. TOPOGRAPHY AND UTILITIES



The City's Bureau of Surveys has completed a detailed fieldsurvey
of existing conditions in and around the entire Charles Center Site. No
major change in the grades of:Lombard, Charles and Baltimore Streets or
Hopkins Place is planned. For spot elevations of adjacent streets and de-
velopment, see Exhibit entitled, Site Definition, page 10.



Utilities are available in adjacent streets subject to the usual ar-
rangements with the City and with the various private utility companies.
Details may be obtained from the responsible City Bureau and/or private
utility company.

II. STANDARDS AND CONTROLS

»



The following standards and controls represent a summary of major pro-
visions in the Proposed Form of Disposition Agreement. They are in-
cluded here solelyfor the convenience of prospective developers interested
in submitting proposals for development, and should not be construed as
representing all of the requirements in that Agreement. The standards an’&
controls listed below are illustrated on, and refer to, the exhibits on pages
10 and 14.

A, TYPES OF FACILITIES



The following uses will be permitted in Development Area 12:

Office Building Facilities

Facilities for Retailing, Retail Services, and Related
Commercial Activities

Tenant Parking Facilities

Commercial Public Parking Facilities

B. SIZE OF FACILITIES



Minimum net rentable office space - 250,000 square feet
Maximum net rentable office space - 300,000 square feet
Retail space - In Area '"B'", a minimum of 38,000 square feet
at or above ground level; in Area "F', a mini-
mum of 12,000 square feet and a maximum of
24,000 square feet at or above ground level.
Minimum tenant parking - 150 normal size auto spaces

C. HEIGHT AND COVERAGE LIMITATIONS (including setbacks andease-
ments)



1. 100% coverage is permitted up to sidewalk grades; coverage
above sidewalk grades is controlled by height and coverage
limitations described below under Items #3 and #4 below.

2. There are no depth restrictions; the substructure must be de-
signed to protect adjacent structures, streets, and utilities.
For the construction depth of the garage in Area 14, see the
Exhibit on the opposite page.

3. No structure or part thereof shall exceed El. 350"'.

The Developer may utilize AIR RIGHTS above the
Baltimore Street sidewalk from El. 57'to El. 75';
however, only that portion of the available air
rights actually utilized by proposed building con-

struction will be conveyed by deed tothe developer. :

»
Within this area, a TOWER may be built with cov-
erage not to exceed 30% of the entire property (i.e.
17,846 square feet) and not to exceed El. 350" in
height; the remainder of this area, outside of ac-

tual tower coverage, shall not exceed El. 75' in

height.

Perpetual easement to be retained at and above
ground level by the City for public pedestrian use.
Private vehicular access (ramp and tunnel) must
be provided as shown on the ''Site Definition'' draw-
ingand will be permitted within the easement area.
No structures will be permitted at or above side-
walk grades except for necessary ramp walls and
railings, the Hopkins Place overpass and its nec-
essary supports (see "REQUIREMENTS" below)
and landscape design elements.

The City will retain a perpetual easement over this
area for public pedestrian access at and above
El. 44' on the east and at and above sidewalk grade
on the west; no structures will be permitted above
these elevations except for required second-level
walkway at El. 59'f, and any necessary supports
and roof, railings and stairs, and landscape design
elements.

This area is a setback from Hopkins Place; no
structures are permitted above adjacent sidewalk
and Park (Area 14A) grades except for upper-level
walkway at El. 59'f, and any necessary supports
and roof, railings andstairs, and landscape design
elements.

No structure, or part thereof, will be permitted
above El. 90'; in any case, no more than two full
floors will be permitted.

The City will lease to the developer, for One Dol-
lar ($1.00) a year until March 25, 1999, the nec-
essary rights to allow him to construct and main-
tain the required egress ramp and tunnel in the
right-of-way of Hopkins Place.

D. REQUIREMENTS



1. The Developer shall provide and maintain a public upper-level
walkway to connect with the Hopkins Place overpass and with

outdoor public use.

Pedestrian access is available along the entire west and north pro-
perty lines at sidewalk elevations of Hopkins Place and Baltimore Street
and from the Public Park on the south and east at approximate El. 44'. In
addition, access is available along the entire length of the upper-level walk-
way (approximate El. 59'), which will connect on the west to the Civic
Center and on the east and north to the legitimate theater, the new hotel
and the rest of Charles Center extending north to Saratoga Street.

Vehicular access will be solely through ramps and tunnels in Hopkins
Place, as shown on Exhibit entitled, Site Definition, page 10. No vehicular
access will be permitted from or to Baltimore Street.
