F. SERVICING, WASTE DISPOSAL, AND EXTERIOR STORAGE





All service activities and facilities shall be provided by the De-
veloper within the structure and entirely below grade El. 44'. :

All waste shall be stored within the structure below grade EL. 44'
and shall be completely screened from public view. Collections will not be !
permitted from the street.

g No exterior storage of a permanent or temporary nature will be
permitted.

H. ARCHITECTURAL COOR DINA TION



To help establish conditions for coordination and excellence of de-
sign throughout the Project, the Agency has created an architectural review
process. This process is carried out with the benefit of expert architectu-
ral advice from a board consisting of:

Pietro Belluschi, Dean
School of Architecture and Planning,
Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Joseph Hudnut, Dean Emeritus
Graduate School of Design, Harvard University

G. Holmes Perkins, Dean
The Graduate School of Fine Arts, University of Pennsylvania

David A. Wallace, Professor of City Planning
Department of City Planning, The Graduate School of Fine Arts,
University of Pennsylvania

Final Preliminary Plans and Specifications and Final Working
Drawings and Specifications for all Charles Center developments (including
landscape design, lighting and signs) must be reviewed and approved by the
Agency, after advice from the Architectural Review Board.

III. DISPOSITION POLICY AND PROCEDURE



The following' Disposition Policy and Procedure for Development Area 12
has been formally adopted by the Commission of the Baltimore Urban Re-
newal and Housing Agency. All specific requirements which must be met
by a developer in submitting a proposal will be found in this Section IIIL.

A. DISPOSITION POLICIES APPLICABLE TO DEVELOPMENT AREA 12,
CHARLES CENTER



1. Basic Objectives of the Agency. The objectives of the Agency
in offering Development Area 12 are to secure the best possible
development in the.interests of the City, as determined by the
Agency, and a price for the land which is not less than its fair
value.



2. Conformance with the Plan. The disposition documents conform
to the Urban Renewal Plan for Charles Center, as amended.



3. Selection of Developer. Each proposal will be reviewed and
evaluated in order to select the bestarchitecturaland functional
design submitted by a qualified developer. The selection pro-
cess willinvolve detailed consideration of the quality of the de-
velopment proposed by each developer, and the identity of the
developer and his qualifications. A qualified developer is one
who, in the opinion of the Agency, has the necessary experience
and financial resources to enable him to complete the develop-
ment of Area 12 within the prescribed time limits. The selec-
tionprocess will be designed toavoid having interested develop-
ers make extensive expenditures for preparation of proposals,
since only a single developer will eventually be selected.



4, Cooperation with Developers Throughout the Entire Development
Program. Disposition documents will recognize the continuing
interest which developers and the Agency share throughout the
development process. The Agency will require that each de-
velopment harmonize with other developments in Charles Center,
and will require that each developer cooperate in an architec-
tural review process designed to achieve this objective.

v.' "‘

Contacts with Developers Prior to Formal Offerings. Prior to



the formal offering of any area in Charles Center, the Agency
has been, and will be, contacted by potential redevelopers in-
terested in the project. The Agency invites such contacts and
will cooperate in every way with developers making such con-
tacts. In these contacts, the Agency will make it clear from the
outset that no advance commitments will be made prior to the .
selection of a developer by the Commission of the Baltimore -
Urban Renewal and Housing Agency.

B. DISPOSITION PROCEDURE FOR DEVELOPMENT AREA 12, CHARLES
CENTER

%

The offering of DevelopmentArea 12 has been publicly announced
throughnewspaper and other advertising. Interested developers
are invited to write the Agency and request the offering docu--
ments for the area. The offering documents are available at
$5.00 a set, and describe the procedures to be followed by de-
velopers whoare interested in submitting proposals for Area 12.
These are detailed in the following paragraphs.

In reply to a written request for the offering documents, in-
cluding a check for the proper amount($5.00 per set requested),
the Agency will send the following items to a prospective de-
veloper:

a. An offering prospectus, in the form of a brochure contain-
ing:

i. Statement of Disposition Policy and Procedure;

ii. Details of the property offered;

iii. Standards and controls which will be applied to the site,
and a summary of other requirements in the disposition
agreement;

iv. Site definition drawings;

v. Other information which may be of interest to a pros-
pective developer, concerning topography, utilities,
street plans, adjacent development, etc;

vi. A list of the information which must be submitted by a
developer wishing to make a proposal for the develop-
ment of Area 12.

b. A copy of the form of disposition agreement that the City
intends to enter into with the developer who is ultimately
selected for Development Area 12;

c. Preliminary subsoil test results for the Charles Center
Project area, prepared by Deleuw, Cather & Company, con-
sulting engineers. This report was published in 1960, and
is not warranted by the City to reflect the current detailed
subsoil conditions in.the Charles Center Project.

field_edited_text_processed:
d. A copy of the Urban Renewal Plan adopted for the Charles
Center Project by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore,
as amended.

The Agency will require thateach prospective developer submit,
in writing, a proposal containing information regarding the de-
veloper and the development he proposes, in accordance with the
section of this Prospectus entitled, ""Information to be Submitted
by a Developer'. This information must be received before
4:30 p.m., August 27, 1965, and no proposals received after
that date will be given consideration. After 4:30 p.m., August
27, 1965, no attempt will be made to withhold the names of those
submitting proposals. However, financial reports and similar
data submitted with the proposal will be treated as confidential.

During the period when proposals are being accepted, no oral

interpretation of the Agency's requirements will be given to any
prospective developer. Requests for interpretation maybe made
to the Charles Center Management Office, and all replies giving
such interpretation will be issued as addenda to all prospective
developers. Such requests for interpretation must be received
by the Charles Center Management Office prior to 4:30p.m., on
July 28. Requests received after that time cannot be answered.

When the announced cut-off date has been reached (4:30 p.m.,
August 27), the Agency will consider the submission made with
eachproposal, in order to select the best architecturaland func-
tional design submitted by a qualified developer.





The selection will be made by the Commission of the Baltimore
Urban Renewal and Housing Agency, after receiving the recom-
mendations of the Architectural Review Board for Charles Cen-
ter (see page 15 herein). The selection of the Commission will
be final, and will be announced within 60 days after the cut-off
date for receiving proposals. Upon announcing the selection, no
attempt will be made* to withhold the architectural designs sub-
mitted with each proposal.

If, after reviewing the proposals submitted, as set forth inPara-
graph 5 above, the Commission finds that two or more designs
submitted by qualified developers are substantially equal in merit,
the Agency will then:

a. Inform the developers submitting those designs of the situa-
tion; and

b. Indicate that, on the basis of the designs submitted, the

property will be sold to the highest bidder among them, by
sealed bid procedure to be determined by the Agency.

ecuted by the developer and made public under the urban
renewal regulations of the Federal government.

b. Redeveloper's Statement’of Qualifications and Financial Re-
sponsibility, to be executed by the developer and retained
in the files of the Agency and the Federal Government under
the urban renewal regulations of the Federal Government.

c. Proposed Form of Disposition Agreement. -
Copies of the two Redeveloper's Statement Forms are available
from the Charles Center Management Office upon request, if a
prospective developer wishes to examine them in advance. The
developer shall return the statements and Agreement, properly
executed, to the Agency within 30 days of their receipt by the
developer. The Agency will then seek the necessary Federal
and localapprovals of the dispositionof Area 12 to the developer
and recommend the execution of the Agreement by the City.
Failure by the developer to return the statements and Agreement,
properly executed, within the 30-day period may result in the
withdrawal of the Agency's offer.

In the event no acceptable proposals are received by the Agency
within the designated time limit, then the Agency reserves the
right to negotiate exclusively with the prospective developer who
first submits an acceptable proposal.

IV. INFORMATION TO BE SUBMITTED BY A DEVELOPER
WISHING TO MAKE A PROPOSAL FOR DEVELOPMENT
OF AREA 12, CHARLES CENTER

Listed below are the items of information and design which must be sub-
mitted by all individuals and firms wishing to enter the competition for the
purchase and development of Development Area 12 in Charles Center. The
development of Area 12 will take place in accordance with all existing City
Codes and the provisions of the Proposed Form of Disposition Agreement,
including the standards and controls summarized on pages 9 through 15 of
this Prospectus.

All proposals from developers must be complete in every respect and de-
livered to the Charles Center Management Office, One Charles Center, Bal-
timore, Maryland 21201, prior to 4:30 p.m., August 27, 1965. This has
been established as the official cut-off date for receipt of proposals from
developers. Requests for interpretation of any portion of the offering docu-

- ments may be made to the Charles Center Management Office prior to
4:30 p.m. on July 28, 1965. Requests received after that date cannot be
“answered. All replies giving interpretations will be issued as written ad-

denda to all prospective developers and will be issued no later than August
4, 1965.

In order to be considered by the Agency, a proposal must contain ten (10)
copies of each item of the informiation and exhibits listed below.

Any proposals which do not contain all of the information below, and/or
which are received after the cut-off date, will not be eligible for consider-
ation by the Agency. Subsequent tothis cut-off date, the Agency will be un-
able to accept any changes, or additional or supplemental information, un-
less such material is requested by the Agency. All proposals from de-
velopers must be complete in themselves, and the Agency will not accept
any oral presentations to supplement the written submission.

Only the items specified below may be submitted. Any other materials
(suchas renderings, models, etc.) which may be submitted by a prospective
developer will not be considered in the selection of the winning design, but
will be returned to the developer at his expense.

V. SIGNS IN CHARLES CENTER, PROCEDURE AND GUIDELINES



(For information only. The developer who is selected will be required to
comply with the procedures below. For sign information to be submitted as
part of a competitive proposal see page 24 herein).

A. Thedesign of all signs must be submitted to the Charles Center Manage-
ment Office for approval at least 30 days prior to erection. The fol-
lowing information is to be submitted:

1

Design of the sign must be made clear, through the submission

of dimensional drawings specifying materials, type face of let-
ters and color. A section through theletters must be submitted,
showing supporting structures and the method of fastening. The
location of the disconnect switch must also be shown.

Location of the sign must be shown in accurate proportion on an

overall elevation drawing of the building. If other signs appear,

or are contemplated, on this same elevation, these also should
be shown in accurate proportion, with materials and colors in-
dicated.

I1lumination of ‘the sign must be clearly indicated, with details

as to type, color and intensity of lighting elements.

B, E)ach sign submission will be considered separately, since the archi-
tectural circumstances will vary in each case; however the following
rules will be applied to all signs:

3

2.

No flashing or revolving signs will be permitted.

5
No audible or odor emitting signs or signs with moving parts
will be permitted.

Exposed light sources will not be permitted, unless justified by
aesthetic consideration.

No signs or lettering will be permittedon the fascia of an over-
head walkway, or to be hung from the soffit of a second level
walkway.

No signs will be permitted which project beyond the building

lines, except in the case of lettering mounted flush on the build-
ing, and in this case, only where no other solution is possible.

26

precedented circumstances provide sufficient justification.

THIS IS
" CHARLES



GENTER

, BALTIMORE









Ty

(2 e

el




o



| Gift of

| Charles Center, as seen from the north.

It is the first Urban Renewal Project
for Downtown Baltimore. With it,
Downtown accepts the challenge of

tomorrow with a bold venture.

Here, in one plan, at Downtown’s Center,
are green parks, elegant and imposing
buildings, convenient and adequate
parking, efficient traffic and transit, and
exciting things to do, see, and hear.
Charles Center is truly a contrast with

the area we know today.

Into the planning for this project have
gone the combined and coordinated
efforts of private and public groups'
working together toward the revitalization
of all Downtown. Out of it will come a

new focus for Downtown.

Though simple in concept, Charles
Center brings to the solution of Down-
town’s problems all of the accumulated
knowledge of many fields. You will see
how Charles Center evolves as a logical
plan . . .. how it ties in with and sets the
stage for the Downtown Master Plan . . ..
how Charles Center will be financed . . . .

how it will be carried out.

You will see how Charles Center benefits
you as a private citizen . . . . and how it
i1s necessary to Baltimore, as an urban

center.

Looking east across Liberty Street from Park and
Lexington Streets.

You are a convention visitor in Charles
Center. From your window high up in
the new 800-room hotel, you look out
southeast toward the Inner Harbor. Be-
low you, the taxis move in and out of
the Lord Baltimore Hotel. People move
back and forth across Baltimore Street
on the pedestrian overpass with the
bright glitter of flags in front of the
3,000-seat Theater and TV Center
where you enjoyed a concert last night.
The Federal Office Building towers
over the Transportation Park where
people hustle down escalators to the
Transportation Terminal that was put
into operation two vyears ago. You
brought your wife to this convention
for you knew she would enjoy the
luxurious comfort of the quarters, the
fine food, and the charm and grace of
Baltimore, in Charles Center.

You are a businessman in Charles
Center. Your spacious air-conditioned
office is in one of the eight new office
towers, the last of which was just com-
pleted. You find it easier to get top-
flight personnel who like to work in this
delightful atmosphere. You drive to
work on the Jones Falls Expressway,
coming off the ramp at Pratt Street
which leads you quickly to the entrance
to the underground parking space re-
served for you. You come by elevator
directly to your building. The majority

‘Qf your fellow workers use the improved

transit system which funnels in and out
of the two transit depots and the Trans-
portation Terminal. At quitting time
transit vehicles are ganged up waiting
to take them home.

You are a shopper in Charles Center.
You have come Downtown by “shoppers
special”, quickly and comfortably on
the completed expressway system. As
you walk east on the Lexington Mall
from the major department store center
at Howard Street, you see the escalator
at the end of the Mall leading over
Liberty Street into Charles Center.
Many of Baltimore’s fine old specialty
shops offer you the opportunity for a
wider selection of goods than you can
get anywhere else. You are impressed
with what has been done in remodelling
the stores on the edge of Charles Cen-
ter. The new enhances the old where
the old has life and quality. Downtown
is just as pleasant and as efficient as

-your regional shopping center and it’s

exciting getting back Downtown again.

a businessman,
or a shopper in Charles Center,

the focus of
the new Downtown Baltimore.

traffic jams, noise

were once all too familiar.

Downtown environment.

BALTIMORE ST
REDWOOD ST















LOMBARD ST.









HOPKINS PLACE

/1 1 [

Charles Center is a 22-acre project for the heart of Downtown. It contains
eight new office buildings, including a new Federal Office Building, a new 800-
room hotel, 400,000 square feet of commercial and specialty retail space, a 3,000-

k. g seat 'T'V Theater Center, a Transportation Terminal and two transit depots,
three public parks, integrated pedestrian malls, and a 4,000-car underground
parking garage.

“ e VERTICAL CIRCULATION *The mark ' denotes the elevation above the mean high tide at the Inner Harbor



LOMBARD ST.

DETAILED SITE PLAN

The Charles Center site slopes from a high point—88'*
above the water level at the Inner Harbor—at Saratoga
and Liberty Streets, all the way to the low point, 20’, at
Lombard and Charles Streets. T hese grades have always
made walking difficult Downtown. In Charles Center,
they have become an asset. Look at the plans in detail.

88’ Begin at the 88" level which extends along Saratoga
Street from the Eglin Parking Garage to Charles Street. A
public park faces St. Paul’'s Episcopal Church across Charles
Street and forms a broad entry into the north end of Charles
Center. On the west and south sides of this park, retail and
commercial frontage forms the ground floor of the north office
tower (1). An arcade leads south to the transit depot at the
next level down, reached by escalator, South of the transit
depot, but still on the 88’ level, more commercial space forms
the base of the second office tower overlooking the public park
to its south.

70’ Underneath the public park at Saratoga Street is a
parking garage at the 70" level. Ramps lead out to a widened
Sharp Street. South of this parking garage is retail space on
either side of the Clay Street transit depot. Buses pull in off
Liberty Street, and move on out to the north on Charles. A
major arcade leads south under office building (2) out to the
main Lexington Mall to the west, At this point the Gallery, or
walkway, is faced on the north by retail space running from
Charles and Lexington Streets, all the way to Liberty and
Lexington. The Gallery meets Charles Street at its present
grade, but extends over Liberty Street with an overpass and
an escalator down toward the main shopping center at Howard
and Lexington Streets.

The Gaﬁery forms a major structural element tying together
retail space at office building (8) and retail and commercial
space at this same level under office building (4). Office build-
ing (5) spans Fayette Street and the Gallery carries pedestrians
over Fayette beside it and to the south of office building (3).
These two overpasses connect with the north side of the Lord
Baltimore Hotel and with retail and commercial space at the
70" level in the new hotel. Between the two hotels, a moving
sidewalk takes them over Baltimore Street and onto the Gallery
which surrounds the southern public park.

58’ Starting again at the north end of Charles Center, the
58 level shows a parking garage extending to the north of
retail space under the office building (2). The retail space
forms the first floor of the stores above at the 70/ level. It faces
out onto the public park, and extends from Charles and Lex-
ington to Liberty and Lexington Streets. At its center are
escalators tying in the various levels above and below. This
retail frontage continues all the way to Fayette Street. At the
Liberty Street end it opens onto a plaza which is the termina-
tion of Lexington Street. Office building (3), office building
(4), and the new hotel all have additional retail space at the
58 level, the present grade of Fayette Street which forms the
south boundary of the public park. A transit depot extends
on the north side of Fayette Street where buses pull in on a
transit right-of-way and out to the west and south.

South of Baltimore Street the Gallery continues at the 58" level.
It connects the TV Theater, retail frontage on Baltimore Street
and commercial space under office building (6). Again esca-
lators at key points carry pedestrians to the lower levels.

field_edited_text_processed:
FAYETTE ST.

40’ At the north end of Charles Center, the parking
garage at the 40’ level extends south all the way to the north
line of Fayette Street. At this point is the main control for the
parking garage. The foundation columns of the buildings
above can be seen, as can the elevators and escalators leading
up to the surface.



CHARLES ST.



REDWOOD ST.

BALTIMORE ST.
L4













At Fayette Street the main entrances and exits from the parking
garage are shown leading south under Fayette Street out to
Baltimore Street. Hanover Street has been divided from the
major entrance to the parking garage by a retaining wall and
serves solely as access to the Lord Baltimore Hotel. Between
Baltimore and Fayette Streets at slightly higher than the 40’
level is the main entrance and forecourt to the new hotel, and
retail, commercial and lobby space adjacent to it. Carsecan
drive in under the hotel from Liberty Street, and then proceed
onto Baltimore Street or down to the parking garage.













LOMBARD ST.



Across Baltimore Street from the new hotel are stores with on e
frontage on the public park as well. Commercial and retail
space surrounds the park except on the south, where the
Federal Office Building stands. The actual level of the public
park is slightly higher than 40 feet in order to provide clear-
ance for the transit vehicles in the Transportation Terminal
directly below. A cluster of escalators leads down to the load-
ing docks. Another group leads up to the TV Theater.

CHARLES ST.









30’ The 30 level extends under the entire site. Four
traffic lanes go under Baltimore Street and connect the two
areas together. To effect this connection, the four lane ramp
from the 30’ level north of Baltimore Street connects to the
20’ level to the south to avoid conflict with the Transporta-
tion Terminal. The Transportation Terminal is the main
feature at the 80’ level south of Baltimore Street. Transit
vehicles come down ramps from a widened Hopkins Place and
leave by ramps to a widened Charles Street. Service fdr some
of the buildings above comes at this level.













LOMBARD ST.

207 The 20 level extends from Fayette Street to Lom-
bard Street. The major entrance to the parking garage at the
20’ level is from Lombard Street at Hanover. It can also be
entered from the 80’ level. Escalators lead directly up to the : »
TV Theater and other key points.



HOPKINS PLACE



10’ The 10’ level extends from Baltimore Street to Lom-
bard Street, from Charles Street to Hopkins Place. It dupli-
cates the 20’ level and is entered from that level by ramps.
It is not shown because it is exactly the same as the 20’ level.

field_edited_text_value:
FAYETTE ST.

40’ At the north end of Charles Center, the parking
garage at the 40’ level extends south all the way to the north
line of Fayette Street. At this point is the main control for the
parking garage. The foundation columns of the buildings
above can be seen, as can the elevators and escalators leading
up to the surface.



CHARLES ST.



REDWOOD ST.

BALTIMORE ST.
L4













At Fayette Street the main entrances and exits from the parking
garage are shown leading south under Fayette Street out to
Baltimore Street. Hanover Street has been divided from the
major entrance to the parking garage by a retaining wall and
serves solely as access to the Lord Baltimore Hotel. Between
Baltimore and Fayette Streets at slightly higher than the 40’
level is the main entrance and forecourt to the new hotel, and
retail, commercial and lobby space adjacent to it. Carsecan
drive in under the hotel from Liberty Street, and then proceed
onto Baltimore Street or down to the parking garage.













LOMBARD ST.



Across Baltimore Street from the new hotel are stores with on e
frontage on the public park as well. Commercial and retail
space surrounds the park except on the south, where the
Federal Office Building stands. The actual level of the public
park is slightly higher than 40 feet in order to provide clear-
ance for the transit vehicles in the Transportation Terminal
directly below. A cluster of escalators leads down to the load-
ing docks. Another group leads up to the TV Theater.

CHARLES ST.









30’ The 30 level extends under the entire site. Four
traffic lanes go under Baltimore Street and connect the two
areas together. To effect this connection, the four lane ramp
from the 30’ level north of Baltimore Street connects to the
20’ level to the south to avoid conflict with the Transporta-
tion Terminal. The Transportation Terminal is the main
feature at the 80’ level south of Baltimore Street. Transit
vehicles come down ramps from a widened Hopkins Place and
leave by ramps to a widened Charles Street. Service fdr some
of the buildings above comes at this level.













LOMBARD ST.

207 The 20 level extends from Fayette Street to Lom-
bard Street. The major entrance to the parking garage at the
20’ level is from Lombard Street at Hanover. It can also be
entered from the 80’ level. Escalators lead directly up to the : »
TV Theater and other key points.



HOPKINS PLACE



10’ The 10’ level extends from Baltimore Street to Lom-
bard Street, from Charles Street to Hopkins Place. It dupli-
cates the 20’ level and is entered from that level by ramps.
It is not shown because it is exactly the same as the 20’ level.

field_edited_text_processed:
THE AUTO AND CHARLES

The automobile is a major factor on the urban
scene—and in Charles Center. Along with better
transit, an efficient traffic system and adequate park-
ing are important to the success of the project. To
be really efficient, parking must be within a block
of the drivers’ destination. With high intensity
development Downtown, this has usually meant
that parking structures occupy valuable land, or
are relegated to the periphery. Charles Center
“buries” the auto when it i1s not in use in a 4000

car underground parking garage.

Of the 19,000 people who will work in Charles
Center, it is estimated that 13,000 will come by
transit. This is about the proportion in the core
of Downtown that travel by transit today. 6,000,
or 319%, will come by car in 3,500 autos. Charles
Center places 4,000 parking spaces immediately
under the uses they serve, allowing 500 spgces for
visitor and transient parking. These 500 create
1,500 actual spaces because of the turnover. The
entire 4,000 spaces will be available at night for
conventions, the TV Theater Center or major
cultural affairs.

The interconnected parking garage may be oper-
ated as one facility by one or more operators. At-
tendant parking will be provided, but the majority
of drivers will park their own cars in metered
spaces, and board escalators or elevators to their
destination. Spaces could be reserved for the ten-
ants of buildings above as required.

Entrances and exits to the parking garage are de-
signed to meet peak hour demand. Extra lanes are
provided to allow for unusual loads, accidents, and
effective distribution to adjacent streets. Cars can
evit and enter an any of the 13 ramps at the rate
of 500 autos per hour per ramp. Under extraor-
dinary conditions all ramps can be reversed to one
direction.

On the streets bounding Charles Center, traffic
lanes have been added to accommodate the cars

The narrow part of Park Avenue, just north of

Street moved eastward. Saratoga Street has also
been widened. 4

Lexington Street has been closed completely. In
the city’s long range plan for the Downtown street
system, Lexington will no longer have any through-
trafhic function. Baltimore and Fayette Streets are
shown as paired one-way streets leading to and from
the Jones Falls Expressway ramps. Lombard and
Pratt Streets serve the same paired, one-way,
distribution function, carrying expressway traffic
across the south part of Downtown. Hanover Street
will be closed from Baltimore Street to Lombard
Street but stay open, although radically remodelled,
from Fayette to Baltimore Street. Redwood Street
will be closed from Hopkins Place to Charles Street.

Charles Street continues as a major northbound
artery, with Cathedral Street, Liberty Street and
Hopkins Place, tied into Hanover Street farther
south, as the paired southbound artery. Additional
relevant one way arteries are shown in conjunction
with the preliminary and diagrammatic layout of
the entire expressway Inner Ring System.

field_edited_text_processed:
PRINCIPLES AND
THE DOWNTOWN
MASTER PLAN

Charles Center is the first stage in the development of
the Master Plan for Downtown. Charles Center’s
elements evolve logically from the. principles to be

CHARLES CENTER: COSTS AND BENEFITS

AN INVESTMENT IN URBAN RENEWAL

The development of Charles Center 1s not only
desirable, but also financially feasible from both
the municipal as well as the private investment side
of the partnership. The economics of Charles
Center are sound and impressive. Charles Center
is well within the capacity of the City of Baltimore
and the private investment market.

Study the table at right on financial requirements.
Total cost of Charles Center will be $127,170,000.
Of this total cost, $17,205,000, or 13.5%, is public
and $109,965,000, or 86.5%, is private.

The total value of all of the properties to be ac-
quired will be $24,035,000. Included in this is the

cost of demolition, relocation, termination of

utility service and a 109% contingency. These cost
estimates are based on a detailed analysis of assess-
ments, property sales since 1944, and recent ap-
praisals in the area.

To translate Charles Center into an Urban Re-
newal Plan and to carry it out as a project will be
the function of the Baltimore Urban Renewal and
Housing Agency. It will be necessary for that
Agency to secure working capital. The Urban Re-
newal and Housing Agency will use this working
capital to do further detailed planning, to com-
pensate private owners for the property acquired
through purchase or condemnation, and to cover
miscellaneous expenses. The amount of working
capital, or revolving fund, will depend on the rate
at which properties are acquired in relation to the
resale of the cleared sites to private redevelopers.

The City’s long term investment of $17,205,000

enterprise. The division of the sizeable private*
utility costs will be subject to an agreement between

the City and the utility companies. All the costs

are included as municipal costs but this figure will

be lowered to the extent that relocation costs are

born by the private utilities.

The source of the City’s total of $17,205,000 will

be primarily from urban renewal bonds issues, or

special legislation, authorizing such facilities as
the Transportation Terminal. Excluding the

Terminal, which would be largely self-supporting
from revenues, the total urban renewal investment
will be $12,505,000. Investing this much in Charles
Center should not, and need not, inhibit other

essential urban renewal programs in the City. It
might be desirable to finance the City costs for
Charles Center by a separate bond issue. In any e

case, no federal aid is contemplated and all of these
costs would be borne by the City.

The value of the sites to the private redevelopers

of Charles Center is conservatively estimated at

E N

$17,230,000. A redeveloper or redevelopers will &

be chosen in accord with policies of the Urban
Renewal and Housing Agency. Final figures on

resale may be determined through competitive
bidding, subject to the restrictions imposed on the

site and the above policy.

Charles Center’s private construction costs total

$92,785,000. The ofhce towers account for;'
$59,435,000; the stores and commercial areas
account for $10,000,000; the new hotel calls for

$11,800,000; and $12,000,000 is the cost of the un-
derground parking garage. Land may be sold to

Iricludes: thé cost ot thé three public parks; the
capital costs of street widenings and changes, and
park development; public utilities relocation costs
and a portion of the cost of relocation of private
utilities; and the construction of the Transporta-
tion Terminal which will function as a municipal

redevelopers with the City retaiﬁiﬁg an easement
for the construction and operation of the parking
garage. The City may in turn, as did Pittsburgh
in Mellon Square, lease, on a long term basis, to a

private firm or firms, the right to construct and

operate the garage in accordance with City policy.

e

A ~ The City’s investment of $17,205,000 will be re-

! THE INVESTMENT REPAID IN NINE YEARS

paid in nine years by the increased real property

" taxes from Charles Center.

o ‘The City now gets only $531,000 a year from

the properties that will be acquired. Their

1957 assessed value was $17,805,876, of which

$11,354,740 was for land and only $6,451,136 for
improvements—dramatic evidence of the uneco-
nomic status of this key Downtown location.

" The additional tax revenue from Charles Center,
~ even after taking into account the temporary tax

loss on the acquired properties, will be $2,084,000

~ avyear. This revenue will amortize the City’s entire
- investment in slightly less than nine years. After
_that Charles Center will provide substantial per-

manent financial returns to the City. This does not
include related benefits such as the increased
values and taxes from adjoining properties, and the
increased return in non-property taxes.

Were it not for Charles Center, the present trend
: toward lower tax returns and lower values in this

- area will continue unabated. There is, in fact,

=7 evidence that the Charles Center area is now over-
- assessed. Market values have been dropping
- rapidly. There are many long term vacancies in
"”once-prime properties and leases are being nego-
- tiated at lower terms. Property sales are closed in
: many instances at prices less than assessments and

lower assessments have been sought by many owners

~ for this reason.

It is only by the development of Charles Center

~ that the City can hope to reverse this trend and
~ create the opportunity for private investment which
~ will trigger into chain reaction the revitalization
- of Downtown Baltimore.

field_edited_text_processed:
THE URBAN RENEWAL PROCESS

Charles Center will be the focus for a creative
public and private partnership. Only such a part-
nership can make it work. The public partner
must create, through urban renewal, the oppor-

tunity for the private partner to invest. It is impor-

tant, therefore, to view Charles Center as an urban

renewal project . . . . to understand how the urban

renewal process works . ... and how it will affect

the people involved.

Two basic steps in this process have already been
taken. One is legislation. The other is the plan.
The legislation is Ordinance #1210, the pioneer
action that makes Baltimore the first city in the
nation to designate its entire Downtown as an
Urban Renewal Area. This action provides the
legal foundation for renewal action for any project
in the area. |

Private interests have developed the Charles
Center plan in cooperation with the City Admin-
istration and Agencies. The Committee for Down-
town, Inc., a private organization concerned with
the future of Downtown as the key to the health
of the whole metropolitan area, retained The Plan-
ning Council of the Greater Baltimore Committee,
Inc., a private, non-profit planning group, to pre-
pare the Master Plan for Downtown. Based on the
recommendations of The Planning Council, the
Committee for Downtown has approved Charles
Center as vital to Baltimore and to the development
of the over-all Master Plan.

The Committee for Downtown proposes . . . . that

the Mayor and City Administration adopt Charles .

Center as an official Urban Renewal Project . . . .
that the Baltimore Urban Renewal and Housing
Agency prepare an Urban Renewal Plan for
Charles Center in accord with the details in this
presentation and submit this Plan to the Baltimore
City Planning Commission for approval . . . . that
the City Planning Commission approve the Charles
Center Urban Renewal Plan, then in accordance
with law refer the Plan back to the Urban Renewal
and Housing Agency for final approval . . . . that
an ordinance be introduced in the City Council,
public hearings held and after due deliberation,
Charles Center be approved . . . . and that the
Baltimore Urban Renewal and Housing Agency
implement the Plan . . . . by taking action -along

18

with other appropriate municipal departments as
called for in the Plan.

CARRYING OUT THE PLAN

In carrying out the Charles Center Urban Renewal
Plan, the Urban Renewal and Housing Agency,
will acquire all of the properties within the Charles
Center area, excepting five: the Fidelity Building,
the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Building, the Lord
Baltimore Hotel, the Lexington Building and the
Eglin Parking Garage.

In acquiring the properties the Urban Renewal
and Housing Agency will negotiate with the owners
and offer fair market value. These values are
determined by a detailed property appraisal. If
mutually satisfactory prices cannot be reached, the
City then condemns the properties in question and
the price is set by a jury appointed by the Court.

In the Charles Center area there are 250 parcels,
not counting ground rents and other real property
interests. All of these property rights will be
acquired either through purchase or condemnation.
As soon as the Urban Renewal and Housing Agency
has acquired a property, arrangements can be made
for the relocation of the occupants and, eventually,
demolition of the building. Obviously, all proper-
ties will not be acquired at once and staging of
both relocation and demolition will prevent strip-
ping the Charles Center area all at one time.

Meanwhile, street changes, utility cut-offs and re-
locations can take place.” Except for Baltimore
Street and Fayette Street, all streets and alleys in
the area will be closed. Baltimore and Fayette
Streets, in the area, will be widened and improved.
Both streets will be torn up and replaced for a
short stretch over the underground connection for
the parking garages.

The bounding streets are affected, as shown. De-
tails of the street changes will be worked out as
part of the Urban Renewal Plan. Where streets
and alleys have been closed in Charles Center, the
utilities will be abandoned, relocated or provided
for by easement. In some cases, utility lines will
have to be removed temporarily to permit un-
interrupted service to adjacent properties and then
be replaced as construction proceeds in Charles
Center. The utility lines in the peripheral streets
are affected very little.

DOWNTOWN URBAN RENEWAL AREA

showing the Central Business District
and Charles Center

Agency prepare an Urban Renewal Plan for
Charles Center in accord with the details in this
presentation and submit this Plan to the Baltimore
City Planning Commission for approval . . . . that
the City Planning Commission approve the Charles
Center Urban Renewal Plan, then in accordance
with law refer the Plan back to the Urban Renewal
and Housing Agency for final approval . . . . that
an ordinance be introduced in the City Council,
public hearings held and after due deliberation,
Charles Center be approved . . . . and that the
Baltimore Urban Renewal and Housing Agency
implement the Plan . . . . by taking action -along

18

with other appropriate municipal departments as
called for in the Plan.

CARRYING OUT THE PLAN

In carrying out the Charles Center Urban Renewal
Plan, the Urban Renewal and Housing Agency,
will acquire all of the properties within the Charles
Center area, excepting five: the Fidelity Building,
the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Building, the Lord
Baltimore Hotel, the Lexington Building and the
Eglin Parking Garage.

In acquiring the properties the Urban Renewal
and Housing Agency will negotiate with the owners
and offer fair market value. These values are
determined by a detailed property appraisal. If
mutually satisfactory prices cannot be reached, the
City then condemns the properties in question and
the price is set by a jury appointed by the Court.

In the Charles Center area there are 250 parcels,
not counting ground rents and other real property
interests. All of these property rights will be
acquired either through purchase or condemnation.
As soon as the Urban Renewal and Housing Agency
has acquired a property, arrangements can be made
for the relocation of the occupants and, eventually,
demolition of the building. Obviously, all proper-
ties will not be acquired at once and staging of
both relocation and demolition will prevent strip-
ping the Charles Center area all at one time.

Meanwhile, street changes, utility cut-offs and re-
locations can take place.” Except for Baltimore
Street and Fayette Street, all streets and alleys in
the area will be closed. Baltimore and Fayette
Streets, in the area, will be widened and improved.
Both streets will be torn up and replaced for a
short stretch over the underground connection for
the parking garages.

The bounding streets are affected, as shown. De-
tails of the street changes will be worked out as
part of the Urban Renewal Plan. Where streets
and alleys have been closed in Charles Center, the
utilities will be abandoned, relocated or provided
for by easement. In some cases, utility lines will
have to be removed temporarily to permit un-
interrupted service to adjacent properties and then
be replaced as construction proceeds in Charles
Center. The utility lines in the peripheral streets
are affected very little.

DOWNTOWN URBAN RENEWAL AREA

showing the Central Business District
and Charles Center

THE CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT






CATHEDRAL ST
GUILFORD AVE.

ST.\PAUL ST.



FALLSWAY

%
g

EUTAW ST.

BALTIMORE ST,

GREENE ST.

HANOVER ST.

MARKET PL
CONCORD ST.

FIRST COMMERCIAL USE DISTRICT
SECOND COMMERCIAL USE DISTRICT

EXISTING SECOND COMMERCIAL
T0 BE CHANGED TO FIRST

20

LIGHT, AIR AND ARCHITECTURE

Present zoning permits the new construction recom-
mended for Charles Center with the possibility of
some minor exceptions. However, it is recom-
mended that the zoning in the area be changed
from its present mixed classification to first com-
mercial. The Board of Estimates will need to grant
special authorization to permit the construction of
the building designed to bridge Fayette Street at
Charles, and other buildings that overhang side-
walks.

In addition to the usual zoning and building con-
trols, certain restrictions on building coverage and
design must be established to ensure that every
building maintains high standards and is in accord
with the principles and elements of the Plan. With-
out such control over light, air, architectural design,

- and materials, Charles Center might be doomed

to failure, or end in mediocrity. Such control can
be expressed in the Urban Renewal Plan as a maxi-
mum and minimum ratio of the total building floor
area above the parking garage to the ground area,

and maximum heights of the buildings not fo

exceed a certain number of stories.

In many cities it has been found desirable to estab-
lish design and coordinating committees made up
of architect and business statesmen whose objec-
tives are to referee conflicts, keep the project on

s #
course, and have a veto power over architecture not

in keeping with the Plan. This kind of committee
is necessary to Charles Center’s proper execution.

NEW PROPERTY LINES

When the Urban Renewal and Housing Agency
has acquired the properties, relocated the occupants
and demolished the buildings, Charles Center can
be sold to private redevelopers in various combina-

~tions of new parcels. The price the redeveloper

pays will depend upon an appraisal of the parcels’
economic worth in relation to Charles Center, what
can be built thereupon, and bidding by private
interests. In any case private redevelopers receive

no subsidy, as they pay the economic value for their

parcels.

The tentative land disposition plan shows ten
parcels to be sold to private redevelopers, although
one redevelopef may buy the entire site and parcel
it out to individual owners after development.
Superimposed on these parcels are the maximum
tower development areas, which, combined with


















limitations on first, second, and third floor coverage
are restrictions on site development. The Urban -
Renewal and Housing Agency, in line with its usual =
policy, will set further restrictions on the use of
the land to ensure consistent and coordinated
development.



The final test of the economic soundness of Charles
Center will be the receipt of firm bids for the land
for its development in accordance with the plans.
While it is not possible to specifically identify re-
developers at the present time, there is sound and
real evidence that a high proportion of the new
buildings proposed in Charles Center have an im-
mediate market from institutions and private

financial interests. g



>

The translation of this interest into firm and sub-
stantial offers from responsible firms is the role of
Baltimore’s private business community in the
partnership with public enterprise. g

TENTATIVE NEW PROPERTY LINES

it el |

RELOCATION

The problem of relocation is perhaps the most
sertous of all. The Urban Renewal and Housing
Agency handles relocation in all urban renewal
projects. Immediately upon the announcement of
such a project they are deluged with phone calls
from people who quite properly want information.
The Agency’s first concern is to get complete data
on the pattern of ownership, leasehold, or special
problems. Assistance is given wherever it is possible
to do so. The Agency is helpful and fair in its
dealings. |

Upon approval of the Plan the 871 business firms,
employing 5,587 persons will be contacted regard-
ing relocation. A few of these firms are owner-
occupants. They are a cross-section of Downtown
business. In the manufacturing and wholesaling
categories they are predominantly in one form or
~another of the garment industry which has unfor-
tunately been a declining activity in Baltimore.
Their relocation should be feasible into the large
-amount of vacant space in the garment area.

For a substantial number of the successful busi-
nesses, relocation may be into Charles Center itself.
Under no circumstances will the area be cleared
at once, and staging of demolition may well permit
~owners or present tenants to remain in their loca-

It is understandable that people who are about to
be displaced or have their business disrupted may
resist plans for Charles Center. Although they may
well see that it is for the larger good, that is small
consolation when they themselves are the ones to
be hurt. The important psychological factor in
relocation is getting across the conviction that
Chdrles Center is really going to happen.

Once owners and tenants accept the fact that
Charles Center is really going to happen, their
greatest relocation resource is their own initiative,
ability to pay economic rents and prices for the
space and locations they need, and their individual
solutions to their own problems.

One of the most serious problems in relocation is
that of the small firm whose business has been
declining and for whom relocation may mean ex-
tinction. For these, there is perhaps no real solu-
tion, but the Agency will give them fair and sym-
pathetic understanding and treatment, within the
limits of available resources and the time schedule
that is adopted.

CHARLES CENTER IS URGENT

MAJOR DOWNTOWN DEPARTMENT STORES
SALES AND TRANSACTIONS





















































SALES 1952-1957 TRANSACTIONS
Millions of Dollars Millions
100 | 27
TRANS
95 A';,j. - 2
90 - 25
85 2
80 SOSBBEHA 93
7568 g 2
VTR ol s TR

REAL PROPERTY ASSESSMENTS
BALTIMORE CITY AND
CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT (WARD 4)



24

In recent years, Downtown, although the center of
an expanding region, has declined. Today, about
the same number of people—94,000—are employed
in the Central Business District, as were twenty
years ago. Over 2,000,000 square feet of once-
productive loft and warehouse space in this area
now lies vacant. This is almost 6% of all floor
space, and creates a critical problem as most of it
is concentrated in depressed areas. Of the 127
blocks in the Central Business District, the vacancy
rate in 26 blocks exceeds 10%, and in 8 others,
some of which are in the Charles Center area, the
vacancy rate is as high as 25%.

The high vacancy is paralleled by lowered retail
sales. Sales in seven major Downtown department
stores last year (1957) were 129 below sales in
1952 . . . . an indicator of Downtown’s declining
health.

Vacant buildings and declining retail sales are only
part of the dilemma. Traflic problems have all
but strangled Downtown activities. The street sys-
tem cannot function as it should, because all of
they traffic of the entire region ‘has had to funnel
through Downtown.

000. In the five years since then, the taxable base

In recent years, Downtown, although the center of
an expanding region, has declined. Today, about
the same number of people—94,000—are employed
in the Central Business District, as were twenty
years ago. Over 2,000,000 square feet of once-
productive loft and warehouse space in this area
now lies vacant. This is almost 6% of all floor
space, and creates a critical problem as most of it
is concentrated in depressed areas. Of the 127
blocks in the Central Business District, the vacancy
rate in 26 blocks exceeds 10%, and in 8 others,
some of which are in the Charles Center area, the
vacancy rate is as high as 25%.

The high vacancy is paralleled by lowered retail
sales. Sales in seven major Downtown department
stores last year (1957) were 129 below sales in
1952 . . . . an indicator of Downtown’s declining
health.

Vacant buildings and declining retail sales are only
part of the dilemma. Traflic problems have all
but strangled Downtown activities. The street sys-
tem cannot function as it should, because all of
they traffic of the entire region ‘has had to funnel
through Downtown.

Property values reflect all of these problems. With
a few exceptions, Downtown properties have de-
clined along with everything else, possibly at an
even more rapid rate. In 1952, real property
assessments in the Fourth Ward (the Central Busi-
ness District) reached a peak: just under $156,000,-
000. In the five years since then, the taxable base
has dwindled to less than $140,000,000 . . . a
decline of over $16,000,000, or 109%. While this

DOWNTOWN: IT’S EVERYBODY’S PROBLEM



A declining Downtown is not just the problem of
the Downtown owner or tenant. Everyone has a
stake in Downtown. First, the loss in Downtown
values must be made up by the rest of the City.
The City as a whole has a tremendous investment
in Downtown. Second, in a decentralized metro-
politan area, many small “downtowns” appear,
which never really take the place of a central Down-
town. The costs of doing business in a centralized
city are substantially lower than they are where
the so-called “friction of space” is a serious factor.
Finally, only a central Downtown can support the
kind of services and cultural and recreational life
which are expected in a modern big city.

field_edited_text_processed:
Partly as a result of and partly as a cause of the
decline of Downtown. Downtown activities have
been decentralizing at a tremendous rate. The
rapid decentralization of Downtown can be ex-
plained in part in terms of traffic and changes in
modes of travel, shopping and living. The most
important single explanation is that there have
been too few opportunities for major private invest-
ment Downtown. The problem of land assembly,
elimination of blighting factors and uneconomic
land uses, and the replanning of Downtown have
been beyond the ability of private enterprise alone.
Public enterprise must create the opportunity
through urban renewal for private enterprise to
revitalize Downtown.

Most recent public and private decisions, made
out of the context of urban renewal, have militated
against a revitalization of Downtown by draining
off the energies and the generative factors that
could give rebirth. Urban renewal can change
this.

The time for such a change is none too soon.
Baltimore is nearing the “point of no return” in
decentralization. Regional shopping centers are
springing up at a rapid rate. More than 2,000,000
square feet of office space is now proposed, or
already under construction, in the outlying areas

.. stark evidence of the decentralization and the
unsatisfied market for such office space in Down-
town. If this trend continues, too much of the
present growth potential may have been drained
off to the suburbs, and Downtown must look for-
ward to a permanent decline.

There is real evidence, however, that it is not yet
too late. A recent survey of the region’s economic
activities shows that the upsurge of the post-war
years will continue at least through 1975, and this
expected regional growth will support Downtown
growth once it is triggered by urban renewal
opportunity. Forecasts to 1975 indicate that the
region’s population (City, Baltimore Co., Anne
Arundel Co.) will grow from the present figure of
1,600,000 to 2,400,000: 800,000 more people. Em-
ployment too, has grown and is growing at a
phenomenal rate. New branch plants of large

national corporations, as well as the expansion of
business already located 1n the region, have added

up to unprecedented economic growth. By 1975,
the number of jobs in the area will reach 911,000,
an increase of 250,000, or 389 over the average
employment levels recorded in 1956 in the Balu-
more area.

THE ROLE OF DOWNTOWN

To properly perform its function in the region,
Downtown should be developed with a maximum
concentration of activities consistent with no con-
gestion. The activities most able to profit by a
Downtown location should be located there. This
principle has been wused in planning Charles
Center. What belongs Downtown can be put very
simply. Those functions which take place in office
space . . . business, professional, cultural, govern-
mental and education activities . . . operate best
Downtown. The office building is the key to Down-
town renewal, although once started renewal may
well continue with a variety of uses.

THE OFFICE BUILDING: MAJOR FUN(iTION DOWNTOWN

The favorable forecast for the Baltimore region
justifies the long range market for Downtown in-
vestment in new office buildings. A short-range
analysis of the market for office space based on a
survey in great depth showed many firms with
immediate space needs.

At present there are 21 major ofhice buildings
Downtown with a total rentable area of over 2,000,-
000 square feet. However, the majority of ofhce
users are located outside the major structures in
secondary facilities: converted lofts, etc. Air-con-
ditioned offices are a rarity and few of the office
buildings have high-speed elevators, suitable floor
areas, or the appointments and convenience of new
ofhice space.

Since World War 11, only 300,000 square feet of
rentable office space has been added Downtown,
half of which is occupied by owner-occupants and
the other half by tenants. There is no margin at
present in Downtown for the expected upturn in
office demands. Ofhice building proposed in the
suburban areas will attract much of it unless there
are new opportunities Downtown.

Charles Center provides eight new office buildings
with two million square feet of rentable area. Based
on the regional forecasts and the intensive survey,
the effective demand justifies this amount of new
space. The growth of the region will absorb it
without creating critical vacancies in the existing
ofhice buildings. 'Since 1947, contrary to the loft
and warehouse vacancies in Downtown, the Down-
town’s major offices have enjoyed occupancies
ranging up to 99%, whereas up to a 5% vacancy
rate is usually considered proper to permit normal
turnovers.

THE NEW HOTEL

Charles Center providés fof a new 800-room hotel,
the first to be built in Baltimore for 30 years. There

is every evidence that a new hotel is needed in
Downtown, particularly for conventions and public
meetings. In Baltimore, there are only five hotels
with 200 rooms or more; in Milwaukee, there are
12; in Minneapolis, 14; in Cleveland, 20; in Phila-
delphia, 21; and in St. Louis and Boston, there
are 23. Baltimore’s proximity to Washington can-
not explain this great differential.

Charles Center’s new 800-room hotel will help to
upgrade Baltimore’s facilities in future years. It,
combined with the existing hotel facilities, will
permit convention facilities not now existing.

RETAIL SPACE DOWNTOWN

Retailing will continue to follow suburban markets
to some degree, but at the same time there should
be better retail opportunities Downtown. To this
end, Charles Center contemplates a total of 428,-
000 square feet in retail space, 300,000 of it north
of Baltimore Street. This is two-thirds of the 640,-
000 square feet of retail space now in the Charles
Center area, excluding banks and personal service
establishments. It is less than 5% of the retail space
in the entire Central Business District. Charles
Center will make for a stronger retail concentra-
tion Downtown, where an estimated daytime popu-
lation of 25,000 persons, including visitors and
shoppers, will create opportunities for considerable
retail activities.

PROJECTED EMPLOYMENT AND POPULATION —
BALTIMORE STANDARD METROPOLITAN AREA

field_edited_text_processed:
THE CHARLES CENTER SITE

The selection of the site of Charles Center was
the culmination of an exhaustive analysis of the
proper location for office space, specialty retail
space and the hotel, and of the condition of property
in the entire Downtown. The specifications for
Charles Center and its development are exacting.
They are as follows:

Charles Center, must be Dramatic in Size and Con-
cept; it cannot be smaller than it is. It must be
Attainable Without Federal Aid, both because of
timing and present legislation. It should Create
An Immediate Opportunity for new investment
Downtown. It should also have Universal Appeal
from the point of view of public approval as well
as the practical reason that a diversified project
reaches into many “market areas” and need not
depend on one alone.

By no means all of Downtown can or will be new.
This first project should Create An Incentive For
Rehabilitation of adjacent properties. In order to
absorb present uses and take maximum advantage
of Downtown location, it should Intensify the Use
of the Site and Eliminate Blighted, Uneconomic,
or Socially Undesirable Land Uses. :

Looking to the future, Charles Center should make
a Contribution Toward Solving Traffic, Parking,
and Transit problems. It should also help set the

stage for subsequent Downtown projects. In this

way, projects become cumulative, not competitive.





BALTIMORE BALTIMORE

ECONOMIC METROPOLITAN STANDARD

REGION BALTIMORE METROPOLITAN
AREA

'SELECTING_. THE SITE

4

It should also tie into as many other programs as
possible and not create problems that inhibit later
development of a rational master plan for Down-
town as a whole.

Charles Center is the only area that meets all the
specifications. It is the only area where a new hotel,
new office space, specialty retail space and a TV
Theater Center may be combined with a Trans-
portation Terminal to create a composite renewal
project.

To determine the specific site boundaries, all build-
ings in an area bounded by St. Paul and Light
Streets on.the east, Howard Street on the west,
Saratoga Street on the north, and Lombard Street
on the south, were examined in detail. Their
deterioration and obsolescence, size, value, tax re-
turn, and general character were carefully analyzed.
Consideration was given to the effect retained

- buildings would have on the environment for

future investment. Finally, in terms of the tech-
nical problems of adequately replanning and re-

- building the area, as well as the question of

consistency of approach, complete clearance with
the exception of the five buildings previously
identified, was inevitably indicated.

The conclusion of this detailed analysis was that
Charles Center would work here and nowhere
else, and that it must be executed essentially as
proposed, or it would not work at all.



CHASE ST

FEDERAL

£

Areais examined in the detailed
analysis leading to the Charles Center Site.

MADISON ST

'EVERYBODY BENEFITS

- Charles Center is necessary, desirable, and sufhicient

to revitalize Downtown Baltimore. The case for

- it as an ofhicial urban renewal project may be stated
- very simply.

Downtown is deteriorating rapidly, although in the
center of an expanding region. The growth poten-
tial of.the region cannot be tapped as a resource

~ for Downtown’s revitalization without the appli-

cation of the urban renewal powers of the City to
create the opportunity for Downtown investment.
Charles Center is necessary to feverse the trend of
Downtown deterioration. Charles Center also must
be developed as planned, to be adequate to reverse
this trend.

Charles Center enables the development of an
entirely different kind of Master Plan for Down-
town than would otherwise be possible. Without
Charles Center, the Master Plan would be a plan
of adversity and retrenchment. With it, Downtown
can be a “‘chooser” instead of a “‘beggar” for new
uses. The Master Plan can be imaginative and
creative. It can consider as economically and
socially feasible such elements as in-town resi-
dential areas, aggressive rehabilitation of the major
shopping center, and renewal of the Inner Harbor
area.

field_edited_text_processed:
CHARLES CENTER: A SOLID FOUNDATION

-

Along with the significant features of old Baltimore, Charles Center is the solid
foundation on which to build a revitalized Downtown. It will set the stage,
along with other positive influences, for the implementation of an imaginative,
vital and realistic Master Plan.

Major influences are at work Downtown already, whose effect will be immeas-
urably increased by Charles Center. The University of Maryland’s Downtown
campus development, increased in scope through being tied into the Urban
Renewal and Housing Agency’s program, will be a strong anchor at the west
end of the Central Business District. Mercy Hospltal like the new Commercial
Credit Building, will be another vital force in the Preston Gardens area.

84, 2%EP R rq)n.



Mt.Vernon Place and its cultural activities act as an anchor to the north.

Urban renewal is a continuous process. It is the adaptation of the physical form
of cities to changing needs. It goes on frequently without the need for public
aid, as it properly should. Where it cannot, urban renewal becomes a public
function to eliminate the deterrents to private investment. Other areas in
Downtown are appropriate for public urban renewal action, and become feas-
ible once Charles Center has set the stage.

Charles Center is a unique opportunity which must be realized. It is the
beginn.ing.

MAYOR’'S ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON SMALL BUSINESS
230 TOWER BUILDING — 222 E. BALTIMORE ST.
BALTIMORE, MARYLAND 21202 -
PHONE: 752-2000 — EXT. 565 AND 596

MEMBERS:

DR. FREDERICK F. EVERHART
ARTHUR W. LAMBERT
MILLARD MERZ, JR.

ELI MILLER

ROGER SANDERS

THOMAS J. D' ALESANDRO, Ill
MAYOR

REUBEN H. LEVENSON
CHAIRMAN



HERMAN KATKOW HON. WILLIAM DONALD SCHAEFER
DIRECTOR ROBERT N. SMELKINSON |
Hon. Thomas J. D'Alesandro, IIT ' October 20, 1970
Mayor 9
City Hall

Baltimore, Maryland 21202
Dear Mayor D'Alesandro:

The attached report represents the culmination of
many years' efforts by your Small Business Committee in
seeking effective solutions to the problem of deteriorating
older business areas. It is a problem of such magnitude
and complexity as to affect practically every metropolitan
area 1in our country, and one that has caused concern on a
national level. '

This pioneer effort by the City of Baltimore formulates
policies and plans for three model study areas reached after
communication and general area of agreement with business
interests in the Light Street and Monument Street areas, and
with representatives of both the business and the residential
community 1n the Pennsylvania Avenue area.

There are contained 1n the report some recommendations
for consideration by yourself and by the City Council, and
by your counterparts 1in other cities.

It 1s appropriate to express our appreciation to the
many individuals and agencies who helped make this report
possible, notably our Chairman, Mr. Reuben H. Levenson; our
liaison with your office, City Council President William
Donald Schaefer; Mr. Isadore Candeub, President of Candeub,
Fleissig and Associates; the U. S. Department of Housing and
Urban Development; and our own Department of Planning and
Department of Housing and Community Development.

Respectfully yours,

MAYOR'S ADVISORY COMMITTEL
ON SMALL BUSINESS





Herman Katkow
Director

field_edited_text_processed:
Introduction

Ten years ago, the Mayor of Baltimore, at the
behest of one city councilman ‘and a small
group of inner city businessmen concerned
about the decline of the older shopping
districts, appointed a Small Business Advisory
Committee. After operating for four years on a
purely voluntary basis, the Committee was
given official status by the authorization of a
modest budget and by the appointment of a
Director.

It was the Committee’s judgment that in
discharging the responsibility which it had
accepted, a three-step approach was in order:

1. Identify the problem. 4

2. Research that had been done previously by
others.

3. Seek professional guidance.

A patient has little difficulty in describing his
aches and pains, so the first step was the easiest.
The Committee members already knew from
their day-to-day operations in their own
businesses the malaise which was adversely
affecting them and their business neighbors, so
it became merely a matter of assembling the
necessary statistics in order that the fever chart
would prove the pa’Eient was really sick. The
emerging picture, not unexpectedly, showed an
acceleration of store vacancies, formerly viable
retail stores occupied for secondary and tertiary
usages, a sharply eroding tax base, a steadily
increasing incidence of crime, and more and
more problems in the fields of sanitation,
health and the general welfare of both the
business and the contiguous residential
community. Also discussed but impossible to
document was the feeling of the Committee
that the diminution of small business had
serious sociological overtones in that it
considered the small businessman an integral
component of this country’s middle class and
that a strong middle class was the backbone of
a healthy democratic society.

The source date available in previous research
was limited to one study prepared in 1957 by
Baltimore’s Department of Planning and its
Department of Traffic Engineering. The
opening paragraphs of that report stated:

’Perhaps the most unusual change in the
Baltimore landscape during the past ten

years has been the construction of
planned shopping centers. They rise in a
sharp contrast to the older established
districts. In the new centers one finds
convenient parking, concentrated stores,
new merchandising techniques, and
sales volumes that tax the imagination.
In the older districts one observes
inadequate parking, congestion,

mixed uses, store structures that are
unsuited to modern merchandising,

and much lower sales volumes.

Naturally, this contrast worries merchants. It
worries the community as a whole. If the
older shopping districts are unable to
successfully compete for business, both
residential and non-residential areas will
deteriorate more rapidly, business failures
will be a constant source of irritation, and
the possibilities for revitalizing the older
districts will decrease. There has been
considerable interest in doing something
about this condition, but thus far no
practical program has been developed."

With all due respect for the last sentence,
candor compels one to report that in the seven
years that intervened between that report and
the Mayor’s Advisory Committee on Small
Business becoming involved, the Committee
found somewhat less than ‘‘considerable
Interest”’. It found an apathy and a tacit
willingness to avoid ‘‘sending good money after
bad”’ in order to concentrate efforts on the new
threat of signs of decline in the Central
Business District. Further on in the report it
pointed out that:

“The general excess of retail area in the inner
city, difficult to eliminate, indicates a
chaotic condition which can be alleviated
only by the application of urban renewal
techniques. It is the kind of situation that
requires the most thorough study and the
most comprehensive treatment. Urban
renewal policy with respect to both shopping
districts and to retail uses in surrounding
residential areas can materially affect the
future of older shopping districts. In the
meantime, neighborhoods will deteriorate
more rapidly; the unneeded vacant stores will
be filled by less desirable nonresidential uses
or forsaken to marginal residential use."

While the report was prophetic in the last
sentence, it did not conclude on a note of
gloom. It made this interesting observation:

“Most of the new shopping centers have had
their brightest years. They are now but
shakily established, apprehensive of still
further nearby shopping center development.
But now the suburban area has almost
reached the limit to which it can support
further sales exploitation. Soon the last
remaining untapped market for the new
merchandising technigues will be the more
densely populated area of the City, where
the older shopping districts are located.
Nothing stands in the way of this exploitation
but an obsolete, congested, and mixed-use
retail structure.”

The Committee was informed that due to lack
of funds and personnel the professional help
requested from other city agencies was not
available. After more than a year of frustrating
meetings with State and Federal agencies and
officials, the Committee’s efforts were finally
rewarded by an invitation to submit an
application for a Demonstration Grant study to
the then U.S. Urban Renewal Administration.
The difficult decision of selecting one from the
several highly qualified consultants interviewed
was resolved with the choice of Isadore
Candeub, President of Candeub, Fleissig and
Assoclates, as prime consultant for the project.
Designated as Project Director was Herman
Katkow, Director of the Mayor's Advisory
Committee on Small Business.

field_edited_text_processed:
. Summary

Project Objectives

The shopping districts established in the older
residential districts of our cities have problems
similar to those of the central business districts.
Unlike the CBD areas, these districts have
neither the plans, the organizational structure
to put the plans into effect, nor the
commitment of local resources and programs
that the CBD areas are increasingly receiving.

This project was designed to carry out a
planning program for three shopping districts in
Baltimore and to recommend methods for the
achievement of these plans over a period of
years. The fact that each of the three areas
substantially differed in a variety of
characteristics led to the expectation of
different findings and results which would have
validity in other communities.

Essential Features of the Study
The study program contained six major
elements as follows:

1. The Research Phase

In addition to the data made available from the
community renewal program and other existing
studies of the Planning Department, specific
studies were carried out reviewing building
conditions, environmental characteristics,
attitudes and market factors.

2. Preliminary Planning

Considerable attention was given to the relation
of each of the centers to its surrounding area
and to the various transportation, urban
renewal and public facility improvement
programs under way or proposed. These
relationships were considered to be particularly
vital in providing the basis for an agreement on
a plan with local business and resident groups
and with city agencies.

3. Development of Planning Objectives
Meetings were held and graphic material
prepared for public discussion to establish
agreement on primary objectives of land use,
district size, parking locations, circulation,
design elements and other elements. Agreement
on objectives was considered to be a vital action
prior to any plan presentation or discussion.

4. Concept Plans
Applying the givens outlined under the
preliminary planning stage and reflecting the



approved objectives, a limited number of

concept plans were prepared and presented for »

discussion purposes. After appropriate review
and some modification these became the basis
for -

5. Development Plans

The specific land use, circulation and design
treatment changes were presented in a
comprehensive fashion suitable for execution.

6. Action Recommendations

Specific recommendations were made on the
utilization of ongoing programs and the
formation of additional administrative
machinery for developing and executing the
plans.

Summary of Accomplishments
The primary purposes of the project were
achieved.

1. Plan Development

Utilizing the procedures identified above, plans
were prepared for each center that related to a
variety of citywide and neighborhood
considerations and reflected the findings of the
surveys conducted under the study program.

2. Plan Concurrence

Following the series of steps outlined above,
there was considerable discussion generated on
plan elements and there was general
concurrence on plans.

3. Plan Implementation

Some of the recommendations of the program
have already been initiated, particularly in the
Pennsylvania Avenue Area. Considerable
further action is required for the full

implementation of the plans for the three areas.

Summary Conclusions

1. Design

The present centers are largely linear strips.
There is a need for treatment in depth
providing focal points, pedestrian plazas,
linkages between building mass and open space
and better functional relations between
circulation, parking sites and service facilities.
Comprehensive improvement can only be
carried out on this basis. The alternative is
individual building improvement and visual
face-lifting that will have little impact on the
functioning of the centers,





2. Financial Support ,
Comprehensive improvement will involve major
expenditures. The scale of these expenditures
for acquisition, public improvements, public
facilities, street changes and the provision of an
adequate level of environmental amenities is
considered to be beyond the capability of the
limited resources of merchants in the centers.

Public investment is affected by three major
constraints.

a. In the competition for public funds, these
centers generally have a much lower priority
rating than the central business district,
residential neighborhoods or prime
employment centers such as industrial districts.

b. The expenditure of public funds for the
limited benefit of local merchants would be
opposed by neighborhood groups with a wide
variety of other needs.

c. The number of shopping centers in the city
creates a problem of priorities with reference to
the expenditure of funds for any single center
to the exclusion of the others.

3. Broadening the Base

ltems one and two above, Design and Financial
Support, lead to the conclusion that a
broadened concept of the role of local centers
would create the basis for a more complex plan
that dealt with an expanded center with
multiple functions. This in turn, would make
the center of more importance to the
neighborhood groups and to the city-at-large.
This would then permit a greater allocation of
funds to the improvement of the centers.

4. Utilization of Existing Features

The convenience aspects of these centers, the
transportation modes, the availability of air
rights over parking areas and one-story
commercial uses--these and other factors
suggest that we are presently under-utilizing our
established business centers. The concepts of
vertical zoning, multiple-use structures and
building complexes are as valid in a subcenter as
in a downtown business district. The scale may
be different.

B. Return to Neighborhood Concept
The development of concentration points
around local centers serving the neighboring
