established business centers. The concepts of
vertical zoning, multiple-use structures and
building complexes are as valid in a subcenter as
in a downtown business district. The scale may
be different.

B. Return to Neighborhood Concept
The development of concentration points
around local centers serving the neighboring

field_edited_text_processed:
area suggests a return to the ‘““neighborhood
concept”’. However, we are not suggesting small
self-contained neighborhood areas: we are
suggesting that we may benefit from
recognizing that our cities are complex
structures with many diverse elements. This
diversity might readily find expression in
concentrated central points tied to
transportation networks, and relating to market
factors and the proper distribution of public
functions. These centers could be designed and
could function as ““Town Centers" reflecting
the specific needs and tastes of the population
that they serve.

6. Social and Economic Objectives

The presence of strong centers could produce
multiple benefits in the form of better
identification with a community;
decentralization of training, health,
administrative and job development programs
and a broader range of job opportunities within
a walking range.

Summary Recommendations
The experience with the Demonstration Project
suggests the following recommendations:

1. ldentification of Business Center Role

The business centers can usefully and
efficiently serve as focal points for local
community development and activities. The
total range of activities, public and private, that
relate to the local community should be
reviewed for possible inclusion in the centers.
Considerable emphasis should be given to
higher density housing, transportation terminals
and changes and the location of central places
for public assembly, cultural pursuits, training
and recreational programs.

2. Concentration and Expansion of Centers
The extended linear commercial strip cannot
provide strong focal points, cannot be
economically served by bulk parking areas and
does not provide strong interaction between
activities. It is recommended that such centers
be concentrated and that linear distances be
decreased.

It is also recommended that the central
portions of the center be expanded to provide
for unified design, organized exterior
circulation and appropriate access and adequate
open space for pedestrian use, landscaping and
sitting area.

A longer range recommendation is for an
ultimate decrease in the number of centers, |
strengthening the more viable ones and seeking
greater productivity of land use of the
submarginal ones through reuse for nonretail
purposes, i.e., housing, industry, open space or
public facilities.

3. Design

The extensive street areas, utilization of
ground-level sites for parking, and single-story
commercial use is a wasteful use of our urban
land. We recommend land consolidation,
elimination of interior streets and vertical
zoning for multiple purposes.

4, Implementation

The scale of effort needed will not be achieved
except through concentrated urban renewal
projects or in various combinations of public
and private administrative machinery and

financing. This will undoubtedly require further
~legislation and experimentation. The scale of

the changes is too broad to be carried out by
private enterprise alone and it is too involved
with the commercial life of the community to
be carried out without the assistance and
participation of private investors and
entrepreneurs.

5. Citizen Participation

The leverage for change consists of strong
community concern, continuous demands and
widespread agreement on the type of
improvements that are needed. The momentum
for change may be stimulated by business
leadership and, in part, guided by it. The
incentive for change is the potential for an
increased tax base, providing additional funds
to the City for health, education, welfare and
other programs. However, major change within
largely residential neighborhoods, where the
residents and the businesses are mutually -
dependent one upon the other, requires the
active interest and participation and initiative
of local residents.

field_edited_text_processed:
11. Post-Study Observations

At the time the program for this study was
established, the scope of the project was limited
to three ‘‘neighborhood shopping centers’” in
Baltimore. The assignment was undertaken on
that basis but, during the course of the project,
a turning point was reached. These observations
are offered as a retrospective comment on the
study and hopefully will help in forming the
approach to similar studies.

The turning point was a realization that the
three areas under study were not merely
“'neighborhood shopping centers’’ and that
their problems were not merely those of small
commercial subcenters. At the same time, there
was a realization that the city was unlikely to
place the three areas high on its priority list and
commit major expenditures there if the three
areas were to continue as small neighborhood
shopping centers.

It became obvious that the traditional
identification of these areas as neighborhood
shopping centers had to change, because the
centers had a much larger role to play than that
of limited shopping areas.

In considering a broader role for the three areas,
it is necessary to regard the city--any city--as

a city made up of a number of sub-units or
communities of interest, and that each sub-unit
has a number of common or central functions.
In fact, the central functions often define the
extent of the community of interest.

Unlike central business districts--traditionally
acknowledged and defined as the central place
of a metropolitan area-the centers of these
sub-units or communities have not been
defined.

Based on this study and incorporated into its
recommendations are a number of conclusions
which are based on a broader concept of
community centers, rather than neighborhood
shopping areas. This new concept offers a new
perspective on community centers for these
reasons:

1. The role of the community center within a
citywide frame is redefined. No longer can
these centers be relegated to low-priority action
status. They deserve recognition as key areas
within the city where public commitment must
be concentrated, where private investment must
be stimulated, and through which social



programs are administered. Token parking,
traffic and retail service improvements will
themselves no longer suffice for the commu nity
center.

2. The role of a community center relative to
its community is redefined. Community centers
must reflect the character of the communities
they serve. Each center must have an identity
of social significance to its community and, to
do this, must offer the complete range of
services and resources that community needs.
Thus, if a community is predominantly black,
the center of that community should cater to
the needs, tastes and budgets of the Black
population. If a community is poor, then the
opportunities for job training, employment and
economic advancement should be concentrated
at the center. And if the community is both
poor and black, the priority for action at the
community center cannot be overstated.

3. The functional role of the commu nity center
is redefined. No longer can community centers
be merely conglomerations of retail stores. The
community center must be a multi-purpose
complex of activities. |t must be easily
accessible by road, mass transit or on foot. Its
activities must be broadened to include
compatible commercial uses, such as offices. lts
market must be increased and improved by
concentrating high-density housing within it or
around it. The broader concept of a community
center is the traditional concept of downtown
proportionately scaled to a community role.

4. The physical form of the community center
has to be reconstructed. Older one- and
two-story buildings constrained by obsolete
zoning ordinances cannot accommodate the
broader physical function defined above. The
air rights above these buildings and the large
parking areas they need are particularly
valuable. Not only will new multi-story
construction above retail uses and parking
provide valuable, concentrated space, it will
also provide improved accessibility to all the
uses involved. The air rights approach has
timing advantages as well: Centers can reserve
large parking lots as "“landbanks’ upon which
multi-story construction can be built when
sufficient demand is created.

5. The image of a community center as
self-contained is broadened to permit linkages
with other major community activities. When a

community is so dominated by a single activity
or character, and where that activity or'zl
character has physical implications, the'
community center should relate to it. A major
facility such as a hospital, university or
industrial complex provides needed markets for
a retail center. 1t also requires services,
accessibility and housing facilities which the
community center can provide. Thisis a
mutually beneficial trade-off which can be
facilitated by physical links such as pedestrian
malls, plazas and mutual parking areas.



6. The commitment to the commu nity center
has been redefined. In a period when the need
for neighborhood stability and personal
identification with and pride in one s own
neighborhood must be recognized as vitally
important to the city as a whole, city
governments must grant the community center
priority status. This means that decisions on
transit stops, decentralized city offices and
zoning changes should be directed toward the
needs of a community center. More important
where public expenditure must be made, the
traditional red tape, delays and budget cuts
must be avoided.

In order to effectively transform a problem ares
of a city into a viable business area, a
meaningful community center and a more
stabilized residential neighborhood, a coalition
of city officials, vested business interests and
representatives of the indigenous community
must all participate in the initial as well as the
subsequent stages of the planning process.

At a time when our older cities are plagued
with problems which outdate traditional
thinking, it is fashionable, and indeed
reasonable, to promote the concept of entirely
new towns which will give us the chance to
start again. These new towns will be models of
city building, reflecting all the new concepts
including those of community centers with a
much broader range of functions. We must
build these new towns, but we dare not forget
the older cities which are responsive to the
same needs. The initiation of new town
concepts in older cities could readily be given
momentum through the revitalization of cent!
places such as the Light Streets, Monument
Streets and Pennsylvania Avenues across the
nation.

—

field_edited_text_processed:
I1l. Background of the Program

Statement of Problem

In the post World War || decades, major
changes in shopping habits and population
expansion into the suburbs of our cities have
resulted in the creation of new regional
shopping complexes competing with older
business districts. These shifts were particularly
damaging to central business districts, and in
most major cities a variety of programs have
been initiated to assist these districts in the
difficult process of eliminating blighted sectors,
traffic congestion, parking shortages and in
setting the basis for physical and economic
revitalization.

The smaller established business districts have
also felt the impact of changing shopping
patterns and of population movements but have
not received either the level of concern or the
relative degree of public improvement efforts
that have gone to central areas.

The present circumstances of these centers vary
with relation to such factors as neighborhood
income, accessibility, the strength and
merchandising ability of local merchants and a
number of other factors. Some have been
severely affected by urban blight; others less so.
Some now have a considerable number of
vacant stores; others have maintained
themselves without major economic losses.

Under either condition, there is a need for a
sense of direction with regard to the future.
Virtually no older center can be viewed as well
designed or fully supported by adequate
circulation, parking, public facilities and
amenities.

These conditions have led to periodic demands
from the merchants of individual centers for
additional parking, improved lighting, better
trash collection and similar services. To the
degree that they can make their voices heard in
the inner circles of city government, when
funds are available and there is no organized
opposition to their proposals, some
improvements are made. However, these
isolated improvements are of limited value and
are far short of the general level of
improvement needed by these centers.

The problem is, therefore, to define what is
needed and to establish a program that would

permit those needs to be met over a period of
time.

Sponsorship of study

This study originated in Baltimore out of the
concern of the Mayor’s Advisory Committee on
Small Business about the need for a program of
improving the older centers and safeguarding
the future of small business operations in these
centers against increasing competition. The first
work undertaken in examining the centers and
their neighborhoods and their shopping
potentialities was carried out under Baltimore's
Community Renewal Program studies.

The sponsorship of this Demonstration Study
by the Mayor’s Advisory Committee on Small
Business was particularly advantageous since it
permitted a thorough review and discussion of
proposals without committing the planning and
urban renewal agencies of the City to official
action on any specific plan.

Representatives of Baltimore's Urban Renewal
and Housing Agency and the Department of
Planning were on the project’s Advisory Board
and the work of these agencies was utilized
during the course of this study.

The Study Areas

The Mayor'’s Advisory Commlttee on Small
Business recommended the study areas after
examining 17 older community shopping
centers, all located outside the central business
district. The three areas chosen for the study
were:

Light Street:

Located south of the central business district
near the Port of Baltimore, it serves a
blue-collar population and contains some
aggressive and moderately successful stores. The
shopping area is on a heavily travelled route
between the central business district and the
port area.

Monument Street:

A basically sound commercial strip located east
of the central business district. Although
deterioration is not yet serious, the businesses
serving the low- to moderate-income pOpulatlon
of the area are not thriving.

Pennsylvania Avenue:
A commercial strip cutting diagonally across

several blocks northwest of the central business
district. It contains areas of severe blight arid
has major traffic problems. The upper end of
the strip is a concentrated and active shopping
area and has been described as the center of the
Baltimore ghetto.

The three centers are typical of many older
shopping areas in cities throughout the United
States. Historically, they were important as
satellite cores which developed on the outskirts
of the growing city. All three centers were
actively developed between 1800 and 1880.

Today, the shopping areas are small centers in a
large region. Baltimore is the center of a
five-county region. Its downtown area is both
the center of Baltimore and to a lesser extent of
the entire region. The three areas under study
are among six such shopping areas in the city
containing public markets. The three shopping
areas are centers of communities which, for
purposes of study, are delineated as trade areas.
It is to these shopping areas that most residents
in the surrounding community come to
purchase food, drugs, furniture and clothing.

- While the three trade areas overlap with trade

areas of other neighborhood shopping areas, the
majority of shoppers originate from a slightly
smaller trade area, determined by a 15-minute
walking distance. All three centers are served by
public transportation and transfer points where
change of mode, transportation and direction
can be made.

In general, these procedures were successfully
followed and programs were formulated for the
three areas with a fair amount of agreement.
However, in the the process of following the
procedure, it became apparent that a number of
faulty assumptions were made. The study
resulted in a number of conclusions, separate
and apart from the design solutions, which are
considered to be particularly relevant to any
future work in this field.

As a matter of record the report describes the
methodology followed, the ultimate concepts
and the proposed solutions which are relevant
and appropriate. This is supplemented with
some observations and suggestions for various
approaches which would be more conductive to
the development of appropriate programs and
plans in this type of area in the future.

Community Renewal Program studies.

The sponsorship of this Demonstration Study
by the Mayor’s Advisory Committee on Small
Business was particularly advantageous since it
permitted a thorough review and discussion of
proposals without committing the planning and
urban renewal agencies of the City to official
action on any specific plan.

Representatives of Baltimore's Urban Renewal
and Housing Agency and the Department of
Planning were on the project’s Advisory Board
and the work of these agencies was utilized
during the course of this study.

The Study Areas

The Mayor'’s Advisory Commlttee on Small
Business recommended the study areas after
examining 17 older community shopping
centers, all located outside the central business
district. The three areas chosen for the study
were:

Light Street:

Located south of the central business district
near the Port of Baltimore, it serves a
blue-collar population and contains some
aggressive and moderately successful stores. The
shopping area is on a heavily travelled route
between the central business district and the
port area.

Monument Street:

A basically sound commercial strip located east
of the central business district. Although
deterioration is not yet serious, the businesses
serving the low- to moderate-income pOpulatlon
of the area are not thriving.

Pennsylvania Avenue:
A commercial strip cutting diagonally across

several blocks northwest of the central business
district. It contains areas of severe blight arid
has major traffic problems. The upper end of
the strip is a concentrated and active shopping
area and has been described as the center of the
Baltimore ghetto.

The three centers are typical of many older
shopping areas in cities throughout the United
States. Historically, they were important as
satellite cores which developed on the outskirts
of the growing city. All three centers were
actively developed between 1800 and 1880.

Today, the shopping areas are small centers in a
large region. Baltimore is the center of a
five-county region. Its downtown area is both
the center of Baltimore and to a lesser extent of
the entire region. The three areas under study
are among six such shopping areas in the city
containing public markets. The three shopping
areas are centers of communities which, for
purposes of study, are delineated as trade areas.
It is to these shopping areas that most residents
in the surrounding community come to
purchase food, drugs, furniture and clothing.

- While the three trade areas overlap with trade

areas of other neighborhood shopping areas, the
majority of shoppers originate from a slightly
smaller trade area, determined by a 15-minute
walking distance. All three centers are served by
public transportation and transfer points where
change of mode, transportation and direction
can be made.

In general, these procedures were successfully
followed and programs were formulated for the
three areas with a fair amount of agreement.
However, in the the process of following the
procedure, it became apparent that a number of
faulty assumptions were made. The study
resulted in a number of conclusions, separate
and apart from the design solutions, which are
considered to be particularly relevant to any
future work in this field.

As a matter of record the report describes the
methodology followed, the ultimate concepts
and the proposed solutions which are relevant
and appropriate. This is supplemented with
some observations and suggestions for various
approaches which would be more conductive to
the development of appropriate programs and
plans in this type of area in the future.

field_edited_text_processed:
IV. The Research Phase

1. Preliminary Survey

Numerous studies and documents prepared in
the previous five years were examined as
possible sources of background material. A
total of 69 reports, brochures and data sheets
and more than 40 maps--all prepared for
various agencies in Baltimore--were

examined to provide a general framework for
understanding the physical, social and
economic forces which had influenced the
development of these three study areas.

It was found that, physically, the three areas
have several characteristics in common, as well
as a few significant differences.

Once important as shopping areas for
residential developments on the fringe of the
growing city, they are now showing signs of
their age. There are large numbers of
deteriorated buildings which are functionally
inefficient and difficult to adapt to today’s
tastes. Ground-floor stores with apartments
above are common, often stretching for several
blocks along major streets or extending for
several blocks in several directions from a main
corner.

The shopping areas are small centers in a large
region, centered in Baltimore. Baltimore is the
center of a five-county region and its
downtown area serves this larger area as well as
the city itself.

The three areas studied each contain a public
market, a common structure divided into stalls
where vendors sell their wares, usually food.
Three other older shopping areas of the 17 such
areas identified by the city also contain a public
market.

The three shopping areas are patronized by
residents of surrounding neighborhoods who
can conveniently walk there to buy food, drugs,
clothing and furniture, as well as by a steadily
increasing number of shoppers who come by
private or public transportation. In that sense,
they serve as centers of a community. They also
have a focus as a place where people in the area
go to use public transportation. All three areas
are well served by public transportation and
also act as transfer points where people can
change mode of travel or change direction,
from one bus to another.

2. Survey and Analysis

a. Building survey

A detailed structural survey was made of all
buildings in the three study areas. A survey
form was designed to measure factors
contributing to deterioration and buildings
were classified into four general categories:

Standard

Deficient - 1st degree
Deficient - 2nd degree
Substandard

The categories were related as much as possible
to possible rehabilitation efforts in the future.
Structures requiring little or no rehabilitation
were rated as standard. Those requiring
rehabilitation so extensive as to be prohibitive
in cost were classified as substandard. In
between were the deficient buildings: Those
which could be easily rehabilitated and those
requiring substantial rehabilitation.

A manual was prepared and training sessions
held for city building inspectors who carried
out the survey, to insure that buildings were
evaluated on a uniform basis. Information
obtained was transferred to data processing
cards and analyzed on the basis of land uses
found in each study area and also on a
block-by-block basis within each area. The
findings of the structural survey are
summarized in the following table.

Analysis of Structural Survey Data

b. General Surveys ]

An evaluation was made of factors affecting the
environment of the three areas, including
exterior building condition, level of street and
sidewalk maintenance, nuisance uses, presence
of adequate utilities, condition of rear yards
and such favorable features as trees and
plantings.

Available city reports were reviewed and a
limited field inspection made to evaluate land
use, building conditions and community
facilities. Street and traffic plans were reviewed
and an evaluation made of traffic and its impact
on the areas. Existing parking facilities were
evaluated in terms of availability, type, location
and appearance.

Property owners in the three areas have made
only limited improvements to their premises
over the years. The resulting deterioration has
left the areas blighted and functionally
inefficient.

There is a high incidence of vacant land and
floor space, and property values have not
increased at a level experienced by other parts
of the city. In fact, tax assessments from 1953
to 1963, including changes in valuation
resulting from demolition and new
construction, showed a decrease in the
seventeen older areas of 6%, while showing an
increase of 27% in the remainder of the city.

Most streets in the three areas are congested,
and there is a lack of parking space for shoppers
and loading space for vehicles servicing the
businesses in the areas. This makes it difficult
for pedestrians to move about safely and
conveniently.

There is a distinct lack of amenities for people
in the area, such as open spaces for resting and
observation, and little, if any, landscaping. In
addition, the visual effect of signs, traffic
signals, street furniture, storefronts and
advertising combine to present an unattractive
scene to the shopper or passerby.

c. Market Studies

Market studies were carried out to determine
the economic potential of the three areas. The
studies consisted of:

field_edited_text_processed:
1. Review and Analysis of Existing Studies
Existing reports were examined to determine
the present function of each area, the size and
scope of its retail sector, characteristics of its
trade area population, and prospective
population and income levels. In addition, each
area was evaluated in terms of special problems
and assets.

General data regarding the city and the region
were examined as a framework for evaluating
the market potential of the three areas. Any
renewal activities, transportation proposals or
similar programs were evaluated to determine
their possible socio-economic effect on each
area.

2. Surveys

A mail survey was conducted among merchants
in the three study areas to gather information
relating to current sales trends, improvements
carried out or planned, and opinions regarding
ways of improving business.

Personal interviews were also carried out among
merchants in the three areas to get a firsthand
impression of their views on the business
outlook, the effects of planned or proposed
public activities such as mass transit and urban
renewal, and' feasible recommendations for
improving their area. It was also possible to
obtain from this survey some idea of the degree
of participation that could be expected in any
improvement program.

Other factors considered in the survey were
traffic and parking conditions, quality and type
of merchandise, driving time to competing
centers and general appearance of the study
area.

Surveys were also conducted of residents of the
trade areas of the three shopping centers to
determine shopping habits and preferences,
income and age groups, and attitudes toward
the facilities or lack of them in the three areas.

The market studies showed that the three
centers are highly dependent on the
surrounding residential areas for their economic
survival because most of their customers are
those who can walk there to shop.

But family income is low, unemployment rates
are high and there is steady decline in the

population of the three surrounding areas. All
of these factors contribute to a declining
market for the goods and services offered by
business in the three centers.

The three areas differ in some of their
socio-economic characteristics.

The Pennsylvania Avenue area, for example, is
in a predominantly Black neighborhood and for
many years was the main shopping area for
most Black people in Baltimore. Local
merchants indicated that many of their
customers continued to shop in the
Pennsylvania Avenue area after moving out of
the neighborhood.

The core of the shopping area has no vacancies
and higher than average sales volume. The
public market plays an important role in the
neighborhood and its sales figures amount to
$93 per square foot, compared to $78 for other
public markets.

Despite this, Pennsylvania Avenue merchants
are losing their customers. Between 1950 and
1960, the trade area population decreased by
20 percent. Urban renewal clearance has since
increased the downward trend. In addition,
changes in social attitudes; €conomic gains and
other factors have enabled many Black people
to move to other parts of the city. Further
clearance programs are expected to result in a
further 23 percent decline in population by
0.

The loss of customers and the continued
prospect of further decreases have caused
merchants--the majority of whom rent
premises--to hesitate in making further financial
commitments in the area.

The Light Street Area has no vacant stores in its
retail core and higher than average sales
volumes. There are vacant stores on the fringes
of the area and some marginal stores along
Charles Street. Although the public market
occupies a prime location, it is not used to its
fullest extent--27 percent of the stalls were

not rented at the time of this study.

The area’s population of 36,300 is primarily
blue-collar workers and about one-third is
Black. This results in merchants being faced
with varying and sometimes conflictin

demands for goods and services. The population



decreased by 23 percent between 1950 aﬁd
1960.

Problems in the Light Street area are not as
evident as in the Pennsylvania Avenue area, but
merchants are growing uncertain about the
future and are less inclined to invest in
improvements. Although the proposed Inner
Harbor project will add more than 1,000
dwelling units to the adjacent area, the
merchants feel that because they will have
higher incomes and because of the project’s
proximity to the CBD, the new residents will
shop elsewhere.

In contrast, Monument Street had a relatively
stable population between 1950 and 1960; the
median income was only slightly below the city
average and unemployment was relatively
moderate. The number of Black residents is
gradually increasing and merchants indicated
that their clientele is about evenly divided
between white and Black.

Although vacancy rates are low in the core area,
there are higher than average vacancies in the
fringe areas of the shopping center. The public
market occupies a prime location but 12
percent of its space is not rented and sales
volumes are low.

Expansion of Johns Hopkins Hospital facilities
is expected to add several thousand employees
and some permanent residents to the area.
Projections indicate an increasing population
but the shifting ethnic distribution may cause
problems for merchants.

field_edited_text_processed:
V. Preliminary Planning

Preliminary planning concepts were developed
at the earliest possible stage to enable
merchants and city officials to discuss various
alternatives for making improvements.

Preliminary concepts were based on an analysis
of the findings of the research phase. These
findings dealt with socio-economic
characteristics, existing physical relationships,
existing and proposed city programs an
environmental problems in the three areas.

For clarity and ease of understanding during
discussions with the various groups involved,
the findings of the study at this stage and the
implications drawn from them were
summarized in tabular form, grouped according
to the four categories shown above, and, with
the exception of socio-economic characteristics,
were also depicted graphically.

The findings and implications for each area are
summarized on the following pages:

1. Pennsylvania Avenue Area

a. Socio-Economic Characteristics

The implication drawn from the finding that
the trade area population is almost totally
Black was that specialized treatment would be
required for the retail core, taking into account
the types of merchandise required and the
concentration of a population that has
relatively low income levels.

The high vacancy rates and declining
population indicated a need to consolidate
retail and service facilities and to either reduce
retail floor space or increase the shopping area’s
drawing power by carrying out dramatic
improvements.

Pennsylvania Avenue has a strong retail core in
the sector of the public market, while the
weaker areas further away have suffered from
increasing dilapidation.

b. Existing Physical Relationships

A major implication in this category deals with
the need to avoid improvement programs that
would reduce the area’s population still further
by removing the multi-family dwellings that are
predominant without replacing them with other
types of housing.

The north-south street pattern, which serves as

a link between the central business district and
outer areas, is a prime cause of congestion,
indicating a need for an alternative route for
such traffic. The length of the commercial strip
development also indicates problems in
providing adequate off-street parking.

c. Present City Program and Proposals

These include intensive rehabilitation under the
Community Renewal Plan, additions to several
public housing projects and a major freeway
system, all of which will have a tendency to
reduce the trade area population and therefore
the potential for retail sales. In addition, a
proposed rapid transit line proposed for a
location a considerable distance away would
tend to pull shoppers away from Pennsylvania
Avenue.

The effect of other public programs of reducing
the population could be offset if housing
densities were increased in an extensive urban
renewal program proposed for the lower end of
Pennsylvania Avenue.

d. Environmental Problems

These dealt with the high incidence of
substandard and deficient buildings, traffic,
accumulation of junk and trash, the large
number of narrow lots and consequently
narrow stores and the extensive use of buildings
for both retailing and residential purposes.

These findings indicated that extensive
rehabilitation was unrealistic because of the
high cost, and that with a consolidation of the
retail core, the commercially deteriorated part
of the linear strip could be used for
high-density residential buildings. The findings
also indicated that through traffic should be
rerouted.

2. Light Street Area

a. Socio-Economic Characteristics

A declining population, relatively high
unemployment rates and an increasing number
of low-income Black people in the area is
reducing purchasing power and causing
conflicting demands for goods and services.

Despite a low vacancy rate, property values are
dropping and improvements are not being
made, indicating a declining position for the
area as a retail shopping center. Ways must be
found of strengthening the position of the

shopping area, including improving the |5qb|ic
market.

b. Existing Physical Relationships

The trade area is essentially an enclave of
owner-occupied row houses surrounded by
industrial and wholesale activities. This will
limit expansion of the trade area unless housing
density is increased.

The location of the area has made it a corridor
for north-south traffic which has had an adverse
effect, and an east-west orientation seems
desirable to conteract this effect. Existing
physical relationships are shown in graphic
form.

c. Present City Programs and Proposals

These include a major urban renewal project to
the north, a major east-west expressway,
extensive conservation and clearance programs
in adjacent areas and a proposal to intensify
industrial development in the area.

These proposals could have a beneficial effect if
full consideration is given to the area’s
potential. Otherwise, the area may increasingly
become an isolated community surrounded by
activities that do not benefit the shopping
center or make use of its potentialities.

d. Environmental Problems

The extensive pockets of decay, both structural
and functional, in the area provide prime
targets for improvements that'would reduce the
size of the commercial core and make it more
compact.

Because of Light Street’s importance as a
business street, traffic congestion should be
eliminated by diverting through traffic to
surrounding arterial roads. Trucks should be
discouraged from using the streets in the area,
possibly by improving alleyways and making
them suitable for loading and unloading.

3. Monument Street Area

a. Socio-Economic Characteristics

A relatively stable population, average incomes
and low vacancy rates compared to the other
areas give Monument Street a brighter future.
There is a need to reduce the amount of retail
floor space available, concentrating on the core
shopping area.
field_edited_text_value:
V. Preliminary Planning

Preliminary planning concepts were developed
at the earliest possible stage to enable
merchants and city officials to discuss various
alternatives for making improvements.

Preliminary concepts were based on an analysis
of the findings of the research phase. These
findings dealt with socio-economic
characteristics, existing physical relationships,
existing and proposed city programs an
environmental problems in the three areas.

For clarity and ease of understanding during
discussions with the various groups involved,
the findings of the study at this stage and the
implications drawn from them were
summarized in tabular form, grouped according
to the four categories shown above, and, with
the exception of socio-economic characteristics,
were also depicted graphically.

The findings and implications for each area are
summarized on the following pages:

1. Pennsylvania Avenue Area

a. Socio-Economic Characteristics

The implication drawn from the finding that
the trade area population is almost totally
Black was that specialized treatment would be
required for the retail core, taking into account
the types of merchandise required and the
concentration of a population that has
relatively low income levels.

The high vacancy rates and declining
population indicated a need to consolidate
retail and service facilities and to either reduce
retail floor space or increase the shopping area’s
drawing power by carrying out dramatic
improvements.

Pennsylvania Avenue has a strong retail core in
the sector of the public market, while the
weaker areas further away have suffered from
increasing dilapidation.

b. Existing Physical Relationships

A major implication in this category deals with
the need to avoid improvement programs that
would reduce the area’s population still further
by removing the multi-family dwellings that are
predominant without replacing them with other
types of housing.

The north-south street pattern, which serves as

a link between the central business district and
outer areas, is a prime cause of congestion,
indicating a need for an alternative route for
such traffic. The length of the commercial strip
development also indicates problems in
providing adequate off-street parking.

c. Present City Program and Proposals

These include intensive rehabilitation under the
Community Renewal Plan, additions to several
public housing projects and a major freeway
system, all of which will have a tendency to
reduce the trade area population and therefore
the potential for retail sales. In addition, a
proposed rapid transit line proposed for a
location a considerable distance away would
tend to pull shoppers away from Pennsylvania
Avenue.

The effect of other public programs of reducing
the population could be offset if housing
densities were increased in an extensive urban
renewal program proposed for the lower end of
Pennsylvania Avenue.

d. Environmental Problems

These dealt with the high incidence of
substandard and deficient buildings, traffic,
accumulation of junk and trash, the large
number of narrow lots and consequently
narrow stores and the extensive use of buildings
for both retailing and residential purposes.

These findings indicated that extensive
rehabilitation was unrealistic because of the
high cost, and that with a consolidation of the
retail core, the commercially deteriorated part
of the linear strip could be used for
high-density residential buildings. The findings
also indicated that through traffic should be
rerouted.

2. Light Street Area

a. Socio-Economic Characteristics

A declining population, relatively high
unemployment rates and an increasing number
of low-income Black people in the area is
reducing purchasing power and causing
conflicting demands for goods and services.

Despite a low vacancy rate, property values are
dropping and improvements are not being
made, indicating a declining position for the
area as a retail shopping center. Ways must be
found of strengthening the position of the

shopping area, including improving the |5qb|ic
market.

b. Existing Physical Relationships

The trade area is essentially an enclave of
owner-occupied row houses surrounded by
industrial and wholesale activities. This will
limit expansion of the trade area unless housing
density is increased.

The location of the area has made it a corridor
for north-south traffic which has had an adverse
effect, and an east-west orientation seems
desirable to conteract this effect. Existing
physical relationships are shown in graphic
form.

c. Present City Programs and Proposals

These include a major urban renewal project to
the north, a major east-west expressway,
extensive conservation and clearance programs
in adjacent areas and a proposal to intensify
industrial development in the area.

These proposals could have a beneficial effect if
full consideration is given to the area’s
potential. Otherwise, the area may increasingly
become an isolated community surrounded by
activities that do not benefit the shopping
center or make use of its potentialities.

d. Environmental Problems

The extensive pockets of decay, both structural
and functional, in the area provide prime
targets for improvements that'would reduce the
size of the commercial core and make it more
compact.

Because of Light Street’s importance as a
business street, traffic congestion should be
eliminated by diverting through traffic to
surrounding arterial roads. Trucks should be
discouraged from using the streets in the area,
possibly by improving alleyways and making
them suitable for loading and unloading.

3. Monument Street Area

a. Socio-Economic Characteristics

A relatively stable population, average incomes
and low vacancy rates compared to the other
areas give Monument Street a brighter future.
There is a need to reduce the amount of retail
floor space available, concentrating on the core
shopping area.

field_edited_text_processed:
Because of the high percentage of car
ownership, there is less emphasis on walk-in
trade and the need for off-street parking and
improved traffic circulation is greater. The high
proportion of owner-occupied stores, together
with a high number of tenant-businessmen, will
require a planning program that provides
investment opportunities. Because of these
factors, rehabilitation will take more time to
accomplish, but should be economically
feasible because of the condition of buildings.

The likelihood of only a moderate population
Increase and a trend toward an increase in lower
income families living in the area will make it
necessary to strengthen the shopping area and
attract customers from other parts of the city.
This will necessitate the improvement of the
public market.

b. Existing Physical Relationships
The trade area consists mainly of single-family

row houses, with a few pockets of two-family
and multi-family housing on the fringes. This
points to the possibility of increasing
population densities to create more market
potential for stores in the area. Another
possibility is to take advantage of the
expanding Johns Hopkins Hospital complex by
providing for the development of multi-family
housing in the immediate area and by providing
goods and services required by hospital
personnel.

Monument Street is part of a one-way street
system and ways of reducing or eliminating
congestion should be provided.

c. Present City Programs and Proposals
These include a conservation program
immediately surrounding the study area and
possible rehabilitation and clearance nearby.
These proposals provide an opportunity to

increase population densities and strengthi'ép the

trade area potential. ;
A proposed subway loop in the area is
considerably removed from the shopping
center. If strategically relocated, it could serve
both the Johns Hopkins complex and the
shopping center.

d. Environmental Problems

Apart from scattered pockets of structural and
functional decay and traffic congestion in the
area of the market, environmental problems are
considerably less acute than in the other study
areas, making it easier to accomplish an
improvement program.

field_edited_text_processed:
VI. Development of Planning Objectives

After discussion of the findings and
implications of the study phase by
representatives of merchants’ groups and city
officials, planning objectives were developed to
provide guidelines for overcoming some of the
problems that were beginning to emerge.

The objectives were presented for discussion in
tabular form for ease of comprehension. Each
objective was accompanied by a list of
considerations that would be necessary in
achieving the objectives. They are summarized
below:

1. Functional Use

The objectives were to strengthen the retail
core, increase population density, provide for
city and other governmental activities of a
decentralized nature, and create open space for
Its aesthetic value.

Among the considerations suggested for
discussion were:

Contracting the retail area to shorten walking
distances

Removing all conflicting nonretail uses

Provision of sites for multi-family housing and
provision for residential units above new stores

Using air rights over existing commercial
structures for multi-family residences

Reserving sites for such facilities as libraries,
health and welfare centers and similar
governmental offices

Creating open space by demolishing blighted
buildings and by providing small courts
between stores in selected locations.

2. Traffic and Circulation

Objectives were to minimize traffic congestion,
improve access to retail cores, provide a
pedestrian-way system and improve loading and
unloading facilities.

Considerations suggested for discussion
included:

Traffic loops around the retail cores

Direct connecting links between retail cores and

major thoroughfares and expressways
Convenient access to public transit facilities

Use of public open space in the form of malls
or small areas in conjunction with pedestrian
pathways

Development of a system of serviceways giving
access to the back entrances of commercial
buildings.

3. Parking

Objectives were to provide adequate off-street
parking in convenient locations and in harmony
with other elements of the core areas, to relate
the needs of moving traffic to the use of streets
for parking purposes and to restrict on-street
parking space to short-term parking.

Considerations were related to distribution of
parking spaces, their type, financing, visual
appearance, and locational considerations and
included:

Large off-street parking areas on the edge or in

the middle of the retail ccres, depending on
circumstances

Surface lots or underground or above-ground
structures, depending on demand, availability
of land and financing, with consideration given
to assembling surface areas for later
development with structures

Various types of financing
Convenient and attractive design

Connections between pedestrian passageways
and parking areas

On-street parking limited to fringe areas
surrounding core and allowed only during
off-peak hours.

4. Visual Appearance

The objective was to create a visual
environment easily identifiable with each area
and related to a central design theme.

Considerations were:

Special types of lighting

19

Uniform sign system

Street furniture designed for its specific usé and
location

Coordinated color scheme for restoration and
rehabilitation

Coordinated landscaping

5. Design Theme
The objective was to achieve a coordinated and
unifying design theme for each retail core area.

Considerations included:

A central design theme to create a visual
environment readily identifiable and which
would have a unifying effect

Use of unique symbols signifying different
types of stores.

6. Public Markets

The objective was to develop the public
markets as focal points and attractions.
Considerations included:

More attractive facades and landscaping of
market buildings and sites

Six-day weekly operation and improved
shopping facilities

A merchants’ cooperative which could lease
premises and be responsible for maintenance,
promotion and merchandising

Redesign of market buildings to permit outdoor
operation in suitable weather

Use of market buildings as accommodation for
merchants forced to move because of
improvement program

7. Elimination of Blight

The objective was to demolish all structures
that could not be rehabilitated economically--
except buildings of historic or architectural
significance--and use the land for new facilities
in keeping with the improvement program.

Considerations suggested for discussion
included:

field_edited_text_processed:
Conversion or elimination of incompatible use
or buildings

Use of rehabilitation where possible, in
preference to demolishing buildings

Incentives to owners to carry out rehabilitation

Increased services and facilities in improvement
areas

Uses of vacant land for retail and other uses
consistent with core area plans

8. General Considerations

In developing the goals and planning objectives
for the three areas, it became apparent that the
core areas served as focal points in their
communities as well as local centers for
shopping and other services.



They act as employment centers as well as areas
where people meet and mingle in a variety of
social activities. They form part of a general
group of facilities and services which people in
cities need and depend upon.

As a result of these considerations, a further
broad objective was developed which was not
provided for in the more functional objectives
listed. This was the development of these core
areas to the fullest degree as focal points of
neighborhood activity. This objective was
emphasized in preparing design plans for the
three areas and in recommending activities
which could be incorporated into them.

field_edited_text_processed:
VIl. Concept Plans

.

*
L

#*
* 3
*



1. Pennsylvania Avenue Area

The Concept Plan alternates provided for the
reduction of existing retail floor space,
improved traffic circulation, substantially
increased parking facilities, improved pedestrian
circulation and an expanded role for the public
market.

Alternative methods of achieving the concept
plans were explored utilizing rehabilitation
methods. However, because of the extensive
dilapidation in the area, even a limited
rehabilitation program would not be
economically feasible and would not amount to
much more than a paint-up, fix-up, clean-up
effort.

A more attractive alternative would be the
creation of a Town Center through a major
renewal program. This could become one of the
most improtant projects undertaken by the
city, to demonstrate that a retail shopping core
of this kind can be revitalized. It could become
the cornerstone for all future redevelopment
efforts in this area.

The Town Center could be designed to provide
a broad range of community services and
facilities, including health; welfare and
education. In addition to up-to-date shopping
facilities with adequate parking facilities, it
could make available facilities for social,
cultural, and similar community activities for
various age groups. Provisions for business and
professional offices and for governmental
activities in the Town Center would increase
employment opportunities in the area.

Many of the facilities now in the trade area
could be consolidated into the Town Center,
freeing land for housing.

The Town Center could serve as a focal point
for services and facilities provided by the city
and other public agencies to residents in the
area. In developing it to serve a wide range of
activities, local citizens should be involved in
the initial planning phases so that the center is
designed to serve their needs.

2. Light Street Area
Concept plans were directed to consolidating
the retail core, increasing residential densities

around the retail core, improving traffic and
pedestrian circulation, improving the public
market and providing more off-street parking.

3. Monument Street Area

Concept plans specified reducing the retail floor
space in the area, improving traffic circulation
and parking, and providing a series of open
corridors and plazas, connected by pedestrian
ways. One important element was to shift the
geographic center of the retail core closer to the
Johns Hopkins Hospital. Another was to
increase residential densities in or near the
study area. In addition, ways of using the
public market area to greater advantage were
explored.

4. Feasibility of Rehabilitation

As part of the preliminary planning stage, the
cost of rehabilitating buildings in the three
study areas was studied, based on an analysis of
improvements carried out by merchants in the
previous five years. This information was
obtained from the merchants’ survey and the
building conditions’ survey.

Ninty-nine merchants reported spending
significant sums since 1961 on improvements to
premises they occupied. Using selected
examples, unit costs for rehabilitation were
developed, based on the condition of the
structure. Costs averaged between $1 per square
foot for correcting deficiencies in a building
rated as standard and $12 a square foot for a
substandard building. Where storefront
modernization took place, the unit cost was
even higher.

Cost estimates were applied to 12 buildings in
each area. |t was assumed that rehabilitation
efforts would be confined to the first floor,
that the front facade would be renovated and
that the building would be used for retailing.
Estimated costs were applied uniformly to all
buildings regardless of the existing state of
storefront modernization. This was done to
provide a uniform base to determine whether a
reasonable range of costs could be arrived at for
the level of rehabilitation anticipated in the
Improvement program.

space in the area, improving traffic circulation
and parking, and providing a series of open
corridors and plazas, connected by pedestrian
ways. One important element was to shift the
geographic center of the retail core closer to the
Johns Hopkins Hospital. Another was to
increase residential densities in or near the
study area. In addition, ways of using the
public market area to greater advantage were
explored.

4. Feasibility of Rehabilitation

As part of the preliminary planning stage, the
cost of rehabilitating buildings in the three
study areas was studied, based on an analysis of
improvements carried out by merchants in the
previous five years. This information was
obtained from the merchants’ survey and the
building conditions’ survey.

Ninty-nine merchants reported spending
significant sums since 1961 on improvements to
premises they occupied. Using selected
examples, unit costs for rehabilitation were
developed, based on the condition of the
structure. Costs averaged between $1 per square
foot for correcting deficiencies in a building
rated as standard and $12 a square foot for a
substandard building. Where storefront
modernization took place, the unit cost was
even higher.

Cost estimates were applied to 12 buildings in
each area. |t was assumed that rehabilitation
efforts would be confined to the first floor,
that the front facade would be renovated and
that the building would be used for retailing.
Estimated costs were applied uniformly to all
buildings regardless of the existing state of
storefront modernization. This was done to
provide a uniform base to determine whether a
reasonable range of costs could be arrived at for
the level of rehabilitation anticipated in the
Improvement program.

field_edited_text_processed:
24

The estimates for rehabilitating buildings with
various degrees of dilapidation fell between the
following ranges:

Standard

Deficient - 1st degree
Deficient - 2nd degree
Substandard

$ 4,000-$ 5,000
$ 5,000 - $10,000
$10,000 - $17,000
$12,000 - $25,000

These figures were compared to property values
and a ratio established. Assuming an average
property value of $10,000 and using this ratio,
costs were estimated for the rehabilitation of a
commercial building in keeping with the goals
of the program. By categories of deficiency, the
following average costs were derived:

Standard $ 4,200
Deficient - 1st degree $ 6,500
Deficient - 2nd degree $12,100

Substandard $16,200

The study showed no apparent direct
relationship between the size of the business,
building condition or assessed value, and the
amount spent on rehabilitation improvements.
Rehabilitation had been undertaken or was
being considered even with buildings in poor or
bad condition.

It was concluded that the question of whether
rehabilitation could be considered feasible
could not be readily resolved. The extent to
which an owner or merchant would be willing
to invest further sums in a property appeared to
rest primarily on three factors: his financial
capability to undertake rehabilitation, the
competitive position of the business and the
anticipated return on his investment.

Other considerations which appeared to
influence the decision to undertake
rehabilitation were examined. They included a
number of individual factors, such as whether

the building was owned or rented, whether it
was a chain store or locally owned, the location
of the business and the effect of competition
and the availability of financing.

The merchant considering rehabilitation may
also be influenced in his decision if a strong
improvement program is contemplated
throughout his area. With group participation
by merchants, a snowballing effect is likely to
take place resulting in rehabilitation being
undertaken by more merchants. An areawide
improvement program could also offer the
attractions of city assistance, additional loan
sources and improved enforcement of codes
and ordinances.

Codes and ordinances controlling the
rehabilitation of existing buildings were
examined as part of this study and several
modifications suggested to make rehabilitation
more feasible.

field_edited_text_processed:
VIll. Recommended Development Plans

1. Introduction

Planning recommendations and development
plans for each of the three study areas were
prepared following discussion of the various
alternatives by merchant groups representing
the three areas, city agencies and the Mayor's
Advisory Committee on Small Business.

This represented the first phase of finalizing
and coordinating the various studies. The
recommended plans were accompanied by a
report on design themes and an action program
for carrying out the recommendations.

2. Planning Recommendations and
Development Plans

Plan recommendations dealt with proposals for
land use, traffic and community facilities.
Development plans described the possible
staging of urban renewal projects where these
appeared feasible, and provided cost estimates
for various public improvements, private
rehabilitation and new construction. The
development plans also suggested the types of
new enterprises or facilities that could
complement the existing retail core in each
study area.

A prime purpose of the proposals was to
provide a basis for the total rehabilitation of
each area with relation to specific objectives.
They provide a framework for unified action by
all concerned with the rehabilitation and
improvement program.

Plan proposals were related to planning
objectives and presented in tabular form. They
were accompanied by graphic illustrations of
various plan elements.

The recommendations and plans for each study
area follow:

a. Pennsylvania Avenue Area

The Pennsylvania Avenue plan calls for a major
effort leading not only to rehabilitation but to
the redevelopment of the shopping core. For
that reason, two concepts were preparad, one
considerably larger in scope than the other.
Although the plan for this area suggests a
combination of rehabilitation and
redevelopment, it would be possible to achieve
its objectives through rehabilitation alone, but
over a much longer time. It might also result in

27

the primary objective--the creation of a Tdvyn
Center--not being achieved. ;

The Town Center concept envisages the
creation of a neighborhood focal point as a
center for shopping, community services and
social activity. The plan separates pedestrians
and automobiles by providing pedestrian-ways,
connecting plazas, arcades and shopping areas.
For automobiles, there are convenient parking
lots on the edge of the core area and there are
lanes provided to provide access to buildings in
the core area. Residential buildings are provided
for in the core area to contribute to the vitality
of the unified Town Center and take full
advantage of the convenience of concentrated
services.

b. Light Street Area

The public market was selected as the focal
point and center of activities in the Light Street
area. The market area would help unify the
retail core and identify it as the central point
for traffic approaching from north and south.

The shopping area was proposed as a compact

" center surrounded by residential and office

uses, possibly in multi-use buildings. The
market area would be converted into a
pedestrian plaza and linked by pedestrian ways
to parking areas and shopping arcades in
mid-block locations.

A loop system would direct traffic around the
retail core and be joined to a one-way street
system linking the area with major traffic
routes passing through the area.

The recommendations also included provision
for such facilities as a branch library, and health
and welfare offices serving the neighborhood.

c. Monument Street Area

To take advantage of the proximity of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital complex, a
concentration of core uses closer to the
Hospital was recommended as part of the
process of creating a more compact retail
shopping area. This link between the retail core
and the hospital would be further strengthened
by providing for multi-use buildings
surrounding a pedestrian plaza with retail stores
on the ground floor. The same area was also
suggested as the location for bus and subways
stops.

field_edited_text_processed:
Another plaza was recommended in the area of
the public market and pedestrian ways would
link the two plazas as well as other parts of the
core. A traffic loop system was suggested to
eliminate or reduce congestion combined with a
one-way street system in and adjacent to the
core. The provision of space for public agencies
serving the area was also recommended.

3. Staging Possibilities

A suggested program for staging the
recommended improvements was presented in
graphic form for each study area. Priorities
were selected on the basis of improvements:

That were primarily rehabilitation

That resulted in maximum improvement with
minimum disruption of existing buildings

That resulted in objectives being more easily
attained

That cost less in relationship to the benefits
gained

That provided maximum benefit to existing
businesses

That could be carried out without federal urban
renewal aid and with relatively low financial aid
from the city

That required a minimum financial
commitment of property owners.

4. Cost Elements

It was considered unrealistic to prepare detailed
cost estimates for improvements in each area
because of the large number of unknown
factors. As guidelines, however, unit costs were
estimated which would enable involved groups
to prepare cost estimates of proposed
Improvements.

Unit costs were given for new construction,
including apartments, office buildings, retail
buildings, parking lot development, street and
sidewalk improvements, construction of
pedestrian malls and landscaping.

5. Design Considerations

An important aspect of the study was the
development of design themes for the three
study areas to indicate factors that should be
considered in any improvement programs and
to show by graphic illustration some examples
of the effects of good design treatment.

A variety of techniques was used which could
be applied to any one of the three areas.
Examples of blockfront treatment, showing
before and after effects, were shown to
demonstrate that the visual image of an area
could be changed considerably with little effort
or expense. Also illustrated was a variety of
designs for street furniture such as light
standards, directional signs, seating and
fountains.

29

Illustrative plans for showing possible treatment
of plaza areas were included to demonstrate the
wide range of possibilities even in limited or
confined areas.

6. Utilization of Urban Renewal

Factors to be considered if urban renewal
projects were utilized to carry out the planning
proposals for the three study areas were
examined. They included the eligibility of
possible project areas, costs, extent and
proposed use of land to be made available for
new development, and relocation requirements.

The review did not attempt to determine
whether urban renewal should or should not be
used but was intended to outline the scope and
extent of work and expense connected with
large-scale renewal programs.

Suggested boundaries for urban renewal project
areas were described within the three areas. A
review of survey data indicated that the three
areas were eligible for urban renewal assistance
in terms of blight and environmental
deficiencies. Estimates were made of relocation
requirements in each area. Cost estimates
ranged from $2.6 million for a minimum area in
the Monument Street area to $14 million for
part of the Pennsylvania Avenue area. Costs
were broken down to show gross and net
project costs and the estimated local and
federal shares, based on a 25% local
contribution.

standards, directional signs, seating and
fountains.

29

Illustrative plans for showing possible treatment
of plaza areas were included to demonstrate the
wide range of possibilities even in limited or
confined areas.

6. Utilization of Urban Renewal

Factors to be considered if urban renewal
projects were utilized to carry out the planning
proposals for the three study areas were
examined. They included the eligibility of
possible project areas, costs, extent and
proposed use of land to be made available for
new development, and relocation requirements.

The review did not attempt to determine
whether urban renewal should or should not be
used but was intended to outline the scope and
extent of work and expense connected with
large-scale renewal programs.

Suggested boundaries for urban renewal project
areas were described within the three areas. A
review of survey data indicated that the three
areas were eligible for urban renewal assistance
in terms of blight and environmental
deficiencies. Estimates were made of relocation
requirements in each area. Cost estimates
ranged from $2.6 million for a minimum area in
the Monument Street area to $14 million for
part of the Pennsylvania Avenue area. Costs
were broken down to show gross and net
project costs and the estimated local and
federal shares, based on a 25% local
contribution.

field_edited_text_processed:
IX. Recommendations for Action

1. Search for Identity

The solutions recommended for the three study
areas are clearly more than a paint-up, fix-up or
cosmetic approach. The answers lie in a
restructuring of the role of each area as the
multi-purpose center of each community.

The official city plan, however, does not
recognize the problem of deteriorating
neighborhood shopping centers as a
community-oriented one in terms of the urban
structure. Designated as no more than retail
shopping areas, the centers are certain to
continue deteriorating in the face of
competition from suburban shopping centers,
lack of public improvements and the general
decay of the physical and social environment,

The centers need an identity around which a
community can prosper. With such an identity,
both the center and the community it serves
would benefit from increased recognition and
private investment. In search of an identity, it
was concluded that the multi-purpose role of
each center could be enhanced by:

Providing a stop (subway or bus) within it of
the new proposed rapid mass transit system

Providing residenfial units for young people and
the elderly

Providing a strong physical relationship to
existing institutions (e.g., Johns Hopkins
Hospital in the Monument Street Area).

These objectives and the needs of the existing
and potential commercial establishments can be
met physically, as described in the plan
proposals, by such devices as:

Using lofts and unused spaces above stores
more efficiently

Using air rights above parking lots and other
spaces for high-rise development

Opening up malls and plazas to relate to
commercial establishments

Combining public and private use in one
structure

None of these proposals, however, is feasible
within the current image of the shopping areas.

Many of the individual store owners are
wrestling with marginal businesses. The city is
heavily committed elsewhere and private
investors have shown little interest in these
older shopping centers.

Significant change is, therefore, unlikely
without the introduction of a broader concept
of the use and the value of these centers.

2. Commitments to Revitalization

If the community center concept is to be
realized, certain commitments to the three
areas must be recognized by:

a. City of Baltimore

The City of Baltimore is faced with a
tremendous backlog of work in the public
sector. Higher priorities for the use of federal
funds for urban renewal programs have been
established for other areas of the city, including
the central business district, the port area and
highly concentrated residential slums.

In terms of city policy, the three shopping
centers have not been singled out for any
special attention, except that they--along with
similar older neighborhood shopping areas--have
been identified in the city's.Community
Renewal Program, together with their
boundaries, trading areas and parking
requirements.

The city should recognize the role of these
areas as community centers, as focal points of
their respective neighborhoods. With this
recognition must come commitments in the
form of policies which will bolster and expand
the role of the existing shopping areas as
community centers. The city must accept the
idea that the central business district in as large
a metropolitan area as Baltimore cannot alone
serve the entire shopping needs of the city and
the surrounding region, and that properly
organized and well-functioning community
centers will enable the CBD to perform its true
role as the center of a large region, containing
the commercial, social and cultural amenities
required by a large population.

To accept this concept will require acceptance
of the idea that proposals to expand and
strengthen the smaller community centers such
as the three under study will not have a harmful
effect on the central business district.

31

It will require the formulation of transportation
plans that recognize the community center\as
the focal point of the surrounding area. It will
require action which will lead to the
establishment of post offices, libraries, health
services and other community facilities and
activities within the new Town Center. It will
require zoning and other planning policies
which permit increased residential densities in
and around the commercial cores and the
development of air rights over existing
properties.

Perhaps more significantly than any other
point, it will require acceptance of the idea that
the city should work to establish these centers
as centers of interest for the surrounding
population. Despite the possibility of criticism
that this policy will increase segregation and
perpetuate ghettos, the concept of a strong
focal point is valid and important in giving
identity, vitality and common meaning to an
area, regardless of whether it is predominantly
populated by white people or nonwhite people.

“ b. Community

The commitment of community residents to
the concept of a strengthened community
center is difficult to analyze and project. The
obvious commitment is illustrated by the high
percentage of walk-in trade patronizing retail
establishments in the three areas. The residents
of the community surrounding each shopping
center need the facilities provided and would
presumably patronize a better-organized
community center more if it provided an
expanded range of goods and services and a
host of community programs and services.

In discussing concept plans with neighborhood
residents, it was found that there was very little
dialogue between the merchants and the
surrounding residents. There was some
resentment, in fact, to the proposals to create
better parking facilities. This resulted from the
attitude that better housing facilities were of
more importance than parking facilities.

Community residents should be able to identify
their self-interests with that of the center’s and
to participate in decisions affecting its future,
which could lead to job training programs and
more employment opportunities in addition to
an improved center.

field_edited_text_processed:
32

c. Merchants

The relatively low percentage of merchants who
own their properties makes it difficult to
encourage improvements that would enhance
the area and contribute to the concept of an
active and viable Town Center.

To the extent that the merchants are highly
dependent on the surrounding neighborhood
for their livelihood, they are committed to its
future. This commitment should be expanded
and deepened in the formulation of plans for
the creation of community centers by
encouraging the participation of merchants in
the decision-making process and providing
opportunities for them to improve their
premises.

d. Property Owners

Property owners fall into two

categories: Those who operate businesses in
the shopping centers and those who rent their
buildings to others. It is reasonable to presume
that those who conduct business in their own
premises have a higher degree of commitment
to the area than absentee landlords.

If the community center concept is to be
successfully implemented, property owners will
have to make'a heavier commitment to the
centers in which their properties are located.
This commitment can take the form of
participation in new investment programs
organized by groups of merchants and owners
banding together, and in other community
groups that recognize the community interest
and work on its behalf. The commitment will
also require improvements to property within
the framework of a general plan of
rehabilitation

3. Need for Cooperation

The program for the improvement of the
demonstration areas is designed, in part, to
establish new patterns of cooperation at the
city level among private enterprise, local
merchants, public agencies, and local residents.
Cooperative planning and program
implementation among these groups is
proposed to achieve the following major
objectives:

To provide the private retail and service
facilities that reflect the consumer needs of
local residents.



To promote maximum local community
identification with the use of the shopping
facilities.

To create a viable center of community interest
and activity as well as an economically
successful shopping center.

To create a functionally and physically
attractive asset in the overall neighborhood
rehabilitation program area.

To generate the maximum renewal of
productive investment and employrmient
opportunities for local residents.

To increase the assessable real estate tax base.

a. Citizens Advisory Council

Based on these objectives, it is essential that
communication with and participation of
neighborhood groups and individuals be
initiated early in the formulation of a
development program. Neighborhood
participation should perhaps be formalized into
a citizens advisory council with a clearly

delineated role in the formulation of policy and

program proposals.

Based on the findings, analyses and conclusions
of this study, a citizens advisory council can be
provided with an adequate basis for discussing
and contributing to major aspects of the
rehabilitation program. A program of
neighborhood participation would be an
excellent vehicle for identifying neighborhood
needs and attitudes that bear on
implementation of the rehabilitation program.
Moreover, this type of neighborhood
participation is likely to offer an effective
approach to dissemination of information to
neighborhood residents.

b. Small Business Commission

Within the existing framework of city
government, there is a need for an agency
directly concerned with the activities of small
businessmen within the community. A small
business commission with the necessary staff
could undertake certain important activities. It
could receive funds from the city government
for its operation, solicit funds from private
individuals or negotiate with other government
agencies at the federal or state level to carry out
programs.

By creating a Small Business Commission
(SBC), the city would be accepting the
responsibility for providing the needed
leadership. An SBC would:

Provide managerial training for small
businessmen

Become a clearinghouse for financial guidance
and assistance

Aid in loan application processing

Provide technical and other assistance in the
rehabilitation or construction of commercial
facilities and structures

Develop plans and programs for areas
containing primarily retailing and commercial
establishments

Coordinate its planning activities with those of
other city agencies

Coordinate development pfograms within
specified planning areas with other city agencies
providing supporting facilities and services

Provide fegal services to groups of merchants or
property owners banding together to form a
development corporation’ . A

Suggest to City Council legislation needed to
carry out its programs

In general, serve as liaison between the small
business community and city, state and federal
agencies

Every aspect of program initiation and
execution proposed in this study should be
carried out in close collaboration with
neighborhood groups.

4. Employment Opportunities

While it was outside the scope of the study to
discuss job opportunities for neighborhood
residents, it would be a severe oversight to
ignore this aspect of the potential program. The
success of the rehabilitation program would be
measurably improved by the creation of new
employment opportunities in the study areas.
Thus, there should be provision for generating
employment opportunities relating to existing
or proposed training programs.

a0
