field_edited_text_processed:
Information on such programs should be
disseminated to participating neighborhood
groups which, in turn, would spread
information to local residents, relating training
needs and opportunities to projected or
available jobs. Many of the training activities
could be conducted under MDTA's On-the-Job
Training Program supplemented by classroom
training and related basic education.

5. Air Rights Housing

In implementing the community concept, the
provision of housing is of prime importance.
Consideration should be given to the use of air
rights over existing and new commercial
buildings for this housing in a similar way that
air rights over railroads and highways have been
used for this and other types of development.

There are major advantages to using this
important resource:

The community centers would be ideal
locations for housing for such groups as the
elderly and young couples. They have a full
array of shopping; they offer employment
opportunities; they are generally close to other



public facilities; and they are activity areas
without the very high degree of movement and
activities associated with the central business
district.

Land for development is already available in the
form of existing parking lots or will be acquired
for this purpose in the future. This land can be
used for the future development of the air
rights over it and one of the objectives of
acquiring land for parking should be to create a
landbank. There may be no existing legal basis
for using land acquired for parking for other
uses, but this is a matter that could be dealt
with thorugh appropriate legislative action.

Most business uses in the neighborhood
shopping areas need only a single floor. Upper
floors that are used for storage, run-down
rooming units, or are unused could be sheared
off and the air rights used for other
development. Further engineering and
architectural studies would be necessary to
accomplish this. Another method would involve
the reconstruction of buildings containing
stores on the ground level, and residential
accommodation above.

30

Whichever procedure is followed, the air rights
over these small business areas representa
valuable city resource and should be more fully
utilized than has generally been the case in the
past. In undertaking such development over
parking and shopping areas, it becomes
relatively easy to keep all service facilities
below grade, with the residential structures
rising from a platform that may have sitting
areas, play space, a garden, a swimming pool
and similar facilities.

field_edited_text_processed:
X. Local Involvement

1. Selection of Study Areas

One of the early decisions made by the Mayor’s
Advisory Committee on Small Business was to
select three of the seventeen older shopping
areas for study instead of singling out one or
two. The rationale was twofold:

a. While none of the three areas could be said to
be typical of all older retail centers, the
combination of three diverse areas came as
close as possible, thus fulfilling the
Demonstration Grant requirement for national
applicability.

b. The Light Street, Monument Street and
Pennsylvania Avenue merchants’ associations
were among the most active and most
progressive in the city; hence, there was reason
to expect a high degree of cooperation in the
development and, hopefully, subsequent
implementation of the plans.

Despite their dependence, to varying degrees,
upon the pedestrian shopper, all three areas
were in critical need of parking. Many shoppers
will bypass closer centers to drive to a more
distant center for a variety of reasons. Some
may have moved from the neighborhood but
continue the habit of shopping in familiar
surroundings; some follow a family tradition of
many years; some have built up a personal
relationship with an owner, manager or sales
person; and some are accepted as charge
account customers by neighborhood stores and
cannot or do not avail themselves of the same
privilege in department stores. Each of the
three areas contains a public market which has
an attraction for many shoppers not within
walking distance. And even those within
walking distance often require a car to load
bulky marketing.

During this Demonstration Project, a precedent
was established with the opening of the City's
first neighborhood off-street parking lot in the
Monument Street business area. A lot for the
Light Street area has been approved and should
be operational in the near future. In each case,
the merchants’ association leases the lot from
the City, manages it and returns all revenue
from its use to the City, with a minimum per
dnnum guarantee. It was felt by the

Committee that the leverage provided by

these lots would be helpful in stimulating the
INitiative for future economic development.

2. Light Street and Monument Street
Although the individual characteristics of each
of the subject areas has been discussed
previously in this report, they share in common
the fact that, except for Charles Street, one
block to the west of Light Street, neither has
yet deteriorated to the degree necessary for
meeting urban renewal criteria. The problem
here, as in so many other fairly healthy centers
elsewhere, is that there are no provisions for
dealing with moderate blight and no funds
available for “‘preventive rehabilitation.”

In seeking an answer, the Small Business
Committee met with representatives of the
business areas and members of the city
administration. Three possible courses of action
were discussed:

~a. Spot clearance. While it would successfully

eliminate the blighted sections in or adjacent to
the core, it was felt that the process would be
too costly and too time-consuming in relation
to the benefits gained.

b. Creation of a citywide Development
Corporation. The Corporation would be a
private one, albeit with quasi-governmental
status, working closely with the appropriate
city agencies, particularly Planning and Housing
and Community Development. Its purpose
would be to stimulate and coordinate all
nonresidential economic development in the
city, including industrial and commercial as
well as retail.

Financing for the Development Corporation
could come from the private sector and from
the Small Business Administration’s 502
Program. Small local development companies
organized for specific and limited objectives
could be formed in such areas as Light Street
and Monument Street. The Development
Corporation would provide professional,
technical and, in some cases, financial
assistance. Details of such a plan must be
further refined and objections expressed to it
must be dealt with.

c. Creation of a “’‘Business Improvement
District.”” This appears to have the most
promise of the three alternatives, and is
essentially a "'self-help’’ program. At the
request of a given business area, the city’s
Department of Planning would assign a district

37

planner to work with the merchants, propérty
owners and, if appropriate, the residents. Any
plan presented would require the approval of
property owners who represent a substantial
majority of the total assessed valuation of the
proposed project district. The City would then
be authorized to issue a bond to finance
detailed planning and execution of an approved
project. The City's investment would be
recovered through an ad valorem assessment to
be imposed upon the properties benefiting
from the improvements, so that it would turn
out to be a self-liquidating venture. The

Maryland General Assembly would have to pass

enabling legislation to give Baltimore this
authority.

In order to more effectively implement such a
project, it would be most helpful if present
federal policy providing long-term low-interest
loans for nonresidential rehabilitation in urban
renewal areas were to be amended so as to offer
the same benefits to a designated Business
Improvement District. ‘

.3.. Pennsylvania Avenue

The Pennsylvania Avenue area offers both the
greatest challenge and the greatest opportunity.
During the term of this Demonstration Project,
it was included as part of the Upton, Urban
Renewal Project and was designated in total
within the Model Cities boundaries.

a. Background

From its earliest days, Pennsylvania Avenue was
a business street. |t was the first road linking
this developing area with rural sections to the
northwest and to the State of Pennsylvania,
hence its name. In 1869, the City Council
provided funds for the purchase of the present
site of the Lafayette Market. One may visualize
the scene in those days of nearby farmers
pulling their wagons down Pennsylvania Road
to sell meats and produce to the inhabitants of
this growing residential area. However, as busy
as it was during the latter part of the 19th and
early part of the 20th centuries, it was not until
after World War | that Pennsylvania Avenue
developed a uniqueness of wider significance in
Baltimore.

Just shortly after the turn of the century, many
Black families who previously occupied houses
only on the small alley streets moved into
residences on the main streets. The ‘Avenue’’
field_edited_text_value:
X. Local Involvement

1. Selection of Study Areas

One of the early decisions made by the Mayor’s
Advisory Committee on Small Business was to
select three of the seventeen older shopping
areas for study instead of singling out one or
two. The rationale was twofold:

a. While none of the three areas could be said to
be typical of all older retail centers, the
combination of three diverse areas came as
close as possible, thus fulfilling the
Demonstration Grant requirement for national
applicability.

b. The Light Street, Monument Street and
Pennsylvania Avenue merchants’ associations
were among the most active and most
progressive in the city; hence, there was reason
to expect a high degree of cooperation in the
development and, hopefully, subsequent
implementation of the plans.

Despite their dependence, to varying degrees,
upon the pedestrian shopper, all three areas
were in critical need of parking. Many shoppers
will bypass closer centers to drive to a more
distant center for a variety of reasons. Some
may have moved from the neighborhood but
continue the habit of shopping in familiar
surroundings; some follow a family tradition of
many years; some have built up a personal
relationship with an owner, manager or sales
person; and some are accepted as charge
account customers by neighborhood stores and
cannot or do not avail themselves of the same
privilege in department stores. Each of the
three areas contains a public market which has
an attraction for many shoppers not within
walking distance. And even those within
walking distance often require a car to load
bulky marketing.

During this Demonstration Project, a precedent
was established with the opening of the City's
first neighborhood off-street parking lot in the
Monument Street business area. A lot for the
Light Street area has been approved and should
be operational in the near future. In each case,
the merchants’ association leases the lot from
the City, manages it and returns all revenue
from its use to the City, with a minimum per
dnnum guarantee. It was felt by the

Committee that the leverage provided by

these lots would be helpful in stimulating the
INitiative for future economic development.

2. Light Street and Monument Street
Although the individual characteristics of each
of the subject areas has been discussed
previously in this report, they share in common
the fact that, except for Charles Street, one
block to the west of Light Street, neither has
yet deteriorated to the degree necessary for
meeting urban renewal criteria. The problem
here, as in so many other fairly healthy centers
elsewhere, is that there are no provisions for
dealing with moderate blight and no funds
available for “‘preventive rehabilitation.”

In seeking an answer, the Small Business
Committee met with representatives of the
business areas and members of the city
administration. Three possible courses of action
were discussed:

~a. Spot clearance. While it would successfully

eliminate the blighted sections in or adjacent to
the core, it was felt that the process would be
too costly and too time-consuming in relation
to the benefits gained.

b. Creation of a citywide Development
Corporation. The Corporation would be a
private one, albeit with quasi-governmental
status, working closely with the appropriate
city agencies, particularly Planning and Housing
and Community Development. Its purpose
would be to stimulate and coordinate all
nonresidential economic development in the
city, including industrial and commercial as
well as retail.

Financing for the Development Corporation
could come from the private sector and from
the Small Business Administration’s 502
Program. Small local development companies
organized for specific and limited objectives
could be formed in such areas as Light Street
and Monument Street. The Development
Corporation would provide professional,
technical and, in some cases, financial
assistance. Details of such a plan must be
further refined and objections expressed to it
must be dealt with.

c. Creation of a “’‘Business Improvement
District.”” This appears to have the most
promise of the three alternatives, and is
essentially a "'self-help’’ program. At the
request of a given business area, the city’s
Department of Planning would assign a district

37

planner to work with the merchants, propérty
owners and, if appropriate, the residents. Any
plan presented would require the approval of
property owners who represent a substantial
majority of the total assessed valuation of the
proposed project district. The City would then
be authorized to issue a bond to finance
detailed planning and execution of an approved
project. The City's investment would be
recovered through an ad valorem assessment to
be imposed upon the properties benefiting
from the improvements, so that it would turn
out to be a self-liquidating venture. The

Maryland General Assembly would have to pass

enabling legislation to give Baltimore this
authority.

In order to more effectively implement such a
project, it would be most helpful if present
federal policy providing long-term low-interest
loans for nonresidential rehabilitation in urban
renewal areas were to be amended so as to offer
the same benefits to a designated Business
Improvement District. ‘

.3.. Pennsylvania Avenue

The Pennsylvania Avenue area offers both the
greatest challenge and the greatest opportunity.
During the term of this Demonstration Project,
it was included as part of the Upton, Urban
Renewal Project and was designated in total
within the Model Cities boundaries.

a. Background

From its earliest days, Pennsylvania Avenue was
a business street. |t was the first road linking
this developing area with rural sections to the
northwest and to the State of Pennsylvania,
hence its name. In 1869, the City Council
provided funds for the purchase of the present
site of the Lafayette Market. One may visualize
the scene in those days of nearby farmers
pulling their wagons down Pennsylvania Road
to sell meats and produce to the inhabitants of
this growing residential area. However, as busy
as it was during the latter part of the 19th and
early part of the 20th centuries, it was not until
after World War | that Pennsylvania Avenue
developed a uniqueness of wider significance in
Baltimore.

Just shortly after the turn of the century, many
Black families who previously occupied houses
only on the small alley streets moved into
residences on the main streets. The ‘Avenue’’

field_edited_text_processed:
38

came to be a street of considerable importance
in the life of the Black community. Theaters
and other places of entertainment built in the
1920’s heralded three decades of relative
glamor and excitement for Pennsylvania
Avenue. Life was dramatically expressed in
music, song and dance from the stage, and
many small “‘clubs’’ provided a setting for
relaxation and laughter. Pennsylvania Avenue
became not only the shopping street for the
community, but its entertainment center as
well. Segregation practices of that time served
to strengthen the focus which the Avenue
provided for the public life of the Black
community. |f they were not served in other
places, this was their street for shopping, for
entertainment and for their parades. The
Halloween and Easter Parades on the Avenue
were gala events.

The list of celeprities who played the Avenue is
long: Chick Webb, Ella Fitzgerald, Louis
Armstrong, Earl ““Father’’ Hines, Count Basie,
Duke Ellington, Lucky Millinder, Sara Vaughn,
Billie Holliday, Tiny Bradshaw, Cab Calloway,
Ray Anthony, Woody Herman, the Ink Spots,
Lena Horne, Pearl Bailey, '‘Baby’’ Lawrence,
Charlie Barnet, and many others. Cab Calloway
and "‘Baby’’ Lawrence were raised in this area.
However, life on Pennsylvania Avenue changed
along with the wider and stronger changes in
Baltimore and the nation. Since the early
1950’s, the vitality of the Avenue has declined.
Social progress has permitted Black shoppers to
purchase services throughout the city. Shopping
and entertainment patterns have changed. In
1970, the Avenue’s needs are redevelopment
and renewal.

stage of the project, all efforts were visualized
as being restricted to the business area only, so
those meetings were with businessmen only.
That was a mistake. When the Town Center
concept began to emerge, a meeting was then
held with the residents as well as the
businessmen. The presentation was somewhat

b. Community Participation

Following the approval of its Demonstration
Grant application, the Mayor’s Advisory
Committee on Small Business held several
meetings with representatives of the
Pennsylvania Avenue-Lafayette Market
Association (P.A.L.M.A.) and other

stage of the project, all efforts were visualized
as being restricted to the business area only, so
those meetings were with businessmen only.
That was a mistake. When the Town Center
concept began to emerge, a meeting was then
held with the residents as well as the
businessmen. The presentation was somewhat

field_edited_text_processed:
39

obscured in the justifiable resentment of the
residents at not being asked to participate from
the very inception of the project. Even though
vastly improved relations were obtained in
many subsequent meetings with the residents,
they never altogether forgot what they
considered a slight.

When the Upton Urban Renewal Project was
announced, in conformance with federal
requirements for local participation, the Upton
Planning Committee was formed. That
Committee was comprised of residents, area
businessmen, and representatives of area
churches and of other organizations. The
Director of the Mayor’s Advisory Committee
on Small Business was invited to sit as a
member. Residents of the area made up the
majority of the membership and leadership.
During its regular bi-weekly and frequent
subcommittee meetings such broad subjects
were discussed as beautification, code
enforcement, traffic and transportation,
parking, health, sanitation, education,
employment, housing, recreation and business
rehabilitation.

It became obvious from these many meetings,
contrary to the view of those who would design
the ideal plan and leave it to others to execute,
that a realistic possibility for implementation
must be in clear view from the very beginning,
even if it means acceptance of less than the
ideal. The importance of community
involvement in the embryonic stages of a
proposed project should not be &nderestimated.
The delays and frustrations involved are more
than offset by the community support gained
which is a political necessity in influencing
decision makers.

In the case of the Upton Project, three
examples bear out the truth of the preceding
sentence:

1. As the Demonstration Grant study
progressed, it became increasingly obvious that
only massive urban renewal treatment could
provide the necessary means to carry out a
Town Center concept. Despite official efforts
by the Small Business Committee to include the
business area in the Upton Project, the City's
plans to include it in a subsequent project some
six to eight years in the future did not change.
However, after the Upton Planning Committee

In the case of the Upton Project, three
examples bear out the truth of the preceding
sentence:

1. As the Demonstration Grant study
progressed, it became increasingly obvious that
only massive urban renewal treatment could
provide the necessary means to carry out a
Town Center concept. Despite official efforts
by the Small Business Committee to include the
business area in the Upton Project, the City's
plans to include it in a subsequent project some
six to eight years in the future did not change.
However, after the Upton Planning Committee

field_edited_text_processed:
40

requested its inclusion in the plan, the City
reconsidered and decided to do so.

2. At the behest of the Department of Transit
and Traffic, the Planning Department favorably
recommended a proposal to widen Pennsylvania
Avenue and convert it into a six-lane
thoroughfare. Over the objections of the Small
Business Committee, the plan cleared the
various agencies and was submitted to the
Mayor for final approval. Again, it was through
the efforts of the Upton Planning Committee
that the Mayor decided against it.

3. Consultants for a metropolitan mass transit
system had recommended an express stop some
distance removed from the core of the
Pennsylvania Avenue business area. After
meeting with the Upton Planning Committee,
the plan was revised and the recommended stop
placed in the heart of the business area.

Because the preponderance of the viable
businesses in the core area were white-owned
and almost 100% of the shoppers were Black,
one of the objectives of the Demonstration
Project was to create an integrated business
community through encouraging and abetting

minority entrepreneurship. At the beginning of
the project, while a number of the stores had
Black managers, there was only one Black
owner in the P.A.L.M.A. business association.
Today, there are five, and one of the largest
stores in the area is on the verge of making the
transition from white to Black ownership.
There is a strong possibility that within the
next decade, the majority of the businesses in
this area will be owned by Black entrepreneurs.

Participation in deliberations of the Upton
Planning Committee was not without problems
for the white businessmen. In many cases, their
motives were viewed with suspicion and they
were constantly put on the defensive. Several of
the white businessmen failed to understand the
psychological necessity that impelled the
distrust and antagonism, and gave up after one
or two meetings. However, those that remained
witnessed a marked decrease in hostility and a
concomitant increase in communication.
Transcending all personal hang-ups, there
emerged the intense desire of the residents for a
better community for their children than the
one in which they were raised. After two years
of meetings, agreements and disagreements,
frustrations and aggravation, pleasant

discussions and harsh words, a final approval
was given to the Upton Urban Renewal Plan
and signed by the Mayor. It is significant that
the final approved plan on which
implementation will begin within the year bears
a remarkable similarity to the concept
developed earlier on the Demonstration Project
as contained in this report. There were those
who felt that the same results could have been
achieved in less time and with far less effort,
and while they may be right, it is equally true
that the plan will be more meaningful to those
affected by it because they had a voice in its
preparation.

field_edited_text_processed:
Dear Citizen:

Baltimore’s Harbor offers a remarkable variety of
opportunities to the thousands of citizens of this City
and State and to an increasing number of visitors.
While for many generations the port has been the
center of commerce, industry and maritime trade,
the harbor is entering a new era. We have
rediscovered the waterfront as not only a place to
earn a living, but a place to live, to eat, to boat, to
relax and to celebrate. Baltimore’s Harbor is a
unique resource. The thousands of jobs associated
with shipping activities and industry now combined
with the millions of visitors to the Inner Harbor,
parks and historic sites makes the harbor one of the
most important economic and social assets to this
City, the State of Maryland, and to the nation. It is
therefore critical that we make well informed
decisions as to how the land, shoreline, and water
are put to use.

This book was developed to provide you with the
background information on how the harbor grew
from its earliest days, issues which affect specific
areas and communities, the complex operations of
the Port and the variety of options which must be
considered for future growth. Millions of public and
private dollars are committed to projects to keep the

Port competitive and to enhance its stance in the
international marketplace. There are also plans which
call for rehabilitating commercial properties,
converting vacant warehouses and building new
housing, improving the water quality, and increasing
the recreational use of the shoreline and water.

These are often complex projects requiring large
sums of money for development and many years. |
believe this book will help you better understand
and appreciate the great variety of factors which
must be carefully weighed to insure the balanced
growth of maritime trade and the public use of this
resource.

The challenge is great, but the return, the reward to
the citizens of Baltimore, Maryland, and our many
visitors makes the effort worthwhile.

Sincerely,

William Donald Schaefer, Mayor
City of Baltimore

field_edited_text_processed:
Baltimore is rediscovering its harbor. Each year
thousands of people are drawn downtown to the
Inner Harbor to festivals, entertainment, shops,
restaurants, and visitor attractions. Once lined with
rotting piers and derelict buildings, the Inner Harbor
today sparkles with new development and bustles
with activity.

Yet few people realize that the 1.5 mile-long
shoreline of the Inner Harbor is but a very small
segment of the Baltimore harbor: less than 4 percent
of the total shoreline. Most of the remaining 40 miles
of waterfront are devoted to the working port - to
marine terminals, industry, and commerce. A much
smaller portion, like the Inner Harbor, is used for
public access and open space. /

This report is designed to clarify the complex
nature of harbor activities and to help readers
understand major issues and concerns related to the
harbor so that they will be better prepared to
evaluate proposals for the future development of this
unique and valuable resource.




The report is divided into four sections. The first
provides an overview of the harbor as a whole - its
past, present, and future. The second section consists
of seven chapters, each of which takes a detailed
look at a specific geographical area of the harbor.
The third section outlines some of the major issues

related to the future of the harbor and presents

several policy recommendations for harbor
development. The final section addresses harbor-
wide programs now underway which will improve
the quality of this resource for the public.

Review this book. Explore areas of the harbor
that you may not have known about. Visit
communities and parks around the harbor’s edge.
Enjoy Baltimore’s Harbor.

Sincerely,

" Larry Reich, Director
Department of Planning

field_edited_text_processed:
" ol





ike scattering seeds, the colonial



legislatures of Maryland and Virginia
= planted hundreds of towns along the
shores of the Chesapeake Bay. Many, like
London Town and Joppa, have disappeared
with little or no trace. Others have
survived as fishing villages, yacht havens or
historic attractions such as Yorktown and
Port Tobacco. A few are busy as county
seats, and Richmond and Annapolis are
the state capitals, but only one of them—
Baltimore—became a commercial and
industrial metropolis ranking among the
top twenty in the nation. Baltimore’s port
was the difference.



7l

The story begins with a 1729 act of the
Maryland legislature authorizing commis-
sioners to survey and lay out a town on
“the north side of Patapsco River” to be
called Baltimore. In January 1730 the
commissioners and their surveyor, Philip
Jones, chose the head of the Northwest
Branch for the town site. They started the
survey at the water’s edge from a “bounded
red oak” at what is now the site of the
U.S.F. &G. skyscraper, and traced an
irregular sixfy acre tract which would
include today most of Charles Center, the
financial district, the Court House, City
Hall, and the Custom House. The edge of
the harbor at that time can be partly
traced in the irregular line of Water and
Lombard Streets.

As it proved, the location of Baltimore
Town was superb for the development of a
seagoing commerce in wheat, flour, and
preserved meats and fish. The original har-
bor, once called the “Basin” and now the
Inner Harbor, was well protected by hills
on the north and south. Two streams,
Jones Falls and Gwynn’s Falls, had the
potential to drive water-powered grist
mills, and a few miles away the Patapsco
River offered much more power. The
source of the raw materials for trade was
in the higher land to the north and west,
the fertile valleys of the Piedmont Plateau
stretching up into Pennsylvania and west
to the Appalachian mountains. This coun-
try was excellent for grass crops, both for
pasture and grains, and it was heavily
wooded with oak.

-

The growing ports of Baltimore and Fells Point, 1792











As always, transportation was the key
factor. One important early artery was the
Susquehanna River which tapped a great
valley in eastern Pennsylvania and emptied
into the Chesapeake Bay not far from Balti-
more. Although its mouth was shallow and
strewn with rocks, at times of high water
barges loaded with grain and farm produce
could be floated downriver and then sailed
or towed to Baltimore’s port. Having sold
their cargoes and barges as well, the barge-
men would then walk or take coaches
back home along the York Road.

By the time of the Revolution a net-
work of roads was being constructed lead-
ing out of Baltimore like spokes in a wheel.
The names are familiar as city streets
today: the road to Belair, to Harford
County, to York, to Reisterstown, to Liberty
Town, and to Frederick. Each was a com-
mercial highway, thronged night and day
with droves of cattle, stage coaches, horse-
men, and with great Conestoga freight
wagons drawn by six horses. The stage
road from Philadelphia and points north
passed through Baltimore on its way south,
making it a crossroads of an interstate
traffic.











The first important industry in Balti-
more was flour milling. There was a water-
powered grist mill on the Jones Falls in
1711, long before the town was laid out,
and by 1810 this stream and the Gwynns
Falls had a dozen or more in operation.

The plentiful forest and the demands of
trade made shipbuilding and the maritime
crafts the next most important businesses.
Fells Point was the center for these crafts,
and also the mariners’ home. To the east at
Harris Creek the U.S. Frigate Constellation
was launched in 1797, the first commis-
sioned ship of the United States Navy, and
many another ship, particularly the famous
“Clippers” which served so well as priva-
teers in the War of 1812. Ropemaking,
cooperage, chandlery, and block making
were among the trades in Fells Point,
along with carpentry, caulking, and rigging.
Baltimore Town, at the head of the old
harbor, remained the commercial center
with warehouses, docks, and the counting
rooms of the merchants.

Although the potential was there, the
real “take off”’ point for Baltimore’s economy
came with the end of the Revolutionary
War. Independence put an end to the British
colonial trade restrictions, and the whole
world was open to American businessmen.

field_edited_text_processed:
The Peale Museum, Baltimore

E. Sachse’s view of the inner basin, 1854

Immigrants from Ireland, Great Britain, and
Germany arrived with capital to invest in
trade and Baltimore’s population doubled
between 1790 and 1800. The final boost
came with the outbreak of war between
France and Great Britain in 1793, a war
which dragged on until 1815. The West
Indian colonies of the warring nations
were particularly hard hit by the interrup-
tion of commerce. They needed food and
lumber and their principal crop, sugar, was
in great demand in France.

This was a risky trade because both
France and Great Britain proclaimed
blockades against each other and seized
neutral ships which appeared to violate
the blockades. America protested these
actions, but even though a good: many
ships were lost, the Baltimore merchants
calculated that they could afford to lose
one out of three ships and still make a
profit.

Controversy over the neutrality issue, as
well as conflicting land claims in the west,
led to war with Great Britain in 1812 which
Baltimoreans supported enthusiastically.
The privateer “clippers” were unleashed
on British shipping with remarkable success.
Then, in September 1814, the city was faced
with defending itself against a British fleet
and army which was bent on destroying
what they called “that nest of pirates on
the Chesapeake.” In the event, the narrow
entrance to the harbor guarded by Fort
McHenry proved impregnable and Balti-
more achieved immortality through a
patriotic poem written by Francis Scott Key
describing the attack. That poem, later set
to music, is now our national anthem.








The war-stimulated economy virtually
collapsed with the declaration of peace
and Baltimore suffered a depression for
years. The remedy came from a radical
source of motive power—the steam engine.
The first steamboat in this area was built in
Baltimore in 1813 and appropriately named
the Chesapeake. In fact, the steamboat
caused a revolutionary change in the
economy of the Chesapeake Bay. In a
short time dozens of boats plied the bay
and its many rivers from Richmond to
Chestertown and points between, bringing
the tobacco of southern Maryland and
Virginia and the fish, oysters, and farm
produce of the tidewater to Baltimore.
From Baltimore went household goods,
fertilizers, and every sort of supplies.
Baltimore was now the commercial entry
port of the region, and because the bay
steamer was both shallow-draft and very
maneuverable, this commerce docked in
the heart of the city along Pratt and Light
Streets. o

Controversy over the neutrality issue, as
well as conflicting land claims in the west,
led to war with Great Britain in 1812 which
Baltimoreans supported enthusiastically.
The privateer “clippers” were unleashed
on British shipping with remarkable success.
Then, in September 1814, the city was faced
with defending itself against a British fleet
and army which was bent on destroying
what they called “that nest of pirates on
the Chesapeake.” In the event, the narrow
entrance to the harbor guarded by Fort
McHenry proved impregnable and Balti-
more achieved immortality through a
patriotic poem written by Francis Scott Key
describing the attack. That poem, later set
to music, is now our national anthem.

field_edited_text_processed:
The steamboat’s speed made the bay’s
raw oysters a feasible cash crop for
delivery in Baltimore and when the process

I(l

for hermetically sealed metal “cans” was
perfected in Baltimore by Thomas Kensett,
Jr., the processing of oysters became a
major industry. By the 1870s Baltimore was
processing upwards of ten million bushels
of oysters a year, and the trade employed
more than 10,000 workers in shucking,
canmaking, printing of labels, and manufac-
turing of boxes. The processing techniques
were used for vegetables as well, and the
city ranked first in the nation in this
industry. The ramifications for the bay’s
economy and society were profound.
Specialized boats were devised for oyster-
ing. Farmers began to plant garden crops
instead of the old staples of tobacco and
wheat. New towns were created along the
shore on what had been wasteland, and
their people looked to Baltimore for a
market and supplies.

The west was still the prize. Balti-
more’s road to Frederick tapped rich farm-
land for the grain and cattle which were
the principal commodities in international
trade, but beyond the Appalachians was
the richer Ohio country which all the East
Coast cities sought to reach. By about 1820
a continuous highway was completed
between Baltimore and the Ohio River. It
was the first complete link between the
East Coast and the Ohio valley.

However, the road was not practical
for moving raw materials on a large scale,
and most of the produce of the Ohio valley
was boated or barged down the Mississippi
River to New Orleans, which became the
fastest-growing city in the United States in
the 1820s. New York’s challenge was the
Erie Canal, a barge waterway between Lake
Erie and the Hudson River, which opened
in 1825 and was instantly successful in
diverting much of the Middle West farm
crops to New York. The freight rate over
the canal was one-tenth the wagon rate.



The Peale Museum, Baltimore

field_edited_text_processed:
Baltimore’s response was an audacious
scheme to build a “Rail Road” to the Ohio
River, nearly 400 miles and over the rugged
Appalachians. Little was known about the
capabilities of a railroad; the longest was
only 14 miles, and ran over a flat plain in
England. Here there could be steep
grades, sharp curves and a great deal of
undeveloped country to cross. Baltimore’s
great hope was begun on July 4, 1828,
with Maryland’s venerable signer of the
Declaration of Independence, Charles
Carroll of Carrollton, as the principal
dignitary. He said that this was the second
most important thing he had done in his
life. While it took 25 years to reach the
Ohio River and cost five times the original
estimates, the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad
was the instrument which transformed
Baltimore’s economy from commercial
exchange to industrialism.

North Locust Point rail yards, late 19th century

Although the railroad’s first cars were
designed to carry barrels of flour from Elli-
cott’s Mills to the port, and agricultural
products always figured heavily in freight
traffic, the railroad was a major consumer
of the products of modern heavy industry.
The demand for rails was first met by
imports, but then Peter Cooper founded
the Charcoal Iron Works in Canton and in
1845 a large water-powered rolling and slit-
ting mill was built at Avalon near Relay,
and the supply of rails was met locally.
Running along the banks of the Patapsco
River, the railroad made it possible to
exploit the sizable deposits of iron ore in
that region.

Maryland Port Administration





Workers for heavy industry, 1925



.

The next watershed in the history of
the port came in 1887 with the founding of
the Maryland Steel Co. and the beginning
of the present Sparrows Point steel works.
Financed by sources associated with the
Pennsylvania Railroad, it relied on a simple
equation: importation of iron ore from
Cuba (later from elsewhere), plus direct
rail transportation of coal and limestone
from Pennsylvania, plus a convenient labor
supply in nearby Baltimore, equals efficiency
and profits. From the first, the Sparrows
Point plant was intended to produce a full

Canning of oysters and vegetables was a prime waterfront industry in Baltimore, late 19th and early 20th centuries. An oyster canning house, 1904.



range of steel products and build ships.
Today the Bethlehem Steel Corp. is the
largest single private employer in the
Baltimore region.

The Sparrows Point plant was the har-
binger of a new pattern of port development,
the siting of large industrial plants along
the reaches of the Patapsco River itself.
The first World War saw the building of an
Army Ordinance Depot and Coast Guard
Yard along the upper Curtis Creek, and
large chemical plants on Curtis Bay.
Further east at Fairfield a new shipbuilding
yard was established to build merchant
ships and barges, and Hawkins Point was
used for ammunition storage. In the 1920s
the Maryland Shipbuilding and Dry Dock
Co. was located at Fairfield, and World
War Il saw a vast expansion of the old Fair-
field yard to produce Liberty and Victory
ships and LSTs. Large copper smelting
plants and oil and sugar refineries filled
out the pattegn of industrialization.

After World War 1l the port prospered
for a time from the export of grain and
coal under the United Nations Relief and
Rehabilitation Program in behalf of the
war devastated nations, and by continued
growth of the Sparrows Point steel plant.
The Fairfield building yard became a ship-
breaking yard and salvage operation. But
the pattern was now clear: Baltimore had
become a bulk cargo port serving large

field_edited_text_processed:
Launching the S.S. Patrick Henry, Fairfield yards, Sept. 1941

The Peale Museum, Baltimore





industries and had little of the highly prof-
itable general cargo business. Moreover,
there was vigorous competition from Norfolk
and other East Coast ports and Baltimore’s
older piers and warehouses had become
obsolescent. The railroads owned most of
the major port facilities and were them-
selves in serious financial difficulty and in

no position to make expensive

improvements.

Those concerned with the well being
of the City and the state recognized that
immediate concerted action was needed if
the port was to regain its competitive posi-
tion and the harbor recapture its historical
role as the focal point for urban activities.
The response was public intervention in
two decisive arenas.

In 1956 the state legislature created
the Maryland Port Authority, later reorgan-
ized as the Maryland Port Administration,
to revitalize the port. Since its inception
the Maryland Port Administration has
invested over $300 million in the construc-
tion and improvement of marine terminals,

enabling the port to capture new trade
and to regain its position as a leading,
diversified center of commerce.

In the late 1950’s the City and the
downtown business community adopted
the Charles Center urban renewal plan, an
effort to inject new life into a downtown
then in a serious state of decline. The Cha-
rles Center project was a stepping stone to
the much larger Inner Harbor renewal
plan which in less than twenty years has
transformed a dirty, derelict waterfront
into the most desirable location for com-
mercial, office, and tourist activity in the
region.





10

field_edited_text_processed:
The modern Port of Baltimore includes
approximately 1,600 acres of water which
encompass the lower Patapsco River, Inner
Harbor, Northwest Branch, Middle Branch,
Curtis Bay, and a number of small creeks.
Its shoreline is approximately 42 miles long,
28 miles in Baltimore City and 14 miles in
Baltimore County and Anne Arundel
County.

Approximately 6,200 acres of land -
about 12 percent of the City’s land area -

lie within proximity of the harbor. Over
4,600 acres of this harbor-related land are
zoned for industry and about 1,400 acres
for residential or commercial activities.
About 200 acres are used as park land, a
large portion of which is the Fort McHenry
National Park and Shrine in South Balti-
more and the Middle Branch Park.

The harbor today is one of Baltimore’s
most important economic resources. It has
been estimated that 79,000 jobs are related
to the port and its operation.

In addition to jobs, the port also

- produces a tremendous amount of

revenue. Each year the port generates
more than $300 million in state and local
taxes. Approximately one-tenth of the gross
state product, the value of all goods and
services originating in the state, is tied to
the port. ;







&

“Pride of Baltimore” in the Inner Harbor, 1984

Jay Steinhour

-
-

P



Activities around the harbor fall into the
following areas:

Maritime Activity:

Baltimore is one of the great world
ports. Each year more than 4,000 ships call
at its shores and nearly 37 million tons of
cargo pass through its marine terminals.
About two-thirds of the total tonnage
handled is foreign cargo. Baltimore’s major
exports are farm machinery, earthmoving
equipment, general machinery, tools, coal,
grain, finished steel, refined copper, and _ . . *
animal feed. Major imports include auto- Epgst e 4 atney S
mobiles (235,000 in 1982), petroleum,
gypsum, sugar, fresh fruits, non-metallic
minerals, and chemicals. Baltimore’s major
trading partners are Japan, West Germany
and Great Britain. Trade is also expanding
with countries in South America and the
Middle East.

The remaining third of the port’s
commerce is domestic cargo having its
origin and destination mainly in the states
of Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, lllinois,
West Virginia, and Virginia as well as -
Maryland.

are used for storage of refined petro-
leum products. Petroleum products,
including gasoline, industrial and
home heating oil, are brought into
the port by pipeline and tanker and
redistributed by fuel trucks and
barges.

Dry Bulk Facilities - A variety of dry bulk goods
are imported and exported through
the port. Generally grain and oyster
shells are exported. The port receives
iron and specialized ores, raw sugar
“and gypsum.

field_edited_text_processed:
B



Maryland Port Administration

Vessels approach the Baltimore harbor
either from the north via the Chesapeake
and Delaware Canal or from the south via
the Chesapeake Bay. The main channel
into the harbor is nominally 42 feet deep
and 800 feet wide. It is currently authorized
to be deepened to 50 feet. However, due
to the continuous process of silt settling
into the channels the authorized depth is
difficult to maintain. The harbor extends
19.9 miles from Fort McHenry to the Bay
Bridge in Annapolis. Three branch channels
link the main channel to various port
terminals.



Ships are loaded and unloaded at 11
major general cargo marine terminals.
These are both publicly and privately
owned. The terminals vary in function and
size, ranging from the 550-acre Dundalk
Marine Terminal to the 5-acre Rukert
Terminal. Most terminals contain storage
space, rail yards, transit or storage sheds,
docking facilities, and berthing space.
Many terminals also include mechanical
cargo handling equipment such as elec
trical cranes, locomotive cranes, freight
elevators, gravity chutes, and cargo plat-
forms or ramps.

field_edited_text_processed:
Maryland Port Administration

b

he 1
k2

L 320 B



Modern container loading operations



Break-bulk cargo







There are four types of cargo handled
by the port. The first two described below
- containerized freight and breakbulk
cargo - are termed general cargo.

Containerized Freight - Baltimore
ranks second among East Coast and Gulf
Coast ports in moving containers, the 20 to
40 foot, van-like boxes that can be lifted
off a ship and placed directly on a truck
chassis. Shipping cargo in containers
reduces handling time and damage. Balti-
more was a pioneer in container handling,
receiving its first container cargo in 1963
when other ports were skeptically waiting
to see if the new cargo-handling technol-
ogy had any future. Baltimore’s early lead
has paid off. Between 1970 and 1976 the
volume of containerized cargo shipped
through the harbor tripled. By January 1977
the Port of Baltimore had moved its first
million containers and by April 1981 it had
handled-its second million.





Breakbulk Cargo - With approximately
88 berths, six-million square feet of
enclosed storage, and five-million cubic
feet of cold storage, the port is capable of
handling large quantities of mixed cargo,
known as breakbulk, which requires
individualized loading and unloading.
Breakbulk cargo is typified by smaller
articles bound for several locations and
specialized items like yachts, air condition-
ing equipment, and farm machinery. In
recent yedrs the port has also become a
leading depot for “project cargo,” in which
all the components for a single project
(for example, a factory or even an entire
village) are marshalled together from many
suppliers, packed, loaded, and ultimately
shipped to their destination. The port has
been able to capture a large share of the
project cargo bound for the Mideast and
Southeast Asia because of its proximity to
many Midwest and East Coast firms special-
izing in multiphased projects, its expansive
rail and highway access network, its exten-
sive storage facilities, and the variety and
flexibility of its cargo handling equipment.





17

Maryland Port Administration

Maryland Port Administration

field_edited_text_processed:
Coal storage prior to being loaded for export

Unloading imports from a modern auto carrier





Bulk Cargo - The major portion of the
port’s tonnage each year is in the form of
bulk cargo. This type of cargo is moved in
large quantities usually in ships which only
carry that one product. These ships take
advantage of the cost savings derived from
handling large quantities of a single cargo
and are often the largest vessels in the port,
requiring deep channels like the 50-foot
channel proposed for the Port of
Baltimore.

There are two categories of bulk cargo,
dry and liquid. Coal, grain, sugar, and ore
are examples of dry bulk cargo. Petroleum
products, molasses, latex and specialized
food and soap bases are all liquid bulk
cargo. In recent years the port has set
records in moving dry bulk carga, particu-
larly coal and grain. The port has 24 bulk
cargo berths. Modern equipment at these
berths makes it possible to unload 6,000
tons of ore an hour and load 11,000 tons of
coal and 270,000 bushels of grain every
hour. Most bulk goods require large
amounts of land for storage while awaiting
export or local distribution after import.-
This can be seen in Canton where there
are many acres devoted to storing petro-
leum and fertilizers, and in Fairfield which
has over 300 acres occupied by petroleum
tank farms and rail yards used to store coal
in cars.



R SRR ]





Automobiles - Baltimore is one of the
top-ranking auto import centers in the
country. In 1982 more than 235,000 cars
from Europe and Japan were imported
through facilities at the Dundalk Marine
Terminal and in Fairfield.

As an adjunct to the port’s cargo trade
there are a myriad of businesses which
service incoming and outgoing ships.
These include 48 steamship agents, 33
freight forwarders, 3 customhouse brokers,
36 combined forwarders/brokers, 10 steve-
doring firms, more than 24 tugboats, as
well as numerous packing, crating, and
warehousing firms, cargo inspectors,
weighers, samplers, surveyors, marine
suppliers, insurance agencies, and interna-
tional bankers.

18



Maryland Port Administration

P

Maryland Port Administration

Transportation System:

Serving the port is an elaborate net-
work of railroads and highways which are
essential to the flow of trade. Two trunk-
line railways operate in the harbor area:
the CSX Railroad and Conrail. Together
these two lines have over 1,100 miles of
track in Maryland and 30,000 miles
nationwide.

In November 1980 the Chessie System
and Seaboard Coastland Railroad merged
to form the CSX Railroad. The new rail
system serves the mid-Atlantic states as
far south as Florida and the entire Mid-
west industrial heartland as far west as St.
Louis. CSX operations in Baltimore are on
the Chessie System’s B& O and Western
Maryland Railway tracks.

The Chessie System’s total volume
of freight traffic in Baltimore in 1977 was
almost 25 million tons. Ten million tons of
this traffic was coal. Mixed freight, grain,
and ore were the other major goods
moved through Baltimore. The Chessie
System serves the industries of Canton
and Sparrows Point on the east side and of
Curtis Bay, Locust Point and Hawkins Point
on the west side.



Conrail traffic bound for Baltimore
generally comes through northeastern
Maryland. In 1977 Conrail hauled 20.3
million tons of freight through Baltimore.
Over a third of this total or approximately 7
million tons was unloaded in Baltimore.
The major commodities brought into Balti-
more by Conrail were ore and trailer-on-
flat-car containers. Conrail also provided
service in the Canton area to a large grain
operation, its own coal pier, and several
industries. o

Besides the two major trunk lines,
there is the Canton Railroad, recently
purchased by a venture capital firm. This
small rail line switches cars between the
CSX and Conrail tracks and moves them to
industries in the Canton area. It currently
operates over 32 miles of track in east Balti-
more. The railroad’s primary cargo in
previous years has been iron ore, chrome,
and manganese. However, most ore is now
brought to Baltimore either by barge or by
truck.

In addition to the railroads, a complete
network of interstate highways, regional
roads, and local streets provides access to
the harbor. The interstate expressways (1-70,
1-83, and 1-95) link Baltimore to neighbor-
Ing states.



20

field_edited_text_processed:
Domino Sugar’s dock - a water dependent industry











Industrial Activity:

Hundreds of industries are located
around the harbor. Some like shipbuilding
and repair yards are direct outgrowths of
maritime activity. In Baltimore there are
three major concerns involved in the con-
struction, repair, dismantling or conversion
of ships. The largest is the Bethlehem Steel
Co. which employs approximately
20,000 persons - its major yards
in Sparrows Point, where all types of
merchant and naval vessels are constructed
and two repair yards, one on Key Highway
and another near Fort McHenry which
have been sold to a development com-
pany. The Sparrows Point yard is unique
not only as one of the world’s largest ship-
yards but also in its location on the
grounds of a major steel mill, which allows
it to make components to order and
deliver them directly to vessels under
construction.

)

Packing oyster shells

Other industries, while not direct out-
growths of maritime activity, are located on
the harbor because proximity to the water
is essential either for the shipment of their
raw materials and finished products or for a
particular manufacturing process. Examples
of this type of industry are manufacturers
like Bethlehem Steel Sparrows Point,
Amstar Sugar, and U.S. Gypsum; petroleum
products importers like Exxon, Apex, and
Chevron; and chemical firms like Conoco,
Olin Corporation, and Allied Chemicals.





21

Maryland Port Administration

Maryland Port Administration

field_edited_text_processed:
Tugs at Fells Point’s Broadway Pier







The two types of industries described
above - those that are direct outgrowths
of maritime activity and those that rely
on water for their shipments or their
production process - are usually designated
water-dependent. These industries actually
use their waterfront locations to ship and
receive goods essential to their operations.
While the number varies from year to year,
it is estimated that between 40,000 and
60,000 people are employed in activities
directly related to the Port of Baltimore.

Other firms are located on or near the
harbor because they benefit from the avail-
ability of water transportation although
they are not dependent on shipping or
receiving goods by water from their own
sites. Such industries are designated
“water-related” and include Procter and
Gamble, E. Renneberg Machinery Co., and
Baltimore Copper Paint Co.



Carr-Lowery - glass container manufacture and B.G.&E.s
Westport Generating Station - non-water dependent industry



Finally, there are industries which are
neither water-dependent nor water-related
but which are nevertheless located on or
near the harbor. They neither directly use
the water for transportation purposes them-
selves nor do they significantly benefit from
the availability of water transportation.
Their location on the harbor may have
historical roots. At one time they may have
relied on the port for their operation, but
economic or technological changes may
have altered their dependency. Their loca-
tion near the water may have been
determined by factors completely unrelated
to the port, for instance low land costs.
Examples of non-port-related industries
around the Baltimore harbor are Locke
Insulators, General Motors, and Lever
Brothers. It is estimated that over 20,000
people are employed by firms not directly
tied to the port’s operations.





22

tion near the water may have been
determined by factors completely unrelated
to the port, for instance low land costs.
Examples of non-port-related industries
around the Baltimore harbor are Locke
Insulators, General Motors, and Lever
Brothers. It is estimated that over 20,000
people are employed by firms not directly
tied to the port’s operations.





22

field_edited_text_processed:
Thames St



-

. waterfront in Fells Point - waterfront commercial activities for over 200 years

Commercial Activity:

While a smattering of restaurants and
ships can be found in most of the areas
around the harbor, the only areas of con-
centrated commercial activity now are the
Inner Harbor and Fells Point.

The Inner Harbor and Fells Point are
experiencing a rebirth of commercial
activity largely as a result of City-sponsored
urban renewal projects which have made
these areas attractive for private develop-
ment. By capitalizing on its dramatic water-
front location, City urban renewal
programs have transformed the Inner
Harbor into the region’s most desirable
location for offices and shops as well as for
tourist trade. With seven new major office
buildings and several hundred thousand
square feet of new retail space the Inner
Harbor provides thousands of jobs and
attracts shoppers from the entire region
and tourists from across the country. In
the past ten years more than $500 million
have been invested in private commercial
ventures like Harborplace, the Hyatt Hotel,
and office buildings.



In contrast to the Inner Harbor, Fells
Point’'s commercial activity largely serves a
local clientele, although the area’s popular
taverns and antique shops attract customers
from the entire region. New-found interest
in downtown living, spurred by the popu-
larity of the Inner Harbor, has created a
market for housing in Fells Point, particu-
larly along the waterfront. This demand is
reflected in proposals for converting the
area’s vacant warehouses into condomini-
ums and for building new shoreline town-
houses, some of which are now completed.

Recreation and Open Space:

Recreational facilities were an early
commerical enterprise in Baltimore’s
harbor. As early as 1807 a private beer
garden at Spring Garden on the Middle
Branch was a popular place for a day’s out-
ing. Fish houses, beer gardens, race tracks,
and camp sites were located throughout
the Middle Branch, Cherry Hill, Brooklyn,
and Canton. The most famous, Riverview
Park, started in 1868 along Canton’s south-
ern shoreline at the site of today’s Western
Electric plant. By the early 1900s the park
had attained the reputation as “The Coney
Island of the South” and boasted dance
halls, a long boating pier, beaches, two

field_edited_text_processed:
The Future of the Harbor

The following activities will figure
prominently in the future of Baltimore’s
Harbor.

Marine Terminals:

Most of the port’s existing marine
terminals are operating at capacity. If
the port is to remain competitive and
capture expanding trade opportunities,
additional terminal capacity must be
provided. To meet projected future
demand, the Maryland Port Administration
plans major investments

Canton Seagirt Marine Terminal -
Using dredge spoil removed for the con-
struction of the Interstate 95 Fort McHenry
Tunnel, the City has filled in the Canton
shoreline to create a new 140-acre site for a
- container terminal. When completed by
the Maryland Port Administration in the
1990s, this new facility will be capable of
handling an estimated 2,250,000 tons of
container cargo annually.

Masonville Marine Terminal - This new
350-acre facility is to be built on filled land
in the Fairfield area. Costing an estimated
$200 million to develop, the Masonville
Terminal will include four berths - two

Canton Seagirt Marine Terminal

opening in the mid-1990s and another two
by the year 2000. Once completed the
terminal will be able to handle more than
three million tons of container cargo a
year.

Channel Dredging:

In conjunction with these investments
in marine terminals, several other related
projects are necessary to the future growth
of the poft. The most important is the
dredging of the main harbor channel from
its current depth of 42 feet to a new depth
of 50 feet. This project will allow the port
to remain competitive and expand its
import and export of bulk products by
accommodating today’s larger, deep-draft
cargo ships.

To economize on shipping costs, com-
panies use large ships of over 100,000 dead
weight tons to transport bulk goods like
ore, coal,.grain, sugar, and petroleum pro-
ducts. When full, these ships ride very low
in the water. Baltimore’s existing 42-foot
channel can accommodate full ships no
larger than 60,000 dead weight tons. As a
result many of the larger coal carrying ships
only partially load in Baltimore, stopping at
another port where the channel depth is
greater to fill to capacity. Dredging the
main channel to 50 feet will dramatically
increase the efficiency of operations of
many of these ships and will allow the port
to move quantities of bulk at lower costs.



27

field_edited_text_processed:
Hart/Miller Islands



To meet the need for disposal of the
material from the 50-foot channel deepen-
ing project the state has built a contain-
ment site for over 50 million cubic yards of
fill at Hart and Miller Islands just east of the
Back River in Baltimoré County. The main
channel dredging, a federal project, and
the construction and operation of the
containment site, a state project, are
complex and costly and will require a
concentrated effort over the next five to
eight years.

The state, working with federal agen-
cies and local jurisdictions, is also studying
various alternatives for handling spoil from
future dredging projects. Even with the
Hart and Miller Islands disposal capacity of
over 50 million cubic yards, methods for
handling the remaining 80 million cubic
yards expected from Maryland projects
over the next 20 years, will have to be
identified. Possibilities include overboard
disposal of clean material, wetlands crea-
tion, containment, recycling, hauling spoil
inland, and burial in a deep trench of the
Chesapeake Bay.

Highways:

A number of transportation improve-

ments are planned to accommodate the
increased cargo trade that will be moving
through the port. The most important
highway project is the Fort McHenry
Tunnel, which is scheduled to be
completed by 1985. As the final link of
Interstate 95 to be built in the City, the
tunnel will cross the Patapsco River
between Locust Point and Canton provid-
ing expressway access between the port
and East Coast cities. The planned recon-
struction of local streets will also play an
important role in reducing traffic conges-
tion in several areas, thereby improving
access between regional highways and the
port.

Coal Export Terminals:

Spurred by the high cost of oil and the
consequent search by countries for
cheaper alternative fuels, the United States
is experiencing considerable worldwide
demand on its vgst coal reserves especially
for generation of electricity in Europe. It
has been estimated that between 1980 and
the year 2000 U.S. coal exports will increase
by 100 to 200 percent. Due to its proximity
to the coal fields of western Maryland,
West Virginia, Pennsylvania, and Kentucky,
the Port of Baltimore will be a major tran-

dredge materials disposal site - early construction stage



29

field_edited_text_processed:
Maryland Port Administration

Consolidation Coal Company’s giant coal loading equipment, Canton





shipment point for outbound coal.

Two new major coal terminals have
been developed on the harbor in Baltimore
City:

Island Creek Coal Company currently
the largest single exporter of coal in Balti-
more, has spent $100 million to expand and
upgrade its existing coal terminal in Curtis
Bay and to construct a new pier. The facil-
ity is expected to export 10 to 12 million
tons of coal per year by the late 1980’s.

Consolidation Coal Co., which pur-
chased all the property owned by the
Canton Co., has invested $110 million to
renovate a ore pier and storage and han-
dling facility at the former Canton Marine
Terminal. As a result of this project, annual
coal export capacity through Baltimore is
expected to increase significantly.

The port’s coal terminals, supported by
an improved transportation system, could
enable the port to move 30 to 40 million
tons of coal per year by 1985, tripling the
12.7 million tons exported in 1980. Clearly,
the increase in coal export will have a*
significant impact on the port and the
entire state.



Industrial Development:

Several private industrial development
projects have been announced:

General Motors has renovated its
Broening Highway plant.

W. R. Grace Co. has purchased an 18-
acre site in Fairfield to develop a liquid
bulk storage and handling facility. In con-
junction, with this project, an existing pier
will be extended 860 feet and rail service to
the property will be expanded and
improved.

Colonial Pipeline Corp., which oper-
ates the Texas-to New Jersey oil pipeline
serving the entire East Coast, plans to
double the capacity of its pipeline, which
serves petroleum storage and distribution
operators in Fairfield.

American Seamless located in Curtis
Bay anticipates expanding its operation and
increasing employment from 60 to 150 to
200.

Holabird Industrial Park, a newly devel-
oped 220-acre industrial park in southeast
Baltimore, has already attracted several
firms. A 22-acre Foreign Trade Zone has
been created and is to be developed and
managed by McCormick Properties.
Employment at the completed industrial
park is projected to be between 1500 and
2,000 jobs.

30

field_edited_text_processed:
Pier 4 Power Plant - Renovated as a family entertainment center by Six Flags Corp.

In addition to these projects that have
been announced, there are additional oppor-
tunities for industrial development around
the port. Canton, Locust Point, and Fairfield
contain a limited number of available sites,
usually under 30 acres. Hawkins Point, with
over 400 acres of undeveloped land, offers a
substantial opportunity for new industrial
and/or maritime related development. If all
400 acres were developed at an average of
12 employees per acre, almost 5,000 new
jobs would result. This opportunity, coupled
with the development of other smaller par-
cels around the harbor and the announced
projects, presents the potential of produc-
ing over 10,000 new industrial and maritime
jobs around the port by the year 2000. This
would constitute a significant contribution
to the City’s employment base.

Residential and Commercial Development:

The redevelopment of the Inner
Harbor has rekindled the public’s interest
in the waterfront as a place to spend time,
shop, and live. While not nearly as exten-
sive as the other types of economic activity
around the harbor, the residential and
commercial development occurring and
expected in the the Inner Harbor, Fells
Point, and Falls Harbor areas is important in



that it represents significant additional
private investment in the rehabilitation of
the City. The activity has generated a new
national, and local, interest in Baltimore as
a place to visit and live.

Several waterfront redevelopment projects
are likely in the future:

Pier 4 Power Plant - In late December,
1982, the City announced that it had
selected the Six Flags Corp. as developers
of the Pier 4 Power Plant. The Power Plant
will be an amusement center including
rides, attractions, a museum, theaters,
shops, and restaurants drawing on the turn-
of-the century as its main theme to open in
1985.

Inner Harbor East - Piers 5 and 6 and
the area east of the Jones Falls, known as
Falls Harbor, has tremendous potential for
future development to attract visitors. With
Little Italy immediately adjacent to the area,
develoﬁ{\ent could build on international
attractions and include a public waterfront
promenade, marina, plaza, and specialized
commercial uses.

Fells Point - Old warehouses are being
converted to condominiums and new town-
houses are being built on the waterfront in



31
field_edited_text_value:
Pier 4 Power Plant - Renovated as a family entertainment center by Six Flags Corp.

In addition to these projects that have
been announced, there are additional oppor-
tunities for industrial development around
the port. Canton, Locust Point, and Fairfield
contain a limited number of available sites,
usually under 30 acres. Hawkins Point, with
over 400 acres of undeveloped land, offers a
substantial opportunity for new industrial
and/or maritime related development. If all
400 acres were developed at an average of
12 employees per acre, almost 5,000 new
jobs would result. This opportunity, coupled
with the development of other smaller par-
cels around the harbor and the announced
projects, presents the potential of produc-
ing over 10,000 new industrial and maritime
jobs around the port by the year 2000. This
would constitute a significant contribution
to the City’s employment base.

field_edited_text_processed:
Anchorage townhouses and marina, Canton waterfront





Fells Point. Together, these developments
will soon offer over 350 dwelling units
representing a significant private invest-
ment in residential development. They will
be augmented by the construction of
marinas and a public promenade along the
shoreline.

Boston Street - On a vacant site along
Boston Street, a developer has proposed
construction of a condominium tower, a
major marina, and a public walkway along
the water’s edge.

Recreation Facilities:

In addition to these economic devel-
opment activities, the future will also
witness the development of several notable
recreation projects on the harbor:

Middle Branch Park System - The City
is in the process of creating a new 150-acre
park system along almost four miles of
shoreline. The park will include several
marinas, public boat launches, fishing piers,
ballfields, tennis and basketball courts, and
a wetland interpretation area. A path will
thread through the new park linking it to
the Gwynns Falls Park, downtown, and the
Patapsco State Park. The Middle Branch
Park will be the largest addition to the









e









City’s park system in over 50 years and one ]
of the most extensive waterfront parks in =
the state.

Canton Waterfront Park - The City
plans to purchase a 10 acre site on the
waterfront at Boston and Clinton Streets.
Development will include a boat launch,
open space, and a site for the City Marine
Police.

Biking in the Middle Branch Park

field_edited_text_processed:
Canton public pier





Public Access in Private Projects -
Working with private developers, the City
has been able to secure public access to
the shoreline in a number of projects.
These include public shoreline promenades
at Thames Point and the Anchorage pro-
jects in Fells Point, a public observation
tower at the proposed Masonville Marine
Terminal, and wetland interpretation areas
provided by Locke Insulators in Reedbird
Park.

Street-End Parks - Public access does
not always have to be on a large scale. The
City has identified several points where
streets end at the shoreline. These hold the
potential for street-end parks. Hull Street
on Locust Point and the shoreline at Boston
and O’Donnell Streets have been devel-
oped as small, public parks and include
landscaping and a short pier for temporary
boat mooring.

Fort Armistead Park - Originally con-
structed in 1898 as one of five forts to
guard the harbor, Fort Armistead has been
unused since the late 1920s. While the 38-
acre park offers a unique view of ships
passing under the Francis Scott Key Bridge
and of the operations of Bethlehem Steel’s
Sparrows Point Plant across the water, the
park was badly deteriorated. Construction
has now been completed which improves
the shoreline, provides boat launches, and

takes advantage of the view afforded by
the park’s bluffs.

Fort Smallwood Park - Another of the
five forts, Fort Smallwood is located in Anne
Arundel County but owned and maintained

Public promenade, Anchorage townhouses on the Canton waterfront



1

by the City. Plans have been prepared call-
ing for the renovation of existing park facil-
ities and the improvement of the shoreline.
These include improvements to bathing
beaches, boating facilities, and recreation
areas.

In addition to these specific recreation
projects, the future may also see the crea-
tion of a new visitor attraction - the Five
Forts of Baltimore. Fort McHenry, Fort
Armistead, Fort:Smallwood, Fort Carroll, and
Fort Howard possess rich histories. Except
for Fort McHenry’s role in the War of 1812,
the history of these forts has long been
ignored. Establishing the Five Forts visitor
attraction would uncover this history. Such a
venture would require finding a public or
private sponsor to rehabilitate three of the
forts (Smallwood, Armistead, and Carroll)
and to establish a tour program. While now
no more than a proposal, the Five Forts
concept holds the potential of contributing
to the City’s angl. the region’s effort to
become a center for tourism and provide
unique educational, historic, and recrea-
tional resources for the public.



33

The Canton area contains extensive
public and private maritime activity. Two
publicly operated facilities — the Marylan
Port Administration’s Dundalk Marine
Terminal, the port’s largest general cargo
and container terminal, and the Clinton
Street Marine Terminal, another container
and general casgo facility — are located
here. Private facilities include the Canton
Marine Terminal complex, Sea Land
container terminal on Newgate Avenue,
Rukert Terminal’s bulk shipment facilities
on Clinton Street and at Lazaretto Point,
and the Exxon and Apex petroleum termi-
nals located on Clinton Street. In addition
to waterfront facilities, there are open
storage yards, warehouses, and liquid
storage tanks serving port activities. Over

field_edited_text_processed:
Booz Brothers Shipyards, circa 1875, Harris Creek and Boston St., Canton waterfront



18,000 people are employed in manufactur-
ing and port-related activities in Canton.

Located on the Northwest Branch of
the Patapsco River, the 2,000-acre Canton
industrial area contains the largest single
concentration of industrial and port activity
in the City. This area includes a number of
the major employers in Baltimore — Lever
Brothers, General Motors, — as well as
many smaller firms, including fertilizer pro-
cessing, contract trucking, and chemical
manufacturing firms.



velopment History

The area derives its name from the
Chinese province of Canton which was the
primary trading partner of Captain John
O’Donnell, the 18th century trader whose
estate developed into the present-day
Canton. The first major industry in Canton
was Stodder’s Shipyard from which the
famous U.S. Frigate Constellation was .
launched in 1797. A portion of Canton was

annexed to the City of Baltimore as early as

1816, and in 1918 the area’s current boun-
daries were established.

Throughout the 19th century Canton’s
shipyards, terminals and industry supplied
much of the materials that fed the city’s
and nation’s growth. During World War |,
Canton’s industries made a significant con-

tribution to the United States armed forces:

the American Smelting and Refining Co.

¥

supplied cartridge casting, the canneries
helped to meet the food demand, and the
terminals located along the waterfront were
major supply bases to the U.S. army in
France. Postwar development saw the con-
struction of Pennsylvania Railroad’s $6
million pier and grain elevator on Newkirk
Street. Other national industries such as the
American Radiator and Standard Corp.,
Lever Brothers, General Motors, and West-
ern Electric constructed major manufactur-
ing plants in the first half of the 20th
century.

During World War Il Canton’s water-
front terminals resumed their earlier role as
a major supply base to America’s armed
forces. After the war private businesses
shared in the general economic boom,
investing heavily in warehouses, piers, and
industrial plants.

36



The Peale Museum, Baltimore

field_edited_text_processed:
o ¢



xisting Conditions

Industrial Activity: Approximately
15,000 employees work in Canton’s more
than 20 manufacturing establishments. Most
of these businesses are concentrated in
four clusters. Bulk material producers, such
as Lebanon Chemical, and Lehigh Portland
Cement, are located on the harbor along
Clinton Street in west Canton. Although
located directly on the harbor, neither
Agrico nor Lehigh Portland make use of
their deepwater access for shipments. A
diverse group of medium and large manu-
facturers can be found along Boston Street
in north Canton. These include GAF Corp.,
Crown Cork and Seal, S. Schapiro and
Sons, and Quality Chemicals. East of New-
kirk Street are Canton’s major employers,
Lever Brothers and General Motors. These
companies employ over 5,000 persons on
approximately 150 acres of land in the
heart of Canton. Apart from other heavy
manufacturing activities, National Gypsum
maintains a facility at Newkirk and Newgate
Streets. Further east, along Colgate Creek,
is another cluster of manufacturers which
includes Universal Foods and SCM Glidden
Paints.

dministration



Maryland Port

View of Seagirt Marine Terminal under development, foreground; Dundalk, background.

..............

The area’s largest employers have been
in Canton since the 1930s. The General
Motors car and truck assembly plant began
operations in 1935, increasing in size from
46 to 167 acres since that time. Employment
at GM peaked at 6,991 in 1978 and has
since declined to 3,500. In 1981 the Balti-
more plant stopped making trucks and
began a major modernization of both plant
and equipment in preparation for produc-
ing the company’s new J-car. However,
decreasing auto sales caused a halt in the
modernization project until late 1982. At
that time a scaled back upgrading program
resumed. It is now anticipated that produc-
tion will center around small vans.

Western Electric Corporation began
operations here in 1929. The plant, which
at one time employed approximately 5,000
persons at its 169 acre Point Breeze site,
announced that it would phase-out its
Baltimore plant.

Lever Brothers has been in Canton
since 1939. The plant manufactures All and
Wisk detergent, Aim and Close-up tooth-
paste, and Dove soap; it employs 1,047
persons. Over the years the company has
made substantial investments in plant
modernization and pollution abatement
equipment. In 1982 the company began
construction of a $10 million sulphanami-
lide facility.

38
