field_edited_text_processed:
' Tanker unloading petroleum products, Exxon terminal





Port Activity: Approximately 2,600
persons are employed in port activities in
the Canton area. Described below are
some of the major private and public port
facilities operating in the area:

*More than 80 percent of all container-
ized cargo passing through the Port of
Baltimore is handled by terminals in
the Canton area. By far the largest of
these is the Maryland Port Administra-
tion’s 550-acre Dundalk Marine Termi-
nal which in 1980 handled 2.8 million
tons, 62 percent of all the port’s con-
tainerized freight. With 13 berths, over
435 acres of open storage, and rail
holding yards for 250 cars, the Dundalk
Terminal is one of the most modern
general cargo terminals in the country.
Approximately 2,000 people are regu-
larly employed at the facility.

Sealand Terminal, site of one of the first container operations in the port



The next largest container terminal is
operated by Sea Land Service, Inc. on
a 28-acre site on Newgate Avenue. In
1980, the facility handled a half million
tons of cargo, 11 percent of the port’s
container tonnage. The company cur-
rently uses the Baltimore facility as a
feeder terminal for its other east coat
facilities.

operated by Sea Land Service, Inc. on
a 28-acre site on Newgate Avenue. In
1980, the facility handled a half million
tons of cargo, 11 percent of the port’s
container tonnage. The company cur-
rently uses the Baltimore facility as a
feeder terminal for its other east coat
facilities.

Maryland Port Administration

Maryland Port Administration’s 550 acre Dundalk Marine Terminal

e i

& & e o - ® s L
9 B :; ‘ A :

Other general cargo and container
terminals in Canton are NBC’s Boston
Street Terminal and the Canton Marine
Terminal, each of which move approx-
imately 4 percent of the port’s total
tonnage.

*Central Soya Finance Corp., a firm

based in Fort Wayne, Indiana, owns
and operates a grain export facility on
Newgate Street in south Canton. The
facility moves thousands of tons of
corn, meal, and wheat through the
port each year.

*National Gypsum operates a pier

located at the foot of Newkirk Street
for the import of Gypsum rock.

*The Rukert Terminals Corp. operates

two bulk cargo facilities along Clinton
Street in west Canton and is currently
constructing covered storage structures
on a 9-acre site. The company primar-
ily handles ferro-alloys, potash, ferro-
nickel, zinc, and copper. A new head-
quarters building and an extension of
its pier from 500 to 800 feet were com-
pleted in 1979-80.

*Conrail operates a coal pier on Clinton

Street. The pier is used to load barges
for local and intracoastal deliveries.
The yards serving this pier were
recently reconstructed to accommo-
date Interstate-95 in Canton. This facil-
ity provides coal to Bethlehem Steel
and several utilities in Delaware and
New Jersey.

*Maryland Port Administration owns the

Clinton Street Marine Terminal which
handles both general cargo and con-
tainerized freight.

*Exxon Corp. owns and operates a large

petroleum terminal and storage facility.
The Exxon installation deals extensively
in residual fuel oil used to fire power
plants and other large industrial boil-
ers. Because of its thickness, this oil
cannot be moved by pipeline but must
be moved by ship and barge.

*Apex Oil and Petroleum Marketing

Corp. which distributes both distillates
and residual fuel oil, maintains a
terminal and distribution facility
immediately south of Exxon on Clinton
Street. Apex Oil purchased the former

ASARCO plant for a future bulk storage

facility.

Apex and Exxon storage and distribu-
tion facilities cover over 200 acres in
northwest Canton.

Planned Development

Private: A significant amount of private
investment has been committed to Canton.
This includes:

*General Motors - In 1981 General
Motors Corp. announced plans for a
major modernization and a 433,000-
square-foot expansion of its Broening
Highway Plant. Total investment in the
project was projected to exceed $500
million. This project was suspended for

-about a year, due to reduced auto

,sales. In September of 1982, GM
announced the modernization would
resume although at a reduced level of
$270 million. As part of this program,
GM has aquired 26 acres in the Hola-
bird Industrial Park from the City with
an option on an additional 24 acres.
The Holabird acreage has been used to
replace a parking lot displaced by the
plant’s expansion on its current site.

*Consolidation Coal Co. - This sub-
sidiary of Conoco Oil Co. acquired the
Canton Railroad, Cottman Ore Pier,
and 110 acres of associated land which
it has developed as a major coal export
facility with an initial capacity of 10
million tons per year. More than $100
million in improvements has included



to Baltimore by unit train, a system in
which an entire train is used to trans-
port a single product to one final
destination. Consolidation Coal Co.
opened the facility in October, 1983.

*Canton Railroad - Canton Develop-

ment Co., a venture capital firm based
in Florida, purchased the Canton Rail-
road from a subsidiary of Consolida-
tion Coal Co. in October of 1982. The
company plans to expand the railroad’s
rolling stock and is considering con-
struction of a new office building.

*Rukert Terminals, Inc. - This Baltimore-

based company is currently improving
its bulk terminal facilities on Pier 5
along Clinton street at a total cost of $7
million, including $1 million in Indus-
trial Development Revenue Bonds. The
improvements include construction of
several new buildings for bulk cargo

storage and reconstruction of a pier

after the completion of the 1-95, Fort
McHenry Tunnel in Canton.

*Apex Qil Co. - Through the acquisition

of the long vacant ASARCO copper
smelting plant on Eastbourne Avenue,
the Apex Qil Co. has increased its
acreage fivefold to over 50 acres.

Public: To support the considerable



1

tion in the Canton area. The express-
way will link the Canton and Locust
Point industrial areas, provide direct
access southwest to the Baltimore-
Washington corridor and northeast to
New York, and relieve truck traffic on
local residential streets north and west
of the Canton industrial area. The
expressway is currently completed to
Keith Avenue. Work on the final phase
of 1-95 in Canton, the Fort McHenry

Tunnel, expressway approaches, and a

toll facility is scheduled for completion
in 1985. In conjunction with work on
the expressway, several new access
routes are being built.

In addition, various local street
improvements are programmed in
Canton; the widening of Ponca Street,
reconstruction of Poncabird Pass and
Haven Street and the reconstruction
and widening of Clinton Street from
Boston Street to Leland Avenue.

*Holabird Industrial Park - On surplus

Army land the city is developing a 170-
acre industrial park. Streets and utilities
are being installed and sites are being
marketed for general purpose indus-
trial uses. When completed Holabird is
expected to provide 2,500-to-3,000
jobs. In 1982 the federal government
approved the City’s application for a
20-acre Foreign Trade Zone.
McCormick Properties was selected by
the City to develop and operate a 20-
acre Foreign Trade Zone located in the
northwest corner of the industrial park.

Among other benefits a Foreign Trade
Zone allows components from over-
seas to be assembled in this country at
a reduced import duty. This encour-
ages new industries to establish assem-
bly plants in the zone and provide new
jobs and property taxes in Baltimore.

*Canton Seagirt Marine Terminal -

Dredge spoil from the excavation for
the 1-95 Fort McHenry Tunnel has
been used to create 147 acres of new
waterfront land between the Sea Land
Service container terminal and the
Western Electric Co. The Maryland
Port Administration will develop the
site into the Port’s second largest con-
tainer terminal. It will include three
new 1,000 foot long berths and an
extension of the existing Sea Land
service berth. The MPA has estimated
in 1982 that it will cost $123 million to
develop the new terminal. This invest-
ment is expected to result in approxi-

private development activity, the City is in mately 380 permanent jobs.
the process of implementing several large-

scale public works projects. These include:

renovation of the pier, construction of
a storage facility for mixing different
grades of coal, and reorientation of the
rail yards to allow more efficient coal
delivery. To speed coal delivery

Clinton St., mix of trucks, autos and parked cars





lssues and Problems

While there are important opportuni-
ties for future development in Canton,
there are also significant problems which
must be overcome if the area is to realize
its full development potential. Among
these are:

*Traffic Congestion - Completion of
Interstate-95 should reduce one of
the major problems that has plagued
Canton for years: truck traffic using
local streets in surrounding residential
communities.

However, several other transportation
problems may persist in the future,
most notably heavy traffic congestion
on many of industrial Canton’s streets.
This problem results from several
factors: the large number of people

“employed in the area, the emptying of
traffic into the area from the Harbor
Tunnel Thruway and from Interstate-
95, the queuing up of trucks waiting to
unload cargo at the area’s many piers,
and the large number of railroads that
cross congested streets.

The planned construction of new
streets and the widening and recon-
struction of existing streets are
designed to help reduce congestion
and to give motorists alternative
routes. However, the proposed expan-
sion of General Motors, the develop-
ment of Holabird Industrial Park,

the recently completed berth at the

t

Dundalk Marine Terminal, and the
development of the Canton Seagirt
Terminal are expected to bring addi-
tional traffic into the area further con-
tributing to the congestion problem.
To help accommodate this new traffic
several further street improvements
may be needed in the future.

*Rail Problems - The Canton area con-

tains an extensive rail network. Both
Conrail and the CSX Railroad maintain
yards in the area for direct delivery to
local industrial and port users. Trains
are switched between these two major
lines and moved to business loading
docks by the Canton Railroad. The
most important rail issue facing Canton
concerns the future of this small
switching railroad. The continued
operation of a switching railroad is
critical to a number of the area’s indus-
tries. It is anticipated that the recent
purchase of the Canton Railroad
assures the area of service in the
future.

Several other issues also face Canton’s
rail system. Traffic bottlenecks created
by at-grade rail crossings on Boston
Street, Newkirk Street (near Holabird
Avenue and near Newgate Street),
Ponca Street, Holabird Avenue, and
Newgate Street pose transportation
problems for the area. The at-grade-
crossing at Boston Street is especially
hampering. Six tracks cross Boston
Street at-grade and the B & O bridge,
which has an 11 foot clearance from
the roadway, adds to the difficulties.
Increased coal shipment for the
Consolidation Coal Terminal may
aggravate’this situation. Besides these
rail/auto conflicts, the rail system itself
suffers from several serious operational
problems.

*Environmental Problems - Canton also

faces several environmental problems.
The absence of public sewers in west
Canton means that industries must
provide their own treatment systems or
discharge into the harbor. While
environmentally necessary, installing a
package treatment system is costly. This
added capital expense can discourage
firms interested in locating or expand-
ing in the area. Given Canton’s close-
ness to the harbor and the area’s high
water table, there is also some ques-
tion as to whether existing septic
systems can offer adequate protection
against soil contamination. On the
other hand, extending sewer lines to
west Canton would be particularly
costly for the City because no federal
funding is available for providing sewer
lines to private industries.

Canton’s other environmental problem
is meeting federal air quality standards.

field_edited_text_processed:
Like much of Baltimore, Canton is
classified a ‘“‘non-attainment” area. A
main cause of Canton’s air pollution is
the dust and other particles raised
from unpaved or deteriorated road-
beds, construction activity, open
storage and transfer of commodities
like coal and chemicals, and open,
unkempt land. This source of pollution
should be significantly reduced once
construction activity is completed on
Interstate-95 and on the various devel-
opment projects in Canton. It can also
be alleviated through the planned
implementation of relativgly inexpen-
sive yet effective methods of control-
ling particle emissions like covering
bulk storage facilities and maintaining
open land.

*Area Conditions — Another problem is
the poor condition of some of the
buildings and facilities in Canton. The
deteriorated buildings along Clinton
Street, for example, detract from
Canton’s image as an efficient indus-
trial port area.

2w
'-

Dilapidated buildings along Clinton St.



uture Opportunities

Consolidation Coal Co.’s purchase in
1980 of the 110-acre Canton Company’s
holdings determined the future of Canton’s
last major developable parcel. While there
are several additional opportunities for
private development in Canton, they are
considerably more limited in scope.

*Lebanon Chemical Development Site -
Lebanon Chemical Co., which pres-
ently operates at two separate sites in
Canton, plans to consolidate all its
operations to its southernmost location
at 2600 South Clinton Street, leaving its
other property at 1800 South Clinton
Street available for industrial redevel-
opment. Before the three acre site
could be marketed the deteriorated
wooden building on the parcel would
have to be demolished and cleared.

*Consolidation Coal Co. Clinton Street
Parcel and Pier - Among the proper-
ties purchased by the Consolidation
Coal Co. were an unused 500-by-50
foot pier at the foot of Holabird
Avenue and a 30-acre parcel across
Clinton Street. Neither are needed for
the company’s coal export operations
and so are potentially available for
alternative development. One option
would be to market them jointly as an
industrial site with deep water access.



Another approach would be to
develop the pier as a small facility for
loading containers onto barges using
the Clinton Street parcel as back-up
storage space required for such an
operation.

*Apex Oil Company Industrial Building
- Several buildings acquired by the
Apex Oil Company at the former
ASARCO smelting site might be leased
for industrial development. Of particu-
lar interest is the largest structure, the
400,000 square-foot tank building.

*Conrail Excess Land - Adjacent to its
coal pier on South Clinton Street, Con-
rail owns an elongated 16-acre tract of
land which it currently uses for bulk
commodity storage. This parcel could
be marketed for industrial develop-
ment. Alternatively, Rukert Terminals,
Inc. has expressed interest in purchas-
ing the site from Conrail and continu-
ing to use it for bulk storage purposes.

*Other Sites

e former Exxon distribution terminal
(10 acres +)

e Colgate warehouses and adjacent
land (70 acres +)

e land adjacent to 1-95 and O’Donnell
Street

other property at 1800 South Clinton
Street available for industrial redevel-
opment. Before the three acre site
could be marketed the deteriorated
wooden building on the parcel would
have to be demolished and cleared.

*Consolidation Coal Co. Clinton Street
Parcel and Pier - Among the proper-
ties purchased by the Consolidation
Coal Co. were an unused 500-by-50
foot pier at the foot of Holabird
Avenue and a 30-acre parcel across
Clinton Street. Neither are needed for
the company’s coal export operations
and so are potentially available for
alternative development. One option
would be to market them jointly as an
industrial site with deep water access.



Another approach would be to
develop the pier as a small facility for
loading containers onto barges using
the Clinton Street parcel as back-up
storage space required for such an
operation.

*Apex Oil Company Industrial Building
- Several buildings acquired by the
Apex Oil Company at the former
ASARCO smelting site might be leased
for industrial development. Of particu-
lar interest is the largest structure, the
400,000 square-foot tank building.

*Conrail Excess Land - Adjacent to its
coal pier on South Clinton Street, Con-
rail owns an elongated 16-acre tract of
land which it currently uses for bulk
commodity storage. This parcel could
be marketed for industrial develop-
ment. Alternatively, Rukert Terminals,
Inc. has expressed interest in purchas-
ing the site from Conrail and continu-
ing to use it for bulk storage purposes.

*Other Sites

e former Exxon distribution terminal
(10 acres +)

e Colgate warehouses and adjacent
land (70 acres +)

e land adjacent to 1-95 and O’Donnell
Street



44

Hawkins Point is located on the
southernmost part of the harbor at the
north end of the Marley Neck peninsula
which lies within both Baltimore City and
Anne Arundel County. Hawkins Point, the
portion of Marley Neck in Baltimore City,
is located adjacent to the Baltimore Belt-
way, Md. Rolite-695 and the Curtis Bay and
Fort McHenry ship channels.

With almost one-half of its 860 acres
undeveloped Hawkins Point offers a sub-
stantial opportunity for industrial growth.
The 12 industries in the area currently
employ over 1,700 persons. While the pre-
dominant activity in Hawkins Point is indus-
trial there is currently a small residential
community concentrated south of Md.-695.

which lies within both Baltimore City and

portion of Marley Neck in Baltimore City,

field_edited_text_processed:
Key Bridge from Fort Armistead’s shoreline





Development History

Hawkins Point was originally part of an
estate called “Cromwell’s Inheritance.” At
the site of what is now Fort Armistead, a
quarantine station built in 1779 housed
victims of the yellow fever epidemic. The
facility remained in use until 1830. Another
quarantine station was built nearby at
Leading Point in 1881 for smallpox victims
and was used as a health station until 1961.
Today this 18 acre property is owned by
the Maryland Port Administration and used
for a dredge spoil disposal facility.

The area’s first industry was Chappel’s
sulfuric acid plant, opened in 1883. The
plant was bought by the Davison Chemical
Co. in 1903 which has since become a
world leading manufacturer of superphos-
phates. The construction of a wooden
drawbridge across Curtis Creek in 1898
provided the stimulus for development in
the area and industrial activity spread from
the Fairfield peninsula to Hawkins Point.

The 46 acre Fort Armistead, originally
built in 1898 to protect the harbor during
the Spanish American war, was acquired by







the City in 1927, nine years after Hawkins
Point was annexed by Baltimore. During
World War 11, this shorefront park was
retained as an ammunition storage depot.

After the war industrial development
resulted in some site improvements to the
area. In 1979 the Francis Scott Key Bridge, a
four lane, 4/5-mile long, arched span, was
built across the harbor from Hawkins Point
to Sollers Point in Baltimore County. Much
of the interior of Hawkins Point, however,
still remains in a semi-rural state.

Refurbished Fort Armistead Park

field_edited_text_processed:
xisting Conditions

Industrial Activity: Four Hawkins Point
manufacturing firms employ approximately
1,600 persons. The largest W.R. Grace’s
Davison Chemical Division with 770
employees, produces automotive catalysts
as well as silicon derivative products. SCM
Corp.’s Glidden Pigments Group estab-
lished its operations in Hawkins Point in
1956 and today employs 676 persons. The
company produces titanium dioxide pig-
ments used in the manufacture of paints.
U.S. Gypsum Co. with 160 employees pro-
duces gypsum building material products,
receiving barge shipments of production
materials at its own pier. Finally, Atlantic
Cement with 12 employees produces
cement and concrete at its batching plant
located on Chemical Road.

Wholesale and trucking firms are also a
significant employer in Hawkins Point. Four
companies provide 105 jobs. The trucking
firms are concentrated south of Hawkins
Point Road along the City/County
boundary. e

>

Hawkins Point is also the location of
four landfill operations. Browning Ferris
Industries, Inc. and SCM Corp. operate
landfills on adjoining sites of 30.56 acres
and 37.95 acres respectively.

The Maryland Environmental Service
developed a facility to handle disposal of
hazardous waste on approximately eight
acres of land owned by the Maryland Port
Administration at Thom’s Cove. The facility
has now been designated to dispose of
chromium waste from Allied Chemical’s
plant in Baltimore City.

At the old Quarantine Station site the
Maryland Port Administration operates a
small facility to dispose of dredge spoil
material from projects in the harbor

Port Activity: Despite close proximity
to deep water channels, only one marine
terminal operates in Hawkins Point. The
terminal is owned by the Maryland Port
Administration and is leased to Eastalco
Aluminum Corporation which operates a
facility for receipt, storage, and shipment of
alumina to its smelting plant in Frederick
County, Maryland. The terminal includes a
30,000 ton silo used for storage of alumina
and a CSX Railroad line which provides
access to the pier. Twelve persons are
employed at the Eastalco Terminal.

Both W.R. Grace and U.S. Gypsum
receive a portion of their raw materials
through the use of private piers.



SCM Glidden’s paint pigment plant

Residential Areas: Hawkins Point has
historically never supported a very large
residential community. For a number of
years just over 100 residents occupied
homes on approximately five acres of
commercially zoned land between Hawkins
Point Road and the Baltimore Beltway.
With the development of the MES hazard-
ous waste disposal facility the State set up
funds to purchase these properties and
allow residents to relocate out of the area.
There are also several smaller clusters of
houses on streets south of Hawkins Point
Road.

Recreation Areas: Hawkins Point’s only
major recreation area is Fort Armistead,
built by the U.S. government in 1898 as one
of the forts to defend the harbor during
the Spanish American War. The fort is
named after Colonel George Armistead,
who served in the battle of Northpoint in
the War of 1812. Baltimore City acquired
the 46 acre tract from the government in
1927 with the provision that the land be
used exclusively for recreation purposes.

Approaching the fort from land there
is a rather large, flat bow! of land rising to
the remains of battlements. This drops
rapidly to a seawall which is built along the
entire shoreline. The remains of the fort
are dominated by concrete gun mounts,
platforms and ammunition storage
chambers below.

The view from the battlements and sea-
wall is exceptional. To the north and east
are Bethlehem Steel’s Sparrows Point Plant
and the confluence of the Patapsco River
and Chesapeake Bay. Dominating the view
to the west is the Francis Scott Key Bridge,
offering a unique view of ships passing
under the bridge.

Using special State funds, the City has
made major improvements to Fort Armi-
stead. A newly landscaped entrance road,
expanded parking for visitors and a boat
launch, a renovated pier and seawall, play
equipment and picnic areas were dedicated
in the summer of 1984. The park, although
not well known, is well used for free boat
launching, fishing, and by people who
simply enjoy watching the port’s activities.



438

field_edited_text_processed:
"9





Planned Development

Baltimore City Landfill. The City has
purchased approximately 142 acres from
the W.R. Grace Co. to develop as a domes-
tic landfill. The site located north of
Hawkins Point Road and between Quaran-
tine and Chemical Roads should provide
the City with landfill capacity for 10 to 20
years.



Issues and Problems

Two projects in Anne Arundel County
outside the boundaries of Hawkins Point
promise to have an impact on the area’s
future. The first development project in
Anne Arundel County affecting the future
of Hawkins Point is the Brandon Shores
Power Generating Station being built by
the Baltimore Gas and Electric Co. The .
station will contain two coal fired units,
one scheduled to go into operation in
1984, the other in 1987. When both units
are running, they will burn 2.5-million tons
of coal per year. In addition, two oil-
powered generating units at the Wagner
Power Plant immediately adjacent to
Brandon Shores are being overhauled for
coal use. After the conversion is completed
by 1990, the Wagner Station will require 1.2
million tons of coal per year.

Coal barge passing Bethlehem Steel’s Sparrows Point plant

Plans call for coal to be brought to
both generating stations by barge. The
second project also involves the Baltimore
Gas and Electric Co. A subsidiary plans to
develop an industrial park on land owned
by B.G.&E.

Rail Issues: Pennington Avenue is the
only route into Hawkins Point and Marley
Neck from the north. The anticipated
increase in the number of trains to service
new industry could block access not only
for employees and trucks, but also for
emergency vehicles. Grade separation at
this point will be a high priority to the City,
but will be costly.

In addition, Glidden, Gypsum, Cosmin
and Kennecott could all be blocked by
train movement across grade crossings lead-
ing to their properties. Further, the CSX rail
line crosses Curtis Creek into Hawkins
Point via a swing bridge. When trains are
crossing the bridge, Coast Guard vessels
cannot move into the harbor from the
Coast Guard Station further south on Curtis
Creek. There has to be careful coordina-
tion between the trains and the Coast
Guard to prevent any delay in answering
emergency calls from vessels in the harbor.

Traffic Issues: The City is planning
improvements to Pennington Avenue.
Improvements to portions of Hawkins Point
Road have been completed and additional
upgrading is projected for the future.



50

field_edited_text_processed:
*Environmental Issues: Several environ-
mental issues figure in the future of
Hawkins Point. While connected to the
City’s water supply and storm water
systems, the area is without public sanitary
sewers. This means that businesses in the
area must maintain their own package (i.e.
self-contained) treatment systems and resi-
dences must use septic tanks. For busi-
nesses that are considering locating in
Hawkins Point, the prospect of having to
install a package treatment system repre-
sents an added development cost.

A federally-sponsored Areawide Waste-
water Management Study has been com-
pleted to assess the need for public sewer
service in Hawkins Point. The study has
concluded that public sewers are needed,
there are a number of ways this need could
be met, including connecting the area to
the City’s Patapsco Wastewater Treatment
+Plant in Fairfield, connecting it to the Cox
Creek Plant in Anne Arundel County, and
connecting the residential community to a
sewer system at the U.S. Coast Guard
Station. However, the unavailability of
federal funds for extending sewer service
to industrial areas leaves the burden of
financing comprehensive sewer service to
Hawkins Point to local jurisdictions.

As in other harbor areas, the develop-
ment of a major coal terminal near

Dust clouds from unloading ore

]ay Steinhour

Hawkins Point requires that dust emissions
from coal cars, coal piles, and loading and
unloading operations be controlled. The
State air quality agency believes that
planned controls on the coal loading
operations would sufficiently limit any
emissions.

There is also concern over the leaking
of pollutants into the bay from the Glidden
Co.’s holding ponds. Acid, leaking through
the dikes of:these ponds has reached the
shallow water area along the shoreline of
the plant. There has already been damage
to wetlands vegetation and the water qual-
ity in the area. The state and Glidden are
currently negotiating solutions to this
problem.

*Port-Related Issue: There are signifi-
cant opportunities for port-related devel-
opment along the northern shoreline of
Hawkins Poing because the land here has
deep water access. However, the waters off
the north shore have served for years as a
disposal site for unwanted “dead” ships.
Thus, before the northern shore can be
developed for activities requiring deep-
water access, the sunken ships in these
waters will have to be cleared.



51

field_edited_text_processed:
uture Opportunities

Hawkins Point contains approximately
400 acres of vacant land. There are four
potential development sites in Hawkins
Point:

*Three sites (90 acres, 179 acres, and 30
acres) owned primarily by a subsidiary
of the CSX Railroad.

*Two sites (30 acres and 132 acres) cur-
rently owned by the W.R. Grace Co.
but are to be purchased by the City for
development as a landfill. Lhese sites
will hold some development potential
for light industry, warehousing and
storage operations upon completion of
the landfill operation.

If the three Chessie sites were
marketed to attract industries which
employ an average of 12 persons per acre,
3,600 additional jobs would be created in
Hawkins Point.

Several factors will influence how these
parcels are developed. The CSX Railroad
has expressed an interest in selling land to
rail dependent activities. If this results in
attracting storage and distribution uses, it is
likely that lower levels of employment will
result. The W.R. Grace sites present the
most difficulty in terms of site preparation.
While the other Hawkins Point develop-
ment parcels are relatively flat, W.R.

Grace’s 132-acre southernmost parcel con-
tains a 100-foot-high hill which must be
regraded to allow the landfill to be devel-
oped. One option for regrading would be
to remove the majority of the hill on the
southern site, selling the resulting six

million cubic yards of earth on the open
market and to the Maryland Port Adminis-
tration for fill. To strengthen the market for
the excavated earth, the northern W.R.
Grace parcel could be sold to the Maryland
Port Administration for immediate use as a
dredge spoil disposal site and for long-term
development as a marine terminal capable
of meeting projected port demand beyond
the year 2000. This alternative would result
in a landfill to handle the City’s needs for a
number of years and a 150-acre (30 acres of
existing fastland; 120 acres of fill) site for a
four-berth marine terminal. While this max-
imum excavation approach would be costly
and the completion of the marine terminal
is 25-to-30 years in the future it offers the
following advantages 1) providing more
employment than the minimum excavation
option, 2) partially meeting the Port’s
immediate needs for a dredge disposal site,
3) providing stable fill material for the
Masonville Marine Terminal 4) meeting the
long-term need for additional port terminal
capacity, and, 5) use as a landfill for the
City’s needs.

Vacant land ready for development



In addition to these significant
economic development opportunities,
Hawkins Point contains an important under-
utilized recreation resource in Fort
Armistead. Through a phased improvement
program using special State funds, Fort
Armistead has been made much more
usable to the public. By providing boat
launches, access down the slopes from the
parking lot to the seawall, pathways along
the seawall, landscaping, play areas, and
athletic fields, the City will revive this
neglected facility. Construction was com-
pleted in the summer of 1984.

Fort Armistead, along with the other
forts in the harbor—McHenry, Carroll,
Howard, Smallwood—could also be tied
together by tour boats and offer the citi-
zens of the region a unique recreational
experience. Each fort would be developed
emphasizing a special feature, McHenry
and Carroll historical, Armistead, Small-
wood and Howard recreational. Visitors
could plan part of or an entire day around
the attractions.





52
field_edited_text_value:
uture Opportunities

Hawkins Point contains approximately
400 acres of vacant land. There are four
potential development sites in Hawkins
Point:

*Three sites (90 acres, 179 acres, and 30
acres) owned primarily by a subsidiary
of the CSX Railroad.

*Two sites (30 acres and 132 acres) cur-
rently owned by the W.R. Grace Co.
but are to be purchased by the City for
development as a landfill. Lhese sites
will hold some development potential
for light industry, warehousing and
storage operations upon completion of
the landfill operation.

If the three Chessie sites were
marketed to attract industries which
employ an average of 12 persons per acre,
3,600 additional jobs would be created in
Hawkins Point.

Several factors will influence how these
parcels are developed. The CSX Railroad
has expressed an interest in selling land to
rail dependent activities. If this results in
attracting storage and distribution uses, it is
likely that lower levels of employment will
result. The W.R. Grace sites present the
most difficulty in terms of site preparation.
While the other Hawkins Point develop-
ment parcels are relatively flat, W.R.

Grace’s 132-acre southernmost parcel con-
tains a 100-foot-high hill which must be
regraded to allow the landfill to be devel-
oped. One option for regrading would be
to remove the majority of the hill on the
southern site, selling the resulting six

million cubic yards of earth on the open
market and to the Maryland Port Adminis-
tration for fill. To strengthen the market for
the excavated earth, the northern W.R.
Grace parcel could be sold to the Maryland

%



A peninsula of land in the southern
part of the city, the Fairfield industrial area
encompasses 57 businesses employing
some 4,800 people, three small residential
communities and an extensive network of
railroads and highways. The many ware-
houses, oil tanks, storage yards, and piers
which prédominate the landscape are
evidence of the area’s role as a major tran-
shipment and storage point for goods as
diverse as oil, automobiles, ore, chemicals,
and lumber. Besides commerce, the area’s
businesses also provide a significant
number of jobs in chemical processing,
asphalt production, metal working, and
general manufacturing.

field_edited_text_processed:
Workers at Bethlehem Steel’s Fairfield yard, WW I







velopment History

Despite repeated attempts by land
speculators to promote industrial and resi-
dential development, Fairfield remained a
rural, agricultural area until the late 19th
century. Prior to that time the only signifi-
cant development had been the founding
of “Freetown,” reputedly the first settle-
ment of free blacks in the eastern United
States.

Two events opened Fairfield to wide-
spread residential and industrial develop-
ment. In 1878 the state bought the Light
Street bridge from its private owner and
eliminated its five cent toll thereby encou-
raging residential development south of the
Middle Branch. Then in 1882 the B&O Rail-
road extented its main line across the
Middle Branch, through Brooklyn, and
down to Curtis Bay. Almost immediately
industrial development began. By the turn
of the century the B&O Railroad built a
coal pier and four other companies opened
plants.

The early 1900s saw a rapid expansion
of industrial development, particularly of
oil and chemical companies, metal pro-
ducts manufacturers, and shipbuilding and
repair yards. By 1918 when Fairfield was
annexed to Baltimore City approximately
2,000 were employed in area industries.



In conjunction with this industrial
development four residential communities
took root: Brooklyn, Curtis Bay, Old Fair-
field, and East Brooklyn (today known as
Wagner’s Point). Most of these began as
clusters of company sponsored housing.

The next major spurt in development
occurred in the 1940s when the govern-
ment established the largest shipyard on
the East Coast in Fairfield to build Liberty
and Victory ships for the war effort. During
the course of the war more than 500 vessels
were built and launched at the Fairfield
yards. Between 1940 and 1944 most of the
remaining vacant land in Fairfield was
developed into new housing for workers,
storage yards, and the expansion of indus-
tries related to the war effort.

After the war the land occupied by the
shipyard was returned to its private owners
and wartime housing was either torn down
or converted to public housing. (Fairfield
Homes was established in this way.) The
end of the war also saw the development
of extensive tank farms in Fairfield and the
completion in 1957 of the Harbor Tunnel
Thruway which linked Fairfield to the inter-
state highway system and the eastern
seaboard.



54

field_edited_text_processed:
Existing Conditions

Industrial Activity: 57 industries are
located in Fairfield: 12 are involved in pet-
roleum storage and refining, 10 in chemical
manufacturing, and 24 are involved in
commodity storage and distribution. Practi-
cally all the rest are engaged in metal
manufacture and fabrication, shipbuilding
and repair, and general manufacturing.

*Chemical Manufacture - Most of Fair-
field’s 10 chemical manufacturers are
located south of the Harbor Tunnel
Thruway crossing. The three largest
firms are FMC Corp., proﬁ'ucer of
organic chemicals and pesticides, with
395 employees; Conoco Chemicals,
maker of detergents and alkalytes, with
182 employees; and Alcolac Corp.,
manufacturer of detergents, with 160
employees.

*Petroleum Storage and Refining - Pet-
roleum companies maintain two types
of operations in Fairfield: tank farms
and asphalt refineries. Fairfield contains
the largest concentration of tank farms
of any area on the Baltimore harbor.
Oil storage facilities, maintained by
eight oil companies, occupy over 300
acres in Fairfield. The tanks store both
light fuels (gasoline, home heating oil,
kerosene, and jet fuel) which can be
piped into the area through the Colon-
ial Pipeline and heavy fuels (used in
manufacturing processes and power
plants) which are too thick to be
moved by pipeline and must be ship-
ped by barge. In addition to the tank
farms, Fairfield contains three asphalt
plants which serve a regional market.
Crude oil used in asphalt production is
brought to these plants by barge or
ship while the asphalt is distributed by
truck or rail.

*Metals Manufacture and Fabrication -
Seven firms engage in metal fabrica-
tion. The largest, Bethlehem Steel’s
Buffalo Tank Division, employs 175
persons in the production of steel
tanks ranging from fuel tanks used by
gasoline stations to nuclear reactor
shields. Another firm, American Seam-
less Tubing Corp., was acquired by
Copperweld, Inc. and is expected to
expand from 60 to 200 employees:
American Seamless produces drill bits
and equipment for drilling gas and oil
wells.

*Shipbuilding and Repairing - The
largest employer in Fairfield for a
number of years was the Maryland
Shipbuilding and Drydock Company at
its Frankfurst Avenue Facility. Maryland
Shipbuilding and Drydock announced
in 1984 that it was closing its operation.

The facility is currently for sale. Fair-
field’s other ship repair firm is the
American Dredging Company which
specializes in the maintenance of
dredging vessels. It employs 17
persons.

*Commodity Storage and Distribution -

Three distinct categories of commodi-
ties are stored and distributed at Fair-
field facilities.

General Merchandise. Low rents and
excellent transportation have made
Fairfield a favorite location for storing
or warehousing a wide variety of pro-
ducts including automobiles, lumber,
steel, and plastics. The largest storage
operation is the Hobelmann Corp.,
which imports and stores automobiles
at its Fairfield facility.

Many small firms lease space in the
long row of warehouses operated by
Harris Heller Terminals between Curtis
and Pennington Avenues and in the
Empire Industrial Center on Benbhill
Avenue.

Solid Bulk Commodities. Three com-
panies store ore and coal in Fairfield.
The CSX Railroad runs both an ore
import yard and a coal export yard on
Curtis Bay. The Island Creek Co. oper-
ates a coal storage and export facility at
Curtis Bay. Overflow at the ore import
facility is stored by the Joseph Hock
Co. at its yard on Northbridge Avenue.

Liquid Bulk Commodities. Besides pet-
roleum, two other liquid commodities
are stored and distributed in Fairfield.
Skyline Terminals, acquired in 1981 by
W.R. Grace Co., handles commodities
for the food and chemical processing
industries. Allied Chemical operates a
terminal which receives chemicals
shipped by barge.

*General Manufacturing - Two sizeable

brick manufacturers operate plants in
Fairfield. Harbison-Walker Refractories
on Patapsco Avenue and General
Refractories on Chesapeake Avenue.

Residential Areas: Surrounded by Fair-
field’s heavy industry are three residential
communities.

*Old Fairfield - This cluster of homes

dates back to the turn of the century
when housing was often built on
industiral land. Currently, this small
black community of about 200 resi-
dents is characterized by industrial
encroachment, unpaved or deterio-
rated streets, vacant houses and lots,
poor street lighting and limited public
transportation. In 1977 the City
extended a sewer line into the area to
service the scattered homes. However,
the operations of a number of the sur-

56

rounding industries, heavily impact the
residents in this area, which has been
industrially zoned since 1931. Residents
who wish to leave the area may
request the City to purchase their
homes and for assistance in relocation.

*Fairfield Homes - Built during World

War Il to house workers for Fairfield’s
wartime industries, Fairfield Homes was
converted to public housing after the
war. Today Fairfield Homes houses
1,002 residents. Bordered north and
south by streets with heavy truck traffic
and separated from the nearest shop-
ping areas by industry and a major
railyard, the community is subject to
high levels of noise and dust. There is
also the difficult and dangerous situa-
tion of having to cross railroad tracks
and highways to reach the nearest
commerical area. In an effort-to
upgrade the community facilities, the
recreation center has been improved
and the playground rebuilt with a“
special grant from the federal Coastal
Energy Impact Program.

*Wagner’s Point - This three-block long,

working class community of 255 resi-
dents originated as housing for
employees of nearby industry.
Bordered on one side by a heavily-
used industrial road and on the other
side by tank farms, Wagner’s Point
consists of approximately 85 row-
houses. The streets in the community
are in generally good repair and the
City maintains a small playground.

Besides the three communities on the
peninsula itself, two others — Brooklyn
and Curtis Bay — border Fairfield on
the northwest and west respectively.

yards of fill soil will be needed to
create the site for the new terminal.
Unique to the Masonville terminal will
be a planned container servicing opera-
tion. This facility will lease, repair and
service containers for companies that
do not wish to make the large invest-
ment in purchasing containers. The
repair and service operation also offers
the prospect of a high level of
employment. In addition, the new
facility will necessitate a number of
significant transportation improve-
ments, including extension of rail ser-
vice into the facility by the CSX Rail-
road, the possible construction of a
new interchange between the Harbor

Tunnel Thruway and the terminal, and
~improvements to Frankfurst Avenue
near the new facility.

Junkyards and homes at Old Fairfield







|ssues and Problems

The future presents a number

of unresolved issues for Fairfield:

*Land Use Issues - Because of the scar-

city of developable land in Fairfield, it
has been suggested that some of the
peninsula’s many tank farms be relo-
cated elsewhere. The proposal is
prompted by a number of factors. First,
it is supposed that oil distributors who
are not dependent on waterborne
deliveries could just as well locate on
peripheral sites in the region further
inland along the Colonial Pipeline.
Second, it is speculated that industrial
or port-related development of the
tank farm sites would yield greater
economic benefits to the city in the
form of taxes and jobs.

It has been found, however, that not
only would it be extremely costly to
relocate the tanks (estimated at more
than $50 million for relocating five
million barrels of storage capacity), but
also even those distributors who could
obtain all their oil through the Colon-
ial Pipeline prefer to retain the flexibil-
ity of being able to receive oil by ship
if necessary.

A second land use issue facing Fairfield
revolves around the conflict between
residential and industrial activity. The
entire Fairfield peninsula is zoned for

Jay Steinhour

the heaviest allowable industrial activ-
ity. This creates problems for the
peninsula’s residential communities
which experience elevated levels of air
and noise pollution, truck traffic, and
industrial encroachment. It also puts
the City in the difficult position of hav-
ing to decide whether to fund
extremely costly projects that will
shore up the residential communities
or to encourage the conversion of the
entire area to industrial activities.

For example, Old Fairfield contains
many vacant lots, deteriorated and
empty buildings, unpaved streets, and
homes that are still not connected to
the public sewer line. Furthermore,
residents have had to witness the
steady spread of Brooklyn Salvage, an
automotive junkyard which has
extended its operations onto vacant
lots and public streets.

The City faces a dilemma. On the one
hand, it could provide new streets and
street lighting, require residents to
hook up to the new sewer line at sub-
stantial private costs, and turn back
Brooklyn Salvage’s expansion by strictly
enforcing the City codes. On the other
hand, the City could encourage the
conversion of the area to its currently
zoned industrial activity by helping
residents relocate. The difficulty is that
some residents have expressed a desire
to move to newer housing outside
Fairfield while others would like to
remain in the area and want the City
to improve services in the community.
The City has offered to purchase the
property of residents who wish to
relocate out of the industrial area. This
conflict is one of the outstanding issues
in the future of Fairfield.

*Traffic Issues — Located at the first

interchange south of the Harbor
Tunnel Thruway toll plaza, Fairfield is
linked to the eastern seaboard by the
Tunnel Thruway. Besides the Thruway,
three major streets (Frankfurst,
Patapsco, and Pennington Avenues)
connect the Fairfield peninsula to the
city amd region. All three streets, which
are heavily travelled today, will
experience increased congestion with
the development of the Masonville
Marine Terminal, Island Creek Coal
Terminal, and future rail-oriented
industry south of Fairfield in Marley
Neck. Particular troublespots occur at
the junction of the Harbor Tunnel
Thruway ramps and Frankfurst Avenue
and at the intersection of Birch Street
and Pennington Avenue where north-
bound traffic routed off Pennington
Avenue onto Curtis Avenue is forced
to make two sharp turns. These two



59

industry south of Fairfield in Marley

and at the intersection of Birch Street
and Pennington Avenue where north-

Avenue onto Curtis Avenue is forced
to make two sharp turns. These two



59

field_edited_text_processed:
turns are particularly difficult for trucks
to negotiate.

Possible construction of new or
improved ramps from the Harbor
Tunnel Thruway directly into Mason-
ville Terminal should help relieve the
first of these problems. Resolution of
the second problem has been
addressed by the redesign of Birch
Street and acquisition of several pro-

perties so that the connection between
Pennington and Curtis Avenues can be

realigned.

*Rail Issues - Three branches of the CSX

Railroad serve the Fairfield geninsula.

While this provides good rail access for

the area’s industries and port facilities,
the train tracks often cross heavily
travelled streets causing traffic tie-ups.
This represents a particular problem
where tracks cross the only route into
an area such as on Pennington
Avenue, the only road into Hawkins
Point from the north, and on Benhill
Avenue the only street serving twelve
firms and their 600 employees east of
Curtis Avenue. The frequency of traffic
tie-ups at grade-level railroad crossings
will increase with the development of
new industrial uses on Malley Neck
especially if these are rail oriented uses
as encouraged by the principal land

owner, the CSX Railroad. Resolving this

possible problem in the future will
require the attention of the City as
well as the CSX Railroad.

*Environmental Issues — The increase in
rail activity due to the growth of coal
exports will also contribute to noise
and air pollution and safety issues. The
City has already begun to address the
latter problem at Fairfield Homes by
constructing improved recreational
facilities which do not require resi-
dents to cross railroad tracks to use
playfields in adjacent communities.
This project is being funded under the
Coastal Energy Impact Program, a
federal program designed to reduce
the impacts of energy resources on
recreational facilities and residential
communities. The air pollution prob-
lem caused by particles released when
coal is transported, loaded, and
unloaded will require the railroads and
the exporters to rigorously put into”
practice techniques designed to con-
trol dust emissions. Methods such as
covering or soaking piles have proven
effective and economical. Other
sources of particulate pollution, open
storage piles, unkept vacant land and
unpaved roads can be controlled
through relatively inexpensive

methods. This can significantly improve

air quality and the development desir-
ability of an industrial area.

Conjestion at Fairfield Homes, stored trailers, trucks, parked cars







Future Opportunities

There is little land in Fairfield available
for new development. All but one of the
developable sites identified in the accom-
panying map are presently used for stor-
age. Since storage facilities are often neces-
sary to support port and industrial activities,
it is not clear whether or when those sites
might be available for development.
Futhermore, two of the sites identified are
adjacent to residential communities which
could limit the kinds of manufacturing
activities that could be located on the sites.
The one vacant site identified as having
development potential is adjacent and
immediately south of the Patapsco Waste
Water Treatment Plant. It contains
approximately 20 acres and affords deep-
water access.

There may also be some development
opportunity available from approximately
20 acres of vacant and underutilized land at
the former Olin Mathieson factory.

In early 1984 the Fruehauf Corp. put its
50 acre Maryland Shipbuilding and Dry-
dock Co. on the market. Located on the
northern shoreline of Fairfield adjacent to
MPA’s planned Masonville Marine Termi-
nal, the site offers possibilities as continuing
to function as a shipbuilding facility or
conversion to a specialized terminal.











The Weyerhaeuser Co. has also placed
its facility up for lease or sale. Located
adjacent to the Maryland Shipbuilding site,
the properties could offer an almost 80
acre parcel for development.

Besides these limited opportunities for
industrial development, there is a possibil-
ity of creating a park and green open space
on the Pennington Avenue landfill located
on the southwest border of Fairfield. The
70-acre landfill which had been used for
demolition debris, incinerator ash and
domestic waste was closed in 1981. A park
and natural green space is planned as
recreational resource for the Curtis Bay
community.



60

field_edited_text_processed:
The Middle Branch of the Patapsco
river is a natural resource of significant
potential. Although industrial and commer-
cial uses are currently dominant, the
Middle Branch has 416 acres of water area
with little commercial shipping activity,
over 150.acres of underutilized open space,
and the largest wetland areas in Baltimore
Harbor. With six miles of shoreline the
Middle Branch has a water surface area
that is 20 times the size of the City’s Inner
Harbor.



Plans call for a combined effort by the
public and private sectors to implement
recreation projects and other improve-
ments in the area over the next decade.
Included in the plans are an upgraded
industrial area at Waterview Avenue to
expand employment opportunities; public
and private mrarinas and boat launches;
shoreline walks and bikeways; improved
water quality and instructional wetlands,
athletic fields and tot lots; fishing piers;
and acres of open green space for the
public. With careful planning and devel-
opment, this area will be transformed into
the City’s most extensive shoreline recrea-
tion facility.



61

field_edited_text_processed:
Boating on the Middle Branch, 1920’s





velopment History

Settlers in the middle of the 18th cen-
tury found iron ore in the areas adjacent to
the Middle Branch and erected an iron
furnace at the mouth of what is now the
Gwynns Falls. This area was also the site of
the City’s first brickyards producing mate-
rials for many of Baltimore’s early
structures.

The rich marshes, and an abundance
of shad, herring, perch, and rockfish, and a
wooded shoreline attracted visitors from all
over the City. By the early 1800s the Middle
Branch became an important recreation
area for the growing City of Baltimore.
Fletcher’s Fish House and a public beer
garden at the foot of Howard Street estab-
lished in the early 1800s were the first of
numerous commercial recreational uses.

By the mid-1800s the area began to
attract industrial uses. Baltimore’s Gas Light
Co. and Western Maryland Railroad’s Port
Covington Yard were established in the
1850s. Other development along the north
and northwest shores during the mid-19th
century included a few breweries, coal
yards, and a glass factory.

In 1916 the Hanover Street Bridge
opened and spurred residential and indus-
trial development of Brooklyn, Fairfield, and
Hawkins Point. Three years later these areas
were annexed to the City. In 1924, the
Western Maryland Railroad completed the

existing bridge across the Middle Branch.
Cherry Hill was developed by the City as a
residential community in the 1930s and 40s.

During the early 1970s three major
property owners along the shoreline
applied to the Corps of Engineers for per-
mits to expand their land area by filling
portions of the Middle Branch. BG&E at its
Spring Gardens Facility requested to fill
seven acres. Baltimore City requested to fill
10 acres with demolition material at the
Central Garage. Carr-Lowery on the west-
ern shoreline needed to fill and improve its
waterfront to improve plant operations.
During the federal review process the
Department of Interior requested a com-
prehensive look at the impacts of these
three permits on the long-range plans for
use of the waterfront and water quality.
Interior also expresseed concern over the
cumulative impacts of these projects com-
bined with the construction of the inter-
change of Interstate 95 and 395 directly
over the Middle Branch.

In response to these concerns the
City’s Department of Planning in 1977
issued the Middle Branch Park Plan, which
called for the creation of Baltimore’s largest
shoreline park along portions of the
perimeter of the Middle Branch and coor-
dination of activities around the waterfront.





62

The plan included proposals for the crea-
tion of boat launches, marinas, playfields,
fishing piers, open green spaces, picnic
areas, plus wetland-preservation-all linked
together by a pedestrian/bikeway trail. A
number of proposals have been carried
out, including the completion of Ferry Bar
Marine Park, Broening Park boat launch,
first phases of the 115-acre Reedbird Park,
removal of sunken boats and barges, and
improvements to the sewer system in areas
near the park.

1-95, 1-395 looking north to downtown

furnace at the mouth of what is now the
Gwynns Falls. This area was also the site of
the City’s first brickyards producing mate-
rials for many of Baltimore’s early
structures.

The rich marshes, and an abundance
of shad, herring, perch, and rockfish, and a
wooded shoreline attracted visitors from all
over the City. By the early 1800s the Middle
Branch became an important recreation
area for the growing City of Baltimore.
Fletcher’s Fish House and a public beer
garden at the foot of Howard Street estab-
lished in the early 1800s were the first of
numerous commercial recreational uses.

By the mid-1800s the area began to
attract industrial uses. Baltimore’s Gas Light
Co. and Western Maryland Railroad’s Port
Covington Yard were established in the
1850s. Other development along the north
and northwest shores during the mid-19th
century included a few breweries, coal
yards, and a glass factory.

In 1916 the Hanover Street Bridge
opened and spurred residential and indus-
trial development of Brooklyn, Fairfield, and
Hawkins Point. Three years later these areas
were annexed to the City. In 1924, the
Western Maryland Railroad completed the

existing bridge across the Middle Branch.
Cherry Hill was developed by the City as a
residential community in the 1930s and 40s.

During the early 1970s three major
property owners along the shoreline
applied to the Corps of Engineers for per-
mits to expand their land area by filling
portions of the Middle Branch. BG&E at its
Spring Gardens Facility requested to fill
seven acres. Baltimore City requested to fill
10 acres with demolition material at the
Central Garage. Carr-Lowery on the west-
ern shoreline needed to fill and improve its
waterfront to improve plant operations.
During the federal review process the
Department of Interior requested a com-
prehensive look at the impacts of these
three permits on the long-range plans for
use of the waterfront and water quality.
Interior also expresseed concern over the
cumulative impacts of these projects com-
bined with the construction of the inter-
change of Interstate 95 and 395 directly
over the Middle Branch.

In response to these concerns the
City’s Department of Planning in 1977
issued the Middle Branch Park Plan, which
called for the creation of Baltimore’s largest
shoreline park along portions of the
perimeter of the Middle Branch and coor-
dination of activities around the waterfront.





62

The plan included proposals for the crea-
tion of boat launches, marinas, playfields,
fishing piers, open green spaces, picnic
areas, plus wetland-preservation-all linked
together by a pedestrian/bikeway trail. A
number of proposals have been carried
out, including the completion of Ferry Bar
Marine Park, Broening Park boat launch,
first phases of the 115-acre Reedbird Park,
removal of sunken boats and barges, and
improvements to the sewer system in areas
near the park.

1-95, 1-395 looking north to downtown

field_edited_text_processed:
Carr-Lowery glass container manufacture







xisting Conditions

The Middle Branch is surrounded by
a variety of industrial and commerical
activities, isolated residential communities,
and parkland. Although water-related
trade once played a role in the movement
of goods, today only one industry still uses
barges.

Industrial Activity: Several industries
dominate the Middle Branch. Moving
westward around the shoreline from the
north side of the Hanover Street Bridge,
the major industries include:

*City of Baltimore Central Garage -
Used for the repair and storage of City
vehicles, a portion of the property
once served as a landfill for demolition

debris.

*Baltimore Gas & Electric Company’s
Spring Garden Plant - B.G.&E. stores
gas at this location and manufactures
steam for use in downtown buildings.
This site was expanded in the late
1970s by filling.

*Carroll Industrial Park - This area con-
sists of parcels of vacant land and

many smaller industries. Using federal
funds and the City’s Industrial Loan
Program, improvements have been
made to streets, parking, and lighting
to attract industry in locating here.

*Northeast Municipal Waste Disposal
Authority - The authority constructed
an incinerator on the peninsula east of
Russell Street, near the mouth of the
Gwynns Falls. This facility is planned to
handle a major portion of the area’s
solid waste, while generating electricity
to be sold to BG&E.

*Baltimore Gas & Electric Westport
Generating Station - This plant gene-
rates electricity on an intermittent basis
for the downtown area.

*Carr-Lowery Glass Manufacturing
Company - The company employs
1,200 persons in the production of
glass bottles and jars.

Employment at Middle Branch indus-
tries has been stable in the past and is
expected to remain stable in the future.

Port Activity: Except for a few barges
to the Baltimore Gas and Electric Co.

Westport Station, waterborne commerce is

non-existent along the Middle Branch.
Although the Spring Garden Channel,
which extends from the Hanover Street
Bridge west and north to the Western
Maryland Railroad bridge, was last
dredged by the Corps of Engineers in

1960, it is still deep enough for the barges

and for pleasure boats. The responsibility
for maintaining the channel belongs to
the Corps of Engineers, which has no
plans to dredge it.

64

Residential Areas: Several residential
areas are near the Middle Branch: Cherry
Hill occupies a large tract of land to the
south, Westport is situated between Russell
Street and the industry on the western
shore; and the South Baltimore community
is clustered along Hanover Street and to
the east.



|

field_edited_text_processed:
R









Fishing at the Middle Branch Park





Planned DeveIOpmeht

The Middle Branch Park Plan has been
a great impetus to development in this
area. Besides spurring a wide range of
recreation-related improvements, it has
provided an incentive for local businesses
to upgrade the appearance of their proper-
ties. Listed below are a number of activities
which are either underway or expected to
be initiated within a few years.

Private/Public: Most of the planned
development on the Middle Branch will be
publicly sponsored. However, there are
also several joint public/private endeavors.

*Waterview Avenue Industrial Park -
The City has designated approximately
40 acres of land north of Cherry Hill
and south of Waterview Avenue as an
industrial urban renewal area. The area
includes 22 manufacturing, warehous-
ing, and retail firms employing over
400 persons. Under the existing
renewal plan businesses are expected
to improve their properties to meet
certain design standards. For its part
the City has reconstructed the portion
of Waterview Avenue north of the
industrial park, widening the median
and providing turn lanes into the busi-
nesses. The new boulevard-styled road-
way will be more in keeping with the
improved industrial area to the south
and the new park which will replace
the junkyards to the north. Sewer ser-
vice, several road construction and
rehabilitation projects, and a landscape
buffer along the south side of Water-
view Avenue have been completed.

An urban renewal plan for the area,
has been approved and recommends
rezoning several properties and sets
standards for new and existing devel-
opment to promote an attractive set-
ting compatible with the adjacent
recreation park.

Marina and the Hanover Street Bridge

65

*Baltimore Rowing Club - The City will
match private funds raised by the
Baltimore Rowing Club to build a stor-
age shed for its rowing shells meeting
space on the south shore of the
Middle Branch just west of the
Hanover Street Bridge.

*Locke Insulators - Locke Insulators has
received a permit to fill approximately
1.5 acres of water which will allow the
plant to expand operations and create

. approximately 100 new jobs. The per-
mit was issued after Locke agreed to
create a 1.5 acre wetland area at Reed-
bird Park to compensate for the water
habitat lost to the fill. Locke Insulator
will also make improvements to the
shoreline and the waterside of its
buildipg.

Public: Much of the public effort cen-
ters on continuing to implement the
Middle Branch Park Plan. Projects that have
been programmed include:

*Reedbird Park - The first phase of con-
struction of this park has been com-
pleted. The park now offers picnic
areas, a shoreline trail, five fishing
piers, athletic fields, a tot lot, tennis
courts and a small stage and multi-use
shelter. The second phase of the park,
completed in 1982-3 includes addi-
tional play equipment for small chil-
dren, additional bike trails and side-
walks for improved community access,
multi-purpose fields, as well as land-
scaping throughout the park. Com-
posited sludge from the Back River
Waste Water Treatment Plan has been
used ‘at Reedbird Park as a soil condi-
tioner to prepare the reclaimed landfill
for planting grass and trees.

*New Waterview Avenue Interchange -
By eliminating the section of Water-
view Avenue that forks off from Potee
Street and constructing a northbound
connection onto Hanover Street, traffic
safety has been improved and park-
land, formerly cut off from the shore-
line, has been tied directly to the
waterfront. This project was completed
in the summer of 1983.

*Southshore Open Space - Land for-
merly occupied by several junkyards
has been acquired by the City and will
be converted to public open space.
Relocation of the junkyards and clean-
up began in 1983. An improved shore-
line and landscaping should be com-
pleted in 1985.

*Relocation Animal Shelter - The City’s
old animal shelter, which was taken for
the construction of the expressway,
will be rebuilt on the northernmost
shoreline of the Middle Branch.

field_edited_text_processed:
Issues and Problems

The problems of the Middle Branch
area fall into three major categories:

onflicting Land Use: First, there is a
conflict between adjacent neighborhoods
and the various junk yards, scrap metal
operations, storage yards, and firms which
often do not maintain a high standard of
operation. Some of these problems have
been addressed in the improvement pro-
gram for Carroll Industrial Park in the
northern portion of the Middle Branch.
Also underway is the purchasg.of several
auto scrapyards along Waterview Avenue
which will greatly improve the area. The
City also plans to work with a number of
the firms in the Waterview Avenue indus-
trial area to improve their level of opera-
tion and appearance.

Another problem is the isolation of
much of the recreational space from adja-
cent communities and other recreational
facilities. Industries often separate open
space from neighborhoods, recreational
facilities are fragmented and generally the
parkland along the Middle Branch is under
used. An example is the 15 acres of open
space south of Waterview Avenue. This
area is cut off from the Cherry Hill com-
munity by a steep hill and roadway and
from the rest of the park by Hanover
Street. Plans call for tying this area together
with the park by paths and bikeways.

Access: Traffic to most Middle Branch
industries uses neighborhood streets in the
Westport, Cherry Hill, and South Baltimore
communities. The heavy truck traffic in
these areas has created safety problems,
divided parts of neighborhoods from one
another, and generally lowered the live-
ability of these areas through noise and
exhaust pollution. The completion of 1-95
and 1-395 is expected to relieve these prob-
lems somewhat. However, many areas will
still be burdened with undesirable levels of
truck traffic. ’

Another access problem is the diffi-
culty of reaching the open space along the
shoreline, particularly the south shoreline
in the vicinity of South Baltimore General
Hospital. Heavily-travelled Hanover Street,
Potee Street, and Waterview Avenue set up
barriers between the Cherry Hill commun-
ity and the waterfront. Even motorists find
it difficult to reach the shoreline under the
present street configuration. Better coordi-
nation of traffic signals for pedestrians, the
pathway under Hanover and Potee Streets,
new sidewalks leading to the park, and a
continuous bikeway should help reduce
this problem.

Water Quality: For many years over-
flow from inadequate sanitary sewers, dis-
charges from industrial concerns; debris;
and storm runoff carrying dirt, oil, and
asphalt from city streets, turned the Middle
Branch into an unpleasant, polluted water
body which supports only the most min-
imal forms of aquatic life. Deposits of silt,
in several areas reaching a depth of 30 feet,
is fused with heavy metals and other toxic
substances, present limitations to develop-
ment in certain areas. Activity in the water,
poses the danger of stirring up these
sediments.

Recently, steps have been taken to
remedy the most severe aspects of the pol-
lution problems. Completion of the South-
west Diversion Main helped to curtail
major sewage overflows and enabled many
faulty septic tanks to be eliminated. Pro-
posals to clean up the shoreline were
included in the Carroll Industrial Park plan.
The fill permits issued to the Baltimore Gas
and Electric Co., Carr-Lowery, and the
City’s Central Garage promote a cleaner
and more stable shoreline by insuring that
the type and amount of fill were
monitored.

The combination of improved water
quality, a stablilized shoreline free from
debris, and adequate sanitary facilities pro-
vides the basis for future water-oriented
recreational activities on the Middle
Branch.

Debris washed-up on the shoreline









T e e e

uture Opportunities ‘

The Middle Branch Park Plan and the
Waterview Avenue Industrial Park Plan
have laid the basis for a number of signifi-
cant future public and private development
opportunities. Many of these are part of a
long-range improvement plan and include:

*Reedbird Park Improvements - As
funds become available, ballfields,
landscaping, bikeways and pedestrian
paths, boating facilities, and other
recreational uses will be added to the
park. Plans call for completion of the
pathway from the play area at Hanover
Street to run along the shoreline and
connect into Baltimore County’s park
and the Patapsco Valley State Park.
There is also the possibility of operat-

ing a boat-rental facility in the
enclosed portion of the river between
Hanover Street Bridge and the B& O
Railroad bridge. Extensive landscaping
for both the east and west portions of
the park is planned. Proposals will also
be developed for using the large hill in
the park for a variety of active recrea-
tional uses.

69

*Waterview Park - A master plan has

been prepared and accepted by the
City for the shoreline area north of
Waterview Avenue. The first phase of
the plan is now underway. The City
has acquired approximately 8.7 acres
adjacent to a City-owned parcel of
about 1.7 acres, totalling 10.4 acres for
park development. The acquisition and
relocation of several junkyards in the
area was-completed by the summer of

11983. All acquired properties will be

graded, seeded and landscaped in
preparation for the second phase of
development. Phase two will include
shoreline stablilization, a multi-purpose
field, wetlands, and public shoreline
access piers at the west end of the
park. The master plan calls for boating
and fishing piers, picnicking and park-
ing facilities, expansion of the existing
boat launching ramp, a shoreline walk
and extesive landscaping to be devel-
oped at the east end of the park (near
the Hanover Street Bridge).

*Pier and Scenic Overlook - With the

new Waterview Avenue interchange at
Hanover and Potee Streets completed,
the old shoreline segment of Water-
view Avenue could be partially
removed and used for parking for a
scenic overlook as well as for a pier
that could be developed at the site.
This area could also be connected to
other sections of the park by a
pathway.

field_edited_text_processed:
vl <~y v STapray s WS W T~y T W - .

~ - »

*Southshore Marinas - It has been esti-

mated that the Middle Branch could
support over 1,200 boat slips by the
1990s. This will be a dramatic increase
from the approximately 350 slips now
available. As the demand for boat
docking space in the harbor grows
beyond the capacity of existing mari-
nas, a portion of the open space along
the Waterview Avenue shoreline will
become a prime location for marinas,

related commercial development, park-

ing and other water-oriented facilities.
It is also expected that existing private
marinas will expand their service and
number of slips as the future demand
grows.

*Waterview Industrial Center - As indi-

cated above, the Waterview Industrial
Center is a major industrial develop-
ment and redevelopment project
which encompasses 22 existing busi-
nesses and 40 acres of vacant land. The
long-range development plan includes
several public improvements and an
expanded urban renewal ordinance to
promote business expansiors and new
industrial development on the area’s
vacant land. It is expected that over $8
million of private investment and 600
new jobs will be generated by develop-
ment activity in the center at the com-
pletion of the project.

*Carr Lowery - There will be an oppor-

tunity for the Carr Lowery glass manu-
facturing plant to build an additional
furnance adjacent to its current site.

*Water Resources Environmental Center

- As part of the Chesapeake Bay Initia-
tives the State’s Department of Natural
Resources has agreed to fund an
environmental center. The center will
be built on the second level of the
new Baltimore Rowing Club facility
and share meeting space. The center
will provide labs and meeting rooms
for area conservation groups;and spe-
cial educational programs.

*Baltimore Rowing Club - The Balti-

more Rowing Club, with support of
the City will develop a club house and
storage facility. With this quality facility
available the rowing club expects to
generate interest in rowing with
colleges, city schools and expand its
membership.

*Trail System - The Middle Branch Park

Plan called for the creation of a con-

tinuous pedestrian/bike trail that
would link the various segments of the

park together and connect the park
itself to the Inner Harbor, Gwynn Falls
Park, and the 9,000-acre Patapsco State
Park.

Rowing returns to the Middle Branch

*Wetland and Wildlife Habitat Devel-

opment and Interpretation - To com-
pensate for the 136 acres of water
habitat taken by the Canton/Seagirt
dredge spoil disposal site for the 1-95
Fort McHenry Tunnel, the Interstate
Division of Baltimore City is exploring
the feasibility of developing wetlands
in the northern Middle Branch. There
are already signs that this area of
degraded water quality is improving.
Wetland vegetation has reestablished
on several small islands and waterfowl
use the areas. If feasible, an expanded
wetland area could itself help improve
water quality by filtering out some pol-
lutants and providing additional wild-
life habitat.

On the east side of the Reedbird Park,
north and south of the Hanover/Potee
Street bridges, existing wetlands will be
improved and expanded. A program of
wetland and water-life interpretation is
envisioned for the area to instruct park
visitors of the importance of a healthly
environment and improving the har-
bor’s water quality. With the improved
habitat and the connections into the
state park system the Middle Branch
Park will offer a unique opportunity
for environmental groups and the
general public to witness the functions
of the complex ecology of this area.



The Department of Planning is explor-
ing additional wildlife related uses for the
park including fish and wild fowl hatcher-
ies. These would provide a much needed
natural resource and a unique educational
opportunity for City residents.

When completed the Middle Branch
Park will be the largest shorefront park in
the entire harbor. The completed park
system, consisting of the Gwynns Falls,
Middle Branch, Southwest and Patapsco
Valley Parks, will offer over 10,000 acres of
recreational facilities, in one of the most
extensive and varied parks in the country,
to this region’s residents.

field_edited_text_processed:
Surrounded on three sides by water
and less than one quarter mile from down-
own, South Baltimore is well located for
industrial and port activity. A number of
industrial firms, including three of the
City’s major industries — Procter and
Gamble, Amstar, and Locke Insulator. Serv-
ing these and,other economic activities are

over 40 miles of railroad track and the soon-
to-be-completed Interstate 95 expressway.

The peninsula also includes three resi-
ential communities: Locust Point, South
Baltimore and Federal Hill. These rowhouse

communities have traditionally been a
ready source of labor for the area’s indus-
tries. Federal Hill now also provides a
strong base for residents who desire to live

within walking distance to downtown and
the Inner Harbor.
