field_edited_text_processed:
xisting Conditions



Industrial Activity: South Baltimore’s
industries are very diverse. Businesses on
the peninsula include a sugar refinery, oil
reprocessing plant, an electric power gen-
erating plant, trucking firms, a pipe and
valve fitting distributor, moving and storage
companies, warehouses, ship repair yards,
as well as manufacturers of soaps and
detergents, electrical insulators and enclo-
sures, paper, paint, industrial fasteners,
cardboard boxes, molasses, syrup, and
animal feed. The industries are located in
three main areas; along Key Highway, in
Locust Point on the peninsula, and in the
southwest section of the peninsula near
Wells Street.

South Baltimore’s four largest indus-
tries are:

*Bethlehem Steel Company’s Key
Highway Shipyard - This major ship
repair yard, which at one time
employed almost 2,000 persons, was
sold in 1984 to private developers. The
City, community and developer have
started a planning process for the
redevelopment of the yard.

*Amstar - This sugar refinery on Key
Highway employs 700 persons. Raw
sugar is brought in by ship, processed
to remove color and impurities, and
then distributed both by truck and
ship. The plant refines approximately
1.2 billion pounds of raw sugar a year
and produces packaged sugar,
molasses for use in animal feed, and
bulk sugar for use in the production of
other food products. Amstar receives
the majority of its raw sugar and fuel
oil by water with over 130 ships
unloading at their docks each year.

*Procter and Gamble - The Baltimore
plant employs 500 people in the manu-
facture of soaps, detergents, and fabric
softeners under such brand names as
lvory, Tide, and Downey. Except for
specialty items like coconut oil which
are delivered by ship, the plant
receives most of its raw materials by
truck and rail and distributes its fin-
ished products by truck.

*Locke Insulator - One of the few
manufacturers of electrical insulators in
the country, this company employs
approximately 500 persons at its plant
off Hanover Street. Its products include
insulators for telephone poles and high
tension transmission lines.

Port Activity: There are three marine
terminals in South Baltimore:

*Locust Point Terminal North - This
terminal, owned by the Maryland Port
Administration and operated by var-
lous companies, contains seven finger
piers which extend out into the water
perpendicular to the mainland. The
piers include seven berths designed for
general cargo and four for bulk cargo.
There are 400,000 square feet of
covered storage, 30 acres of open stor-
age, and rail holding yards for 2,700
cars. Two 75-ton, electric gantry cranes
are located on Pier 4. The channel
serving the terminal ranges in depth
from 30 to 34 feet. Among the com-
panies which utilize the piers of the
north terminal is the Indiana Grain
Cooperative, a grain export company
that recently modernized its entire
handling system to increase its storage
capacity to 13-million bushels with a
loading capability of 125,000 bushels
per hour. Three latex import opera-
tions are also located at the north ter-
minal: Uniroyal, Firestone, and Good-
year. The three facilities make the Port
of Baltimore the largest latex import
center in the United States. Latex is
used to manufacture a variety of pro-
ducts including tubing, glues, carpet
backing and medical equipment.

*Locust Point Terminal South - At this
terminal ships berth parallel to the
mainland and are loaded or unloaded
by one of four cranes, including the
port’s only heavy-lift, 350-ton crane,
known as the “Baltimore 350.” The
marginal pier configuration where
ships dock right along side the main-
land is particularly efficient for
handling containers which are this
terminal’s major cargo. Owned by the
Maryland Port Administration and
operated by Atlantic and Gulf Steve-
dores, Inc., the southside terminal
includes 120,000 square feet of covered
storage and 23 acres of open storage.
The channel serving this terminal is 36
feet deep.

*Port Covington Terminal - Located in
the southwestern section of South
Baltimore east of Hanover Street and
owned by the CSX Railroad, the Port
Covington marine terminal contains
190 acres separated into two sections
by the Baltimore Gas and Electric Co.’s
Gould Street Station. The 130-acre
western section of the facility includes
an ore pier, a vacant covered pier, and
a nonfunctioning coal pier. South of
the three piers the Louis Dreyfus Co.

operates a 23-acre grain export termi-
nal. Between the Dreyfus facility and
Locke Insulator Company is a 50 acre
parcel which contains the vacant
Lehigh Cement Company building, an
abandoned repair shed, and underutil-
ized railroad tracks.

Transportation: The CSX Railroad
through its Baltimore and Ohio Railroad
and Western Maryland Railway division
serves South Baltimore industries. Its exten-
sive system of tracks date back over 100
years when the railroads first established
major port facilities in Locust Point.

Highway access to South Baltimore is
provided by an interchange with south-
bound Interstate 95 and via Route 2,
Hanover Street and a full interchange at
McComas Street and Key Highway. Three
local streets serve as major arteries: Key
Highway, Fort Avenue, and McComas
Street. '

Residential Areas: The Locust Point
peninsula supports three communities,
South Baltimore and Federal Hill which
extend from the Inner Harbor south to
Interstate-95 , and the Locust Point neigh-
borhood which is clustered on both sides
of Fort Avenue east of Key Highway. South
Baltimore and Locust Point are primarily
working class communities with many of
the residents owning their homes especially
in the Locust Point neighborhood. While
the industries of the area have provided
stable employment for many of the resi-
dents the communities are also directly
impacted by the operations of the termi-
nals, railyards and manufacturing plants.
Heavy truck traffic, noise, vibrations and air
pollution are all concerns which have been
expressed by members of the communities.

Recreation Areas: The South Baltimore
peninsula contains five parks. Fort
McHenry, a national historic park on the
eastern tip of the peninsula, attracts over
700,000 visitors a year, most arriving by car.
Federal Hill Park affords a dramatic vantage
of both the Inner Harbor and the Key
Highway Shipyard. Latrobe Park in Locust
Point and Riverside Park and Swann Park in
South Baltimore offer recreation facilities
for neighborhood residents.



74

Planned Development

Private: The Locke Insulator Co. gained
approval in 1982 to fill 1.5 acres of shore-
line to expand its plant. The added land
will allow the company to remain at its cur-
rent site and add approximately 100 new
jobs. To compensate for its expansion into
existing water area, the company has
created a new wetland of comparable size
at Reedbird Park further south on the
Middle Branch.

Public: A great many public improve-
ments are programmed for the South
Baltimore peninsula, most of them in con-
junction with the construction of the Inter-
state 95 expressway.



*Interstate 95 - The completion of this
1-1/2-mile segment of roadway, which
will connect the existing Hanover
Street interchange to the roadway in
Canton and will include the eight-lane,
Fort McHenry Tunnel, represents the
final link in an expressway connecting
Baltimore’s harbor to the entire east
coast. This final segment costing over
$800 million will be completed in two
phases. In December 1982 the roadway
was opened from Hanover Street to
Key Highway, and by 1985 from Key
Highway across the harbor to Canton.
Coupled with the highway construc-
tion there have been improvements to
McComas Street and the installation of
noise barriers and earth mounds to
shield the Francis Scott Key Public
School and Latrobe Park from highway
noise.

*B & O Riverside Yard - The locomotive
service and maintenance center for all
B & O operations in Baltimore has been
relocated for the construction of Inter-
state 95. As a result the B& O has built
a new maintenance shop, oil storage
tank, and internal service road.

*Locust Point North Marine Terminal -
The Maryland Port Administration has
scheduled improvements to several
piers at its north terminal. In the next
few years, a wooden pier will be
replaced with a steel and concrete
structure, an old shed will be demo-
lished, and existing piers will be paved
and lighting installed.

*Hull Street Park - Though close to the
water, the Locust Point community has
no direct public access to the harbor.
Most of the shoreline is devoted to

“industrial, port, and rail activities. To
give the community an opportunity to

enjoy the shoreline, the City converted

the northern end of Hull Street into a
small park with a pier for docking
boats and for fishing. The project was
completed in 1984.

Construction of the Fort McHenry Tunnel



*Southern High School Playfield - Con-
structed in mid-1983 on land just to
the east of the school the playfield will
provide a football practice field and a
track and field area.

*Wetlands - In return for decreasing the
water area of the harbor by filling in
the shoreline at the Canton-Seagirt site
with spoil from the Fort McHenry
Tunnel dredging, a 5.3-acre, land-
scaped wetland area will be created in
a cove adjacent to Fort McHenry. The
marsh, which will provide a habitat for
wetland plants and animals, will be
enclosed by a submerged stone dike.



|ssues and Problems

Port-Related Issues: Two concerns face
the Maryland Port Administration’s cargo
handling operations at the North and South
Locust Point Terminals. First, there is
insufficient storage space for incoming and
outgoing cargo. As a consequence, export
cargo must be held in other parts of the
City and then hauled to the terminal when
the appropriate ship arrives. This is both
costly and inefficient. Import cargo must be
immediately loaded onto trucks and rail
cars, creating scheduling difficulties. The
scarcity of available storage space limits the
number of ships the Locust Point terminals
are able to handle.

A second concern which faces the
South Locust Point Terminal and adjoining
industries is the possible adverse effect of
the new expressway on the available “stack-
ing”’ and manuevering space for trucks. A
busy marine terminal requires considerable
space where trucks waiting to load or
unload cargo can line up. The Interstate
Division of Baltimore City, the Port Admin-
istration, and local industries have worked
to accommodate these concerns and allow
for the construction of Interstate-95 and

the Fort McHenry Tunnel. Actual operation
of the terminal with the completed high-
way will test these solutions.

While not as critical to South Balti-
more’s port activities as to port activities
elsewhere on the harbor, dredging the
harbor’s main channel from its current
depth of 42 feet to a new depth of 50 feet
might benefit the grain operation on Pier 7
at the Locust Point North Terminal.

Traffic and Parking Problems: The resi-
dential communities of South Baltimore
and Locust Point have long faced the
annoying problem of truck traffic on local
residential streets. This problem should be
somewhat reduced by the new internal
road linking North and South Locust Point
Marine Terminals constructed by the Port
Administration.

Environmental Issues: The most signifi-
cant environmental issue in the South
Baltimore area is air pollution. Like all the
heavily industrialized areas around the
port, South Baltimore has been classified by
the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
as a “‘non-attainment area” for airborne
particles. These particles, or suspended par-

ticulates, are very fine and are released into

the air by industrial processes, vehicle
exhausts, construction and demolition activ-
ities, vacant, unkept land, loading, unload-
ing, and storage of dry bulk goods. Inhal-
ing these particles, especially over a long
period of time, can lead to severe respira-
tory problems and damage to the lungs.
The problem should be significantly
reduced once,the extensive construction
work is completed on Interstate 95 in 1985.
However, full and effective control of the
problem will also require technological
innovations making it economically practi-
cal to control the particulate pollution pro-
duced by grain and other bulk material
transfer operations and the many acres of
railyards in Locust Point.



/5

Maryland Port Administration

uture Opportunities



There are several significant develop-
ment opportunities in South Baltimore.

Port Covington: With the exception of
the Dreyfus Grain operation and the Balti-
more Gas and Electric Co.’s Gould Station,
much of the 190-acre Port Covington com-
plex is either vacant or underutilized. Its

~owner, the CSX Railroad, has expressed

interest in the long-term redevelopment
potential of this major waterfront parcel.
Four alternatives have been developed for
discussion purposes. All proposals assume
that the eastern portion of the site, approx-
imately 60 acres, would remain as a site for
expansion of the harbor-related activities.

1) Industrial Park - Dreyfus Grain Termi-
nal would remain. The area would be
developed for industrial sites.









Foreign Trade Zone, Industrial Park 3)
and Regional Shopping Center - Drey-

fus Grain is relocated. The waterfront is
developed as a specialized Foreign

Trade Zone using existing ship chan-

nels and piers. Inland area is devel-

oped as an industrial park. The western

-portion of the property is used for a

regional mall geared to capture the

south and southwest Baltimore City,
Baltimore and Anne Arundel County 4)
markets. Mall is oriented to the water-

front with a large marina, nautical

shopping complex, and public shore-

line promenade.

Stadium/Hotel/Marina and Sports
Complex - The majority of the site is
developed for a new regional stadium.
Parking is entirely on grade with direct
access to and from Interstate-95 and
Hanover Street. The waterfront would
be developed with a hotel and sports
complex, a major marina, nautical
shoppiftg center, and public shoreline
promenade.

entire site becomes the location of a
major water and rail oriented manufac-
turer. This could include plants for
auto assembly, steel fabrication, etc.
This could provide employment for
over 1,700 people if developed at 12

uture Opportunities



There are several significant develop-
ment opportunities in South Baltimore.

Port Covington: With the exception of
the Dreyfus Grain operation and the Balti-
more Gas and Electric Co.’s Gould Station,
much of the 190-acre Port Covington com-
plex is either vacant or underutilized. Its

~owner, the CSX Railroad, has expressed

interest in the long-term redevelopment
potential of this major waterfront parcel.
Four alternatives have been developed for
discussion purposes. All proposals assume
that the eastern portion of the site, approx-
imately 60 acres, would remain as a site for
expansion of the harbor-related activities.

1) Industrial Park - Dreyfus Grain Termi-
nal would remain. The area would be
developed for industrial sites.









Foreign Trade Zone, Industrial Park 3)
and Regional Shopping Center - Drey-

fus Grain is relocated. The waterfront is
developed as a specialized Foreign

Trade Zone using existing ship chan-

nels and piers. Inland area is devel-

oped as an industrial park. The western

-portion of the property is used for a

regional mall geared to capture the

south and southwest Baltimore City,
Baltimore and Anne Arundel County 4)
markets. Mall is oriented to the water-

front with a large marina, nautical

shopping complex, and public shore-

line promenade.

Stadium/Hotel/Marina and Sports
Complex - The majority of the site is
developed for a new regional stadium.
Parking is entirely on grade with direct
access to and from Interstate-95 and
Hanover Street. The waterfront would
be developed with a hotel and sports
complex, a major marina, nautical
shoppiftg center, and public shoreline
promenade.

Major Manufacturing Facility - The
entire site becomes the location of a
major water and rail oriented manufac-
turer. This could include plants for
auto assembly, steel fabrication, etc.
This could provide employment for
over 1,700 people if developed at 12
people per acre.

field_edited_text_processed:
Recent photograph of Locust Point, Key Highway; Inner Harbor, upper right

Key Highway: The waterfront land
along Key Highway stretching from the
Inner Harbor, south and then east to
Amstar Sugar holds unique potential for
redevelopment.

The former Bethlehem Steel Key
Highway Ship Repair Yard was purchased in
1984 by a developer. The City, community
and the developer have initiated a plannin
process to formulate plans for the site. All
participants in this effort are concerned
that consensus is reached as to the mix of
land uses, number of residential units,
public access to the shoreline, water uses
and impacts on the South Baltimore
community.

East of the former ship repair yard are
a number of smaller parcels. Although
several are vacant or underutilized, the Cit
views this area as a resource for future
employment. Also located along this
shoreline are a City-owned facility for
repair of fire equipment and the Baltimore
Museum of Industry. Any redevelopment
of this area will include the proposed
expansion of the Baltimore Museum of
Industry and provision of public shoreline
access, when reasonable.

Land Under Interstate-95 - Six oblong
sites ranging in size from .5 to 1.8 acres
located under the elevated portion of the
expressway between Hanover Street and
Key Highway might be suitably developed
as parking or open storage yards for nearb
industries.

Port Covington East - Approximately

60 acres of land lies east of B.G.&E.’s Gould

treet Station. This property, which is City-
owned and leased to the Western Mary-
land Railway until the early 21st century,
offers potential for expanded port opera-
tions. Current plans are to turn over the
property to the Port Administration for
expansion of the South Locust Point
Marine Terminal.

Wells Street Area - Older industrial
areas in Baltimore like Carroll Industrial
Park have benefited from public improve-
ments and public administrative assistance
in marketing vacant properties. Businesses
in the vicinity of Wells Street might also
benefit from such an approach. Funds from
the federal Economic Development Admin-
istration were used to reconstruct Wells
Street. Two development opportunities
present themselves immediately. The first is
a vacant, dilapidated building on a 2.6-acre
site at the southeast corner of Wells and
Charles Street. The building could be razed
and the site offered for redevelopment.
There are also opportunities for marketing
buildings to maritime users.

Bethlehem Steel Fort McHenry Yard -
With the construction work on Interstate-95
completed, a 16-acre parcel may become
available for redevelopment in a water-
related or water-dependent use.

The story of Baltimore’s Inner Harbor
redevelopment is one of the most dramatic
urban successes in recent times.

Today’s harbor promenade, museums,
entertainment attractions, shops, offices,
apartments, townhouses, hotels and open
spdce are the fulfillment of a concentrated
program effort, now 20 years old, to turn
rotting piers, ramshackled buildings and
dirty waters into an urban showplace.

The Inner Harbor is Baltimore’s
magnet, the focus of interest for delega-
tions from this country and abroad who
come to learn the lessons of Baltimore’s
comeback. It is the place Baltimoreans take
visitors to show off their city.

Tk

11

odpcenimanareonyseo oL
¥ %
P ’%‘

AL AL

e Foda
kR
R
K

Pk
PR R



What visitors and natives see today
represents a concerted effort that dates
back to the mid-1950’s, including a fortu-
nate combination of people and circum-
stances and solid planning.

And while this chapter focuses on the
events directly related to the revival of the
Inner Harbor*and its future direction, it is
important to keep in mind its context as
part of a citywide revival effort. The overall
job development, neighborhood renewal,
transportation projects and other revival
strategies of the city from the 1950s forward
play an important background role in the
Inner Harbor’s success story.



79

field_edited_text_processed:
Baltimore’s Inner Basin, late 19th century



velopment History



The Beginning

Baltimoreans picked up the July 16,
1956 edition of The Evening Sun to find
bannered across the front page Planning
Director Arthur McVoy’s Prospectus for
Downtown Baltimore which promised to
make it “one of the most exciting cities in
the world.” The newspaper story like the
document itself was deliberately vague,
futuristic—and visionary.

To a city such as Baltimore, talk like
McVoy’s was at variance with the reality of
the day. Baltimore had developed, as one
article put it, a sizable inferiority complex.
There were overcrowded and deteriorated
neighborhoods; the downtown was losing
its focus as the retail center; and many city
blocks around the harbor were occupied
with vacant warehouses.

“It was perceived as a city with a great
past and no future, and if you made it you
were moving to New York or Philadelphia
or Chicago,” an American Institute of
Architects account recalled. There was a
thin middle class, little support for cultural
activity, few good restaurants.

Baltimore in the 1950s, in short, was on
a downward spiral, like many older cities in
the Northwest. And if an outward, visible
sign of the city’s poor condition was

needed, the Inner Harbor waterfront pro-
vided it. “

By the 1950’s, most commercial ships
had moved elsewhere and the Bay steamers
had disappeared altogether from their Light
Street docks. In the description of one
observer, much of the Inner Harbor had
the look of Dresden after the war. Much of
the area held only derelict warehouses.
Abandoned cars were found along deserted
streets which during the evening were
populated by toothless winos and rats.

So, the new vision for downtown Balti-
more naturally met with skepticism. How-
ever, the suggestions were not ignored by
all. When Planning Director McVoy wrote
of “water oriented cities such as Stock-
holm, Rio de Janeiro, Venice and Copen-
hagen,” there were some in Baltimore who
shared his aspirations, first in the down-
town business community, later in the city
government.

Catalyst for Action

The triggering event by most accounts
for what has followed took place in late
1954, when O’Neill’s Department store, one
of the city’s biggest, closed. This jolt came
on the heels of years of declining retail
sales downtown. At the time, only one
major new office building had been con-
structed in mid-Baltimore in 25 years; six
major employers had moved out of down-
town; property assessments were falling in
the area; and the vacancy rates were as

high as 25 percent in some downtown
blocks.

With the O’Neill’s closing, J. Jefferson
Miller, executive vice president of The

80

Hecht Co., took action. Miller is credited
with persuading the Retail Merchants Asso-
ciation, of which he was a director, to look
into what other cities were doing to cope
with similar problems. The quick conclu-
sion was that the merchants by themselves
could not bring about a turnaround. In
1954 they formed a Committee for Down-
town and recruited members from utilities,
banks and other property owners.

A

At about the same time another new
business/civic group, the Greater Baltimore
Committee, composed of 100 top execu-
tives of the metropolitan area was formed.
Both the Committee for Downtown and
the Greater Baltimore Committee agreed
that downtown renewal had to be a top
priority. In 1956, the Greater Baltimore
Committee created a wholly owned subsi-
diary, the Planning Council, to address
redevelopment issues. The Planning Coun-
cil was funded in April, 1957, through
efforts of the Committee for Downtown
and the Greater Baltimore Committee,
each contributing $150,000 and $75,000,
respectively, to prepare a comprehensive
study and plan for action for downtown.
The Planning Council’s team was headed
by David Wallace, a nationally known
planner and architect.

The team’s first effort was an overall
look at about 220 acres at the center of Bal-
timore’s downtown. “We soon realized that
unless something drastic was done in the
form of an immediate project, we would
lose our investors. Charles Center was a
response to the need for some action,”
Wallace has recalled. '

80

diary, the Planning Council, to address

and the Greater Baltimore Committee,
each contributing $150,000 and $75,000,
respectively, to prepare a comprehensive
study and plan for action for downtown.

by David Wallace, a nationally known
planner and architect.

look at about 220 acres at the center of Bal-

response to the need for some action,”
Wallace has recalled. '

field_edited_text_processed:
The Peale Museum, Baltimore





e

......

The Charles Center Project

The Wallace team proposed a single,
dramatic project that would reverse the
downslide. The proposal for the 33 acre
Charles Center project, located north and
west of the Inner Harbor, between the
retail and financial districts, was completed
in 1958 and presented to Mayor Thomas J.
D’Alesandro, Jr. The plan was received with
enthusiasm and turned over to the Balti-
more Urban Renewal and Housing agency
for detailed review and a feasibility study.
In March, 1959, the City Council adopted
Charles Center as an official urban renewal
plan.

The Charles Center plan’s adoption in
1959 effectively made the city government
and the downtown business community
partners, with a shared objective. This part-
nership was formalized in 1959 with the
establishment of the Charles Center Man-
agement Office, led by ). Jefferson Miller,
to implement the project under a personal
contract with the city. The creation of this
office was a major factor in the speed with
which private developers were persuaded
to invest in the project. Through this man-
agement office the City could combine the
flexibility of a private corporation with the
city’s powers to raise working capital and
assemble land through emminent domain.

e

Inner Harbor Initiative

Construction was well underway at
Charles Center when Mayor Theodore R.
McKeldin, Jr., sounded the charge for Balti-
more to take its next big step forward: re-
claiming the Inner Harbor. In his inaugural
address on May 21, 1963, McKeldin talked
of an “enthralling panorama of office build-
ings, parks, high-rise apartments, and mari-
nas’’ around the old harbor. He urged that
a plan be developed for the area, consist-
ing of 240 acres including the financial and
municipal districts, adjacent to the still-
developing Charles Center Project.

At the time of Mayor McKeldin’s call,
the Inner Harbor had already been partially
cleaned up. Beginning in 1950 under
Mayor D’Alesandro, Jr., the piers and
decayed structures at the west end of the
Inner Harbor along Light Street had been

‘removed.

The Planning Council was again com-
missioned to prepare a proposal and David
Wallace’s firm, Wallace-McHarg of Phila-
delphia, was hired. Funding for this step
was an arrangement involving three
groups, with $35,000 provided by the city
and $25,000 each from the Greater Balti-
more Committee and Committee for
Downtown. This three member partnership
was an important step in Baltimore’s move
toward increased government initiative in
the redevelopment process.

The conceptual plan that was pro-
duced a year later, while it has been

Harbor skyline, view north from Key Highway



altered in particulars, has provided the
basic guidance for the redevelopment that
constitutes today’s Inner Harbor area. The
spirit of the 1964 plan was described this
way:

“This historic spot, its basin and its
shorelines, can become the stage for a
dramatic exercise in urban renewal.
Now the scene of run-down docks,
wharves, and with few exceptions,
economically unsound enterprises, the
.Inner Harbor emerges as a candidate
for the best use of water and open
land in post-war U.S. urban renewal.
Instead of cutting the water off from
the city as almost all our cities do, Bal-
timore will thrust the living, 24-hour-a-
day city into intimate, vivacious contact
with the harbor whence it sprang.

In the place of the old piers, multi-lane
expansions of Calvert and Light Streets had
been built in the early 1950’s with parking
lots directly on the water and a small patch
of green space at the intersection of Light
and Pratt Streets, known as Sam Smith Park.
The widened roadway had been built on
fill at the western edge of the harbor
where the steamships had once docked.
The transformation had begun. However,
the western edge of the water was given
over entirely to vehicles, and the obsolete
structures which remained at the north and
south sides of the harbor, many in poor
condition, still constituted a barrier to pub-
lic use of the area. There were no provi-
sions for access to the shoreline and no
attractions to draw people to the still pol-
luted water’s edge.

The 1964 plan called for a 30-year, $260-
million effort along the harbor’s edge and
in the adjacent financial and municipal dis-
tricts. Over 700 pieces of property were
involved. The city was fortunate to already
own the key, 18-acre waterfront along Pratt
and Light Streets which was purchased after
the 1904 fire and expanded by fill in the
early 1950’s.

In 1964 the voters authorized $2 mil-
lion in bonds to finance the first steps in
redevelopment of the Inner Harbor, less
than 10 years after the first concerted action
had been taken in Charles Center to re-
verse downtown Baltimore’s decline.

Another aspect of the 1964 plan is
worth noting. It called for opening the
harbor’s edge to the public. And while it
seems a natural recommendation to us
today, it should be remembered that in
1964 waterfronts were usually ignored and
were often proposed for highways. As late
as 1968, there were still plans for a super-
highway along Montgomery Street and the
base of Federal Hill with a bridge over the
Harbor which would have cut off the Har-
bor basin from the rest of the City.



81

day city into intimate, vivacious contact
with the harbor whence it sprang.

In the place of the old piers, multi-lane
expansions of Calvert and Light Streets had
been built in the early 1950’s with parking
lots directly on the water and a small patch
of green space at the intersection of Light
and Pratt Streets, known as Sam Smith Park.
The widened roadway had been built on
fill at the western edge of the harbor
where the steamships had once docked.
The transformation had begun. However,
the western edge of the water was given
over entirely to vehicles, and the obsolete
structures which remained at the north and
south sides of the harbor, many in poor
condition, still constituted a barrier to pub-
lic use of the area. There were no provi-
sions for access to the shoreline and no
attractions to draw people to the still pol-
luted water’s edge.

The 1964 plan called for a 30-year, $260-
million effort along the harbor’s edge and
in the adjacent financial and municipal dis-
tricts. Over 700 pieces of property were
involved. The city was fortunate to already
own the key, 18-acre waterfront along Pratt
and Light Streets which was purchased after
the 1904 fire and expanded by fill in the
early 1950’s.

In 1964 the voters authorized $2 mil-
lion in bonds to finance the first steps in
redevelopment of the Inner Harbor, less
than 10 years after the first concerted action
had been taken in Charles Center to re-
verse downtown Baltimore’s decline.

Another aspect of the 1964 plan is
worth noting. It called for opening the
harbor’s edge to the public. And while it
seems a natural recommendation to us
today, it should be remembered that in
1964 waterfronts were usually ignored and
were often proposed for highways. As late
as 1968, there were still plans for a super-
highway along Montgomery Street and the
base of Federal Hill with a bridge over the
Harbor which would have cut off the Har-
bor basin from the rest of the City.



81

field_edited_text_processed:
The Inner Harbor Project

A project of the dimension of the
renewal of the Inner Harbor had to be
phased. Three areas, labeled simply Inner
Harbor Project | (the first phase of 95 acres
next to the water), Inner Harbor West, and
Inner Harbor East were created to imple-
ment the City’s plans.

By 1965 there was recognition that a
specialized management entity was needed
to implement the Inner Harbor program.
The Charles Center Management Office
was transformed into Charles Center-Inner
Harbor Management Inc., a nopeprofit
corporation with ). Jefferson Miller as
chairman. Martin Millspaugh, a Baltimorean
who had been Assistant Commissioner of
the U.S. Urban Renewal Administration and
Deputy General Manager of Charles Cen-
ter, was named President. Walter Sondheim,
Jr., a prominent businessman and former
chairman of the Baltimore Urban Renewal
and Housing Commission, joined the CC/
IH Corp. as Vice-Chairman in 1970. After
Mr. Miller’s death in 1972, Mr. Sondheim
became chairman and Mr. Millspaugh
became President and Chief Executive.

Action came fairly fast— just two years
after Mayor MKeldin launched the Inner
Harbor renewal area. Plans for the Inner
Harbor Project | area were made public
and designated as the first target; voters
approved a $12,000,000 loan for the Inner
Harbor in 1966, and the Urban Renewal
Plan was approved by the Mayor and City
Council in June of 1967.

Baltimore continued its success in tak-
ing full advantage of sources of Federal
funding that had begun in Charles Center.
In 1968 a $22.4 Federal Grant was released
for Inner Harbor Project I. These funds
coupled with the voter approved bond
money, meant that Baltimore could pro-
ceed in earnest with land purchases and
clearance of the old warehouses and other
run down structures.

Although few Baltimoreans were aware
of it at the time, the City had begun the
process of reclaiming the waterfront for
public use. Initial work involved bulkhead-
ing the Inner Harbor shoreline—an expen-
sive proposition — and placing landfill to
provide an expanded western waterfront.

During the same period Mayor Mc-
Keldin appointed David W. Barton as Chair-
man of the City Planning Commission.
Mayor McKeldin mandated Barton to re-
vamp the Department of Planning to better
address the planning issues facing the City.
The Department expanded and together
with the Greater Baltimore Committee,
other planning agencies, consultants and
the private sector prepared a plan for long
range development of the city center. The
plan for MetroCenter, covers over 1,000
acres and details parks and open space,

Light St., looking south, Locust Pt., 1938

:

residential and commercial areas, and low
and mid-rise structures envisioned for the
harbor. The MetroCenter plan which was
presented in 1968 called for nearly $1 bil-
lion in new investment in the center of the
city, building on the success of the Charles
Center and early Inner Harbor initiatives of
the 1960s.

The years from the early 1970’s into the
1980s were filled with a series of events
which would dramatically alter the physical
appearance of the Inner Harbor and the
population’s perception of Baltimore as a
City.

Construction of a new, expanded
shoreline bulkhead began in the early 70s.
In the midst of this vast construction pro-
ject visitors to the harbor witnessed the first
new buildings and piers in almost 70 years.
When the brick promenade was added on
the north, west, and southern shorelines in
1975, visitors were ready to celebrate the
growing sense of pride in a city slowly
emerging from the difficult years of the
1950s and 1960s. As Charles Center neared
completion in the late 1960’s and early
1970’s the City began to sponsor special
events to attract people back into the
downtown. Jazz on the Plaza, the first City
Fair were intitiated in Charles Center. The
city government led by William Donald
Schaefer, elected Mayor in 1971, expanded
on this strategy of reintroducing Baltimore’s
residents to their waterfront by sponsoring
an ever increasing number of events

throughout downtown with a special focus

on the Inner Harbor. The Mayor knew that
if people had positive feelings about their

field_edited_text_processed:
visit to the harbor, this would spread to
other parts of downtown and eventually
the entire city.

In 1972, Pier | along the northern
shoreline was rebuilt for the U.S.F. Constel-
lation, built in 1797 and the oldest ship in
the U.S. Navy. The first of the Inner Har-
bor’s public attractions was in place.

In 1973, the city shifted the City Fair to
the Inner Harbor. This event, begun in 1969
to celebrate the City’s neighborhoods, is a
deliberate effort on the part of Baltimore to
create good feelings about the city. The fair
has grown into an immense, enthusiastic
September spectacle; an estimated two
million persons attended the weekend
event in 1983. Part of the resistance that
later developed to plans for some of the
buildings along the edge of the Inner Har-
bor stemmed in part from the public’s fear
that the City Fair would be displaced as
Pratt and Light Streets were developed with
major new buildings. The fair was relocated
in 1981 to Marketplace, the Pratt Street
Boulevard, and Piers 5 and 6.

Another milestone occurred in 1972,
completion of the first building in the
Inner Harbor area, Christ Lutheran’s Harbor
Apartments south of the McCormick spice
factory. In 1973, one of Baltimore’s tallest
buildings, the U.S.F. & G. home office was
completed.



Light St., Harborplace, 1983

As the country observed its bicentenial
in 1976, Baltimore took advantage of one of
the most spectacular events created for the
celebration, the Tall Ships. A special com-
mittee of city residents and local corpora-
tions worked to attract a major visit of this
fleet of the world’s sailing ships. A two
week long celebration was planned. More
tall ships visited Baltimore than any other
_ 3 q American port except New York and New-
. romenadade

- e
= =

, looking south, City Fair, 1973




Inner Harbor Manaemet 83

port. The area’s residents were caught up
in the excitement and welcomed the crews
and visitors with the kind of fervor unheard
of since Baltimore greeted Lafayette on his
triumphant tour 150 years earlier. Over two
and a half million visitors, many from the
Midwest and adjoining states, poured into
the city. The event also drew visitors from
the Washington and Baltimore suburbs and
introduced them to a newly emerging
Inner Harbor.

By 1976 there was enough physical
evidence of the downtown/harbor transfor-
mation to come to make it attractive. The
number of buildings either underway or
occupied grew each year. The IBM office
building near Pratt and Light Streets, was
finished in 1975. The Maryland Science
Center designed by architect Edward Durell
Stone at the harbor’s southwestern edge
was opened in 1976, and playing fields
were completed at the south side of the
harbor. 1976 also saw the dedication of the
Harbor Campus of the Community College
of Baltimore. The C & P Telephone Co.
completed its building at Pratt and con-
struction was underway on the World
Trade Center, the harbor’s dominant struc-
ture, which opened in 1977.

Beyond the one-time spectacle of
the Tall ships, the Inner Harbor area was
(and is) used all summer by city-spon-
sored, weekend ethnic festivals and other
activities. The green open space behind the
shoreline promenade became the city’s
front yard, the place to gather, celebrate,
and enjoy city life.

After the success of the Tall Ships visit,
the future of the Inner Harbor as a gather-
ing place fer the region’s citizens was
sealed. What wasn’t settled yet was the final
nature of that place and how people
wanted to see it used.

The Charles Center and Inner Harbor
projects were nearly uninterrupted success
stories to this point. Nothing as complex
and innovative as these undertakings would
be without some difficulties.

An illustration of the latter occurred in
1977 when Baltimore was negotiating to
bring a hotgl to the Inner Harbor. A major
new hotel was needed to make the city’s
planned Convention Center (opened in
1979) attractive to conventions. But the
drawing power of the Inner Harbor was
still not clear to investors in 1977. As Mayor
Schaefer has recalled “We were practically
on our knees to get some hotel chain to
make a commitment.” In fact the first two
hotel developers selected were unable to
carry out their plans. In order to make it
possible for the Hyatt chain to build in the
Inner Harbor, Baltimore obtained a $10-
million federal Urban Development Action
Grant which, together with a $2 million set-
tlement from an earlier hotel developer,

field_edited_text_processed:
Opening day, Harborplace, 1980



was loaned to the owners of the Hyatt
chain. The City constructed a $4 million
parking garage. In return, the hotel is to
repay the city loan at seven percent and
pay a base ground rent, plus 2/3’s of the
hotel’s profits to the City. The City leased
the land on which the Baltimore Hyatt
stands for 34 years, with an option to
extend for 20 additional years. The hotel
also pays its full share of property taxes.
These terms, which reduced the private risk
capital to $4 million of a total package of
over $37.5 million, has proven to be a good
investment for all concerned. The Balti-
more Hyatt is one of the most successful in
the entire chain and the hotel"is now seek-
ing to buy out the City’s interest. Hundreds
of city residents have been employed, and
an important drawing card has been pro-
vided for Convention Center business.

More than 10 years after the initial re-
development activity began, the Rouse
Company came forward with a proposal to
erect the shopping component of the Inner
Harbor plan, two pavilions of shops and
restaurants along the Inner Harbor prome-
nade. The proposal which was-unveiled in
1978 was called Harborplace. While gener-
ally well received there were mixed reac-
tions to the proposal.

A sizable segment of the public op-
posed any commercial use of what had
come to be viewed as “their’” open space.
Others opposed the loss of valuable open
space they had come to enjoy at the
water’s edge. Some opposition came from
the Black community which felt it might be
frozen out of high-priced shops and restau-
rants. Several owners of shops and restau-
rants in South Baltimore and Little Italy
feared their businesses would suffer.

Although city plans had always called
for commercial use along the shoreline of
the Inner Harbor, the reality of the Rouse
plan galvanized opponents. As the former
chairman of the City Planning Commission
put it, “Baltimoreans are so pleased with
the first phase of their Inner Harbor that
they fear, if it is completed as originally
planned, they won’t be pleased.” To
address the opposition, private citizens’
groups and the Rouse Co. worked to pre-
sent the favorable aspects of the plan, pro-
viding extensive efforts to include minority
firms, significant minority hiring, high tax
returns and careful attention to design.

With the backing of the city, business
community and many citizens groups, the
referendum on Harborplace in 1978 passed
with 54 percent of the vote. Since that turn-
ing point, many of those in opposition
have come to express support for the way
Harborplace has turned out. As part of the
referendum, 26 acres around the harbor
basin are to remain forever as public park
space.





On July 2, 1980 Harborplace opened to
a noontime crowd of over 50,000. For the
city Harborplace has turned out to be a
bonanza many times over, from the reve-
nues that have poured forth from the 18
million visits to the 140 shops and stands in
their first year of operation, the worldwide
publicity that has followed the spectacular
success of Harborplace and the Inner Har-
bor redevelopment in general, and the use
of pavilions and promenade as the city’s
modern-day boardwalk.



Opening day Harborplace, 1980

Maryland Port Administration



Peter Solmmsen

INNER HARBOR

DEVELOPMENT EVENTS

1955 Greater Baltimore Committee formed

1956 Plan for Inner Harbor by Planning
Director McVoy published

1959 Urban Renewal Plan for Charles Center
announced and approved by City
Council.

1960 Charles Center Management Office
established

1963 Mayor McKeldin sets Inner Harbor

- redevelopment as a major objective for
the city

1964 First bond issue for $2,000,000 approved
for Inner Harbor

1965 Charles Center/Inner Harbor Manage-
ment, Inc. established

1966 Renewal planunveiled forInner Harbor
Project |. Voters approve loan for
$12,000,000.

1968 Inner Harbor project started with the
release of a $22.4 million Federal Grant.

1970 Metro Center plan for downtown
completed by Baltimore City Depart-
ment of Planning

1972 Constellation moved to permanent
berth at newly constructed Constellation
Pier.

1973 Dedication of John L. Deaton Medical
Nursing Center. First major new building
in Inner Harbor.

1973 4th Annual City Fair moved to Inner
Harbor site.

1974 First harbor tour service opened by
Baltimore Patriot at Constellation Dock.

1975 Shoreline promenade completed
around Inner Harbor

1976 Maryland Science Center opens

1976 Rash Athletic Field completed on south
shore of Inner Harbor

1976 Operation Sail: visit of Tall Ships to
Inner Harbor and Fells Point.

promenade

1978 Harborplace wins voter approval.

deck opened in World Trade Center.

1979 Baltimore Convention Center opens

1980 Harbqg-place opens

1981 National Aquarium in Baltimore opens

1981 Pier 6 Concert Pavillion completed

1981 Hyatt Hotel opens

1981 City Fair moved to Market-Place and
piers 5 & 6.

1982 Six Flags Corporation given right to
develop Pier 4 Power Plant.

1983 Rouse Co. announces plans for lot at
Pratt and Calvert. Development of a 500
room hotel, 1200 space parking garage,
office building and a 100,000 square foot
shopping gallery.

1984 Redevelopment of piers 5 & 6 begins

with reconstruction of bulkhead and fill.

office building and a 100,000 square foot
shopping gallery.

1984 Redevelopment of piers 5 & 6 begins

with reconstruction of bulkhead and fill.



Inner Harbor Management

field_edited_text_processed:
xisting Conditions

The many different uses and features
that comprise the network of attractions in
the Inner Harbor today began falling into
place in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

Two major restaurants, apart from
those housed in Harborplace, have located
at the Inner Harbor. The Chart House
opened in 1979 on Pier 4 on the northern
side of the harbor, the first attraction in
that area. Extensive renovation of the old
maintenance shops of the Gas and Electric
Co.’s Power Plant was involved. In 1977,
construction began on the Innef Harbor
marina, the first new major boating facility
to be built in the harbor in years. The
Rusty Scupper opened in 1982 alongside
the city marina on the south edge of the
harbor.

On top of the 30-story World Trade
Center that has become one of the Inner
Harbor’s symbolic structures is The Top of
The World, a public observation deck
opened in 1979. Developed by the Balti-
more Office of Promotion and Fourism, the
observation deck provides the public with
a chance to view the sweep of Baltimore’s
harbor as it spreads from the city center to
the Chesapeake Bay.

Along the western boundary of the
Inner Harbor at Charles Street and Pratt
Street Boulevard are a number of major
buildings completed in the late 1970’s and
early 1980’s. The Baltimore Convention
Center opened in 1979 and provides 115,000
square feet of exhibit and 45,000 square
feet meeting space. Construction was
financed by a $35 million state bond issue
and $10 million in City funds. The Conven-
tion Center tied to the other attractions of
the Inner Harbor, has advanced Baltimore
as a meeting place for many national and
international groups. A major requirement
of the convention market is an adequate
supply of hotel rooms to meet the
demands of the increasing number of vis-
itors. The Hyatt Regency Hotel opened in
1981 with 500 rooms and the potential for
adding 350 more. This luxury hotel is
directly connected to the Convention Cen-
ter and Harborplace by a series of over-
head pedestrian plazas and walkways.

Immediately north of the Convention
Center is the Equitable Center. As the
home office of the Equitable Trust Bank,
the building also contains a shopping mall
and department store branch. A pedestrian
arcade runs through the building, connect-
ing Charles Center with the Convention
Center, the Hyatt, Harborplace and the
promenade.

~In a large triangular piece of land at
the juncture of Light Street and the Pratt
Street Boulevard is the McKeldin Square

and fountain. The fountain is designed to
operate in all but the coldest weather and
replicates waterfalls, pools and rushing
streams. Visitors may walk around and over
the fountain.

The most spectacular singular addition
to the Inner Harbor has been the National
Aquarium in Baltimore, located at the end
of Pier 3.

It’s success is a phenomenon parallel
to that of Harborplace. As the visitor wait-
ing lines attest, the Aquarium has become
a magnet which has exceeded the city’s
original expectations. Instead of a projected
600,000 annual visitors, the facility was
toured by 1.6 million during 1981-82, its
first year. Designed by Peter Chermayeff of
the Cambridge Seven Associates, the aqua-
rium was built by the City of Baltimore for
$21.5 million. The stunning building houses
5,000 specimens of aquatic life and a tropi-
cal rain forest.

As the Inner Harbor project area has
expanded, the City’s attention has been
drawn to the east along the Pratt Street
Boulevard and to Piers 4, 5 and 6 and
across the Jones Falls to Falls Harbor. In
1981 the City erected a concert pavilion on
the end of Pier 6. This large tent structure
can seat over 2000 people under the can-
opy and 400 picnickers outside. Boaters
have room to moor along the side of the
pier. In 1982 canopied pedestrian bridges
linking little Italy and the piers were com-
pleted permitting easy access to harbor
attractions and parking. One of the newest
additions, also completed in 1982, is the
renovated, ornate Eastern Avenue Pumping
Station which houses the Department of
Public Work’s Museum. Adjacent to the
pumping station is a unique sculpture
composed of an above-ground replica of a
street intersection. There, visitors can learn
of the complexities of sewers, gas lines,
storm drains and street construction.

But it is the two Harborplace pavilions,
with their shops, restaurants, and colorful
markets that have captured the public’s
attention. The installation, at a cost of $22
million, has come to be the symbol of the
complete turnaround that has taken place
since 1967 at the Inner Harbor. The indices
of the success of Harborplace are many:
first-year visits totaling 18 million; sales of a
reported $400 per square foot, or more
than twice that in traditional shopping
malls; over 2,000 new jobs; inclusion of the
promised high portion of minority firms
among Harborplace’s 130 shops and restau-
rants, and several millions of dollars paid
each year to the City and State in taxes and
parking revenues.

Now the Inner Harbor promenade,
almost a mile and a half long, functions like
a boardwalk tying together attractions,

businesses and the many special events
along the waterfront.



lssues and Problems

Along with the overwhelming success
of the Inner Harbor there are several issues
to be addressed. Heading the list continue
to be two problems which have confronted
Baltimore for at least 30 years, namely traf-
fic and parking. Pratt and Lombard Streets
along the north side of the Inner Harbor
are two of the city’s major traffic arteries.
Improvements to the existing street system

* and the new 1-95 Fort McHenry harbor

tunnel, will draw off some of the through
traffic, especially heavy trucks, but there is
every likelihood that Pratt, Lombard and
Light Streets will continue to carry heavy
traffic. The City has addressed this problem
through the use of innovative traffic con-
trol devices, traffic police to direct vehicles
and pedestrians at critical intersections dur-
ing peak hours, and by promoting the
development of overhead walkways allow-
ing visitors to reach the harbor without
conflicts with traffic. There is a widespread
public perception that parking is inade-
quate in the Inner Harbor. While there are
over 5,000 spaces open to the public within
several blocks of the promenade, many
people claim that it is difficult to find a
parking place. The actual fact is that at
nearly all times, there are hundreds of
unused parking places within several blocks
of the Harbor. The public is not always
aware of those spaces, however. The City is
addressing this issue by extensive signing of
parking garages and provision of maps
showing where parking is available. In addi-
tion, the City has plans for adding new







86

i
s
RTINS D
SRR B

Boating in the Inner Harbor

The Rouse Company

RN

Galleria at Harborplace - Rouse Co., Hotel, shopping arcade, office and parking, 1986/87

































































A ey

parking spaces in several locations as
demand increases. Further, the opening of
the first leg of the Baltimore subway should
improve access to the area and alleviate
some of the parking demand.

Adjacent residential communities of
Little Italy, Federal Hill, and Otterbein are
concerned about the impact on their neigh-
borhoods of heavily attended Inner Harbor
events. The City has developed residential
permit parking programs to limit the park-
ing impact and continues to work with the
neighborhoods to help them maintain their
residential atmosphere.

Finally, boating safety has become a
growing concern as more and more boat-
ers use the Inner Harbor for recreational
boating. As recreational boats are drawn to
the Inner Harbor’s basin they must navigate
through the country’s fourth most active
port. In the basin itself, a relatively small
water body, tourist boats, pleasure craft,
visiting ships, and paddle boats must com-
pete for limited space and right-of-way.
The Mayor’s Task Force on Boating Safety
was appointed in 1981 to develop ways of
dealing with potential conflicts. Added
police authority to deal with boating infrac-
tions has been implemented as a first step,
and the Task Force continues to address
the issues of speed, congestion and the
location and development of major marinas
to facilitate the growing interest of recrea-
tional boaters and allow the port to con-
tinue to grow.

o



Planned Development

If the past is any record of success
then the plans and projects announced
offer the prospect of continued additions
to the commercial, residential and recrea-
tional resources for Baltimore. The follow-
ing are projects planned or underway.

Camden Yards — On the western
boundary of the Inner Harbor projet area
are 22 acres of land including the Camden
Station owned by the CSX System. This
property lies to the immediate west of
Otterbein and is proposed for residences, a
hotel and offices. The first phase —the new
Federal Reserve Bank Building was com-
pleted in November, 1982.

Pratt at Calvert Street — In early 1982
the Rouse Company won the right to

. develop a $190-million hotel/retail/office/

parking eomplex on the vacant lot imme-
diately north of Harborplace along Pratt
Street Boulevard. The Rouse Company has
announced that the Westin Hotel chain will
operate a 550 room hotel. Included in the
complex will be over 600,000 sq. ft. of
commercial space and offices, and a 1200
parking garage.

Pier 4 Power Plant — At the end of
1982 the Six Flags Corporation was selected
by the City to turn the former power plant
on Pier 4 into a family entertainment cen-
ter. The estimated cost of this project is $26
million. Work began on the building in the
fall of 1983.

Light Street High-Rise — The Murdock
Development Corp. has begun the con-
struction of a tower with 165 condomini-
ums and a luxury hotel with parking and
commercial space on the vacant land south
of McCormick’s spice plant on Light Street.

Piers 5 and 6 and the Lower Jones Falls
— Piers 5 and 6 and the east bank of the
Jones Falls present a major new opportun-
ity for continuing the expansion of the
Inner Harbor and are now undergoing in-
tensive planning study. Proposals for this
area include continuing the public walkway
around the entire perimeter of the shore-
line, tying in with the walkways now in
place across piers 3 to 6 and the Inner Har-
bor promenade; installation of marinas;
and public plazas with a dramatic view
across the water to the downtown’s skyline
and harbor ‘activities.

Beyond the Falls Harbor/Little Italy
area is Fells Point where private renovation
is taking place. Ultimately this historic
waterfront neighborhood will be tied to
the Inner Harbor by means of a pedestrian
walkway along the harbor’s edge and rede-
velopment of the intervening land area.

“The Brokerage” — To the north of
the harbor along the Jones Falls, “The
Brokerage” is under development. This $28
million project is being undertaken by a
private developer who is renovating an
entire block of derelict commercial build-
ings for shops and offices, building a ga-
rage and new office space and constructing
a market pavilion in the historic Fish Market
Square.

The excitement that the Inner Harbor
redevelopment has engendered, in Balti-
more, throughout the United States, and in
all parts of the world, is hardly over. The
projects described above and those on the
drawing boards and in prospect make it
obvious Baltimore is not through showing
what can be done with a prime waterfront
location.

In 1963 a friend is said to have told
Mayor McKeldin about his trip to Stock-
holm and what splendid use that city made
of its waterfront. Today delegations from
far corners of the world visit Baltimore to
take back th&lessons of the Inner Harbor’s
success.



87

most diverse waterfront communities in the
city. Since its founding, it has been a hub
of activity for merchants and traders. Fells
Point today reflects this heritage in its row-
houses and shops, its angular streets, and
its continuing maritime character.

Fells Paét now evidences an exciting,
if sometimes jarring, mix of maritime, indus-

Fells Point is one of the oldest and
most diverse waterfront communities in the
city. Since its founding, it has been a hub
of activity for merchants and traders. Fells
Point today reflects this heritage in its row-
houses and shops, its angular streets, and
its continuing maritime character.

Fells Paét now evidences an exciting,
if sometimes jarring, mix of maritime, indus-
trial, commercial and residential activities.
The area, long a home for immigrants from
Eastern Europe, sailors, among others, is
today experiencing a resurgence in residen-

field_edited_text_processed:
Fells Point, looking south, Broadway, Recreation Pier

renovated and vacant warehouses con-
verted to condominiums. At the same time,
there is still considerable industrial and
maritime activity in the area as witnessed
by the Arundel Corp. concrete plant on
the east, the Allied Chemical Co. plant in
the west, and the various warehouses and
tugboat companies which line the shore-
line. The area also supports a thriving
commercial trade with many taverns,
antique shops, and an open stall market
which attracts customers from the entire
metropolitan area.

The Canton waterfront extends from
Chester Street eastward along Boston Street
to Clinton Street. From the late 18th cen-
tury the Canton Shoreline has been primar-
ily industrial. It was the site for one of the
earliest shipyards, Stodder Brothers, which
was responsible for the construction of the
U.S. Frigate Constellation in 1797. Boston
Street was for many years known as
“Canners Row”’ because of the number of
canning firms located on or near the water-
front. Although the Canton community
extended to the north side of Boston Street
the waterfront was cut-off from public use
because of the industrial activities. It has
only been in the last fifteen years, since the
removal of a number of older buildings in
preparation for the once proposed 1-83,
that the shoreline has become visable and
available to the general public.



Development History

Settled in 1730 by William Fell, Fells
Point was one of the three original settle-
ments which joined together in 1797 to
form the City of Baltimore. Fell had rightly
recognized the unique advantage for ship-
ping that the area’s stable shoreline and
deep water offered. By the mid 18th cen-
tury, Fells Point dominated the other two
settlements, Baltimore Town and Jones
Town, in waterborne commerce and ship-
building. The waterfront was lined with
piers and warehouses, and the community
supported a mixture of commerce and
residential development. Shipbuilding was
a major industry, especially to the east
along Boston Street and in neighboring
Canton.

Most of the Canton waterfront east of
Harris Creek was originally settled by Cap-
tain John O’Donnell who arrived in the
area in 1785. Within a few years O’'Donnell
was the owner of over 2,500 acres stretching
from Harris Creek eastward into the Can-
ton industrial area. His son, Columbus,
joined with Peter Cooper in 1827 to form
the Canton Company. Cooper, In turn,
developed the Boston Street Ironworks,
located at the current site of the American
Can Company. For the next hundred years
the Canton waterfront would be a center
for industrial activity, including cannaries,
box manufacturing, railyards, and special-
ized steel equipment and plate fabrication.

In the 19th and early 20th centuries,
Fells Point was an important entry port for
the great influx of European immigrants.
While many remained only shortly in the
area, Fells Point still boasts a sizable Polish
and Eastern European community.

As technology changed, shipping and
maritime activities gradually moved to other
locations on the harbor. Today many for-
merly active piers have rotted away and a
number of warehouses stand ready to be
renovated into commercial and residential
uses.

In the 1960s an alignment for the Inter-
state 83 expressway was chosen that would
have routed the roadway through the cen-
ter of Fells Point. The City purchased
houses and land to make way for the road.
Realizing the area’s historic character and
the potential for residential and commer-
cial development, citizen’s groups opposed
the alignment and urged the City to seek
other routes. The City responded by pro-
posing that the expressway be built in a
tunnel south of Fells Point. This new align-
ment allowed the houses previously ac-
quired to be sold for rehabilitation. Subse-
quently, the escalating cost of highway con-
struction has prompted the City to propose
lower cost alternatives.





90
field_edited_text_value:
Fells Point, looking south, Broadway, Recreation Pier

renovated and vacant warehouses con-
verted to condominiums. At the same time,
there is still considerable industrial and
maritime activity in the area as witnessed
by the Arundel Corp. concrete plant on
the east, the Allied Chemical Co. plant in
the west, and the various warehouses and
tugboat companies which line the shore-
line. The area also supports a thriving
commercial trade with many taverns,
antique shops, and an open stall market
which attracts customers from the entire
metropolitan area.

The Canton waterfront extends from
Chester Street eastward along Boston Street
to Clinton Street. From the late 18th cen-
tury the Canton Shoreline has been primar-
ily industrial. It was the site for one of the
earliest shipyards, Stodder Brothers, which
was responsible for the construction of the
U.S. Frigate Constellation in 1797. Boston
Street was for many years known as
“Canners Row”’ because of the number of
canning firms located on or near the water-
front. Although the Canton community
extended to the north side of Boston Street
the waterfront was cut-off from public use
because of the industrial activities. It has
only been in the last fifteen years, since the
removal of a number of older buildings in
preparation for the once proposed 1-83,
that the shoreline has become visable and
available to the general public.



Development History

Settled in 1730 by William Fell, Fells
Point was one of the three original settle-
ments which joined together in 1797 to
form the City of Baltimore. Fell had rightly
recognized the unique advantage for ship-
ping that the area’s stable shoreline and
deep water offered. By the mid 18th cen-
tury, Fells Point dominated the other two
settlements, Baltimore Town and Jones
Town, in waterborne commerce and ship-
building. The waterfront was lined with
piers and warehouses, and the community
supported a mixture of commerce and
residential development. Shipbuilding was
a major industry, especially to the east
along Boston Street and in neighboring
Canton.

Most of the Canton waterfront east of
Harris Creek was originally settled by Cap-
tain John O’Donnell who arrived in the
area in 1785. Within a few years O’'Donnell
was the owner of over 2,500 acres stretching
from Harris Creek eastward into the Can-
ton industrial area. His son, Columbus,
joined with Peter Cooper in 1827 to form
the Canton Company. Cooper, In turn,
developed the Boston Street Ironworks,
located at the current site of the American
Can Company. For the next hundred years
the Canton waterfront would be a center
for industrial activity, including cannaries,
box manufacturing, railyards, and special-
ized steel equipment and plate fabrication.

In the 19th and early 20th centuries,
Fells Point was an important entry port for
the great influx of European immigrants.
While many remained only shortly in the
area, Fells Point still boasts a sizable Polish
and Eastern European community.

As technology changed, shipping and
maritime activities gradually moved to other
locations on the harbor. Today many for-
merly active piers have rotted away and a
number of warehouses stand ready to be
renovated into commercial and residential
uses.

In the 1960s an alignment for the Inter-
state 83 expressway was chosen that would
have routed the roadway through the cen-
ter of Fells Point. The City purchased
houses and land to make way for the road.
Realizing the area’s historic character and
the potential for residential and commer-
cial development, citizen’s groups opposed
the alignment and urged the City to seek
other routes. The City responded by pro-
posing that the expressway be built in a
tunnel south of Fells Point. This new align-
ment allowed the houses previously ac-
quired to be sold for rehabilitation. Subse-
quently, the escalating cost of highway con-
struction has prompted the City to propose
lower cost alternatives.

field_edited_text_processed:
xisting Conditions

Industrial and Port Activity: Even
though several former industrial buildings
are being converted to housing, most of
Fells Point’s waterfront is still zoned for
industrial activity. There are four primary
industrial activities in Fells Point: warehous-
ing, maritime services, a concrete batching
plant, and a large chemical plant.

At the extreme western tip of Fells
Point is the Allied Chemical Corp. plant on
Philpot Street. The plant manufactures chro-
mium chemicals and compoufids.

Also located along the western boun-
dary of the area are several metal parts
warehouses and the H &S Bakery.

Around Broadway are several ware-
housing operations, the most notable being
Rukert Terminal Corp., which has operated
in Fells Point for a number of years at the
foot of Broadway and in several historic
warehouses along Thames Street. Also
located adjacent to Broadway are several
ship chandlers who supply goods to ships
for their operations. :

There are two major industrial opera-
tions east of Broadway; one is the Arundel
Corp.’s concrete batching plant on Wolfe
Street, the second is Belt’'s Wharf with two
active warehouses on Fell Street and a ware-
house operation on Aliceanna Street in the
old National Can Company building. Raw
materials at the Arundel Corp., which are
delivered by barge, are mixed to form con-
crete which is then trucked to construction
sites in the region.

In the Canton area, along Boston Street
at Lakewood, is a cluster of large industrial
and warehouse buildings including the old
J. S. Young factory, now vacant expect for
warehousing in several large buildings; R.
Renneburg and Sons, manufacturer of steel
machine products; two large warehouses
between Boston Street and the harbor; and
the American Can Co. plant covering sev-
eral city blocks on the northside of Boston
Street at O’Donnell Street.

Towing companies on Boston Street
and at the Recreation Pier, are the major
maritime businesses now along the Fells
Point shoreline. The City Pier at the foot of
Broadway is also occasionally used as a
temporary mooring for cargo ships waiting
assignment to a pier in another part of the
harbor. The City’s Marine Police Unit was
located for many years at Broadway Pier in
Fells Point. The unit has now moved to Pier
6 in the Inner Harbor, in temporary
facilities.

At the eastern end of Boston Street is
NBC Lines where containers are consoli-
dated from other ports and distributed to



Maritime activities, tugs at the Recreation Pier

larger ships for shipment or inland
destinations.

Commercial Activity: Fells Point pro-
vides a diverse mix of commercial activity.
Associated with the area’s towing compan-
ies are ship chandlers who supply provisions
and services to ships docking in the Balti-
more harbor. Along Broadway, the area’s
commercial spine, there are hardware
stores, banks, secondhand and specialty
shops, antique stores, and restaurants. And,
there are the taverns. Fells Point contains
one of the highest concentrations of tav-
erns of any community in the City. The bars
attract an interesting clientele of visiting sail-
ors, young singles, local residents, and tour-
ists. Fells Point’s open stall Broadway
Market also draws customers from the en-
tire region. This mix of commercial activity
is considered one of Fells Point’s major
assets.

Residential Areas: There has been a
strong residential community in Fells Point
since the founding in the early 18th cen-
tury. Originally houses were built in Fells
Point for those who worked nearby in the
port and in related maritime businesses.
During the 19th century, Fells Point became
the home of thousands of Eastern European
immigrants many of whose descendents still
live in the area.

During the 1960s a trickle of new resi-
dents, many artists and “urban pioneers,”
discovered Fells Point. As the appeal of liv-
ing in an historic community adjacent to the
harbor grew, increasing numbers of people

began to move into the community to ren-
ovate its 19th-century brick rowhouses. To-
day, the market for housing in Fells Point
has advanced to the point that developers
have proposed converting many of the
area’s abandoned warehouses to condo-
miniums and apartments and constructing
new townhouses on vacant land.

Recreation Areas: To provide a focal
point for the community, the City invested
more than $1 million to construct a brick-
paved plaza in the bed of South Broadway
between Lancaster and Thames Streets. The
plaza is used for community events and fes-
tivals as well as a place to watch the bustling
activity which is a day-to-day occurrence in
Fells Point. The City has also constructed a
neighborhood park with a play area for
small children, green space, and gazebo at
the corner of Thames and Wolfe Streets.
Besides these new facilities, the Recreation
Pier with a second-story outdoor basketball
court and its indoor game room has long
been a valuable resource for the Fells Point
community. In 1984 the Chester Street Park
and Promenade was completed.

In the Canton area there is a small
recreation center with courts and play
equipment and several playfields at East
and Ellwood Streets. The City has also con-
structed a public pier at Boston and Lake-
wood Streets.





2

field_edited_text_processed:
Planned Development

Private: The composition of the Fells
Point/Canton shoreline is rapidly changing.
This is evidenced by the following projects.

*The Anchorage: In late 1982 construc-
tion began on the Anchorage, a devel-
opment which in the first phase in-
cludes 40 townhouses overlooking a
public waterfront promenade and an 80
slip marina. The second phase of the
project includes construction of an ad-
dition 700 feet of the public prome-
nade, a 260 slip marina and yacht club
and a high-rise condominium. The pro-
menade will provide almost one-
quarter mile of public shoreline access.



*Thames Point: The Wolfe Street por-
tion of the former National Can Co.
plant has been renovated into approxi-
mately 32 rental units, with the first re-
served for commercial activity. A public
boardwalk and a small marina for 50
boats have also been developed. Work
has begun on Phase Il of the project
which will develop 87 additional units.

Henderson’s Wharf: The former B& O
warehouse on Fell Street and the adja-
cent tip of land that was the original
Fells Point have been awarded to a firm
to redevelop as a complex of apart-

| ments, inn, commercial space and a 225
slip marina. The shoreline around the
vacant parcel and the ground floor of
the building is to be a public prome-
nade. Development in the future could
expand to also include waterfront
townhouses and provide parking on
adjacent properties.



*Admiral Fell Inn: A developer an-
nounced in January, 1983, that this for-
mer industrial building at Thames and
L Broadway is to be converted into an

Thames Point, before and after renovation into luxury inn. Completion IS EXPECtEd in 1985.
apartments :





Chester Street Park and Promenade: To
accommodate the parking needs of the
developer of the former National Can
Company building at Wolfe and Ali-

« ceanna Streets the City agreed to sell a
portion of its property at Chester Street.
In return, the developer has constructed a
public shoreline promenade, landscape
a small park and plant street trees along
Chester Street. This will enhance one of
the most important links between the
community and the waterfront and pro-
vide another portion of the shoreline
walk.



93

Jackson Building: A company which
manufactures products for air filters has
rehabilitated the industrial building at
Boston Street, east of Linwood. The
company has provided a well designed
building which provides jobs and can
co-exist with future waterfront uses.

Public: The City of Baltimore has pro-
grammed a number of projects in Fells
Point and along the Canton waterfront
to encourage and support private resi-
dential and commercial development.

Street Rehabilitation and Reconstruc-
tion: There are a number of local
streets which are slated for either re-
habilitation or complete reconstruction.
These include Thames, Wolfe, Lancas-
ter, Shakespeare, Bethel, Fleet, and
Eastern. The most extensive public in-
vestment in Fells Point will be the up-
grading of streets between the existing
Jones Falls Expressway and Interstate 95
presently under construction in Canton.
At one time planned as a full, limited
access expressway passing south of
Fells Point in a tunnel, the City has pro-
posed more modest designs due to es-
calating construction costs. This would
include improvements to Fleet and Ali-
ceanna Streets and reconstruction of
Boston Street.

*Broadway Market Renovation: Now
that improvements to the market’s
south shed have been completed, the
City is undertaking various further im-
provements to the north shed. Many of
these were initiated in 1982. Recon-
struction of the north facade should be
completed in early 1984.

*Boston Street Pier: A small pier is
under censtruction on the shoreline at
Boston and O’Donnell Streets to give
public access to the water’s edge and
to provide a place for small boat moor-
ing. The project is funded by the fed-
eral Coastal Energy Impact Program
with assistance from the State’s Water-
way Improvement Division.

*Public Waterfront Access: In conjunc-
tion with several private development
projects, public promenades, walkways,
and small parks will be built along the
shoreline using funds from the federal
Urban Development Action Grant Pro-
gram, other federal and state sources,
and private capital. Designed to insure
that the public has access to the shore-
line, these improvements will be con-
structed at the same time as the accom-
panying private development.
