field_edited_text_processed:
Trains still travel the streets through Fells Pt.







ssues and Problems

The prospect of a significant growth in
residential development poses several
important issues for Fells Point and the
Canton waterfront.

First, there are the potential difficulties
that could develop between the newer resi-
dents and long-term residents. The influx
of new residents could dilute the influence
over community activities exercised by resi-
dents who have lived in Fells Point and
Canton for many years. This in turn could
undermine the uniquely European quality
and stable home ownership which has
been one of the area’s appealing character-
istics. The influx of new residents also pre-
sents a potential economic threat to Fells
Point and Canton’s long-standing residents.
It is feared that the influx of new residents,
who are able to pay much higher prices for
their homes, will drive up property values
so high that moderate-income residents
will no longer be able to afford to pay pro-
perty taxes and will have to leave the com-
munity. Both the social and economic
issues posed by the rapid development of
more expensive housing in Fells Point and
by adjacent construction in Canton will
have to be addressed if the communities
are to retain the diversity that are their
hallmark.

A second issue raised by the changing
character of the area is the provision of an
adequate number of parking spaces for the
new uses, including residential and com-
mercial development and the proposed
marinas. If all the proposed marina slips in
the Fells Point/Canton waterfront were
developed as commercial facilities between
600 and 750 parking spaces would have to
be provided. This in addition to spaces
required for new apartments and condo-
miniums, offices, shops and restaurants.
There are clearly not enough spaces cur-
rently available. Larger projects will have to
consider new parking structures or convert-
ing portions of older buildings into parking
facilities.

Another issue is the potential conflict
between the new housing development and
industrial activity in the area. New middle-
and-upper-ihcome residents are not likely
to enjoy the truck traffic, trains, noise, and
dust associated with heavy industry. At the
same time the City will not want to dis-
courage job-creating industries by severely
restricting the scope of their activity. The
difficult challenge facing the City in the
years ahead will be to situate and phase
new residential development to minimize
direct conflicts with existing industry.

Another arena of potential conflict is
the harbor itself. Many of the proposals for
waterfront housing in both Fells Point and
Canton include marinas in their plans. As
the number of pleasure craft docked on the
shoreline grows there is increasing likeli-
hood of conflicts with the work boats sta-
tioned at Fells Point and other areas of the
harbor. To avoid potential conflicts, marina
proposals will be reviewed with commer-
cial shippers and towing companies so that
revisions can.be made to the plans to insure
the safety of the waterways for all vessels.
The City is also preparing guidelines for
marina development to assist in the loca-
tion, configuration, and size of future
marinas.

A final issue is insuring that private
developers of waterfront land continue to
provide public access to the shoreline.
While most of the shoreline in Fells Point
and Canton is privately owned, it is City
policy that the public at large be guaran-
teed access t8 the harbor, which is consi-
dered a public resource. As development in
Fells Point and Canton increases, the City
will continue to work with developers to
design public walkways, parks, and prome-
nades compatible with the privately spon-
sored projects.



95

residential development poses several
important issues for Fells Point and the
Canton waterfront.

that could develop between the newer resi-
dents and long-term residents. The influx
of new residents could dilute the influence
over community activities exercised by resi-
dents who have lived in Fells Point and
Canton for many years. This in turn could
undermine the uniquely European quality

sents a potential economic threat to Fells

dered a public resource. As development in

will continue to work with developers to
design public walkways, parks, and prome-
nades compatible with the privately spon-
sored projects.

field_edited_text_processed:
Future Opportunities

The waterfront in Fells Point and Can-
ton offers the unique opportunity of devel-
oping a major new residential community
along an historic working waterfront. Vacant
warehouses and commercial buildings
stand ready for rehabilitation. Derelict piers
and crumbling shorelines could be rebuilt
for marinas, public promenades, and water-
front parks.

Among the most promising future
development sites on the western shoreline
of Fells Point are: .

*Brown’s Wharf: Located at Thames
Street, this parcel includes just over an
acre of vacant land on the waterfront
and the historic Brown’s Wharf, ware-
houses constructed in the early 19th
century.

*Terminal Corp. Warehouse: A large
brick warehouse on Thames Street with
waterfront on three sides. One of the
most prominent buildings along the
Fells Point waterfront. =

*Jackson Wharf: Just west of the Ter-
minal warehouse on Thames at Caro-
line, Jackson’s Wharf is also a large
brick warehouse with access to the
shoreline. There is also a small amount
of vacant land adjacent to the building
along the waterfront.

The above sites and a number of
properties inland are currently owned by a
developer.

The Canton waterfront was designated
an urban renewal area in 1984. There are
several opportunities along this shoreline to
provide facilities for both new residents
and visitors as well as Canton’s existing
citizens:

*]. S. Young Property: Located in Can-
ton on Boston Street this parcel and the
adjoining properties of the John Ren-
neberg Co. and Marine Repair Services
offer long-range redevelopment poten-
tial. Preliminary plans have been pre-
pared for the J. S. Young property
which includes a recreationally oriented
office/commercial complex and a full-
service marina. -



*Canton Waterfront Park: The City,
with assistance from the State’s Depart-
ment of Natural Resources is moving
to purchase approximately ten acres of
waterfront land at Boston Street
between Linwood and Clinton Streets.
The site will be developed for a large
waterfront park, a boat launch, and as
a permanent home for Baltimore’s
Marine Police and DPW’s Marine
Division.

*Vacant Land North of Boston Street:
Working with the Canton community,
the City has proposed redevelopment
of approximately 16 acres of vacant .
land. The proposal envisions an expan-
sion of the existing park immediately to
the east and development of the re-
maining 11 acres of land for town-
houses compatable with the Canton
community. This includes a nursing
home and approximately 160 units of
moderately priced housing.

*Linwood Associates Building: This
large warehouse at Boston and Lin-
wood offers redevelopment opportuni-
ties for a variety of uses. The ground
floor could provide much needed
parking and the building offer excel-
lent views of Ft. McHenry and the port.

Linwood Associates building, Canton waterfront, part of the once active cannery row along Boston St.

field_edited_text_processed:
Overall
Goal:

Maximize the
use of a
unique
resource



The harbor is not only a valuable
resource for the City, State and nation, it is
also a scarce resource. While many small
ports have been established along the Che-
sapeake Bay during the past 300 years only
Baltimore had the combination of water,
rail, roads, labor, capital, and civic leader-
ship to grow into a world port. Few states
have a harbor which offers such a diverse
opportunity for industrial and maritime
development, recreation, housing and pub-
lic access as the Port of Baltimore.

Because of the limited amount of land
with direct access to shipping channels very
little of the shoreline remains vacant or
available for future development. To insure
that a limited resource, the Port, is utilized
to maximize its positive economic impact
every effort should be made by the City,
State and private sector to provide both
adequate, modern terminals facilities and
secure suitable development opportunities
for growth industries that are capital and
job intensive. This will require identifying
sites and improvements that can satisfy
industrial and commercial activities with a
particular need for locating in the port and
also meet the objectives of the diverse mar-
ltime operations.



98
